HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Potential Savings Of National Care

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH business lobbyists generally oppose national health insurance, it could bring substantial savings to many companies, according to a new study by the Economic and Social Institute, a nonprofit research organization in Washington. The institute looked at medical costs in the steel and electronics industries and the additional taxes that these industries would face in a Government-financed system like Canada's.
The study found that under a Canada-style system, USX and Bethlehem Steel would have net savings of $2,300 to $3,200 for each union worker in the first year. It estimated smaller savings for technology-oriented companies like Xerox, Motorola and Hewlett-Packard, which typically have relatively young employees who have accepted the cost-slowing disciplines of health maintenance organizations and other managed care groups. The institute put the average savings for the three companies at $1,000 to $2,300 for each employee. 
 Such estimates of savings are disputed, to be sure, as the Bush Administration and Congress grapple with rising voter concern about health-care costs. The growing number of employers that provide little or no medical coverage would, of course, see their costs rise, which helps explain why business groups have had trouble finding common ground on health policy.
Walter B. Maher, who heads the Chrysler Corporation's health policy office in Washington, said many large companies were facing higher costs because hospitals and doctors had raised fees to cover services to millions of uninsured Americans. Among the uninsured, he said, are three-quarters of all restaurant and hotel workers, half of the retail employees and 60 percent of low-income people, who have been shut out of Medicaid by hard-pressed budget cutters in many states.
Mr. Maher said the institute study, directed by Jack E. Meyer, a health economist and official in the Nixon, Ford and Carter administrations, was consistent with official comparisons of spending in industrial countries. The United States spent $2,566 per capita on health last year, trailed by Canada at $1,795 and Sweden at $1,421. "The frightening thing," Mr. Maher said, "is that the gulf has widened between the U.S. and our main competitors." Germany spent $1,287 and Japan $1,113.
The study, paid for by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, said that under a Canadian-style system, national health spending would decline by $241 billion a year, even after the addition of $14 billion to cover uninsured Americans. There would be $113 billion in administrative savings, $114 billion through the reduced use of medical technology and the elimination of malpractice costs, waste and unnecessary care. It said reducing physicians' incomes to Canadian levels would save $28 billion.
Challenging the numbers, John Sheils, a health-care consultant who has studied the Canadian system, said administrative savings would be only $46 billion. Mr. Sheils, a vice president of Lewin/ICF, a management consulting firm in Washington, added that Americans would rush to use free care, which would inflate spending by $79 billion. That would wipe out the savings and produce net additional costs of $33 billion.
Uwe E. Reinhardt, a Princeton University health economist, said American physicians' fees were two and a halftimes those in Canada, largely because the American physicians spent nearly half of their $260,000 average gross income last year on overhead costs like extra clerks to handle paperwork, amortization of laboratory machines, and malpractice insurance. Overhead has been rising 6 percent a year. But in Canada, where there is less paperwork, and expensive equipment is discouraged in doctors' offices, overhead costs have remained constant, he said.
Dr. John M. Eisenberg, a member of a Congressional advisory commission on payments to doctors who is chief of general internal medicine at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, said reducing doctors' earnings to Canadian levels would save only about 5 percent of total health-care spending. He noted that although take-home pay was considerably higher for American surgeons, anesthesiologists and a number of other specialists, the incomes of family doctors and internists were similar in the two countries.
But even if physician incomes were held down, medical costs would continue to rise because 18,000 new doctors graduate from medical school each year, say Dr. Kevin Grumbach and Dr. Philip R. Lee of the Institute for Health Policy Studies at the University of California, San Francisco. In a study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association last spring, they said there would be 176 active physicians for every 100,000 people by the year 2000, compared with 144 in 1986. Even if physicians' incomes were held to the general inflation rate, they said, the new doctors would increase national health expenditures by $21 billion in 2000.

HEADLINE: Japan Plans New Drive To Buy More U.S. Goods

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
In the surest sign that American trade officials are about to arrive in Tokyo, the Japanese Government said tonight that it would soon announce another program to encourage companies here to buy more components and materials from the United States and to enter more strategic alliances with American companies.
Details of the program, called the "Business Global Partnership," were sketchy, although it seemed less specific than last year's effort, which included a tax credit to companies that increased their overseas purchases by 10 percent or more. 
 Still, the announcement of the program by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry tonight seemed to reflect the deepening worries here over the ballooning trade deficit, which has soared as Japanese consumers slow their purchases of Western luxury goods.
 
Message for Baker and Hill
 The new program was raised briefly today by Michio Watanabe, Japan's new Foreign Minister, in talks with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. But it seemed intended for Carla A. Hills, the United States special trade representative, who arrives here later this week for the first time in two years.
A senior official of the ministry said tonight that the program, which will be officially announced this Friday, will initially involve 40 big Japanese companies that trade with the United States. Those 40 companies, he said, account for roughly half of all of the trade between the two countries.
He said the companies' performance would be "monitored at a regular interval." But there appeared to be no method of enforcement to assure that they carried through out purchases of American products and materials.
In an announcement that seemed timed to the Government initiative, the Toyota Motor Corporation, one of Japan's largest exporters, announced today that its purchase of American-made auto parts, materials and equipment would grow to $5 billion in the Japanese fiscal year that runs from April 1994 to March 1995. In the current fiscal year, the company has said, it expects to buy $3.2 billion in American-made goods.
 
'A Natural Progression'
 A spokesman for Toyota said today that because the auto maker was expanding its manufacturing in the United States and importing more American parts for similar models made in Japan, the increase was "a natural progression." But the announcement, he said, was part of the company's effort "to cooperate with what MITI is doing."
The Nissan Motor Company said on Friday that it would increase its American purchases to $3.3 billion in the 1994 fiscal year, up more than 40 percent from the current level of $2.3 billion.
In addition to purchases of more American parts and components, the plan described by officials today encourages Japanese companies to seek American partners so that they can design new products with foreign components. "We have asked companies to cooperate before, but never in so comprehensive a way," the senior Japanese trade official said tonight.
In addition to auto and electronics companies -- which get the most attention from the Government here -- producers of glass, paper, even electric power were asked to participate in the program.
The plan was originally planned for release during President Bush's planned trip here in late November. But Mr. Bush canceled his Asia tour last week in what appeared to be a concession to Congressional critics who said he was focusing too much on foreign policy and too little on the recession in the United States.
Officials at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry conceded tonight that their plans might be stymied unless the Japanese economy picked up. Through the 1980's, Japan's growth in imports was led by consumer spending. But recently, that has fallen off as Japanese have begun to worry about the effects of the economic slowdown.
During her visit here, Ms. Hills is expected to concentrate on the negotiations on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. An important point for the United States is to obtain a concession by Japan that it will gradually open its rice market. That concession appears to be near.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Up in Light Day Overseas

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved a bit higher in light trading yesterday.
The gains were recorded during trading in Asian and European markets. Activity in the cash market for Government securities was closed in the United States in observance of Veterans Day. 
 Trading in Treasury bond and bill futures did take place at the Board of Trade. In a shortened session in Chicago, prices rose slightly. At the close of trading, the nearby December bond contract was offered at a price of 100 14/32, up by 5/32.
 
Economic Data Due Tomorrow
 The pace of activity should quicken somewhat today, but market participants said business was likely to remain sluggish until tomorrow, when new economic reports, including producer price data for October, are scheduled to be released.
At the close of overseas trading in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds yesterday, the new 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.86 percent, down from 7.87 percent late on Friday.
Among note issues, the new 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.40 percent in when-issued trading, compared with 7.41 percent late on Friday. And the outstanding 6 percent two-year notes were offered at a price of 100 21/32, down by 2/32, to yield 5.64 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills were unchanged from late on Friday.
 
3-Month Bills at 4.61%
 Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.61 percent. Six-month bill rates were offered at a discount rate of 4.67 percent.
Because of the Veterans Day holiday, the Treasury's weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, normally conducted on Monday, will be held today.
Traders in the markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal securities said activity was extremely slow. Prices of most issues in both markets were unchanged on the day, the traders said.
No new issues of corporate or tax-exempt securities were priced yesterday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ex-Head of C.F.T.C. Eager to Begin Fed Job

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Susan Meredith Phillips, the former chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and a proponent of free markets, has sailed through the Senate confirmation process to become a governor of the Federal Reserve Board.
"This is every economist's ultimate dream," she said in an interview yesterday. "I'm thrilled." 
 Ms. Phillips, 46 years old, the vice president for finance at the University of Iowa in Iowa City, will finish the remainder of Martha R. Seger's 14-year term that began on Feb. 14, 1984. The Fed now has one remaining vacancy on its seven-member board. Lawrence Lindsay, a White House economist, has been nominated by President Bush and has been approved by the Senate Banking Committee, but not yet by the full Senate.
A finance expert, Ms. Phillips's hands-on administrative experience and membership on several corporate boards helped propel her into her new job, she said. "As a chief financial officer of a large university, I'm always trying to issue debt and financing projects."
Ms. Phillips is not known to have strong views on monetary policy. At her confirmation hearings, she said she shared everyone's disappointment in recent economic reports. But she also struck a cautious note when asked whether the Fed should act more aggressively. "We have to be very careful not to create new problems," she said yesterday.
At the Fed, Ms. Phillips is expected to focus on regulatory issues. She headed the futures commission from 1983 to 1987, in a period in which firms won greater ability to use options and futures.
"She'll put less stress on mandating minimums and maximums," said Jerry L. Jordan, the chief economist at the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, "and more on having institutions divulge more information so that the market can act as the ultimate disciplinarian."
But favoring free markets should not be confused with laissez-faire, Ms. Phillips warned. "I spent a lot of time at the C.F.T.C. strengthening commodity exchanges's audit systems," she said. "That's why they performed so well in the 1987 stock market crash."
Ms. Phillips, who was born in Richmond, was an Air Force brat who lived in half a dozen states, England and Germany by the time she started high school. A college math and chemistry major at Agnes Scott College in Georgia, Ms. Phillips went on to earn a Ph.D. in finance at Louisiana State University in 1974.
Ms. Phillips will be joining a male-dominated institution in which expertise counts for a lot and policy debates often take on the air of university seminars. But those who have known her for a long time have no qualms.
"She'll do superbly," said Linda Pickthorne Fletcher, the dean of business school at the University of Tennessee in Chattanooga and Ms. Phillips's doctoral adviser. "She's very analytical, and she'll concentrate on the things that she knows best."

HEADLINE: New Energy Bill Held Unlikely Soon

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Despite optimistic predictions by proponents of conservation and renewable fuels that major new energy legislation would be on the Senate floor by Thanksgiving, Congressional officials say it may be impossible to pass anything more than a limited alternative for months.
Ten days ago, liberal Democrats and an unlikely coalition of environmental groups, small utilities and the automobile industry derailed the Bush Administration's energy bill. Building a coalition for a substitute will be much more difficult. 
 "It's going to be a tall order to come up with a new energy bill," said Senator Frank H. Murkowski, an Alaska Republican who is a member of the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. "The birth pains that came with the last one were extensive."
The old energy bill, which was backed by the White House and the oil industry, tried to stitch together a grab bag of provisions that addressed off-shore and Arctic oil drilling, conservation, incentives to promote greater efficiency in buildings and appliances, deregulation of the utility industry and alternative energy sources like nuclear and hydroelectric power.
Without the impetus of a crisis, like the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last year, which gave the old energy bill a push, Congress is likely to change its approach and deal with such issues individually, in a fashion that will fail to establish a coordinated strategy, analysts say.
"It's out of sight, out of mind," said Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, a Democrat who is the chairman of the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. He had sponsored the defeated legislation.
"The price of gasoline is O.K. now, so there must not be a problem," he said. "A Gallup poll shows that nearly a majority of the American people don't know that we import any oil." Nearly half the oil consumed in the United States is imported.
 
Several Bills Under Way
 A few alternative bills are now in play, but none appears to have a chance of passage until late next year, at least.
One, sponsored by Senator Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat, would mandate an increase in automobile fuel efficiency from the current 27.5 miles a gallon to 40 over the next decade. The Senate Commerce Committee passed the measure, which environmentalists say would conserve 2.5 million barrels of oil a day, but lobbying by the auto industry has so far helped impede action by the full Senate.
The auto industry helped defeat the original energy package because executives feared liberals would add amendments on the floor to mandate fuel efficiency. With the industry reeling from decreased sales, several senators who helped Mr. Bryan sink the original bill are now opposing his efforts to raise mileage standards.
Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who heads the House Committee on Energy and Commerce and is one of the strongest advocates of the auto industry in Congress, is working to keep anything similar to the Bryan measure from being considered in the House.
Daniel Becker, a lobbyist for the Sierra Club and a primary strategist for the environmental movement on energy legislation, said Mr. Dingell could stop his committee from considering the Bryan bill, but he would be unable stop the full House from adding it as an amendment to a House energy bill next year.
But a number of House staff members who monitor energy policy are not as confident.
"Dingell is a very formidable adversary," Mr. Bryan said.
But even if both Congressional chambers do pass the bill, the White House has threatened to veto any legislation that includes stricter fuel-economy standards, arguing that the country cannot afford to burden the industry with more costs.
 
Alaska Drilling Measure
 The House Merchant Marine Committee is considering legislation that would allow oil drilling in the Alaskan National Wildlife Refuge. It was the strong opposition by environmental groups to opening up one of the country's last virgin preserves that sank the old energy bill, and the House measure is not considered any more passable.
Representative Philip R. Sharp, an Indiana Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Power Subcommittee, is sponsoring legislation that would promote the construction of natural gas pipelines, seek reductions of carbon-dioxide emissions that cause global warming and encourage the development of renewable energy sources like wind, solar and geothermal power.
Mr. Sharp's panel overwhelmingly approved his measure, but not before it carved out several of his most ambitious proposals.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans To Insure Soviet Deal

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
A Federal agency has agreed to provide partial insurance against expropriation, political violence and currency convertibility problems for an American investment fund that plans to purchase $250 million worth of minority stakes in the commercial affiliates of Soviet companies in the military industry.
James D. Berg, executive vice president of the agency, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which is known as OPIC, said today that the agreement was reached on Friday and represented the agency's first dealings on investments in the Soviet Union. 
 The move came in response to President Bush's endorsement of closer economic ties with the Soviet Union at his meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in July. Then, in September, the President waived for the Soviet Union a clause in the Foreign Assistance Act that barred OPIC from doing business in Communist countries, Mr. Berg said.
 
Helps American Companies
 OPIC's purpose is to further United States foreign policy and to enable American companies to compete with foreign rivals, which often receive more generous assistance from their governments.
Formidable barriers remain before OPIC actually provides the insurance. The managers of the investment fund, called the Soviet Companies Fund, have not yet struck any deals with Soviet companies. And no insurance policies will actually be written until the agency has an agreement with the Soviet Union or the republics for either Moscow or the republic governments to take primary responsibility for any claims.
Mr. Berg said he expected such an agreement by the end of this year.
The collapse of central authority in the Soviet Union has also made investing there more treacherous, with success no longer assured by cozying up to a few key ministers, said Eugene J. Milosh, president of the American Association of Exporters and Importers.
 
Confusing Signals
 A small company in northern Virginia recently held a news conference here to announce that it would be marketing Soviet jet fighters and aircraft engine parts. An official from the company's Soviet partners then took the podium and announced that the jet fighters would not be available at all.
The fund is being jointly sponsored by Batterymarch Financial Management, a Boston company, and the State Commission on Military Industrial Production in the Soviet Union. It will invest in commercial companies being created by military enterprises that the commission oversees.
OPIC is reserving for the Soviet Companies Fund $100 million of its available insurance coverage. The insurance will cost roughly 25 cents to 60 cents for every $100 of coverage for the fund's investors. American taxpayers will have to pay only if claims are filed and OPIC cannot collect from Soviet or republic authorities.
Given the mounting political, economic and financial chaos in the Soviet Union, the insurance premiums represent, "a fantastic buy," Mr. Milosh said.
 
A Good Loss Rate
 Mr. Berg said that OPIC's premiums were based on the type of project rather than the location. OPIC's loss rate is less than 1 percent, he said.
Marilyn J. Pitchford, chief financial officer of Batterymarch, said the company had identified six Soviet companies as likely investment prospects and eight additional companies as promising. Referring to recent reports that some Soviet entrepreneurs may be seeking to defraud foreign investors, she said, "We've certainly heard that, and it's something we're not naive about."
One of the likely prospects is Leningrad Optical Mechanical Enterprises Amalgamated, which makes both lenses for the military and microscopes and medical devices for looking inside the human body, Ms. Pitchford said. Another prospect produces aircraft and another specializes in metallurgy and ceramics.
Although Soviet consumer-goods industries have a dismal reputation for backwardness, the Soviet military sector is considered to have some of the world's best scientists pioneering some technologies.
 
$250 Milion Fund
 Based on informal commitments and expressions of interest from investors, mostly large pension funds, the Soviet Companies Fund will have about $250 million when legally binding commitments are made at the end of this month, Ms. Pitchford said. Batterymarch manages about $6.5 billion in the United States and abroad.
Each investor in the fund will have the choice of whether to pay for insurance; only 40 percent coverage would be available if all investors sought it and had to share the $100 million in coverage. OPIC insures up to 90 percent of any single investment, so that the $100 million could provide coverage for $111 million worth of investments.
The fund will be seeking stakes of about 30 percent in Soviet companies, with employees, cities, republics and the affiliated military enterprises owning the rest, Ms. Pitchford said.
Conservatives here no longer object to American partnerships with the Soviet military-industrial complex. "The idea that OPIC would be giving political risk insurance here seems to be right," said Stephen D. Bryen, who was Deputy Under Secretary of Defense for trade security policy throughout the Reagan Administration.
Kim R. Holmes, director of foreign policy and defense studies at the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington, said that he was skeptical of using Government money to insure private business risks anywhere abroad, but had no objections to American money being invested in deals with Soviet military-supply companies.
"Any kind of American investment that could help conversion I think would be a good idea," he said.
Ms. Pitchford said that even if the joint ventures proved successful, she doubted that military companies holding stakes in them would use the profits to produce more weapons. "We do believe what we've heard about Yeltsin and Gorbachev, you know, having a commitment to scale down the military," she said.

HEADLINE: Careers;
For Nurses, Travel and A Job, Too

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
TO fill their nursing vacanies, hospitals around the country can draw on Travcorps Inc. of Malden, Mass., and its data bank of 10,000 nurses willing to travel.
"At any one time we have 1,200 to 1,500 nurses actively placed in hospitals around the country." Bruce M. Male, 49 years old, the president and owner of the company, said last week. "This is a people business." 
 Hospitals pay one fee to Travcorps, and out of that Travcorps pays a nurse anywhere from $17 to $27 an hour. It also pays for the nurse's travel to the hospital and arranges for living quarters. Its benefits package for nurses includes standard life, health and accident insurance. "We don't have a pension plan for them," Mr. Male said.
He would not say how much above expenses Travcorps charges as its fee. "It's proprietary information," he said. But he did say: "We are less expensive than the typical local nursing registry; they have higher overhead than we do. We only advertise in national journals."
"We send the hospitals who need nurses a complete personnel file on each referral," he said, "plus we require mandatory phone interviews with the nurses by hospital personnel. We do get occasional rejections of nurses by the hospital, but on the other hand we accept only about one out of five nurses who apply for job placement."
Travcorps does not charge anything if a nurse goes to a hospital and does not work out, he said.
His favorite story involves a hospital, no longer in existence, in Muleshoe, Tex. "It's a nowhere town that had a little hospital with about 25 beds," Mr. Male said. "The nurses found the people there to be very appreciative and ready to open their homes because of a lack of rental living quarters. Over a period of time we supplied about eight nurses for that hospital, since closed because of financial problems about three years ago."
As for turnover, he said: "No, we do not have shock troops to send in case a nurse gets sick or leaves the job, but we do have that computer system. If the nurse leaves suddenly, replacement becomes top priority."
Unlike nurses who sign with a local registry to work for a week or so, his nurses sign for three months, and often stay for another three months.
Sometimes they are assigned to work the difficult-to-fill night shifts that typically are 11 P.M. to 7 A.M.
"We also do a lot of 12-hour shifts," he said. "This gives nurses a shorter workweek and more time to explore the area."
A nurse might be sent to a relatively exotic location like Alaska or Hawaii. More typical would be an assignment to Florida to help meet the big winter demand for nurses to treat retirees and vacationers. In the summer, nurses might be needed at hospitals in northern vacation areas. "Not in Masachusetts," he said, "because of our recession."
"Some do private-duty work," he said. He recalled a nurse who spent months caring for an Arab sheik and helped get him home to the Middle East. "But that is not our main business," he added. "Supplying hospitals is."
"We have two profiles of our typical nurse," he said. The majority are single women about 27 years old. "We get several wedding invitations every month from this age group," he said, Others are single women over age 45 who are interested in travel.
Once the assignments are over the nurses can stay with the hospital or they can return home and await another assignment.
Mr. Male said he founded the company as "a frustrated entrepreneur about 14 years ago."
He had graduated from Tufts University, where he majored in biology and chemistry, and then got a master of health sciences degree at Northeastern University, also in the Boston area. He worked for a health-care supplier but wanted to "get out on my own."
The growing shortage of hospital nurses "gave me the concept of traveling nurses to fill shortages around the country," he said.
"To start, I had $1,739 in my checkbook, a telephone, plus an American Express card to use for booking flights for the first nurses I sent out," he added. "I also had two kids, a mortgage and no income."
His first client was Maureen McGuire, then director of nursing at the Tulane University Medical Center in New Orleans. "She was brave enough to take my first nurses," he said.
Today Travcorps has "a very large computer" and about 100 staff people, many of them working in data processing and accounting, he said.
"We have some nurse representatives who do customer service work with hospitals that might hire the firm's nurses," he said.
He does a lot of traveling himself -- yesterday he was at Brackenridge Hospital in Austin, Tex., where his company has about 60 nurses.
Dr. Joyce J. Fitzpatrick, dean of nursing at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, said the traveling nurses concept "is a very good idea," adding that "it keeps many nurses in nursing."
She warned that some agencies had not adhered to professional standards, and she urged the hiring hospitals to check the nurses they hire carefully. Travcorps has been around 14 years, she pointed out.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mixed Signals On Westinghouse

BYLINE: By John Holusha

 BODY:
WHEN the Westinghouse Electric Corporation unexpectedly announced last month that it was taking a $1.68 billion write-off because of problems with property loans at its credit subsidiary, it became part of the real estate mess of the early 1990's. The price of the stock dropped steadily from the low 20's to the midteens.
It bottomed out -- at least temporarily -- at $15.75 in late October and then began a slow recovery, closing at $17 yesterday, down 25 cents. But a lot of uncertainty remains. 
 Has it taken all the bad medicine, or are there more surprises? Can the dividend be held at $1.40 a share? Will it be trimmed or eliminated as the price for a new package of credits from banks?
Nicholas Heyman, an analyst at County NatWest, predicts the worst is yet to come. The current dividend, he said, "is not sustainable." The only question, he continued, is how much will it be reduced? "At this point, the best case is a cut to 70 cents; the worst is elimination."
In Mr. Heyman's view, the latest write-off coupled with a write-off taken earlier this year but charged against 1990's results merely trimmed the price of Westinghouse Credit's portfolio to the level of properties being marketed by the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is cleaning up the remains of collapsed savings and loans. To sell its properties aggressively, Mr. Heyman said, Westinghouse will have to make further price cuts.
"We are talking another $500 million to $1 billion" in write-offs, he said.
When this news comes out, perhaps in the fourth quarter, he expects the stock's small recovery to evaporate. "The second bounce down will probably be lower," he said, noting that Westinghouse shares bottomed at about $13 in the early 80's.
Company officials have tried to send signals that they are concerned about preserving the dividendbut will do what is necessary to arrange the bank credits. In a statement provided by the company, the chairman, Paul E. Lego, said, "Cutting the dividend is one of the last things I would like to do" in shoring up the company's financial structure. But, he added, "I will do what I have to do."
The company also said it was encouraged by its talks with banks but did not expect to have agreements in hand before the end of this month.
As might be expected of a company that has given off such mixed signals that analysts' estimates of earnings for the year range from $1.25 a share to $2.03, there are other points of view.
Kemp Fuller Jr., an analyst with Baird, Patrick & Company, sees sun through the clouds.
Mr. Fuller points out that credit is only a small part of the Pittsburgh-based company, adding that "the remaining parts of the business will recover when the economy recovers."
He said the most recent write-off had cut Westinghouse's real estate to market value and the properties could probably be sold without much more fuss.
Mr. Fuller added that even though it would take three to five years to clean up Westinghouse Credit's real estate and leveraged buyout portfolio, the company had already absorbed the cost.
And he noted that dividends were paid out of cash flow, not reported earnings, so that payments were likely to continue, though he warned that the payout might be trimmed to $1 a share.
As a result, he considers the stock a good buy at the current level. "By the end of the fourth quarter, the stock price is going to start reflecting next year's expected earnings," he said.
Mr. Fuller said he estimated that Westinghouse would have operating earnings of $2.25 a share in 1992, compared with his estimate of $1.75 a share this year. In 1993, he sees $2.75 a share.
Based on these estimates, he expects the stock to rise to $27 in a year and as much as $33 by late 1993.
"Westinghouse is one of the beaten-up stocks" he said. "It is in a testing phase now" and should begin to rise by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading As U.S. Banks Take Holiday

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled lower in light trading on world currency markets yesterday.
Gold prices rose across the board. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $355.30 an ounce, up $1.10 from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $1.30 an ounce, to a late bid price of $355.10. 
 American banks were closed for the Veterans Day holiday, though many kept their currency-trading operations open. Still, the trading session was shortened and activity was extremely light, traders said.
The dollar opened higher in Europe, but traders tested the downside in the absence of any market-moving news and succeeded in pushing the American currency lower. Analysts said the dollar ran into strong support at 1.6440 German marks.
"That is a very important number," said Richard Levine, a foreign-exchange broker at Merrill Lynch & Company. "It is in between the dollar's high and low for the year, and it's going to be very hard to get momentum going one way or another" without some fundamental development.
He said interest-rate moves in either Europe or Japan would still influence dollar trading, but there was only speculation that any changes were on the horizon.
"The market is actually starving for some new information fundamentally," Mr. Levine said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.18 yen to close at 130.05 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 130.20 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 130.05 yen, down from 130.43 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7695, from $1.7680 late Friday. In New York, it cost $1.7705 to buy a pound, compared with $1.7630 on Friday.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $354.50 an ounce, up 35 cents from late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose $1.15, to a closing bid of $354.80. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.41, to close at $355.35.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Lowers Outlook On Growth in U.S. for 1992

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Because of longer-than-anticipated economic weakness in the United States, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has significantly reduced its forecast for American growth for next year but does not foresee the economy slipping into a recession.
The revised forecast places growth in the United States in 1992 at about 2.5 percent, down from the 3.1 percent predicted six weeks ago. 
 In addition, senior officials at the Paris-based organization said that for the second half of 1991, American economic growth would be about 1.4 percent, about half the 2.7 percent rate that it predicted in early October.
"We're not looking for a double dip, but the economic weakness may continue into early next year," said an O.E.C.D. official who would speak only on the condition of anonymity.
At a news briefing, a senior official said that for 1991, American economic output would decline by between two-tenths and five-tenths of 1 percent.
The O.E.C.D., which is often called the club of rich nations, has 24 members, including the United States, Japan, and the nations of Western Europe. The group fosters economic cooperation and is respected for its forecasting ability.
In early October, the organization's staff prepared a fall forecast for the industrial nations, but officials said the only country that had required a significant downward revision was the United States, because of its stubborn economic sluggishness.
The organization's top economists are to present their projections on Tuesday at a meeting of the organization's main economic policy committee. That committee is headed by Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
The O.E.C.D.'s revised forecast for 1992 compares with a forecast of 3 percent by the International Monetary Fund in October. The Federal Reserve has projected growth in the gross national product for 1992 at between 2.25 and 3 percent; the Bush Administration has been more optimistic with a prediction of 3.6 percent growth, though it may yet revise its figure.
 
'Weak, Slow, Feeble'
 "We have said the rebound will be weak, slow, feeble," said a senior O.E.C.D. official. He said the Federal Reserve Board's recent interest-rate cuts had not done enough to spark cuts in other rates that are pivotal for investment, like bank lending rates and long-term interest rates.
"The rebound we were expecting at a certain date hasn't happened," he said. "We think it will be delayed several months. There is uncertainty right now for business investors. There are credit worries, and the budget deficit worries a lot of people."
He added, "There isn't a contraction; there is just an absence of expansion."
Despite the recent economic weakness, the O.E.C.D. is holding to the forecast it made last July for 3.3 economic growth in the United States in 1993.
The organization's forecast for inflation in the United States has improved since July. It projected that American inflation would be 3.9 percent this year, 3.4 percent in 1992 and 3.1 percent in 1993, falling to 2.9 percent in the second half of 1993. Last July, it forecast that inflation would be 4 percent this year and 3.6 percent next year.
 
Soft Landing for Japan
 The organization also revised downward its projection for Japanese economic growth next year. In July it forecast that Japan's economy would grow by 3.5 percent next year, but its newest report predicted growth of 2.5 percent next year, partly because of the pressure on the financial sector.
Japan is going to have a soft landing, one official said.
But for this year, the organization predicted growth for Japan at a robust 4.6 percent, while in July it predicted 3.5 percent growth. It said Japanese growth would be 3.6 percent in 1993.
For Germany, the O.E.C.D. predicted growth of 3.5 percent this year and 2.1 percent next year, as Germany's high interest rates slow the economy. For 1993, the organization projected growth of 2.5 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BRIEFS

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Dow Dips 3.36, to 3,042.26, in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Most stocks traded higher yesterday on light volume, while the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 3.36 points, to 3,042.26, pulled down by General Motors. The Nasdaq index, meanwhile, reached its third high in as many days.
Without the influence of the Treasury bond market and banks, both closed for Veterans Day, stocks traded in a narrow 10-point range most of the session. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 129.1 million, down from 183.3 million on Friday, as the composite scratched out a 0.25-point gain, to 217.07. Gaining issues narrowly outpaced losing stocks by 838 to 748.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, one measure of blue-chip activity, was up just 0.23 point, to 393.12, with the American Stock Exchange composite up 0.76, to 391.24.
 
Nasdaq Is Active
 Nasdaq trading was brisk, however, with the index up 2.63 points, to a record of 550.71. The Russell 2,000, an indicator of smaller stocks, also reached a high, up 0.48, to 186.79.
William Raftery, a technical analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham, saw yesterday's market as dull and quiet, with special situations ruling the day. He predicted that such a situation might continue for another day or so in advance of a several economic reports scheduled for this week, including the producer price, consumer price and industrial production numbers for October.
Blue-chip issues opened down yesterday, but the broad market was off only a little, as secondary stocks continued to attract some buyers in slow holiday trading.
General Motors and Ford Motor fell under pressure, after S.& P. on Friday placed G.M.'s long-term debt and commercial paper under review for possible downgrading and revised the outlook for Ford's senior debt to negative. General Motors fell 1 3/8, to 32 5/8, while Ford dropped 1, to 25 1/8.
Dillard Department Stores, which reported yesterday that third-quarter profits rose to $1.05 a share from 88 cents a year ago, rose 5/8, to 128 3/8.
Lower earnings expectations might have caused Syntex to fall 1 1/8, to 41 3/8. Jerome Brimeyer, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, said he had moderately reduced his 1992 and 1993 earnings estimates for the company, citing higher expected expenses.
Barr Laboratories, which last week said the Food and Drug Administration had asked it to sign a consent decree requiring a shutdown of operations because of what Barr described as "minor infractions" involving 16 of its 170 products, was off 3 3/4, to 23 1/4. The company said it was cooperating with the F.D.A.
Environmental Systems was up 3, to 16, The company said it had receieved a buyout offer from Brambles Industries of Australia.

HEADLINE: Power of the Mortgage Twins

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
In a spacious office just north of Georgetown, James A. Johnson has the latest technology: a video monitor that flashes both the news and prices from Wall Street and displays a small window with a television screen showing live debates from Congress.
It is a neat symbol for Mr. Johnson, whose job as chairman and chief executive of the Federal National Mortgage Association bridges political and financial circles. Fannie Mae, as it is informally known, and its smaller brother, Freddie Mac, a second Government-created mortgage financing company, have scored their greatest successes this year in both worlds. 
 As the main sources of credit for American home buyers, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which is also known as the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, finance about one home in four. So far, they have enjoyed their most profitable year on record. Propelling their earnings, which are expected to approach a total of $2 billion, are low interest rates, which have encouraged a wave of mortgage refinancings, and the decline of savings and loan associations, their main competition.
 
Mission of the Companies
 The two companies were created by the Government to make the purchase of homes more affordable. These publicly traded corporations accomplish their mission by raising money relatively cheaply in debt markets, using the cash to buy mortgages from banks and savings and loans, and then either holding the mortgages or repackaging them into securities that are sold to investors.
The process provides banks and savings and loans with fresh cash to issue more mortgages. In the last few years, favorable interest rates have also enabled Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to post larger profits by taking advantage of the difference between the price at which they borrow money and the price at which they issue their mortgage-backed securities.
But critics in the Bush Administration and on Capitol Hill assert that over the long term, the two companies have become so unrestrained that they could pose enormous liabilities to taxpayers, because no one thinks the Government would stay on the sidelines should they ever encounter difficulties.
Senior executives at the two companies say that the criticism is misplaced and that they are in a sense becoming victims of their success.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have grown more than two and a half times in the last five years, issuing more than $1 trillion in obligations. The Government provides the companies with a wide array of tax benefits, regulatory breaks and securities law exemptions not shared by any of their competitors in the banking and savings and loan industries.
The two companies are the nation's largest issuers of corporate debt, and since the markets generally view their securities as Government-backed, they are able to raise money more cheaply than any other business. They also enjoy multibillion-dollar credit lines with the Treasury.
So far, their defense has staved off the critics from making any legislative or regulatory inroads that threaten their autonomy. The companies have resoundingly rebuffed calls for a drastic overhaul that would put them under tighter Government control. And despite suggestions of phony bids by customers who buy their debt, they have managed to keep the lid on the details.
In a reflection of their persuasive political power, the companies wrote much of a bill, adopted overwhelmingly by the House in September, that would give them more autonomy in some areas than they had before and impose less onerous capital requirements than some lawmakers wanted. They also have put the brakes on an effort to get the Securities and Exchange Commission more actively involved in regulating them.
 
Generous Contributions
 Some critics say their successes are not solely the product of their policy choices and business acumen, and point to the roster of prominent former Government members on their employee and lobbying payrolls, including former White House officials and Cabinet members from both parties -- and to generous campaign contributions.
These critics maintain that the companies continue to pose significant potential risk to taxpayers, particularly if interest rates rise drastically, and that they have railroaded Congress into adopting rather lenient legislation.
Alfred A. DelliBovi, Deputy Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac "have the broadest constituency in the United States after the President," since they serve so many homeowners and also have the support of mortgage bankers, real estate development groups and customers on Wall Street who make tens of millions of dollars selling their debt.
Executives at the two companies attribute their political gains to their track record of providing enormous amounts of cash to the housing market, and in so doing keeping housing costs lower while simultaneously providing returns on equity averaging about 25 percent for the last few years.
 
'A Great Success Story'
 "This has been the greatest year and most eventful year ever for Freddie Mac," notes Leland C. Brendsel, chairman and chief executive of the company.
Mr. Johnson's view is similar. "It's a great success story," he said. "One of the points I generally make to people in the Administration and people on Capitol Hill is that in the context of there being so few clear public-policy successes, you should rejoice in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac rather than fight them. This is a very unique idea that Congress and the Presidency put in place that works beautifully."
Their critics include a number of lawmakers, members of the Bush Administration and competitors who assert that the companies' political victories have been the result of forging alliances with powerful interest groups, paying off some critics to gain their support, playing the different regulatory agencies off of each other, and wielding influence through an unusually heavy reliance on a cadre of executives and lobbyists who had previously served as officials in the Government and in Congress.
The critics also assert that shareholders instead of homeowners receive too much of the billions of dollars that the companies receive in Government subsidies through tax breaks and perceived Government guarantees, estimated by some to be $2 billion to $4 billion annually.
 
'Laughed Out of Town'
 "To me, the rules totally change when you get a subsidy," said Mr. DelliBovi, who as H.U.D.'s Deputy Secretary is the Administration's second senior housing official after his boss, Jack Kemp. "If Lee Iacocca came to town and said give us this kind of subsidy for these kinds of returns, he'd be laughed out of town."
"They want to make us a regulator in name only," he added.
Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa and a respected member of the House Banking Committee, was the lone dissenting vote in his committee on the legislation about the companies, because he believed that it does not set adequate capital standards to insure that there would not be a taxpayer bailout if the economy ever turns against them.
And Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, asserted that executive compensation at the two companies was excessive, pointing to this year's $27.5 million retirement compensation package for Fannie Mae's former chairman, David O. Maxwell, as well as the $1 million-plus salaries of six officials. Three of the 10 highest-paid executives in Washington work at Fannie Mae.
 
Exception to the Critics
 Mr. Johnson and Mr. Brendsel take strong exception to the critics, pointing to studies they have commissioned that conclude that most of the benefits flow not to their shareholders but to homeowners. Mr. Johnson said salaries and bonuses at the company were "at about the median for large financial institutions."
The legislation adopted in late September by the House imposes three sets of capital levels to be monitored by H.U.D.. Perhaps the most important capital level requires the two companies to hold capital of 0.45 percent to 2.5 percent of their assets. Banks and savings associations, in contrast, will be required to have a minimum capital to asset ratio of 4 percent, adjusted for risk, beginning next year.
Administration officials had originally proposed more strict capital measures, but senior Treasury officials decided on lower limits in the face of a lobbying blitzkrieg.
The companies have put an impressive bipartisan list of former Government officials on their lobbying and employee payrolls, including Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Health, Education and Welfare Secretary in the Carter Administration; Kenneth M. Duberstein, President Ronald Reagan's last chief of staff; Harry C. McPherson, a White House adviser in the Johnson Administration, and Leonard Garment and Henry C. Cashen 2d, two former senior advisers to President Richard M. Nixon who are partners at the Washington law firm of Dickstein, Shapiro & Morin.
Mr. Johnson himself has strong bipartisan connections, having served as chairman in Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign in 1984 and as managing director with Richard G. Darman, President Bush's budget director, in the Washington office of Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Freddie Mac recently added to its well-connected roster Mitchell Delk, the former chief lobbyist for the S.E.C., and Fannie Mae recently hired John Buckley, the former director of communcations at the National Republican Congressional Committee and deputy press secretary to the Reagan-Bush campaign in 1984.
 
Political Action Committee
 The two companies' legislative agenda has been assisted by generous campaign contributions. Fannie Mae is the only known federally created organization to have a political action committee, which in recent years has contributed more than $110,000 to lawmakers. Tens of thousands of dollars have also been contributed by its senior executives.
In the thick of the Congressional debate over the legislation this summer, Fannie Mae went on a grant binge, donating hundreds of thousands of dollars to almost a dozen low-income housing, community and consumer groups that had initially expressed strong support for tougher legislation, but ultimately backed down. Both the groups and Fannie Mae assert that the grants did not affect the outcome of the legislation, but Mr. Leach believes otherwise.
"The timing of the grants is self-evident," he said. "This is the most important legislation since the inception of Fannie and Freddie and they pulled out all the stops to make sure potential critics were silenced."

HEADLINE: Southland Posts Slight Profit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The Southland Corporation today reported lower-than-expected third-quarter earnings of $5.8 million, as the economic downturn and cool weather took a toll on its 7-Eleven convenience stores.
Southland said the performance weakened its ability to meet some terms of its agreements with major bank lenders, which were made as part of a Chapter 11 reorganization. 
 The company said it hoped to renegotiate some of the lending terms. Under Southland's accord with its banks, the company had been expected to post higher year-to-date earnings before taxes and other items.
Southland finished the bankruptcy process in March and is now largely owned by the Ito-Yokado Company of Japan and the Seven-Eleven Japan Company.
The company's earnings for the three months ended Sept. 30 came to 1 cent a share. During the corresponding period last year, Southland lost $122.8 million. Revenue was $2.15 billion, down 4.9 percent from $2.26 billion a year ago, when the company operated 180 more stores.
Southland's chief executive, Clark Matthews, said the company did not expect an improvement the rest of this year or in 1992 because of greater competition and weakness in the United States economy.
The company owns or franchises more than 6,000 7-Eleven stores in the United States and Canada. Seven-Eleven Japan operates about 4,300 7-Eleven stores in Japan under an agreement with Southland. Licensees operate 2,300 more 7-Eleven stores in 19 other countries.

HEADLINE: Doctors View Health Plans As Eroding Their Autonomy

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Nov. 11

 BODY:
In Dr. Stephen P. Kelly's red-brick office building here, medicine's past shares space with medicine's future. This is a doctor who still makes house calls. Yet as he leaves to visit ailing patients, he passes a computer that contains the billing requirements of 16 health-care networks, each of which has different rules about how much he can charge and what procedures he can perform.
Dr. Kelly cannot continue in this medical time warp much longer. He feels an obligation to join the networks, he says, because his patients' employers have joined them, and this is the only way he can keep his patients. But the networks pay less than his customary fees, which means that he has to see more patients, going farther afield in Westchester County, to maintain his income. That leaves him less time for the patients he was trying to serve in the first place. 
 "Something has to give," he says.
He is making fewer house calls.
 
Networks Gather Patients
 The choice Dr. Kelly faces -- autonomy vs. income -- is being faced by doctors throughout the region as the "managed care" medical system strengthens its foothold here. Many patients are attracted to the reduced costs and the lack of paperwork offered by the networks. Employers admire the networks' ability to limit health-care costs. But doctors have their own point of view.
Like so many other changes in health care in the last decade, this one reminds doctors of something many prefer to forget: Medicine is no longer the sacrosanct profession romanticized by Dr. Marcus Welby; it is a business, and a difficult one at that.
"One of the reasons I went into medicine in the first place was I didn't want to work for anyone else," said Dr. Richard Fass, an oncologist in Yonkers who recently resigned from a network a week after joining because the network told him where to send blood samples for analysis, something he has been doing in his own office for several years.
"They're going to win eventually," he said, conceding that he will probably join other networks soon, "but at least I'm putting up a fight."
Under "managed care," an employer pays a fee to a health-care network that may describe itself as a "health maintenance organization" or "preferred provider organization" or may use an individual name, such as Pru-Care, Physicians Health Service, Oxford or Healthnet.
When a company joins a network, employees are given a list of the doctors who have agreed to be part of it. The doctors must agree to accept the fees set by the network and to clear all major procedures with the network before performing them. Some networks pay doctors a flat yearly fee for each patient, but most pay them for each visit and procedure.
If an employee visits a participating doctor, the patient pays a small "co-payment," usually about $10, and the rest is covered by the network at the rate it has set with the doctors. If an employee visits a non-participating doctor, some networks will reimburse the patient for a percentage of the outside doctor's fee, usually 80 percent. A few will pay nothing.
With health-care costs rising and the economy slowing, more employers are joining networks, which means that more patients are in such plans, so more doctors have to join as well.
Most doctors do not join happily, and their major objection is financial; the plans pay less for each visit than the doctors would otherwise charge.
 
Lower Fees Charged>
 "Your charge per visit becomes a fiction," said Dr. Steven Golub, an internist in East Meadows, L.I. "The company decides what you charge."
Dr. Tracey Jayne Fein, an obstetrician in White Plains, refused to join one network because it would reimburse her $12 a visit, compared to her standard rate of $100. Her fee for delivering a baby, including nine months of prenatal care, is $4,500. The one network of which she is a member pays $3,000.
Dr. Kelly, in Dobbs Ferry, charges $40 for an average office visit, and most of the 16 plans to which he belongs pay about $25, though a few pay as much as $45. "I'm seeing more patients and recouping less from each patient," he said.
Dr. Fass, the Yonkers oncologist, said he quit one network a week after joining it because he was told that patients would not be reimbursed unless all blood analysis was done at one Westchester center. For several years, Dr. Fass has been doing much of his blood analysis himself to increase his earnings.
Doctors also object to the plans on the basis of sentiment. "It's a terrible way to choose a doctor, just a name on a list," Dr. Kelly said.
Doctors and patients traditionally found each other through recommendations from friends or referrals from other doctors. Under the network system, physicians complain, doctors are treating patients who know nothing about them.
"If someone I've worked closely with sends me someone who he feels I would be good for, that's one kind of relationship," said Dr. Bruce Yaffe, a Manhattan gastroenterologist and internist. "But when a guy I never heard of looks down the list and chooses me because of where my office is and he can pronounce my name, well, that's a different level of communication."
Doctors say they are equally uncomfortable referring patients to other network physicians whom they have never met. The referral system is a tradition, part collegial camaraderie and part financial quid pro quo. The networks allow referrals only to other member doctors, if they have no personal and professional relationship with the primary physician.
The practice makes Dr. Richard Mones, a Manhattan pediatrician who belongs to six health networks, uneasy. "I have to tell my patients outright, 'I don't know who this person is, and that's the way we have to do it in 1991,' " he said. "It makes everyone very uncomfortable."
While all the doctors interviewed stressed that they treat all patients alike, regardless of the insurance, many said they knew of others who were not as thorough or as kind with the patients who belonged to network plans.
"If you come in and my schedule's a little tight, my initial reaction is to treat you over the phone," said a doctor who declined to be named of the attitude he sees in some colleagues toward patients in network plans, particularly the "per capita" plans that pay a flat yearly fee for each patient.
"If you do come in, I'm not going to do anything that's going to wow you so you come back all the time. There's no added incentive for docs to be on their best behavior. They may not meet somebody in an emergency room at 6 o'clock on Sunday night, they may just send them to the emergency room."
Why, then, do doctors join the plans?
 
Patients Are the Key
 Some do so to retain patients. "I saw patients who I really liked as people and as patients leaving me because their employers had decided on a different health plan," said Dr. Kelly, who joined his first plan about five years ago when the Ardsley and Dobbs Ferry school districts, where many of his patients worked, adopted a network plan.
Others join to find more patients. "The economic fact of pediatric practice is volume," Dr. Mones said. "You have to see a lot of patients to make a nice living."
A few join to get their first patients. "It's a good way to start a new practice," said Dr. Maryellen Romano of Staten Island, who was the sole gynecologist on the Pru-Care doctor list when she opened her practice two and a half years ago. She normally charges $100 for an initial visit, but Pru-Care pays only $78.
There are doctors who refuse to participate in the plans. "I can still make a healthy living without them, thank God," said one surgeon in Weston, Conn., who declined to allow his name to be used.
Others limit the number of plans they join. Dr. Fein, for instance, belongs to only one.
And a growing number are making their peace with the new reality. "Complaining doesn't change anything," Dr. Kelly said. "Whatever private practice used to be, now it means I'm basically running a small business. I could walk out of here and run a small clothing company. It's all the same."

HEADLINE: BAKER ASKS JAPAN TO BROADEN ROLE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d called on Japan today to assume a more active role in protecting democracy and advocating free trade, instead of relying on "checkbook diplomacy" to protect its narrow interests or waiting for foreign pressure to force it into action.
"We recognize that Japan's leaders, and its people, are now grappling with a difficult adjustment in Japan's world role," Mr. Baker said in an address to the Japan Institute for International Affairs. 
 "You are beginning to fully appreciate your national capabilities -- and your responsibilities -- around the globe. Your 'checkbook diplomacy,' like our 'dollar diplomacy' of an earlier era, is clearly too narrow."
 
A U.S. Blueprint
 The remarks by Mr. Baker, who met today with Japan's new Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, and its Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, did not mark any sharp departure from United States policy. But they pointed the way to future Japanese-American relations as envisioned by Washington in the post-cold-war era.
Specifically, Mr. Baker is seeking a greater Japanese role in promoting a compromise in global free-trade talks; in United Nations peacekeeping efforts, and in a campaign to dissuade North Korea from developing nuclear weapons.
An example of the stance urged by Washington is Tokyo's participation in an international conference on Middle East issues that is expected to convene in the next three weeks as part of the peace process begun in Madrid last month.
Mr. Baker's comments here were seen in particular as public support of pending Japanese legislation that would permit the Government to send troops on limited United Nations peacekeeping missions, their first duty abroad since World War II.
The bill moved toward approval today when the leaders of the small Komeito party said they would back it, assuring enough votes for passage.
A debate over the bill began in Parliament this week, with Prime Minister Miyazawa assuring opposition lawmakers that participation in such peacekeeping efforts would not violate the Japanese constitutional ban on the use of military force.
Mr. Baker seemed to voice American frustration, particularly in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, that Japan had not assumed a fair share of the global burden of defending democracies or sufficiently supported free trade, even though it is a prime beneficiary of both. Although Japan contributed roughly $13 billion to the gulf war effort, it did so reluctantly, and Americans gave it scant credit.
 
Postwar Minesweepers
 Mr. Baker said the gulf war might turn out to be a "watershed event" in a transformation of Japanese policy.
"We recognize the difficulty of achieving a consensus on a security challenge in what might have appeared to be a far-off land," he said. "We appreciate Japan's generous financial contribution to the allied effort. And we know the significance of Japan's minesweepers plying the troubled waters of the Persian Gulf." He referred to the decision to send minesweepers to the gulf after the war was over.
In his meetings today with Mr. Miyazawa and Mr. Watanabe, Secretary Baker reassured the two leaders that President Bush's sudden cancellation of a visit to Tokyo intended no slight to Japan and that he wanted to reschedule the trip very soon.
Some American officials have suggested that the President regrets having canceled the trip, apparently in response to domestic criticism that he was spending too much time abroad. They hint that the President could reschedule it as early as next month.
Mr. Baker, in his speech today, his first major policy address on Asian affairs, also called on North Korea to match the offer of the South to forgo development or possession of any material used in building a nuclear bomb.
The Secretary of State, who will begin a three-day visit to South Korea on Tuesday, is trying to step up pressure on the North to open its installations to international nuclear inspection and dismantle a complex north of Pyongyang, the capital, that is suspected of being the center of a nuclear-bomb-making project.
This comes as Japan and other Asian countries are expressing fear that the United States may be missing important warning signals about the North Korean nuclear project, much as it missed some in Iraq. American officials concede that they know even less about North Korea's abilities than they did about Iraq's. And because they don't want to be accused again of overlooking a major threat, they have begun to sound the alarm.
"We learned from the case of Iraq," Mr. Baker said, that even International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards "cannot insure that a renegade regime will not seek to acquire nuclear weapons."
"The only firm assurance against a nuclear arms race on the Korean peninsula," he said, "would be a credible agreement by both Seoul and Pyongyang to abstain from the production or acquisition of any weapons-grade nuclear material."
North Korea on Sunday rejected Seoul's initiative. American officials say their first response will be to try to enlist China, Japan and the Soviet Union in diplomatic efforts to induce the North to comply.
Mr. Baker urged the Japanese to exercise greater leadership not just in economics but also in building democracy, promoting respect for human rights, stopping the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and facing up to challenges of the environment, narcotics and refugees.
"Japan should step forward as a leader in confronting global issues rather than relying on 'gaiatsu' -- foreign pressure -- to justify decisions on economics or security affairs that are in its own interests," Mr. Baker said.
 
Contentious Rice-Import Issue
 In particular, he said, Tokyo should take a much more active role in helping to forge a compromise in the Uruguay Round of trade talks that are aimed at removing or lowering tariff barriers to trade and investment.
Mr. Baker reiterated that Japan begin by lifting its longtime ban on rice imports, a concession by the governing Liberal Democratic Party to politically powerful rice farmers. The Japanese told Mr. Baker that they were ready to consider this longtime American request but made no firm commitments.
"As one of the primary beneficiaries of the open world trading system," the Secretary of State said, "Japan should lead, not follow, in the effort to preserve and strengthen that system."
Although Prime Minister Miyazawa speaks English fluently and has known Mr. Baker for many years, he chose to speak to him in Japanese through an interpreter.
Mr. Miyazawa, who has been Prime Minister less than a week, has been criticized in the press for showing off his English, and has stirred concern that he might somehow give something away in English that he would not in Japanese.
When Mr. Miyazawa informed Mr. Baker today that he would speak through an interpreter, Japanese officials said, the Secretary laughed loudly, apparently appreciating the political humor in the situation.
In a rather unusual move, Mr. Baker, while praising Japan for upgrading its military, said there must be a "balanced two-way flow of defense-related technology -- an increasingly critical resource in the security system."
American officials said the Japanese should help contribute to the defense of democratic countries by sharing more advanced defense technology, particularly that used in fighter aircraft.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d meeting yesterday with Japan's Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, at Mr. Miyazawa's residence in Tokyo before their talks on the future of Japanese-American relations. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A12)

HEADLINE: LEADERS IN ALBANY DRAFTING NEW PLAN ON BUDGET DEFICITS

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and New York State's legislative leaders are considering an unusual multiyear fiscal plan that could remove the state's budget woes from the political spotlight until after the 1992 election.
In talks that began over the weekend in Albany, budget negotiators have been discussing a plan that would simultaneously attack this year's budget gap of $689 million and the gap of more than $2 billion projected in the next fiscal year's budget. They would then draft a grand budget solution that would stretch into 1993, thus spreading the pain, proponents argue, over a longer period. 
 The proponents of the plan argue that it clearly would benefit Mr. Cuomo, who has said the budget problems afflicting the state and New York City pose the primary obstacle to his running for President.
 
An Election Year
 But in an election year in which incumbency could prove a liability, the plan also could prove helpful to members of the Legislature, which has irritated many voters in recent years by repeatedly failing to pass budgets that were balanced and on time. Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, the primary proponent of the plan, suggested today that both the Democrats who control the Assembly and the Republicans who control the State Senate would benefit politically if the public perceives they are making a serious attempt to restructure the state budget.
As outlined by top legislators, legislative aides and Cuomo administration officials, the plan would require selected cuts in state programs and a freeze in spending for most state agencies at this year's levels.
If that freeze persists for at least 15 months, some state officials believe they could eliminate not only the $689 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget but also a gap in next year's budget that is projected to exceed $2 billion and could be far larger.
 
'Helps All of Us'
 "I think," said Mr. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, "it helps the Governor. I think it helps all of us. This lets you do your cutting more fairly. And it gets people out of Albany quickly and helps solve the problem."
The state officials made clear that the concept was embraced far more enthusiastically by the Assembly and by the Democratic Governor than by the Senate Republicans. Senate leaders have said they prefer to close the state's budget gap with stiff cuts in social services.
But aides to Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller said the Democrats were encouraged that the Senate negotiators had not knocked the plan off the bargaining table.
As outlined by officials familiar with this weekend's discussions, the multiyear budget would control state spending either through the end of the next fiscal year on March 31, 1993, or through June 30, 1993, if the fiscal year was changed.
Because of the plan's technical and political complexity, state officials said their ability to structure such a solution was far from certain. In previous years, the Legislature and the Governor have spent months trying to break their annual budget impasse.
Last summer, for instance, the Legislature did not pass a budget until a record 65 days after the start of the fiscal year. It could be particularly difficult for the Legislature to deal with this year's budget gap in a special session in the next two months because Mr. Miller will be on trial in Brooklyn on Federal fraud charges. The trial starts on Tuesday.
 
'A Useful Approach'
 The Governor's press secretary, Anne W. Crowley, confirmed that Mr. Cuomo was interested in the concept of a multiyear budget but said the political and financial feasibility of such a plan remained uncertain.
"It would be a useful approach if we could find a way to do that," she said. "We don't know yet whether we'll be able to, but that's what we're discussing."
Ms. Crowley said that if the negotiations over the multiyear plan broke down, Mr. Cuomo would present a budget-cutting plan to close this year's budget gap and would call the Legislature to Albany for a special session.
 
Preparing Own Plan
 A spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., played down the idea that the Republicans were actively negotiating a plan. "I wouldn't call them earnest discussions," said the spokesman, John E. McArdle. "Have they met a couple of times? Yeah. But that is not the direction we prefer to proceed with."
Mr. McArdle said that the Senate Republicans were preparing their own plan for dealing with this year's budget gap and that it would rely heavily on deep cuts in Medicaid and other social services. He also complained that a multiyear plan would require the state to borrow money.
Mr. Cuomo has identified unexpected growth in Medicaid expenditures and unexpected weakness in revenue collections -- both of which he attributed to the recession -- as the main causes of the budget gap. The Governor and both legislative leaders have said they do not want to close the budget gap by raising taxes in a recession.
 
Political Difficulties
 That the multiyear plan remains on the negotiating table reflects both the severity of the state's budget problems and the political difficulties they pose for Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature.
Mr. Cuomo, in his public comments, has said it would be extremely difficult to run for President while the state and New York City are suffering severe budget problems. Having established that connection, the Governor needs to be able to convince New Yorkers that he has not abandoned the state and city in times of crisis if he chooses to run.
The passage, or even the announcement of an agreement in principle, of a multiyear budget plan might allow Mr. Cuomo to make the case that the state's finances are sound. That would give him more freedom to devote the winter and the spring to the Presidential primaries and not to budget talks with the Legislature.
 
Anti-Incumbent Sentiment
 The Legislature faces its own elections next November, and legislative leaders took full note of the anti-incumbent sentiment registered by voters across the state and the nation in last Tuesday's elections. In local elections from Long Island to Rochester, voters eagerly tossed out incumbents from both parties.
Both Mr. Miller and Mr. Marino have said they want to pass a budget quickly next year so their members can go home to campaign. And in light of last week's election results, both want to give New York voters the sense that the Legislature has taken a bold step to cure the state's recurring fiscal problems.
