HEADLINE: Duke Campaigns on Distorted Facts Despite Rebuttals and Clarifications

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Whether he is rallying his supporters or defending himself on a talk show, State Representative David Duke often twists the statements of others and distorts facts to make his point.
The subjects of his false claims include his record of fighting in Southeast Asia, his criminal record, his positions on the environment, the structure of welfare payments, the potential effect of his election on tourism in Louisiana, and the record of his Democratic opponent, former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards. 
 Also, while continuing to say that his Christian beliefs have led him from the intolerant views he expressed as a leader of the Ku Klux Klan, Mr. Duke has admitted that he underwent this religious conversion as a teen-ager and that as an adult he has not belonged to a church.
Most politicians, Mr. Edwards included, repeat the same stock phrases and examples in their campaign statements and sometimes stretch the truth. But, in his campaign to become governor of Louisiana, Mr. Duke has repeated a variety of blatant misrepresentations even after his opponent,news organizations and the subjects of his statements have publicly tried to clarify the record.
 
Talking Affirmative Action
 An essential element of Mr. Duke's political philosophy is his assertion that affirmative action programs discriminate against white people.
A favorite example of his involves postal jobs. Last week on the CNN television interview program "Larry King Live," Mr. Duke said: "I mean when you take a test for the Post Office in this country right now and you're white, you're very likely to have your test score dropped 15 or 20 points and if you are a minority you are liable to have it raised 15 or 20 points, and I think when you take a test for a job or a promotion or a scholarship you should get what you score on that test. I think that is basic human rights."
Asked whether this assertion was correct, Sandra Stewart, a spokeswoman for the United States Postal Service in Washington, said "absolutely not." No test scores are altered on the basis of race, she said. Veterans receive an extra 5 points on their scores and disabled veterans are given 10 points.
Mr. Duke, who is running as a Republican, continually misrepresents facts about his personal history. For example, in asserting that he would bring a new era free of corruption to the state if elected on Saturday, he says, "I have never broken any laws."
But court records analyzed by the Louisiana Coalition Against Racism and Nazism show that Mr. Duke was arrested and convicted in 1976 for incitement to riot when he led a group of his followers in an assault on a plainclothes police officer who was observing a meeting of neo-Nazi and Klan groups that Mr. Duke had organized.
In 1972 he was arrested twice, one time when the authorities said he was making firebombs and another time when the authorities said he fraudulently solicited money for George Wallace. Those charges were later dropped.
 
Activity in Laos
 Similarly, he often says at campaign rallies that "I fought Communism in Southeast Asia." His campaign biography says specifically that he worked for the State Department in Laos and that he was a volunteer for missions with Air America, the air transport company operated by the Central Intelligence Agency.
An investigation of these assertions in 1990 by The New Orleans Times-Picayune found that in 1971 while Mr. Duke visited his father, who was working for the Agency for International Development in Laos, he taught a State Department English class to Laotian military officers. But the director of the language schools said Mr. Duke was dismissed after six weeks because a drawing of a fire bomb was found on the blackboard in his classroom.
In addition, two Air America pilots in Loas at the time denied Mr. Duke's account of clandestine flights, and Selective Service records cited by the newspaper show that Mr. Duke obtained a student deferment as soon as he was classified 1-A, meaning he could be called immediately for military service.
 
Assertion on Welfare
 Mr. Duke has continued to make misrepresentations despite efforts by his opponents and news organizations point out the facts.
For example, the main theme of his campaign is a call to change "the liberal social welfare system which encourages the rising illegitimate welfare birthrate." He agitates his white audiences with statements like, "middle-class families have difficulty affording children of their own right now and yet we are financing a very high illegitimate welfare birthrate."
He has continued to state this even after Mr. Edwards and several Louisiana newspapers have noted that the average size of a welfare family in the state is three, typically a mother with two children, and that the increased payment for an additional child is $11 a week.
"That's hardly an incentive to have a baby," said Mr. Edwards.
While Mr. Duke asserts that a change in the welfare system would help cure the state's budget crisis, Mr. Edwards and newspaper reports have noted that welfare eligibility standards are set at the Federal level, that the Federal Government pays nearly 75 percent of the costs of Louisiana's welfare program and that state expenditures amount to about 2 percent of the state budget.
 
Meetings Do Move
 In what is developing as a major issue in the governor's race, executives in the tourism and convention industry have protested that Mr. Duke's election would cause the cancellation of meetings and sporting events, a portion of the economy that has accounted for a large part of Louisiana's meager economic growth in the past few years.
Mr. Duke has countered this by repeatedly saying that Arizona was threatened with similar losses when it chose not to make a holiday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday. "There was no net loss of convention business," Mr. Duke said.
Larry Hilliard, vice president of the Phoenix and Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau, said in an interview that from the time that Gov. Evan Mecham rescinded the holiday in January 1987 to this week, "we've had 148 groups cancel meetings, representing 134,000 delegates with an economic impact in excess of $77 million."
In addition to these losses, the owners of National Football League franchises voted last March to remove the 1993 Super Bowl from Phoenix because of a state referendum Nov. 6, 1990, that upheld the decision not to have a King holiday. According to the N.F.L., a Super Bowl generates between $125 to $150 million for a local economy.
Mr. Duke has dealt with the Super Bowl issue, as he did at a news conference last Friday, by saying repeatedly: "Its been said we would loose the Super Bowl if I were elected, but the N.F.L. issued a formal statement that we don't enter politics. We don't care who the governor is. It has nothing to do with our site-selection process."
After Mr. Duke made a similar statement last Monday on "Larry King Live," Greg Aiello, director of communications for the National Football League, told reporters, "We have consistently said the same thing and we have certainly not said what Mr. Duke said that we said."
Mr. Aiello said that Mr. Duke was apparently referring to a response by Paul Tagliabue, commissioner of the National Football League, to reporters who asked about Mr. Duke. Mr. Tagliabue said: "We have not given it any thought. We are in the football business and we are following the Saints in Louisiana not the governor's race."
Mr. Aiello noted that the Phoenix case showed that the football owners, rather than the commissioner, choose Super Bowl sites and do take political issues into account.
Mr. Duke sometimes offers false information when he has other options. For example, Mr. Edwards's record on the environment in his three terms as Governor could easily be attacked for his weak enforcement of pollution laws, but Mr. Duke repeatedly says that "during that time we had the greatest toxic waste dumping of any state in the country."
In fact, Texas has three times as many sites on the Federal National Priorities List of toxic waste sites requiring cleanup. And by several other measures Texas ranked as the leader in dumping.
Mr. Duke then usually goes on, as he did at a rally Friday, to declare: "I'm not going back to that. I'm going to protect our precious environment."
His arguments did not move the New Orleans Sierra Club, which today joined other environmental groups that have already endorsed Mr. Edwards. The club issued a statement saying that contrary to his assertion, Mr. Duke had voted in the Legislature to cut financing for the state Department of Environmental Quality and once referred to the department as a "witch hunting gang of political flunkies."

HEADLINE: Pittsburgh Builds Airport of Future Now

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:
Through a haze of dust stirred up by earth movers, one of the most innovative major aiport terminals in the United States is nearing completion in a clearing twice the size of downtown Pittsburgh. Scheduled to open in October 1992, the collection of new buildings, their centerpiece an unusually designed X-shape, is being counted on to redefine the 39-year-old Greater Pittsburgh International Airport.
Planners hope the terminal, with its vaulted ceilings and driverless underground trains, will complete an image transformation begun decades ago. Once known as a gritty old steel town of blue-collar workers, Pittsburgh has become a commercial center of office towers and high-technology industries. 
 The new airport buildings, known informally as the midfield terminal because of their location between two runways, are also being seen as a way to lift the economy in a region of 2.2 million people.
"This is the single greatest economic generator this area has seen," said Scott Simmons, an economic development specialist for Duquesne Light Company, an area utility.
 
Gamble or Good Investment
 Nonetheless, with the American economy in a lingering slump, the building of an airport terminal in the shadow of an old one, refurbishing runways and putting in a 7.5-mile expressway to tie it all to the region's highways, amounts to a $1 billon gamble.
Supporters of the 900-acre project 16 miles west of Pittsburgh said they view the airport construction and related projects as a prudent investment.
Several other cities, including Denver, Newark and San Jose, Calif., have started or plan to begin airport projects. The plans are being made in spite of projections that the number of American air travelers, flat for the last three years, is not expected to increase soon.
Officials of USAir, the airline that is to use 53 of the new terminal's 76 gates as one of the focal points of its route network, say they do not see their heavy financial commitment as a gamble.
 
Airline at the Limits
 "We are concentrating on it being an opportunity," said David Shipley, a USAir spokesman at the airline's corporate headquarters in Arlington, Va. He agreed that there is a "risk factor" is being a major participant in such a monumental project, but he said the airline wanted to expand in Pittsburgh and was "maxed out in capacity" at the current terminal, in which USAir has 36 gates.
But the new terminal is seen as more than an economic gamble and a symbol of civic pride. It is also an attempt to advance airport efficiency. Unlike those at most airports in the United States, the terminal was designed specifically for jet travel and the rapid movement of passengers.
It is divided into three sections, separating the passengers according to their needs. In one section, called "landside," passengers will be able to buy tickets, check or claim baggage and rent cars. The second, "airside," section, is the X-shaped building, where passengers will be boarding or getting off planes. The third section includes, among other things, a 25-gate commuter terminal and the aiport's only security check-point. The buildings are connected by underground passenger and luggage shuttles.
The X-shaped concourse building is the centerpiece of the new design. Because the building's arms are studded with gates, airliners can reduce their taxiing to pick up or discharge passengers. Airport officials estimate that airlines will be able to save $12 million to $13 million a year in fuel costs.
In planning for more than 20 years and under construction since June 1987, the terminal may be one of the largest current construction sites in the United States.
For Pittsburgh, which long ago had to transform its economy from one almost literally built by steel to one balanced on high-technology industries, corporate offices and service industries, the airport project has come to mean as much to further development and diversification as it does to area aviation.
"This airport meant far more than transportation," said Steven George, director of Penn's Southwest Association, a not-for-profit organization that recruits businesses to the Pittsburgh region. "It means jobs, development, growth."
In a report earlier this year, the Greater Pittsburgh Office of Promotion for the Allegheny County Department of Aviation estimated that more than 81,000 jobs will be created over the next 20 years by the new airport complex.
Already, a number of motels and office buildings have sprung up near the new terminal.
"I think whole new cities will grow up around the airport," said Tom Foerster, chairman of the Allegheny County Board of Commissioners that governs the county in which the airport is situated. Mr. Foerster, who has served as a county commissioner for 24 years, has long supported expanding and improving the airport.
The county will own and operate the airport, but much of the cost of building the new terminal and operating it will be paid by increases in USAir's fees. A 30-year lease binds the airport's economic health to that of the airline.
Ultimately, some increases in fees will be passed on to travelers, said USAir officials.
Allegheny County contributed $42.5 million to the project. It also issued $608.7 million in county bonds, which will be repaid by USAir. The Federal Aviation Administration is contributing another $101 million and the state $85 million.
The $190 million access expressway being built to the airport is a separate project of the Pennsylvania Department of Transportation. In addition, Allegheny County has spent $150 million in the last five years to improve the airport's landing field.
The new terminal includes 3.3 million square feet, which will make it about four times bigger than the present terminal, about two miles away. Although the new terminal will have 76 jet gates initially, it can accommodate about 100 if necessary.
The existing terminal, built in 1952, has 54 gates, and has been expanded four times. "We were just unable to add onto it anymore," Patrick J. Boyle, deputy director of marketing and public affairs for the County of Allegheny Department of Aviation.
Joseph Schofer, a professor of civil engineering and transportation at Northwestern University's Transportation Center in Evanston, Ill., said making airports faster and more efficient makes sense, particularly in anticipation of an economic upturn. "Better than half of air travel in the U.S. is for business purposes," he noted.

HEADLINE: Veto of California Job-Bias Bill Unites Gay-Rights Forces Against Governor

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11

 BODY:
For most of his adult life, Scott Greig has been building his career and, though homosexual, seldom paid much attention to the gay-rights movement. A Republican, he voted last year for Pete Wilson for Governor, seeing him as a moderate Republican who was sympathetic to gay people.
But these days Mr. Greig, a 30-year-old executive with a computer manufacturer here, regularly marches in demonstrations denouncing Mr. Wilson and has joined forces determined to hound the Governor at every turn and to drive him from office. 
 The main instrument of Mr. Greig's conversion was Governor Wilson's veto of a bill that would have protected homosexuals against job discrimination in California. Six weeks after Mr. Wilson vetoed the bill, which he said was too burdensome for small businesses, the gay-rights movement appears to have been galvanized in a way that has not happened in years, drawing a large number of professional and white-collar protesters like Mr. Greig into the fray. After nearly a decade of preoccupation with AIDS, the focus is shifting back to equal rights.
 
'They Become Equal'
 "For years, the civil rights issue had been overshadowed by AIDS," said Valsin A. Marmillion, a political consultant here who is a co-founder of a fast-growing new gay organization, League America, that is attracting large numbers of people who were uncomfortable with more radical groups like Queer Nation. "Now they become equal, or civil rights predominant."
The issue has compounded Governor Wilson's growing troubles. Having already alienated conservatives with recent tax increases, he has now also offended many liberals because of this veto and other recent actions. Political experts, Democratic and Republican alike, are beginning to doubt that Mr. Wilson, once spoken of in some circles as a Presidential contender in 1996, can win re-election as Governor.
Leaders of national gay rights groups say that the anger that began in California and has been widely reported in publications written for homosexuals has begun to spread across the country. Urvashi Vaid, executive director of the Washington-based National Gay and Lesbian Task Force,said the anger recalled that following the assassination in 1978 of Harvey Milk the gay San Francisco supervisor, by a jealous political rival. and a
And she compared the mood to that surrounding the 1969 confrontation with police officers outside The Stonewall Inn, a tavern in Greenwich Village, an event that spurred the current gay-rights movement. "People are calling it Stonewall II," she said.
Torie Osborn, executive director of the Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Community Services Center, said, "The last time I felt this kind of energy was in the 70's."
A demonstration is planned at a fund-raising dinner here on Friday for state Senator Ed Davis that Mr. Wilson plans to attend. And an effort begun by state employees to recall the Governor has been joined by gay groups.
It remains to be seen how long the protests will last, but for now Mr. Wilson has found himself involved in a confrontation almost everywhere he has ventured since the Sept. 29 veto. The night after, protesters did $250,000 of damage at a state office building in San Francisco. The next day, protesters rushed a stage at Stanford University where Mr. Wilson was speaking. That same day, also at Stanford, he found himself at a luncheon sitting near Tom Nolan, President of the San Mateo County Board of Supervisors, who is gay. "I told him he was wrong," Mr. Nolan said.
The gay protests have taken other forms as well. Michael Moore, a furniture designer and interior decorator in San Francisco demanded that his $2,000 campaign contribution be returned. Mr. Moore, who describes himself as an "old-school Republican," said he had heard Mr. Wilson promise to sign such a bill in a number of fund-raising events. When his request was rejected, he threatened to sue for "breach of promise," and received a check from the campaign committee.
"He will be hounded by gay people wherever he goes for the rest of his political life," said Thomas B. Stoddard, of the Lambda Legal Defense and Educational Fund, a gay legal advocacy group in New York.
The measure, designated as Assembly Bill 101 and sponsored by Assemblyman Terry B. Friedman, a Democrat from Los Angeles, would have prohibited job discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation under the state's Fair Employment and Housing Act. Governor Wilson had given strong indications that he would sign it. In his veto message, Mr. Wilson denounced "gay-bashing bigots" but said the bill was unnecessary because existing laws, policies and court opinions conferred many of the same protections.
Many experts said that an underlying reason for the veto was to protect the Governor's ally, Senator John Seymour, against a challenge next year from Representative William Dannemayer, a conservative Orange County Republican who is a dogged foe of gay rights. They said the veto also was intended to shore up Mr. Wilson's flagging support among Republicans.
The merits of the bill have been lost in the symbolism the veto has acquired for homosexuals. What has been particularly unusual about the protests is that they are coming mainly from the Los Angeles area, rather than from San Francisco, the traditional focus of gay politics on the West Coast.
 
Change in Los Angeles
 "What's amazing is to have it in Los Angeles," said Randy Shilts, national correspondent for The San Francisco Chronicle. "They'd usually rather have a cappuccino than go to a riot."
Over the last decade, the AIDS epidemic diverted most of the attention among gay groups away from politics, and the traditional leadership was depleted. In the last two or three years, a new, more radical movement has been building, embodied in such organizations as Queer Nation and Act Up, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power. But according to Mr. Shilts, these groups had limited appeal to the vast majority of gay men and women who were more interested in earning a living.
The Wilson veto, with its implications for job security in fragile economic times, observers say, served to politicize the non-political.
But some fear that the protests, and particularly television images of violent ones, will backfire, and they have already strained relations between gay leaders and Assemblyman Friedman. "The demonstrations have led to a backlash from the majority of Californians who previously supported the bill," said Mr. Friedman, the bill's sponsor. "Though I understand the frustration, it is most important to channel it in an effective way that can lead to a law."
As for Mr. Wilson, his chief spokesman, Bill Livingstone, said Mr. Wilson would veto a similar bill if passed by the legislature next year. He added that Mr. Wilson had backed gay causes while in the Senate but that the Governor had felt that there was no evidence that gay people suffer from "long-term pervasive discrimination" in the workplace.
For many, the issue is Mr. Wilson'sleadership and credibility. "He angered all the gays, and all the right wing by calling them bigots," said David Townsend, a Democratic political consultant in Sacramento. "He's really acting like a one-termer right now. He seems to be under siege."

HEADLINE: Erbil Journal;
B-o-o-m! It's Bush's Message and Sweet to Kurds

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ERBIL, Iraq

 BODY:
President Bush woke up this Kurdish capital at 4:30 A.M. one day recently with a sonic boom from a United States Air Force jet that shattered glass and startled the residents. But it was difficult to find a Kurd who was angry about it.
"In spite of all the broken windows, we would like them to come even more," said a 60-year-old Kurdish elder, who smiled and offered his hand and a blessing to a visiting reporter instead of giving his name. 
 "Hajji Bush," one of Kurdistan's terms of endearment for the American President, can be heard in the murmur of the city market crowd as a distant, dull roar heralds another flight of American warplanes.
"Here comes the taxi" is another common refrain as Kurds look skyward several times a day to follow the passage of the silver streaks of American air power.
 
Deterrent Against Army
 In the state of a precarious peace with Baghdad, Iraq's Kurdish minority is clinging to the visible deterrent these warplanes represent against any threat of repression from the still formidable remnants of President Saddam Hussein's army, part of which is encamped south of the city.
For the first time since Mr. Hussein and his Baath Party came to power in 1968, the Kurds have been living, for months now, without the omnipresence of Baghdad's security forces and secret police. Many say they have become used to it.
"We will never agree to the return of the regime of Saddam Hussein," said a young Kurdish guerrilla named Ali, his chest crossed with ammunition belts.
In Erbil recently, there was a wedding party on every vacant lot in some neighborhoods. Hundreds of Kurds locked arms in a circle of song and dance as the sun glinted off the bright sequined gowns of the women.
In the countryside, where the valleys are wearing the golden stubble of the harvested wheatfields and the sunflower crop is drooping from the first frost, the Kurds are busy rebuilding earthen-roofed homes before winter. About 135,000 still have refugee status, with many living in tents.
 
The Gunships Have Gone
 What is different this year, however, is the absence of the Iraqi helicopter gunships that since 1988 had prowled the slopes and valleys of the Iranian and Turkish border regions searching for infiltrations by Kurdish guerrillas, smugglers and refugees.
As a consequence, tens of thousands of Kurds are moving back to what remains of the villages destroyed by Mr. Hussein in his attempts in 1975 and 1988 to collectivize the Kurds in new towns on the arid and dusty flatlands of Kurdistan.
Though the exhaustion of war and insurrection continues to combine with the economic pressure of the international trade embargo, which is hurting every Iraqi household, a measure of joy is not hard to find among the Kurds today.
"The people are suffering in a very happy way because they haven't had this experience in 23 years," the Kurdish elder said. "They are experiencing freedom and the absence of the regime of Saddam Hussein."
How long this absence will continue is the unknown that provides much of the political anxiety that exists here.
The deterrent value of the "Hajji Bush" flights underscores the delicate balance that exists eight months after the allied coalition defeated the Iraqi Army in Kuwait, a defeat that touched off insurrection and a harsh crackdown by Mr. Hussein's army.
As they wait for the conclusion of negotiations with Baghdad over the future of Kurdish autonomy, talks carried out by Massoud Barzani, chief of the Kurdish Democratic Party, Iraq's 3.5 million Kurds have taken responsibility for their own survival. An army of "pesh mergas," the guerrilla fighters of Kurdistan who sign contracts to "walk before death" in the name of Kurdish self-rule, is now administering most major cities in the region.
Kurds now control their traditional lands throughout the mountainous border region, from the disputed city of Khanaqin less than 100 miles northeast of Baghdad in an arc that goes north along the Iranian border and westward along the Turkish border all the way to the disputed city of Sinjar near the Syrian frontier.
The Iraqi Army has generally fallen back to protect major Arab cities like Mosul and the oil center at Kirkuk, whose status is a major point of contention. Mr. Hussein has been preventing thousands of Kurds who fled Kirkuk during the March uprising from returning to their homes.
 
Army Abandons Positions
 Iraqi tank and infantry brigades could be observed recently abandoning their dug-in positions east of Erbil and on the northern and eastern approaches to Sulaimaniya, apparently in an effort to cede additional Kurdish territory to the administration of the pesh mergas.
Kurdish leaders say they are trying to work in close cooperation with the army to maintain the peace in Kurdistan and to prevent the kind of outbreak of fighting that began in October in the disputed towns of Kifri and Kalar and then spread to Sulaimaniya, where Kurdish forces captured and executed 60 Government soldiers.
Abdul Mohaiman Barzani, a Kurdish leader and a cousin of Massoud Barzani, says his most pressing problem now is the wheat crop, which must be planted before the snows come. There is a desperate shortage of spare parts for tractors and other machinery needed for planting.
"If we don't plant the wheat this month," he said, "this will not only be the biggest problem in Kurdistan, but in all of Iraq."

A Kurdish clan in Dohuk arrived recently for a meeting with Mr. Barzani on the negotiations. (Patrick E. Tyler/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Its Eye on Election, White House To Propose Health Care Changes

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Bush Administration officials say Senator Harris Wofford's victory in Pennsylvania will force them to propose significant changes in the health care system sooner than they intended, but they insist that the election results last week cannot be read as an endorsement for any specific proposal, and many Democrats agree.
Thus, Mr. Wofford's success guarantees an impassioned debate on health policy by candidates for President and Congress in 1992, but it does not necessarily mean that successful candidates must follow him in advocating a comprehensive program of national health insurance with a major new role for the Federal Government. 
 Mr. Wofford, a Democrat, trounced former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh in the election last Tuesday after making a demand for national health insurance a centerpiece of his campaign.
The Administration has stepped up its deliberations on health care in an effort to respond to Democratic accusations that President Bush neglected the issue for three years.
 
Issue for '92 Election
 White House officials had expected that Mr. Bush would sidestep the issue next year, on the assumption that Congress would not take up comprehensive health care legislation until after the 1992 elections. But Administration officials now say that for political reasons they must have more to say about the issue before then.
While attending a NATO meeting in Rome on Friday, Mr. Bush said he would "like to have a comprehensive health care plan that I can vigorously take to the American people" before the 1992 election.
The problems are well known. The United States spends $2 billion a day on health care, far more for each person than any other country, yet 34 million Americans have no health insurance.
"More and more, health care is a voter issue, up there with crime and education," said Alixe R. Glen, spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services.
In January 1990, Mr. Bush said in his State of the Union Message that Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, would lead a review of how to improve access to health care while restraining its cost.
"I am committed to bring the staggering costs of health care under control," Mr. Bush said. Since then, health care prices have shot up 15 percent, while the Consumer Price Index for all items has increased 7.7 percent.
Dr. Sullivan's long-delayed study has now been virtually completed, but it has not been formally sent to President Bush, apparently because no one at the White House has requested it. But White House officials are generally aware of its contents because they participated in the review.
Dr. Sullivan rejects the idea that the United States should emulate Canada by offering health insurance to everyone through a Government-financed program. Rather, as he has said in speeches and Congressional testimony, he favors state experiments to test new ways of delivering health care; changes in the ways people live to foster better health; legislation to make health insurance more available to small businesses, and new restrictions on the award of damages in malpractice lawsuits.
Administration officials say Dr. Sullivan's package is significant. But it is not nearly enough to satisfy Democratic lawmakers or medical economists who have shaped the debate on this issue for more than a decade.
Rather than propose any grand, sweeping plan, Administration officials say, President Bush would attack Democrats on the ground that their proposals would lead to Government price controls, the rationing of health care, a deterioration in the quality of care and an increase in taxes.
 
'At Pentagon Prices'
 Constance Horner, who studied the issue as Deputy Secretary of Health and Human Services from May 1989 to September of this year, came up with one of the Republicans' favorite lines. A program of national health insurance run by the Federal Government, she has warned, would have "all the compassion of the Internal Revenue Service and the efficiency of the Postal Service, at Pentagon prices."
Dozens of Democrats in Congress, like Representatives Marty Russo of Illinois and Pete Stark of California, say Mr. Wofford's victory shows that voters want national health insurance, and they predict that his success will embolden other candidates to exploit the issue.
Another signal came from a ballot question in New Jersey, where voters were asked if Congress should enact "a national health care program" covering everyone, with "minimal out-of-pocket expense to taxpayers." Of the 1.4 million voters answering that ballot question, 78 percent said yes. The question said nothing about how the program would be financed.
Mr. Wofford himself says the Pennsylvania result was not necessarily an endorsement of any specific health care proposal. "The vote of Pennsylvania was not for my plan, but it was for action," he said. "It was for action now."
Edward H. Lazarus, a Democratic poll taker who conducted surveys in Pennsylvania after the election, agreed, saying, "Voters want to see action on health care, but they don't know what action they want."

HEADLINE: Belt-Tightening Crimps Westport Dining

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 10

 BODY:
There is no Indelicato's now, no old-fashioned spaghetti house like the one in the 1964 novel "Reuben, Reuben," where working-class locals and New York commuters uneasily encountered each other at tables topped with red-and-white checked tablecloths in a Westport that was disguised as the town of Woodsmoke.
These days, the commuters are the locals, and places like Indelicato's and the coffee shops that once represented the range of restaurants in bedroom communities were long ago overwhelmed here by Francine's and Pancho Villa's, Onion Alley and Soup's On, the Pompano Grill and Panda Pavilion. There are more than 60 restaurants in Westport, making this wealthy town of 24,000 -- the home of celebrities, artists, advertising executives and writers -- the dining capital of Fairfield County and the restaurants themselves one of its largest industries.
 
Feeling the Tax Bite
 But not all is well. Just as restaurateurs from midtown Manhattan to Southampton, L.I., have found that people are staying home -- and eating less when they do dine out -- those in Westport have seen the region's recession enter their dining rooms. The always-sharp competition has become sharper, especially since the state's first income tax kicked in last month, and the gulf between the winners and the hangers-on has widened. 
 For the customers, as always, bad times are a good time to have money to spend. But many restaurants are being reminded that there are other ways to spend it.
"The video stores are all busy, and that's because people are getting a video and going home," said Sean Coughlin, who has owned the Mooring, overlooking the Saugatuck River on Riverside Avenue, for 15 years. "Everybody thought Westport was a rich town and everybody had money, but one of the first things people cut out was this business."
Riverside Avenue, which runs along the Saugatuck River for a mile and a half from Boston Post Road to the train station in Saugatuck, has 9 restaurants -- until recently, 10 -- ranging from the Hot Dog Stand to Da Pietro's, one of the most highly rated, and expensive, in Connecticut.
Some, like the Mooring, have made adjustments to bolster business. After a good summer, Mr. Coughlin has gone into his off-season with early-bird specials, dinner specials and a lighter menu that lets people eat more quickly and cheaply. "Westport has always been a very competitive town," he said. "The good restaurants are buckling down and doing what they have to do to ride it out."
 
Some Are Always Busy
 Others, like David DeRosa, the owner of noisy, always crowded De Rosa's, near the station, still have people waiting outside. He has also started a delivery service to meet a growing demand for takeout orders. And while he still gets business customers, he says they are changing the way they do business. "I do notice they're cutting back," he said. "We have more companies calling and asking for detailed checks for their employees' expense accounts."
If signs of stress are not obvious at Mr. DeRosa's doorstep, they are evident just across the street, where Tang's Westport, a Chinese restaurant, closed in September.
Jean Cronin, assistant vice president of the Connecticut Restaurants Association, said many restaurants did not start feeling pinched until spring or summer. Things got worse in October, when the state's income tax took effect.
Pietro Scotti, the owner and chef of Da Pietro's, a northern Italian and French restaurant near Boston Post Road, blames the income tax for a 15 percent drop in his weekday business.
Da Pietro's is still jammed on weekends, but the regulars who make up a large part of its business show how Westport's restaurants are tied to the entire region's economy. They come from as far as New Haven and New York, but ever since he opened in 1988, Mr. Scotti said, "very, very little from Westport."
At the Mooring, Mr. Coughlin said he had heard plenty about the income tax as he walked through his dining room. "A lot of them say they don't have to live here, and they can move out," he said.
He has no illusions that Westport, by itself, supports 60 restaurants. He lists where people come from -- Stamford, Wilton, Orange, the Naugatuck Valley -- and then the corporations that are leaving or cutting back: United Parcel Service in Greenwich, Richardson-Vicks in Shelton, Norden Systems in Norwalk, Saab Cars USA in Orange.
The people most hurt by the changing business are the waiters and waitresses, who serve fewer, less expensive dinners. "Waiters are working twice as many shifts to make the same money," said Laura Tamburo, the manager at Porky Manero's.
Adding insult is the one bit of good news for most Connecticut residents: the recent reduction in the sales tax to 6 percent, from 8 percent. For diners accustomed to doubling the tax on their bill to figure their tip, it suddenly adds up to a 12 percent tip, instead of 16 percent.

HEADLINE: Charting a Poor Community's Future

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
There are business people and homeowners, a nurse and a police officer, people who live on Social Security and the president of Hartford's Board of Education. There is the owner of a body repair shop, who is also coach and mentor to the 360 teen-agers of the Martin Luther King Soccer League.
Together they are charting an ambitious plan to restore one of Hartford's poorest neighborhoods, Upper Albany, and improve life for the 10,000 people who live there. 
 And standing behind the 17 members of the Upper Albany Neighborhood Collaborative is the Ford Foundation and its long history of involvement in urban renewal, including its support in 1967 for the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation in Brooklyn, the country's first community development with private and public funds.
"What makes Upper Albany exciting is we're addressing a community in its entirety, not piecemeal," said Franklin A. Thomas, Ford's president, who once headed the Brooklyn renewal project. "We're building on Bed-Stuy roots, but doing it better." Ford is also financing neighborhood collaborations in Detroit, Memphis and Milwaukee in the hope that the four will create models that will have national impact.
 
A Choice for Residents
 So far, the Upper Albany Collaborative, which began operating 13 months ago, has no visible improvements to show off. But that does not trouble Ford officials or the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving, which was delegated by Ford to assist the Collaborative. The Hartford philanthropy banks the Collaborative's funds but clearly, it's the neighborhood members who lead.
"If there already was a grand plan, I would be worried because it would mean we were doing what always has been done in the past -- telling the community what's good for it without giving its residents a choice," said Alan E. Green, assistant director at the Hartford Foundation. "Choice is what is important. We have an opportunity here in Hartford that may not come again."
Mr. Green, 45 years old, grew up in Upper Albany, and as a youth delivered newspapers along the tree-lined residential streets, which still have handsome Victorian-era homes that are on the Federal Register of Historic Places. But there are also stretches of empty factories and vacant stores where the jobless congregate and drugs are sold.
In giving Upper Albany $1.1 million and pledging "multimillions more" in coming years, Ford stipulated that the renewal must be comprehensive, addressing an array of social and economic concerns. Ford also insisted that the collaborative be run by a diverse mix of people from the neighborhood. According to the 1980 census, 81 percent of the people in Upper Albany are black while another 15 percent are Hispanic.
Still, one Collaborative member, Esther Bush, director of the Urban League of Greater Hartford, maintains the board is overly middle-aged and wants to add younger people, maybe a gang member or a youth who kicked a drug habit.
 
Weighing Goals and Concerns
 The collaborative, after many weeks of weighing goals and the concerns of residents, agreed to focus initially on education, employment, homeownership and economic development. The board moved slowly, acknowledged Ralph Knighton, its chairman. "Some members did not have an in-depth understanding of poverty," he said. "It takes time to expose them."
Even so, deciding priorities has not been easy in a neighborhood where crime is high, schools are crowded and joblessness is widespread. At least 38 percent of the households receive public assistance and 73 percent are headed by a single parent.
But the neighborhood also has its assets like access to Keney Park, at 693 acres one of the largest recreation areas in New England. It also has a commercial strip and an active merchants' association with more than 160 members and bus lines that carry thousands of commuters to jobs downtown. The Artists Collective, a multi-arts cultural organization, is moving into the neighborhood.
Some people look at the Upper Albany factories, now shuttered, and envision them transformed into housing or into marketplaces for vendors who now sell their wares on the street.
So far, the Collaborative has operated without voting, whittling away at disagreements until the dissenting members were willing to say "I can live with that." The phrase became the board's slogan, and the members have had it printed on T-shirts.
Few of the members were acquainted before they were brought together by the Hartford Foundation with the help of a researcher, Gerald Waite, who grew up in the neighborhood and who canvassed the 21-block area to prepare a profile of the neighborhood.
The members, who serve without pay, meet at least twice monthly. Many ideas have been floated: some members would like to see a loan fund developed to help promote homeownership. Others are concerned that the community is not getting enough help to keep its streets clean and safe. And some would like to see residents compile report cards on city services as a way of keeping up pressure on government.
Inevitably, the Collaborative's first year has been used mainly to build trust and confidence among its members, said Prof. Harold A. Richman, a social-welfare analyst from the University of Chicago who will evaluate the projects in Hartford and the other three cities.
"They must develop a sense that working together, they can accomplish changes," he said, "but the test of concrete achievments is still ahead."

HEADLINE: Bishop H. Donegan, Episcopal Leader, Dies at 91

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan, the Episcopal Bishop of New York from 1950 until 1972 and an early church advocate for the rights of blacks, women and the poor, died yesterday at his home in Sanibel, Fla. He was 91 years old.
His longtime chaplain, the Rev. Geoffrey R. M. Skrinar, said the Bishop died of cancer of the throat. 
 Bishop Donegan, in his 22 years as spiritual leader of the New York diocese, transformed its social conciousness. A slender courtly man with cool blue eyes, he took a diocese with some of the most patrician families in the country and focused its attention on the needs of the growing ranks of the poor.
A landmark in that journey was his announcement in 1967 that money that had accumulated to finish the construction of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on Amsterdam Avenue at West 112th Street, would instead be given toward housing and development projects in nearby Harlem.
 
'Broken and Incomplete'
 The structure, seat of a diocese that embraces Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island and seven counties north of the city, is the world's largest Gothic-style cathedral. Its construction began in 1892.
"This unfinished cathedral, towering as it does over this great and suffering metropolis, shall be the prophetic symbol that our society is still as rough-hewn, ragged, broken and incomplete as the building itself," he said.
The halt in construction continued for a time under his successor, Bishop Paul Moore Jr., a lanky activist with a more forceful public style who intensified the diocese's involvement in several social causes. Work on the cathedral resumed in 1973.
Bishop Donegan had worked to expand the role of women in his church. In 1956, he approved their election as wardens, vestry members and delegates to the national conventions.
 
Ordained Women as Deacons
 In 1971, after the national church permitted it, he ordained two women, Carol Anderson and Julia Sibley, as deacons. The Episcopal Church has since decided to ordain women as priests and bishops.
"He bridged the gap between World War II and the tumult of the 1960's," Mr. Skrinar said.
Bishop Donegan lived quietly in the bishop's residence on the cathedral grounds or other church homes. He enjoyed reading biographies, listening to Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, swimming, painting landscapes and playing an occasional game of golf.
After his retirement as bishop, he joined the staff of St. James Church on Madison Avenue at 71st Street, where he had once been rector. He took up the duties of a parish pastor, though in lighter fashion, preaching occasionally and assisting at communion.
 
Honored by Queen Elizabeth
 The retirement included long summers in England, where he was born Horace William Baden Donegan in Derbyshire on May 17, 1900. In 1957, Queen Elizabeth II named him an honorary commander of the Order of the British Empire.
His family left England when he was 10. He lived in Toledo, Ohio, and did his undergraduate work at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., when it was known as St. Stephen's College, and later at Oxford. Mr. Donegan received his divinity degree from the Episcopal Theological Seminary in Cambridge, Mass., in 1927 and became a priest in 1928.
After serving as rector of Christ Church in Baltimore from 1929 to 1933, he became the rector of St. James, which has one of New York City's most prominent congregations.
After 14 years at St. James and several appointments in national church posts, in 1947 he was elected Suffragan Bishop of New York, the second highest post in the diocese. On the retirement of Bishop Charles K. Gilbert in 1950, Bishop Donegan was enthroned as the 12th Bishop of the diocese.
 
'Evil Days' for the City
 Presiding at a church situated on the edge of an area of poor black and Hispanic people, he quickly began speaking out on the need for equality of opportunity. In 1953, he denounced conditions in schools and housing and high incidence of crime and urged different faiths to pool resources to alleviate "the evil days" the city had fallen on.
The church may have to "sacrifice much that is time-honored" to minister effectively in a city whose racial and economic patterns were changing, he said in 1954.
In 1957, he announced a $5 million program for building new churches in poorer areas of Manhattan and the Bronx, saying New York City was "the most strategic missionary opportunity that faces the church."
In his genteel way, he crusaded for civil rights within his church as well. He chastised the Church Club, a prominent organization of Episcopal laymen, for failing to admit black members, declaring that in the Episcopal Church "there is no room for prejudice."
 
'Sins of Segregation'
 In a pastoral letter in 1956, he asked the diocese's churches to acknowledge "our own sins of segregation in our own community." He chose to read the letter in one of the city's most fashionable churches, St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue at 51st Street.
His forthrightness had its costs. At a special service marking his 15th year as Bishop, he observed that his civil rights stances had resulted in the withdrawal of substantial gifts pledged for completion of the cathedral.
"I am faced with the fact," he said, "that one reason it is unfinished is because I, as Bishop of New York, have taken certain positions which I had to do as your Bishop."
Outspoken on other causes as well, Bishop Donegan condemned the "un-American tactics" of the Congressional investigations led by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and deplored efforts to introduce religion into the public schools. In a pluralistic society, he said, the public schools should not be a vehicle for teaching "a religiously grounded ethic."
 
Drew Line at Draft Refusers
 Shortly before Christmas 1955, the Bishop sponsored an apartment near the cathedral for a family of four refugees from Germany, and he later helped the husband find a job.
During John F. Kennedy's campaign for President in 1960, the Bishop told churchgoers that Mr. Kennedy's Roman Catholic religion should not be an issue. In the same address, he assailed the South African policy of apartheid as "morally unsupportable, spiritually unpardonable and shamefully tragic in its consequences."
There were, however, nuances to his liberalism. During the Vietnam War, in a 1965 address to the Patriotic Societies of New York, he said he could not understand young men's refusal to serve their country, even as conscientious objectors.
"Were it in my power," he said, "I would fine every person who did not vote, and reward doubly everyone who enlisted in the service of our country, whether as an Episcopalian in the armed forces or as Quaker in the courageous group who will carry the wounded off the field of battle."
The Bishop is survived by two nephews and a niece.
A Liturgy of the Resurrection will be at 10 A.M. Saturday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The body will lie in the cathedral Thursday from 4 P.M. to 8 P.M. and Friday from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
One Woman's Quiet Battle Against Child Abuse

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: LEVITTOWN, N.Y.

 BODY:
TUCKED in among all the junk mail dumped at her house here the other day, Norma Lemily got a letter with neat but unfamiliar feminine handwriting. The postmark was from Maine, of all places. "Dear Norma," it began, "you may not remember me."
It went on to recount some problems the woman had experienced with her young children. Now, they are in high school, the woman reported, and she regularly receives compliments on their behavior. "I can't hear those compliments," the woman wrote, "without thinking of you." 
 Mrs. Lemily stuck the salmon-colored card into a small file. Such appreciative notes are the total wages she receives as a volunteer counselor in the silent guerrilla war against one of society's secret sins: child abuse. Hundreds of such dedicated but unsung volunteers toil in the metropolitan area and beyond. Some work for church or social agencies. Others, like Mrs. Lemily, work for Parents Anonymous, a California-based organization whose nationwide phone line, (800) 421-0353, steers troubled parents into more than 1,100 local group-therapy sessions where everyone has problems but no one has a last name.
Most Monday nights for the last 11 years, the 63-year-old Mrs. Lemily has left her own grown family and comfortable home to spend two hours in some borrowed conference room or church basement listening to terrifying tales of physical and emotional abuse of children by parents of all economic classes. Members of the small self-help groups are referred by themselves. They attend one time or scores of times. Typically, they are silent at first. Most are mothers, who know what they do is wrong but seem unable to unlock such destructive behavior.
Enrollment is easy but scary. Since child abuse is such a social taboo, there are few safe forums where abusive parents can vent feelings, find out they are not alone and learn better ways of being a parent.
"So often over the years," says Mrs. Lemily, "I find myself swallowing shock." There are tales of slaps or punches thrown at youngsters, often repeatedly. Emotionally destructive are details of tiny tortures inflicted, praise withheld for earnest effort, needless criticisms, epithets tossed. "You are so stupid!" many say so often the youngsters come to believe it -- and to pass it on to the next generation. The children also learn what behavior ignites the abuse, which can seem better than no parental attention, especially when it's often followed by remorseful hugs.
"You're told you're stupid by your parents," says Mrs. Lemily, "so you're attracted to a man who says the same thing. It's perversely comfortable. Then your child regularly spills his juice. And out comes all that anger."
In families of several children, one typically attracts parental lightning, such as the 5-year-old whose mother made him eat apart from the family. Mrs. Lemily might well expect her counseling successors (or possibly the police) to see that youngster in trouble sometime down the road. She might also expect to see the boy's siblings, who swallowed with their dinners a powerful dose of guilt for not trying to protect him from such injustice over the years.
Given that there are no skills tests to earn the right to parenthood, Mrs. Lemily contents herself with cleaning up corners of the inevitable mess. She likens her job to that of a surgeon who wastes little time lecturing a writhing patient on healthier living habits. "I tell them that what they did was terrible, but they are not terrible people. They've heard enough of that for years."
"You were never judgmental," wrote the Maine woman.
Which, if you think about it -- and Mrs. Lemily would be delighted if you did -- is precisely the sort of behavior she is trying to instill in parents.
This all comes, of course, with rewards and costs. Mrs. Lemily's three children quickly became sensitive to not pursuing the identity of the many distressed telephone callers. "At first," adds Mrs. Lemily's husband Tom, a lawyer, "she'd come home and have to talk, talk, talk to let off steam. I'm Irish. I'd just blow up if I heard all that. But she's from Canada, so it was harder for her."
There are times now when Mrs. Lemily's mind starts to glaze at the 800th parental account of inexplicable anger. But she reminds herself that although she will never see them, each case involves vulnerable children. "The permutations and combinations of human behavior are infinite and fascinating," she says. "The work, even the midnight calls, lets me feel like part of a solution."
Parents come and go in the group with no formal graduation. And stress seems worse in these tough times. But occasionally another handwritten missive arrives from a parent saying, with amazement, how much the children have changed since the parent entered the group.
That's when Mrs. Lemily smiles.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

Designers' Credos
It was a week for fashion manifestos, some of them pips, some of them squeaks. 
 "I believe in intentional chic," wrote Christian Francis Roth in the program for his show last Tuesday. "I hope this doesn't sound sexist, but as a man, the most attractive woman for me is the one who looks really polished . . . totally 'done.' "
Donna Karan appeared on the runway to introduce a recession rap song:
"Accentuate the positive. Eliminate the negative. Latch on to the affirmative. Don't mess with nothin' in between. To illustrate what I say, picture petticoats, a hot new bustier."
Oddly enough, a substantial part of Ms. Karan's collection was gray.
Mary McFadden's program included some wispy prose about "the turgid dream world of Beaudelaire" and "Gaughin." Atmospheric but iffy in the spelling department.
Liza Bruce's manifesto included three cards with the headings "Liberte," Egalite," "Modernite." (What about Maternite?) "She believes that women now have the opportunity to make radical changes in the way they dress," her statement read. "This is not to say that Liza is a feminist or that she espouses feminist dogma." Heaven forbid.
Isaac Mizrahi did not present any overall written statement, but his program was peppered with witty gems to introduce each series of styles: "FTD" for a group of dramatic floral dresses and coats, "Rattlers" for Western-inspired long black dresses.
"High Heels in the Park" was one splendidly evocative phrase. Can't you just see the clothes?
 
Marc Jacobs's Attitude
 The Perry Ellis showroom was hopping a day after Marc Jacobs's rousing spring show last week.
Faxes were already pouring in from magazine editors who wanted to borrow clothes, for layouts or dancing. Buyers from Bergdorf Goodman indicated that they were upping their order over last spring's, a positive sign in today's retail climate. Executives from R. H. Macy said they wanted to take the collection to their I. Magnin store in Beverly Hills for an encore show.
This would be appropriate, since most of the clothes were inspired by Los Angeles. They included wild Technicolor ball skirts with cabana scenes from the Beverly Hills Hotel, cacti and Oscars, all hand-painted by Bill Beilke and Sissi Siska, from sketches by Mr. Jacobs. (The skirts will be available by special order only, at about $7,000.)
The key to this collection's success was attitude.
"For several seasons, I'd been worrying about the needs of the market," Mr. Jacobs said. "But business in general has been so bad, I decided to just let go and have fun."
 
Waterproof Leather
 Timberland has come up with what it calls the first waterproof leather apparel collection: field jackets, bombers and leather pants, for men and women.
Timberland developed the first guaranteed waterproof leather work boot about 20 years ago, according to Jeanne Wallace, a spokeswoman for the company in Hampton, N.H. Most waterproofing agents are sprayed on after the clothes have been made.
The new line, made of nubuck leather, which resembles buckskin, was treated during the tanning process with a special agent developed by Timberland and the 3M Company.
The clothes, which cost from $500 to $1,060, are sold in the Timberland store at 709 Madison (63d Street).
 
Young Men and Macy's
 Macy's Herald Square is opening a new 30,000-square-foot selling floor on Sunday to showcase clothes targeted toward young, fashionable men. Among the labels are Cavaricci, Marithe and Francois Girbaud, Guess, Boy London and Cross Colours.
"It's a brand new space within the store," said Steven Kornajcik, senior vice president of sales promotion for Macy's Northeast. The area, on the balcony, was used for offices.
On the street, on movie screens, on MTV, it seems that today's fashion leaders are young urban men.
"It's a trendy market that moves quickly," Mr. Kornajcik said. "It's related to music and life style."

HEADLINE: Argentina Films a French Classic

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11

 BODY:
It is enough of a risk anywhere to try to create a popular movie out of a monumental work of literature. But to attempt it in this country with its history of hyperinflation, social turmoil, horrible telephone system and military uprisings would seem to guarantee disaster.
Yet three small production companies, from the United States, France and Argentina, have persuaded William Hurt, Raul Julia and Robert Duvall to team up with this country's most celebrated director, Luis Puenzo ("The Official Story"), to create a screen version of "The Plague," by Albert Camus. Since early August, this polyglot production has been working 6 days a week, 14 hours a day in the Bohemian section of La Boca, the quaint 19th-century Plaza Dorrego and the elegant residential neighborhood Palermo Chico, to transform Mr. Puenzo's script into a movie.
 
Hope for Future Films
 With a budget of $14 million, the project is small by world standards but large for Argentina, and possibly significant to the country's future as a center for filming. 
 "If we can come in on time, on budget, we can put Argentina on the map as a place for the international movie industry," said Oscar Kramer, the Argentine associate producer of "The Official Story," which won an Oscar in 1986.
Unlike Camus's novel, which was set in North Africa in the 1940's as a metaphor for the Nazi occupation of France, Mr. Puenzo's version is set in a port city somewhere in Latin America in 1991. Despite the differences, the core narrative is the same: a recounting of how the plague, brought to the city by rats, radically changes the character and conduct of people making desperate efforts at self-preservation.
So far, the film makers appear to be beating the odds against filming in Buenos Aires. Since many Argentines have Italian, British, German, Spanish or French ancestry, it has been easy to find scores of bit players. The riches accumulated in Argentina in the first part of this century have given the country a large inventory of fine European antiques, providing a valuable source of props.
And since the Government of Carlos Saul Menem adopted a new economic policy in March, inflation has stabilized and the country's currency, the austral, is no longer wildly fluctuating. It has been noted that if the movie had been done in France, the cost would have been two or three times greater.
"Now we can sign a contract and have no fear about what the currency will do," said Mr. Kramer. "I can meet my budget. The unions aren't working against us so we can work extra time if we need to. We don't have to use black-market tricks like before."
With the Latin American setting, the political message of "The Plague" should be unmistakable. Mr. Puenzo says he hopes the movie will be a warning that while military dictatorships are on the wane, the plague -- or political oppression -- is biding its time.
"Camus's point was that the plague might go away for a time, but will always come back in a little different form," Mr. Puenzo said in a recent interview. "Everyone seems to be embracing a new form of pragmatic optimism. We're talking about the end of history, the end of philosophy. That is very dangerous, because to believe that, you have to sacrifice values based on true ideals. We're thinking that everyone will live happily ever after."
For Mr. Puenzo, the movie version of "The Plague" represents a continuation of "The Official Story," which he made in 1984 on a budget of $300,000. The first Argentine film to win an Oscar, it dealt with the days of military dictatorship in Argentina and the Government's systematic program of killing, or making disappear, people who opposed it.
 
Multiple Offers
 The movie version of "The Plague" has had a long and complicated history. The owners of the rights to Camus's masterpiece -- his daughter, Catherine, son, Jean, and his publishing house, Editions Gallimard in Paris -- were trying to decide among a number of offers in 1986, including bids from the producer David Puttnam, from Israeli, Italian and Japanese producers, and from Mr. Hurt himself.
AIDS had become an explosive issue, and many saw Camus's work as a metaphor for that disease.
But the rights were eventually sold to an independent American producer, John R. Pepper, of Pepper-Prince Company Ltd., based in New York, primarily because his vision was different.
"We did not want to make this a statement on AIDS," Mr. Pepper said. "This has a much broader application. Camus was making a political statement and we wanted to be true to that. We told them we would not make the movie without heavy French influence since this is a French national monument. And that while it was important to be faithful to the soul of the novel, it was also important to be irreverent."
To provide the French dimension, Mr. Pepper asked the Compagnie Francaise Cinematographique to join him and Mr. Kramer on the project. The head of the French group, Cyril de Rouvre, contributed $3 million of his personal fortune to get the stars he wanted.
Mr. Julia said it would be "a mistake to go and see the film and compare it with the novel."
The actor plays Cottard, a shady operator who is fleeing from the law and who actually enjoys the panic provoked by the plague. "We don't want to be the novel," he said. "You have to leave the novel in your home when you see the movie."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Bonilla Heads Class Of '91 Free Agents

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
When the results of last year's chase were complete, seven free agents had attained contracts worth $3 million or more a year. This year's chase begins today, and Bobby Bonilla will try to reach $5 million, perhaps $6 million, a year. Jack Morris, Frank Viola and Danny Tartabull are other free agents seeking the stratosphere of the salary scale.
This is the first day free agents can negotiate and sign with any of the 26 teams, and after expiration of last night's midnight deadline, a record 98 players made up the free-agent class of '91. 
 Morris, Minnesota's World Series hero, and Otis Nixon, Atlanta's drug-suspended outfielder, filed yesterday, as did Mike Pagliarulo, Junior Ortiz and Al Newman of the Twins, Max Venable of California and Steve Ontiveros of Philadelphia.
Just short of filing, Bill Wegmen, whose 15-7 performance this year gave him a 51-51 career record, reached agreement with the Milwaukee Brewers on a four-year, $9.5 million contract. He earned $440,000 this year. Glenn Davis of Baltimore, who filed for free agency on Nov. 1, agreed to a two-year contract with the Orioles.
Morris became a free agent because the Twins had shown no inclination to elevate his economic status to the area Roger Clemens and Dwight Gooden inhabit. Earlier this year, the two pitchers signed contract extensions that made them baseball's highest-paid players, Clemens with an average of $5,380,250 a year and Gooden at $5.15 million a year.
"Now that Jack is a free agent, he has an open mind," Richard Moss, the pitcher's lawyer, said yesterday. "He didn't become a free agent just to raise the price for the Twins."
Morris signed with the Twins last winter as a second-look free agent, the result of the union's collusion cases against the owners. Under terms of that contract, Morris could have earned $3.65 million next year, but he opted not to exercise his option, deciding to seek a contract in the $5 million-a-year range.
Last spring Bonilla rejected the Pittsburgh Pirates' offer of $4 million a year for four years and subsequently did the same with a $4.2 million-a-year offer. At the time, he wanted five years and might have accepted $20 million.
Now he stands to gain $5 million a year for five years, although with Gene Autry and the California Angels geared to sign him, the price could go even higher. The Pirates reportedly made Bonilla a new offer, valued at $18.5 million for four years with an option for a fifth year, during the weekend. Dennis Gilbert, Bonilla's agent, did not return telephone calls seeking comment on their response.
The Mets are one of the teams interested in the outfielder, who this season batted .302, hit 18 home runs and drove in 100 runs. Last year, the Mets refused to offer Darryl Strawberry, their own free agent, a fifth year, steadfastly holding to what they said was a club policy not to sign a position player for more than four years.
Strawberry defected to the Los Angeles Dodgers, who gave him $20.25 million for five years. Now the Mets have acknowledged that they may have to ignore their policy and go to five years for Bonilla.
The Mets, hoping for an early strike, may make Bonilla a substantial offer quickly, but they don't figure to go as high as $5 million a year. Furthermore, Bonilla isn't expected to bite at an early offer. In rejecting the Pirates' offer eight months ago, he gambled that he would not be injured and he would have a good season. If he was willing to wait until after the season, then he probably would wait a few weeks now.
Whereas Bonilla won his gamble, Viola, in effect, lost his. He rejected the Mets' offer of $13 million for three years, then had a dreadful second half, compiling a 2-10 record. He may still command $4 million or more a year simply because teams are so desperate for pitching.
After Bonilla, the best hitter in the free-agent class is Tartabull, who this season batted .316, hit 31 home runs, drove in 100 runs and led the American League with a .593 slugging percentage. Although he has been a consistent run producer, Tartabull is not valued as highly as Bonilla because some teams question his attitude.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Hiatus in the Fun

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Reality dropped in on America twice last week. One visit any time is remarkable; two in a week, extraordinary. Press and television were flabbergasted. They are so benumbed by make-believe that so much reality was bound to make them giddy.
The first visit occurred at midweek. Scattered election results, subjected to intense scrutiny, revealed that, yes -- yes! -- there really was a middle class. What a commotion in the press. What an upsetment in television. "Middle Class Lives!" 
 This was followed almost instantly, so swift is the analytic genius of the media, by "Middle Class Suffers!" What it suffers has, of course, been obvious for months to everybody not addicted to kidding himself. For the first time in maybe 50 years people who cannot be dismissed as shiftless louts are worrying about how they are going to pay the doctor, pay the rent and pay the butcher.
To recognize this had been impolite until last week's elections, for press and television, despite conservative belief that they are hotbeds of Bolshevism, have been exceedingly timid about offending Republican Presidents since The Washington Post took on Richard Nixon way back when.
Not surprisingly then, they largely accepted the official statistics and official pronouncements from official pronouncement issuers, and played the Republican tune on the economy, which went, "Let's make believe and keep our fingers crossed." With last week's elections, economic reality finally became an acceptable subject for press and TV to dwell upon.
The more timid received official approval to say "hard times" when the President canceled a grand tour of Asia, obviously to create the perception that he preferred to stay home and deal with the causes of middle-class discontent.
Before the country could relish this rare onset of reality about the economy it was confronted by Earvin (Magic) Johnson forcing it to face another reality, which is that AIDS is a disease that threatens absolutely everybody. So far it has been politically and economically convenient to consider it an affliction visited only on certain luckless minorities.
As Johnson pointed out with such eloquence in his news conference, it can strike even the noblest among us, and surely will, if not directly then through those we love. The media response to Magic was an astonishing torrent of film and print such as one rarely sees except for the start of wars and the fall of tyrants. It filled newspapers and television for three or four days, instantly obliterating from memory the big midweek visit of economic reality.
This is one reason reality has such a hard time surviving in America. Media overdosing quickly wears out reality's welcome, stimulating appetites for the relief of make-believe. After bombardments of news about the pain of unemployed fathers and the despair of young home buyers in a world of $150,000 "starter homes," we want to cry out: "Enough! I've been hit by reality from my cradle. Now stuff me with fun!"
Magic Johnson may escape this destiny and keep the country at grips with reality for the long run. Let's hope so. The precedents, however, are not encouraging. Remember Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf? Remember everybody saying he might be a good Presidential candidate? That was right after he led the armies to victory in the desert war. Remember the desert war? Remember the victory?
The overwhelming media absorption in Magic's case reflects the astonishing importance which Americans give to sports and sports heroes. To be sure, it helps that Earvin Johnson is not just another sports hero, but also a gentleman of surpassing charm. Still, is there any actor, any statesman, any warrior, any politician less than a sitting President who could produce such massive outpourings by announcing that he had tested positive for HIV?
Sports are almost as hostile to reality as politics. Sports lull us with romantic speechifying about the glory of team and teamwork while it corrupts our universities and exploits poor talented kids not quite talented enough ever to play in Magic's league. Politics beguiles us with shabby hocus-pocus which creates "images" and "perceptions" to distract us from realities.
Magic Johnson has shown us how to deal elegantly with reality. It's something refreshing in sports, as it would be in politics.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 4; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Discussions of Poverty Can't Leave Out Race

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 29 article about studies comparing poverty rates in Europe and the United States confuses and misleads on two counts. Though race is the throbbing reality underlying the conflict, you never address it directly. That omission oversimplifies our social problems and makes them substantially more difficult to solve. 
 You quote an explanation of our poverty rates by the social scientist Timothy Smeeding -- "we choose to tolerate a lot more poverty than do other countries" -- but never probe for an explanation of this tolerance. It might, for example, have been instructive to note that the poverty rate for blacks in the United States is three times that for whites.
In an era when Reagan-Bush racial politics shape our national social policies, the omission of the racial factor is a profound journalistic error. Particularly when a central point in the study you describe is the comparison of the performance of our racially divided society with that of relatively homogenous European countries.
More troubling are quotations from Douglas Besharov of the American Enterprise Institute. In attacking Mr. Smeeding's thesis that European poverty rates are lower because of more generous and effective social policies, Mr. Besharov says, "the problem is we don't have the same kind of poor people," and "Our problem is with poor people who don't work."
In a country that has become accustomed to code words, nobody has to ask what he means.
One of the problems with Mr. Besharov's position is that the facts get in the way. In a study for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, a Northwestern University economist, Rebecca M. Blank, has found that though the work effort of the poor increased at a faster rate in the 1980's than in the 60's, the decline in poverty in the 80's was minimized by a sharp reduction in wages. By contrast, poverty dropped sharply in the 60's because of rising wages.
Moreover, poverty rates of families that included both workers and children increased by one-third in 1979-90, according to the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities. Two million poor Americans worked full time in 1990, and the center estimates there are 5.5 million to 6 million people in the families supported by them. All in all, at least 8.7 million poor people worked full- or part-time last year, according to the center.
Carol Fennelly, a director of the largest homeless shelter in Washington, recently said on television that 65 percent of the people who use that facility work full- or part-time.
Finally, Mr. Besharov's analysis, resting on the fecklessness of the American poor, omits considering the bias of employers. Recent studies for the University of Chicago urban poverty and family life study suggest that employers prefer immigrant male workers to native-born black males even when blacks are willing to work for lower wages and the immigrants have less language facility. Those studies might help explain why there are so many discouraged workers, who want work, but have given up looking, among the black poor.
Avoidance and denial have characterized much of America's treatment of the racial issue for centuries. Those devices have made it extremely difficult to solve our racial problems and to address social issues related to them.
 
ROGER WILKINS
Prof. of History, George Mason U.
Fairfax, Va., Nov. 3, 1991
