HEADLINE: Discussions of Poverty Can't Leave Out Race;
Value of Comparisons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In an Oct. 29 article reporting research findings on how badly the United States compares with other advanced industrialized countries on poverty, you quote Douglas Besharov stating that European comparisons are meaningless ("I think it's hokum," he says). 
 Mr. Besharov argues that European policy solutions would produce harmful side effects in the United States, and that if comparisons are made, the United States should be compared with Bulgaria and Romania rather than Germany, France and the Scandinavian countries. Mr. Besharov, a noneconomist, attacks two economist-researchers of high standing for "technical flaws."
Even a casual observer of history or current affairs knows that in fact countries can and do learn from the experiences of others and that European comparisons have meaning and value in the United States policy debate. For example, the most popular social program in the United States is Social Security, a program that we and more than 100 other countries around the world "borrowed" from Europe, where it was "invented" more than a century ago.
Then, if we are concerned about economic competitiveness, we would certainly want to compare ourselves with those countries with which we compete -- and clearly countries in the European Community are among our competitors. Since when does the United States -- one of the richest countries in the world -- look to Romania and Bulgaria as a standard by which to judge ourselves?
Furthermore, if international comparisons are so meaningless, why is United States industry so concerned about how the Japanese and the Germans are achieving their economic successes? International comparisons do not tell us what to do, but they enrich significantly the options to consider in a search for wise policy.
The United States has a high poverty rate not because many of the poor are not working, but because about half the poor are still poor despite working. European countries emphasize work-incentive policies and assure those who work -- especially those with children -- adequate family income through supplementation.
 
SHEILA B. KAMERMAN
ALFRED J. KAHN
New York, Nov. 1, 1991
 
The writers are directors of cross-national studies at the Columbia University School of Social Work.

HEADLINE: President of Troubled Bridgeport University Quits

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON

 BODY:
Janet D. Greenwood resigned last night as president of the financially ailing University of Bridgeport.
A spokesman for the university said she would remain as a tenured faculty member and president emeritus. 
 Her resignation was announced after a five-and-a-half-hour meeting of the university's board of trustees. Dr. Greenwood had served as president of the private Connecticut nonsectarian university since 1987.
"She served the university during a very difficult period," said Colin Gunn, chairman of the board.
The board of trustees announced that Edwin G. Eigel Jr., the university provost since 1979, has been named interim president.
The change of leadership comes three weeks after the trustees voted unanimously to reject a possible takeover of the university by a group founded and largely financed by the Unification Church and its leader, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.
Both Dr. Greenwood and Mr. Gunn had urged serious consideration of the church's proposal that included the promise of $50 million to help the university solve its financial crisis. The university has been weakened by a decades-long slide in enrollment and the longest faculty strike at any American university.
Some students said Dr. Greenwood's resignation was a positive sign. "We need some new leaders and hopefully they'll find someone," said Suzi Murray, editor of the student newspaper, The Scribe, in an interview with The Associated Press.
Dr. Greenwood left the campus after the board meeting and did not comment on her resignation. In earlier statements, she had said the university was suffering because of the recession and because of Bridgeport's own financial problems.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 13, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in some copies yesterday about the resignation of the president of the University of Bridgeport in Connecticut misidentified her. She is Janet D. Greenwood. An article discussing her departure appears today on page B5.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Banking on Currency Union

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IS one currency, controlled by one central bank, the next logical step to a truly integrated European economy? Or is it an act of hubris, a marriage that will ruin a beautiful friendship?
Eight distinguished European economists assembled by the Center for Economic Policy Research, an independent think tank in London, dismiss fears that the prospective partners are fundamentally incompatible. They maintain that the European Monetary Union, anchored on Germany's determination to maintain stable prices, offers Europe a cheap way to banish inflation and lower capital costs -- provided national economies retain some fiscal flexibility to cope with shocks. 
 A more realistic worry, they argue in a report published a month before European heads of state are expected to announce the marriage banns, is that union will expose the checking and payments system to the sorts of pressures that destroyed America's savings and loans and cost taxpayers some $200 billion.
One attraction of a common currency is greater certainty in business costs: A French manufacturer who sells fork lifts in Milan will no longer have to worry about the franc-lira exchange rate on the day of delivery. But the real prize is price stability.
The community's high-inflation economies -- Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy, Britain -- have all made progress in stabilizing prices. But the cost of anti-inflation credibility, measured in slower growth and high unemployment, can be substantial. By contrast, an irrevocable commitment to an independent central bank that operates under Germany's long shadow should lower inflation expectations overnight. And with currencies locked in permanent embrace, investors in the weaker economies should no longer demand more interest to compensate for the risks of future devaluation.
The authors of "Monitoring European Integration" acknowledge that the temptation to fiscal indulgence cannot be eliminated by putting a lock on the door of the central bank. It is possible, even likely, that national governments will resolve political conflict by spending more than they tax. And the resulting stimulus could spill into the rest of the community, much the way deficit spending in California can add to the inflationary demand for goods from Oregon. But the answer, they argue, does not lie in tight fiscal rules.
National economies need some fiscal flexibility to buffer shocks -- say, a natural disaster or a collapse in the price of a critical export. And in any case, a fiscal rule based on government deficits or national debt would be arbitrary if it were applied to all countries. Belgium, for example, typically runs bigger budget deficits than Britain or Spain, but is less inflation-prone. David Begg, one of the eight economists and a professor at the University of London's Birkbeck College, suggests a more promising approach is to reduce incentives to profligacy. The report recommends that governments that run big deficits be required to index their debts to inflation or interest rates. Thus any national government's "success" in exporting inflation to the rest of the monetary union would carry the penalty of increasing the government's debt burden.
Mr. Begg would also limit the risks that banks could take in holding government debts, thereby preventing a national government's default from threatening the overall European banking system. That would make it more practical -- and thus more credible -- for the European central bank to refuse to prop up government borrowers no longer deemed creditworthy in the private market.
This last point touches on what the eight economists cite as the greatest potential risk in monetary union. While Eurocrats have spent many a lunch devising fiscal and monetary rules for the new union, little effort has been put into the problem of regulating the integrated payments system. And if nobody bothers to check the impulses of imprudent lenders, European taxpayers could end up like their American counterparts.
That is why fully a third of the report is devoted to the design of banking regulation. The authors, in brief, would opt for a system of deposit insurance, with premiums tied to risk. They also want banks that make riskier loans to buffer the risks with fatter cushions of capital.
One might still wonder, though, whether incentive-based regulation, which strives for safety with the least possible interference in private capital markets, is really enough. The debacle in America does not prove that a healthy balance is impossible to manage. But it has certainly left many American analysts wary of any reform that does not build a wall between the checking and payments system and other banking services.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Scott Paper Redraws Organizational Chart

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
Struggling to cut costs and raise sagging profits, the Scott Paper Company announced a management reorganization yesterday that reshuffles executives worldwide.
The moves are intended to focus the company on its two main businesses, coated paper for publishing and personal-care and cleaning products, said Michael Kilpatric, a spokesman for the Philadelphia-based company, which makes Scott tissues, Cottonelle toilet paper and Viva paper towels and other brands. 
 "We need to be more aggressive in order to get in shape," said Mr. Kilpatric, who said the reorganization resulted from a four-point plan the company announced in January.
That program called for a reduction in working capital, greater control of capital spending, the divestiture of some assets and such cost reductions as employee layoffs.
The company has laid off about 600 workers in Britian and has said it will make additional job cuts worldwide. It also plans to sell three of its businesses: the food-service container business; bulk nonwoven products like disposable diaper liners, and the specialty papers division.
Because of the recession and increased competition from rivals like Procter & Gamble, Scott's business has taken a battering this year. For the third quarter, profits dropped 58 percent, to $28 million, compared with $64.8 million in the comparable period last year.
One of the more significant executive changes announced yesterday was the appointment of P. Newton White, a senior vice president, to head a newly formed global unit that will oversee commercial business for tissues and other paper products. Mr. White, who is 49 years old, joined the company in 1967 and most recently had been in charge of Scott's Pacific operations.
The consumer business in the Pacific will be headed by Clemens S. Andes Jr., who had been the managing director of Scott Ltd., the company's business in Britain.
John J. Butler, who had headed Scott's European unit, will become the company's chief administrative officer, replacing J. Lawrence Shane, who will retire. Paolo Forlin, managing director of Scott's Italian operations, will head the consumer business in Europe.
Ashok Bakhru, previously the chief financial officer, will be in charge of Scott's international wet-wipes business and will continue to head the company's health-care operations.
Ellis A. Horwitz has been appointed vice president and general counsel. He replaces Norman M. Heisman, who becomes counsel to the board of directors.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
One State Rating Affirmed, Another Is Cut by Moody's

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service has taken a look at two states' general obligation bonds, affirming one and downgrading the other.
The ratings service affirmed the A rating given to New York State's general obligations, which total $22.1 billion of tax-supported debt. Despite what it calls "a diverse and substantial economic base" in New York, Moody's notes that "real reforms have not yet been devised" to solve the state's financial problems, including the unrestrained growth of Medicaid payments. 
 At the same time, Moody's lowered by a notch, to Aa from Aa1, the rating assigned to New Hampshire's general obligation bonds. New Hampshire's bonds still have a higher rating than New York's.
The rating change affects an issue of $60 million in capital improvement bonds to be offered on Monday, as well as the state's general obligation bonds, of which about $566 million are outstanding.
Moody's said the change also affected all state-guaranteed bonds of local government units and of the New Hampshire Municipal Bond Bank.
Moody's noted that "the effects of the nation's economic recession are worsened in New Hampshire by real estate property deflation, bank failures, and consequent reduced access to credit." Such negative factors "may persist for a protracted period," Moody's said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Narrowly Mixed Amid Uncertainty on Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other currencies yesterday as traders continued to speculate about the direction of interest rates in the United States and overseas.
Analysts said the dollar drew some support from a Los Angeles Times article quoting senior officials at the Federal Reserve as saying the central bank has virtually decided against any more interest rate cuts this year. 
 The dollar is raised by stable or higher interest rates, so the possibility that United States rates will not drop is a positive sign for investors.
But the dollar's advance was small. Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for Bank of New York, said the American currency was not on an upward trend, and he attributed its gains to traders adjusting their holdings.
Mr. Ryan said the market's was also interested in reports that German officials believe they cannot reduce rates in their country. Those reports strengthened the mark.
The dollar was little changed against the mark in New York, edging up to 1.6400 marks from 1.6399 late Monday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6355 marks from 1.6410.
In Japan, interest rates are expected to decline. But traders there say the drop has been anticipated for so long it may not have a severe impact on the yen.
The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen, falling to 129.95 yen in New York, from 130.05 yen on Monday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 yen, to 129.95 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 129.60 yen.
The British pound fell slightly against the dollar, dropping to $1.7700 in New York from $1.7705. In London, sterling fell to $1.7730 from $1.7810.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.4535 Swiss francs, up from 1.44725; 5.6045 French francs, up from 5.5990; 1,235.00 Italian lire, up from 1,232.00, and 1.13475 Canadian dollars, up from 1.13275.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.4508 Swiss francs, up from 1.4487; 5.5880 French francs, down from 5.6055; 1.8425 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8505; 1,231.50 Italian lire, down from 1,232.72, and 1.1315 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1314.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
With Acquisition of Agency, Girgenti Enters a New Area

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
UNDERSCORING the growing strength of agencies that specialize in health-care advertising, one of the largest such independent shops is acquiring an agency that specializes in consumer accounts.
Girgenti, Hughes, Butler & McDowell Inc., which creates campaigns for health-care clients like 3M Pharmaceuticals and Sanofi-Winthrop, is buying Rubin Reid Noto & Ehrenthal Inc., an agency at which food, fashion and cosmetics companies are the main clients. 
 "It's a bit of a twist," Mel Rubin, chairman of Rubin Reid, said in an interview yesterday in New York, at which he and principals of Girgenti, Hughes discussed the deal.
While the sluggish economy wreaks havoc at many companies, the health-care field is thriving. Steve Girgenti, president of Girgenti, Hughes, said the turnabout makes sense because "most medical agencies today are doing significantly better than their consumer counterparts."
Several trends are helping the explosive growth of health-care advertising.
One is the marketing of prescription drugs, like the hair-growing drug Rogaine, directly to consumers. Both agencies have enjoyed success in those endeavors: Girgenti, Hughes with Minitran, 3M Pharmaceuticals' nitroglycerin patch used to treat heart disease; Rubin Reid with Nicorette, the nicotine-based chewing gum made by Marion Merrell Dow.
Another trend is the increasing number of over-the-counter products that are marketed through big-budget consumer-ad campaigns.
The deal is being described as a stock-swap acquisition of Rubin Reid, with an office in Manhattan, by Girgenti, Hughes, with offices in Manhattan and Minneapolis/St. Paul. Each agency will operate as separate divisions under a Girgenti corporate entity. (New names for the corporate parent and the agency divisions are likely.)
The deal combines Girgenti, Hughes, founded in 1986 by former executives of the Bologna International health-care agency, with Rubin Reid, founded a year later from what was the Shaller Rubin agency. It forms a shop with billings that exceed $90 million -- and no client conflicts, Mr. Girgenti and Mr. Rubin note -- and more than 70 employees.
Already, the combination is paying off, said Mr. Girgenti and Mr. Rubin: The two agencies, in their initial joint new-business presentation, received special-project assigments from the Wyeth-Ayerst drug division of the American Home Products Corporation. Billings, they added, will be more than $10 million.
A new executive structure is being put into place as a result of the deal. Mr. Girgenti becomes chairman and chief executive of the Girgenti corporate entity, and Mr. Rubin becomes vice chairman of Rubin Reid. And each agency division gets its own chief operating officer: for Girgenti, Hughes, Bill Butler, who was executive vice president of Girgenti, Hughes; for Rubin Reid, Herb Ehrenthal, who was president of Rubin Reid.
On the creative side, Frank Hughes and Mark McDowell, who had been vice presidents and co-creative directors at Girgenti, Hughes, become executive creative directors of the new agency.
For now, each agency will remain in its own office in Manhattan, Girgenti, Hughes at 11 East 26th Street, and Rubin Rein at 386 Park Avenue South. Later this year, they will move into a larger, combined space at 100 Avenue of the Americas.
The deal is the latest in a series of transactions in which smaller agencies are joining forces to better meet the challenges of the continuing sluggish economy and their mega-agency competition. Other examples include the merger of Weiss, Whitten and Carroll Raj Stagliano in June to form Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano, and the purchase in August of two agencies by Griffin Bacal Inc., which merged them to form an agency within the agency called the Business Marketing Communications Group.
On a personal note, Mr. Girgenti and Mr. Rubin said, the deal serves to reunite them: In the early 1970's, Mr. Girgenti was Mr. Rubin's client when the former was in product management for the drug division of Du Pont and the latter was at Shaller Rubin.

HEADLINE: USAir Sets Off a Round of Discount Fares

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
USAir yesterday announced discounts of 10 to 25 percent off most existing excursion fares for travel to almost all its destinations between Jan. 7 and March 31 -- usually the period of least air travel. American, United and Continental Airlines said they would match USAir, while Delta Air Lines said it is likely to do so today.
While the nonrefundable fares will not necessarily result in the lowest fares offered on each route during the last 12 months, during which Eastern Airlines cut fares extensively in a futile attempt to avoid liquidation, USAir's announcement comes when most carriers have been trying to raise fares -- or at least hold the line -- to stanch the industry's continuing losses. 
 Last year United States airlines lost almost $4 billion, the worst combined loss in history, and they have continued to lose money as a result of recession and the fallout from the Persian Gulf war.
Continental will also match the $1,100 round-trip international air fares announced by Trans World Airways yesterday, while American, United and Delta are still studying whether to do so. T.W.A. said the new fares would be discounted by at least 50 percent.
All T.W.A.'s overseas destinations are included except Cairo and Tel Aviv, and the fares are good from 88 of the 102 cities in the United States served by T.W.A. and Trans World Express. Among the gateways excluded from the T.W.A. promotion, which requires that tickets be purchased by Nov. 29 for travel through March 31, 1992, are New York, Newark, Boston, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Washington/Dulles.
"Those are already competitive markets, and we're trying to generate more international traffic from the South, the Southwest and Midwest," a T.W.A. spokesman said.
The USAir fares require a 14-day advance purchase and a Saturday night stayover, and are based on a mileage formula that includes distance and whether the destinations are peak or off-peak. Travel to southern and central Florida, Arizona, Nassau, in the Bahamas, and Colorado must be completed by Feb. 9, 1992, and tickets to those destinations must be purchased by Jan. 25. The last date to buy a ticket for most other markets is Feb. 29.
Under the new fares, the lowest offpeak excursion round-trip fare from Pittsburgh to Los Angeles will be $378, a saving of $60 over the current lowest price of $438. The round-trip saving from Boston to Washington will be $70 -- $158 compared with a current $228.
 
Discounts to Houston
 Continental's new New York to Houston round-trip fare will be $318, a 14 percent saving over the carrier's current $368 fare, and Newark to San Francisco will be $378, 24 percent less than the current $468.
American said it had not formulated its new fares, but added that the discounts it offered would be off its current lowest advance purchase fares.
While USAir's market share for the first nine months of 1991 was only 7.8 percent, compared with almost 19 percent for United, 18.8 for American and 15.3 for Delta, according to Aviation Daily, the larger carriers almost always take the position that they have to match their smaller rivals to maintain market share.
But they have not felt the same urgency to match T.W.A.'s price cuts, which are aimed largely at attracting business travelers, in part because of T.W.A.'s weakened financial condition. The carrier's market share through September 1991 amounted to less than 6.4 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Overseas Buying Sends Prices Up

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A wave of overseas buying helped to push up prices of Treasury securities yesterday. But for the most part, domestic investors remained on the sidelines.
Traders emphasized that virtually all of the price gain, amounting to nearly a point for some longer-dated issues, was achieved during overnight trading in Asian and, later, European money markets. 
 "We are basically unchanged from where we were when I came in at 7:30 this morning," a government bond trader in New York said. "There has not been much activity to speak of since then."
 
Growth Report Cited
 Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Economics, said foreign demand for Treasury securities might have been stimulated by sharply lower estimates for 1992 growth in the United States released on Monday by the Organization for Econonic Cooperation and Development.
The more sober view came as a real surprise to many overseas, Mr. Fabbri said.
"I believe that the information in Europe about the United States and what is going on here lags what is actually happening," he said.
Mr. Fabbri, who was in Britain last week for several speeches, told his audiences that growth in the fourth quarter "looks meager, and the first quarter looks dangerous."
He added, "I don't think that people expected that sort of talk when they came through the door."
 
Letter From Markey
 Traders in the United States, who had Monday off in observance of Veterans Day, were reluctant to speak about the letter that Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who is the chairman of a House subcommittee on telecommunications and finance, sent to dealers late last week.
In the letter, Mr. Markey asked for information pertaining to bidding at the Treasury's three-year note auction last week.
Demand at that auction was exceptionally weak, and Mr. Markey, responding to news reports that the auction represented a protest by dealers against new Treasury bidding rules, said he was seeking to determine if those accounts were valid.
Heather L. Ruth, the president of the Public Securities Association, an industry group, said that "in conversations with our members, market conditions at the time of the three-year were uncertain, but not because of the rule changes, and not because of a dealer protest, which I don't believe occurred."
Ms. Ruth said failure of the Federal Reserve Board to cut its discount rate on Nov. 5, the date of the three-year auction, and very low short-term interest rates were the primary causes for weak demand at the auction.
The decline in short-term rates that occurred after the Fed cut the discount rate on Nov. 6 was reflected at yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills. The securities were sold at the lowest interest rates since April 1977.
 
3-Month Bills at 4.64%
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.64 percent, down from an average rate of 4.74 at last week's auction. It is the lowest three-month bill rate since April 25, 1977, when it was 4.518 percent.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 4.71 percent, compared with an average rate of 4.80 percent a week ago. It is the lowest rate on a new six-month bill since the auction of April 18, 1977, when the average rate was 4.708 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 103 14/32, up by 30/32, to yield 7.82 percent, compared with 7.90 percent late Friday.
Prices of issues sold by the Treasury at last week's refunding auctions continued to advance.
For example, the new 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 7.34 percent, down from 7.40 percent on Monday.
Among secondary Treasury note issues, the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 1/32, up by an eighth of a point, to yield 6.62 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 22/32, down by 1/ 32, to yield 5.62 percent.
 
Many New Debt Issues
 Corporations responded to the continued decline in interest rates by pricing a huge volume of new debt issues.
Yesterday, 10 companies offered more than $2 billion in asset-backed securities and more conventional debt obligations.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Growth Seen

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The trade deficit, which has been improving for the last four years, will worsen next year as sluggish world demand dampens American export growth, the Bush Administration said today.
The statement by Treasury Under Secretary David Mulford, was the first public estimate of next year's trade deficit by the Adminitration. 
 Mr. Mulford, testifying to Congress on the Administration's semiannual trade and exchange rate report, said that the merchandise trade deficit was likely to widen by between $5 billion and $10 billion next year.
Mr. Mulford said the Administration expected this year's deficit to drop to $65 billion. That forecast, which is in line with private economists' expectations, would be down from last year's $101.7 billion deficit and be below $100 million for the first time since 1984.
The Treasury report noted with concern that trade imbalances are rising again in Japan. The deficit with Japan is likely to account for two- thirds of America's total imbalance this year.
While the total American trade deficit is expected to fall by 36 percent this year, the deficit with Japan is expected to show little if any improvement.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 11.85, Closing At 3,054.11

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks rose smartly in active trading yesterday, with a firm bond market underpinning gains in equities. A number of indexes reached new record highs, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.85 points, to 3,054.11.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, a measure of blue-chip activity, rose by 3.62, to a new high of 396.74, surpassing the old record of 396.64 set on Aug. 28. Trading on the American Stock Exchange moved the index up by 1.13 points, to 392.37. 
 Record highs were also set by the Nasdaq index of over-the-counter issues, which rose by 4.97, to 555.68, and by the Russell 2,000 index of small stocks, which rose by 1.23 points, to 188.02.
The Nasdaq and the Russell indexes have now hit new highs in four straight trading sessions.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 199.5 million, with the Big Board's composite index up 1.93, to 219.00. Monday's volume was 129.1 million. Advancing issues outpaced declining ones yesterday, 1,092 to 595.
Anthony Ludovici, the senior vice president and senior investment analyst at Tucker Anthony, said that yesterday's performance was impressive, with a cross section of the large stocks and broad market moving together. "And if it we get an economic recovery in 1992, the basic industry stocks will be in the vanguard," he said.
"Secondary and speculative issues that have been strong this year hopefully will not fade in a recovery," Mr. Ludovici added.
 
7 of 10 Big Stocks Up
 Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, reported that in yesterday's market, 7 out of 10 of the largest-capitalization stocks listed on the S.& P. 500 were up, confirming that the rally was led by the bigger issues. They also noted that the nearly 2-to-1 ratio of gainers over losers was in line with a broad base involvement.
In trading yesterday, analysts said Travelers had signed an agreement to sell all the stock in its New York-based investment banking unit, Dillon, Read, to Dillon's managers and the British merchant bank Barings P.L.C. The price was $122 million, and Travelers's stock rose 1/4, to 20 1/4.
In an announcement after the market closed on Monday, Tektronix, which manufactures electronic equipment, said its second-quarter results would be about 30 percent below results a year ago, as well as under all Wall Street's estimates.
Yesterday, the stock fell 3 3/4, to 17. The company said it had cut more than half its work force over the last 10 years and it saw very little fat that could be trimmed further.
Environmnetal Systems, which said on Monday that it had received a $16-a-share offer from Bramble Industries of Australia, fell 1/4, to 15 3/4.
The American depository receipts of British Airways, which are traded on the Big Board, rose sharply yesterday after the airline reported higher-than-expected earnings for the first half of the year. The receipts rose 3 5/8, to 39 1/8, a 52-week high.
Because of the increasing likelihood that McDonnell Douglas will find an Asian partner for its commercial jetliner business, traders said, Judith Bollinger, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, raised her rating to a "buy" from a "hold." They noted that she had raised her 1992 earnings estimates, as the stock rose 4 5/8, to 77.
At a meeting in New York yesterday, Nucor, a steel-products company, told analysts that it expected its fourth-quarter earnings to be higher than the 72 cents a share it reported in the third quarter. Most analysts had been expecting results that were flat to slightly higher.
Nucor's stock rose 1 1/2, to 80 5/8, as analysts also noted that several new plants were ahead of schedule.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Pawnshops Shed Their Dingy Image

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
With unemployment up and bank credit tight, more Americans are having difficulty getting loans. Consider then what Wall Street analysts are calling a superb bet on hard times: investing in stockholder-owned pawnshops.
Although pawnshop customers have traditionally been hourly workers whose low wages disqualified them from bank loans, more middle-income consumers, facing layoffs or salary cuts, are turning to them. 
 The rising demand for pawn loans might itself make an investment in a publicly held chain like Cash America Investments Inc., the industry leader, appealing. But what has piqued analysts' interest is the economics of the business. Because the usury ceilings governing pawn shops are typically much more liberal than for other lending operations, pawn operators can often charge annualized interest rates well into the triple digits.
 
A No-Loss Situation
 And because the collateral that customers post -- from electric guitars to jewelry to firearms -- is typically worth twice what is lent, a pawn operator has to work to lose money. An added bonus is that unlike banks, which must repossess collateral, pawn operators hold goods until a borrower repays. The merchandise on display represents forfeited collateral and is typically sold for a hefty profit.
"They make 20 percent gross profit on defaulted loans and 205 percent interest" on loans repaid, said Steven Kent, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs who specializes in emerging growth companies.
In recent years, however, the pawn industry has been consolidating. Although it continues to be dominated by thousands of small operators, the business has a number of larger concerns that because of their size have the money to make their stores larger, lighter and brighter. The new pawnshops more closely resemble the showrooms of major catalogue retailers than the traditional shabby storefronts. These big pawnbrokers can also make more loans and achieve economies of scale.
Besides Cash America, based in Fort Worth, the publicly held chains include Ezcorp, Express Cash International and First Cash, all also based in Texas., and U.S. Pawn Inc. of Denver.
 
The Top Attraction
 But Cash America is attracting the most attention on Wall Street. Not only is Cash America's network of more than 150 pawnshops in eight states the largest in the industry, but it is also one of the most sophisticated pawn operators, having recently installed a new computer system to track merchandise inventory levels and borrowers' repayment histories.
Believing that Cash America's expansion and modernization will generate double-digit earnings growth, Dennis C. Van Zelfden, an analyst with Rauscher Pierce Refsnes, recently issued a "buy" recomendation. Although the company's shares slipped 12.5 cents, to $19.125, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. many analysts see the stock rising to the mid-20's over the next year.
"What we're talking about is applying modern management techniques to an industry that has not had the capital to apply those techniques, let alone expand," Mr. Van Zelfden said of Cash America. "I see continued, fairly stable 20 percent annual earnings growth."
 
'Stronger Balance Sheet'
 David H. Hochstim of Bear, Stearns is another analyst looking closely at Cash America. Although he has not yet made a recommendation, Mr. Hochstim said Cash America "has a stronger balance sheet than the typical individual pawn operator who lends less than the market will bear because of his or her personal financial situation."
Mr. Van Zelfden is also recommending Ezcorp, No. 2 in the industry with more than 50 stores, all in Texas. Because it is starting from a smaller base than Cash America, Ezcorp is growing faster, with the number of Ezcorp pawnshops expected to triple in two years. Mr. Van Zelfden is also impressed by Ezcorp's management-training program, which trains prospective pawnbrokers to evaluate pawned merchandise and to run Ezcorp's point-of-sale inventory-tracking system.
Trading over-the-counter, Ezcorp could also be a $25 stock in two years, Mr. Van Zelfden said. It gained 62.5 cents yesterday, to $14.75.
"Ezcorp is what Cash America was three years ago," Mr. Van Zelfden added,
The pawnshop business does have risks. Laws limiting the interest rates have been on the books for years in most cases, so it is unlikely that the limits will be lowered significantly. But a number of states have tightened licensing requirements for pawn operators, which could drive up acquisition costs for the big operators by reducing the number of shops for sale.
Additionally, pawnshops always run the risk of accepting stolen merchandise. Mr. Van Zelfden, who recently wrote a long report on pawnshops, said Ezcorp was currently facing investigations at two of its shops in connection with stolen goods. Finally, because a new pawnshop can be opened for less than $175,000, the industry could attract a slew of new competitors, leading to more risky lending on everyone's part and lower profits.
For now, most analysts remain bullish on the industry, particularly Cash America, which they say has a significant lead over any rivals. And while worsening economic sluggishness could lead to more borrowers' defaulting on their pawnshop obligations, any increase in default rates could be offset by sharply higher demand for loans.
"Pawnshops don't necessarily benefit during a recession," Mr. Kent of Goldman, Sachs said, "but they can remain successful during hard times."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: A New Discipline in Economics Brings Change to Latin America

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
Suddenly, a look at the economic map of Latin America shows a startling change. After a decade of no growth, crippling inflation, rising foreign debt, protectionism and bloated state payrolls, governments -- at least for now -- have found a new economic religion.
Balanced budgets are in, as is privatization, the buzzword for selling off government enterprises. Negotiations to reduce foreign debt have been successful in some countries, especially Mexico, and are continuing in others. Stabilization and discipline have become winning political slogans. The free market, open economies and deregulation are now part of the vocabulary of taxi drivers and laborers. 
 In Latin American cities there are signs of change everywhere.
In Concepcion, 200 miles south of here, three new paper plants costing more than $1.3 billion are opening. In Buenos Aires, the Park Plaza Hotel is overrun with investment bankers from New York, London, Bonn and Paris looking for deals. In Lima, adventurous business executives talk with the Peruvian Government about its plans to sell off state-run enterprises.
 
'Committed to Free Enterprise'
 "We have a country committed to free enterprise, where there are established rules, a central bank you can deal with and zero bribery," said Vincent A. Russo, general manager of Santa Fe Forestal y Industria, a $460 million pulp plant in Nacimiento, Chile, that is owned by Shell Oil, Scott Paper and Citicorp. "There's not a lot more you can ask for."
Driving this new-found optimism and economic activity are profound policy changes that run from the Rio Grande to Tierra del Fuego. The new consensus says that inflation is bad, particularly for the poor, that governments do not know how to run businesses, that printing money is political suicide and that tax evasion, a time-honored sport here, should be punished severely.
Also, in the face of democracy's growing popularity, Marxism has all but disappeared. All of Latin America, except for Cuba and Haiti, have democratically elected governments. In early 1979, Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru and Uruguay were all run by military dictatorships. Military governments -- except in Chile -- have been unable to run stable economies. Huge amounts of unpaid debt borrowed over the last decade or so underscore the insolvency of those governments and their inability to meet social needs. Now, the only alternative seems to be to generate jobs through internal growth.
There has been a psychological lift for several countries, including Mexico and Venezuela, from the Bush Administration's debt reduction plan. Especially in Mexico, the negotiation of a successful debt plan lowered the level and cost of billions of dollars in foreign commercial bank loans and eased the economic burden on a new Mexican administration. With the added imprimatur of aid from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, a successful debt reduction agreement has made Mexico and some other countries more attractive to foreign investors.
Even though both Argentina and Brazil have yet to frame a debt reduction agreement, the mere prospect of one has been a spur to foreign investor interest.
 
Country by Country
 In Argentina, President Carlos Saul Menem has announced a vast deregulation of his country's economy, reversing decades of protection for industries. In Chile, a prospering free-market economy generated by Gen. August Pinochet, who stepped down from office 18 months ago, has been maintained by a coalition of his successors. In Bolivia, the poorest country on the continent, a general and his leftist opponent have teamed up to impose tight monetary discipline and promote growth. And even in Peru, long plagued by poverty, President Alberto Fujimori has instituted a severe package of economic restrictions that are unpopular but accepted as necessary.
In the last two months three respected organizations -- the International Monetary Fund, the International Bank for Development and the United Nations -- have all issued cautious reports predicting a new era of vigorous, through sporadic, economic growth.
But none of these new policies have been able to wipe out poverty. In 1980, 40 percent of the Latin American population was considered living in poverty. By last year, that had risen to 44 percent. In Peru, where the minimum wage is $50 a month, 90 percent of the people are considered to be either unemployed or underemployed. In Chile, five million people, or a third of its population, is considered to live in poverty.
What astounds economists and analysts is that the tough economic medicine continues to be popularly supported even though it has resulted in large government layoffs, a precipitous drop in the buying power of the average citizen and less spending on public needs like housing, water and electricity. In both Mexico and Argentina the incumbent political parties won large midterm elections because of economic stability.
 
Brazil Plans Frustrated
 Brazil is the only country still struggling to produce a plan to stop perennial inflation. President Fernando Collor de Mello has been frustrated by an opposition Congress and has failed to persuade the public that with the dole and a relaxed life on the beach, Brazil will remain in the past.
In other Latin nations, results are more impressive. In Chile, inflation is under 20 percent and foreign investment this year, at $3 billion, is triple what it was in 1990. Mexico will record 20 percent inflation for the third year in a row, and its economy will grow close to 5 percent. Venezuela, an oil importer that benefited from last year's oil run-up, has scored 10 percent growth so far this year, with higher levels of inflation, around 35 percent, but far less than the 90 percent inflation in 1989. Argentina, after 1,000 percent inflation in 1990 and 6,000 percent in 1989, imposed a stringent economic policy earlier this year, and has had an annual inflation rate of less than 20 percent in the last three months. Colombia is also generating about 20 percent inflation and 2.2 percent growth.
The new governments defy old Latin stereotypes. Parties that promoted highly nationalistic, isolationist policies in the past, like President Menem's Peronist Party in Argentina, are now seeking friendship with the United States for economic and political reasons.
"We can't wait for anybody to help other than ourselves," said Oscar Imbellone, president of CPC International in Buenos Aires. "We need to use our own management know-how, capitalist structure, innovation and research and development. We have to do the things all civilized countries do."
 
A Risky Game
 Still, politicians know they are playing a risky game -- just how long will people endure the pain of unemployment for the sake of future prosperity? That worry has generated efforts to add some social spending to the economic plans, without risking their effectiveness. Chile has doubled business taxes to 10 percent, and used the new funds on education, medical care and housing.
"The thinking here is that there will be stability as long as the poor see the Government is making an effort," said Oscar Altimir, director of the Economic Development division in the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America, based in Santiago.
But while the rich continue to get richer, the gap between them and the middle and lower classes widens.
In Bogota, Colombia, Pilar Barco, a language professor, and her husband, Francisco Garcia, a fine arts professor and commercial artist, together make about $500 a month, which is four times the minimum wage, "and still we never buy clothes and we live a minimum existence," she said.
One response in the attempt to spur economies is to get government out of business and privatize everything from state oil companies to railroads to park maintenance, with the hope of creating an industrial sector that generates jobs.
Chile was long the leader of the privatization movement under General Pinochet. More recently, Mexico has led the way with the privatization of its telephone company, which raised $2.3 billion in foreign capital from a stock sale. Some countries seem in a race to privatize before the public gets tired of seeing its patrimony on the auction block. President Menem of Argentina has ordered his Economy Minister to finish all such sales in 1992.
A second self-help response is the formation of alliances aimed at creating more competitive economies. Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay are trying to create a free-trade zone by 1994 called Mercosur. Mexico and Chile have signed a free-trade agreement. Colombia and Venezuela are trying to integrate their economies. And everyone is looking to the negotiations between Mexico and the United States on a free-trade agreement.
"When they sign that, we are going to be the next ones knocking at the door," said Guido Di Tella, Argentina's Foreign Minister.
 
Spillover Is Feared
 In all this, the trouble spot is still Brazil, a vast country of 125 million people, the largest debtor in Latin America and so large that troubles there will always threaten to spill into other countries.
While President Collor de Mello was easily elected in 1990, and seemed poised to revamp the economy, he has failed so far. A bank account freeze followed by wage and price controls eventually collapsed. Recent attempts to privatize the state's crown jewel, a big steel plant, were nearly undone by protesting union workers.
Since then, a loss of confidence in the President has pushed the country close to hyperinflation. Late last month, for example, the cruziero fell 10 percent in one day against the dollar.
Latin businessmen, who have kept some $170 billion outside their home countries for years, are beginning to bring some money home. Some are taking advantage of higher dollar interest rates, but much of the money is for long-term investment.
Latin countries are also devising ways to raise capital. Eduardo Stern, vice president of Chile's newest and largest ski resort, Valle Nevado, is trying to get Government approval to allow pension fund managers -- by law restricted in the types of investments they can make -- to invest in a new hotel. "I dreamed of this project from my youth, but no way was it possible then," Mr. Stern said. "This type of transaction is proof this country has changed."

THE LEADERS
 ARGENTINA: Efforts to stabilize currency, toughen tax collection and stop printing money to cover the deficits have cut inflation and given Argentina reputation as the next emerging economy. President Carlos Saul Menem, using executive power, has decreed the deregulation of almost all industry. Now seeking to renegotiate $60 billion debt.
 CHILE: The new Government retained most open-market policies left by General Augusto Pinochet, but has raised some taxes for social programs. After bout with inflation in 1990, the central bank has restricted money growth. Foreign investment pouring in.
 COLOMBIA: Years of sound money and fiscal policies have made this country one of the continent's most stable. Broad reductions in tariff barriers have forced protected industries to compete or close. Austerity has limited domestic growth and consumer demand. Also, the continued flow of drug dollars has stymied real industrial development and fight against drug trafficking has drained resources.
 MEXICO: The three-year-old Government of Carlos Salinas de Gortari has sold off 150 state-owned companies in an aggressive privatization program, stabilizing the economy and resulting in almost $7 billion in foreign capital this year.
 VENEZUELA: A cut in taxes and tariffs by President Carlos Andres Perez returned economy to growth last year after a drop of 8 percent in 1989. The Gulf crisis and th rise in oil prices also helped, but added to Venezuela's perennial problem of excessive inflation.
 
THE LAGGARDS
 BRAZIL: The Latin American giant is struggling to end the days of excessive state employment and the habit of paying for government deficits by printing money. A freeze on bank accounts and wage and price control failed to halt inflation. A privatization program is struggling. Loss of confidence in President Fernando Collor dePello could cause severe inflation.
 PERU: Despite tight monetary controls, a refusal to raise Government salaries, layoffs of thousands of workers and broad deregulation, Peru is still struggling with recession, which is worsened by terrorism and drug trafficking. President Alberto Fujimori trying to gain investor confidence by settling disputes with three U.S. companies.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Banks are cutting interest rates on credit cards for some customers, but they would just as soon not advertise it. First National Bank of Chicago, Banc One and a growing number of others are beginning to offer cards with rates around 14 percent, far below the 19.8 percent that has been the standard. [Page A1.]
A bill that would let local governments regulate cable television prices has been delayed in the Senate and may not come up before Congress adjourns later this month. [D1.]
Earnings fell at J. C. Penney, the Limited and Nordstrom while May Department Stores posted a gain. Caldor had a loss. [D1.]
An R.T.C. official is being disciplined for trying to sell a property seized from a failed savings and loan for what he believed was a higher price than the Government would have otherwise received, according to Government officials and documents. [D10.]
Legislation to overhaul the banking system is expected to be introduced as early as today in the Senate and the House. [D20.],
 
Companies
Travelers agreed to sell Dillon, Read to a joint venture between the management of the old-line Wall Street investment house and Baring P.L.C., the venerable British merchant bank. [D1.] Baring's chairman, Peter Baring, has watched as one non-American investment bank after another has tried to break into the U.S. and reaped only losses and frustration. [D7.]
USAir cut fares 10 to 25 percent for travel to almost all its destinations between Jan. 7 and March 31. American, United and Continental Airlines will match the lower fares. [D1.]
A senior official of Kissinger Associates has denied a news report that Henry Kissinger recommended that B.C.C.I. hire a Washington firm to initiate a "public relations offensive" a day after the bank was indicted on charges of money laundering. [D2.]
Integrated Resources has tentatively agreed to be sold to Bankers Trust New York for $565 million. [D4.]
 
International
A look at Latin America's economic map shows big changes and the new economic religion includes terms like balanced budgets and privatization. [A1.]
Argentine President Carlos Saul Menem arrives in the U.S. today in hopes of enhancing his country's image. [D2.]
 
Markets
Stocks rose smartly and the Dow rose 11.85 points, to close at 3,054.11. [D10.]
A wave of overseas purchases helped lift Treasury prices. But most investors remained on the sidelines. [D16.] Yields on deposit accounts plummeted. [D8]
Platinum and other precious metals futures prices rose sharply in reaction to a two-day strike by South African miners. [D17.] The dollar was mixed. [D17.]
 
Technology
New systems will help to speed up data transmissions by computers, which may account for 80 percent of the traffic over the public telephone network within five years. [D9.]
A way of preserving sperm without refrigeration is being developed by a company that specializes in biotechnology patents. [D9.]
 
Today's Columns
Monetary Union offers Europe a cheap way to banish inflation and lower capital costs, a group of European economists said, Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Investing in pawnshops is considered by some Wall Street analysts as a superb bet on hard times. Market Place. [D1.]
Girgenti, Hughes, Butler & McDowell is buying Rubin Reid Noto & Ehrenthal. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D20.]

HEADLINE: Favored Credit Card Holders Quietly Given Lower Rates

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Banks are reducing the interest rates they charge on credit cards for some customers, but many bankers would just as soon not advertise it.
The rates are going down as the banks try to keep their best customers, many of whom have wondered why the interest rates on their bank cards had not fallen along with the prime rate, mortgage rates or the interest they receive on deposits. Frustrated by the stubbornly high rates, card holders have been doing comparison shopping for the best credit card deals and have been turning in their costliest cards. 
 The First National Bank of Chicago, Banc One of Columbus, Ohio, and a growing number of other banks now offer cards with annual interest rates of about 14 percent, far below the 19.8 percent that has been the standard at the largest banks for years.
 
Higher Annual Fees
 The availability of the lower rates is often jumbled, and sometimes the price of a rate cut is a higher annual fee. Many small banks that offer lower-rate cards do not advertise them outside their local market, while the largest banks that do advertise widely are trying to stick with higher-rate cards. Some banks are trumpeting lower rates to snare more customers, while others, like Citibank and First National of Chicago, are granting the lower rates only to their most creditworthy customers. First National is not taking any applications for the lower-rate cards and is not advertising them.
As the lucrative credit card business attracts new competitors each year, from the Universal Card issued by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to ones affiliated with the likes of the Ford Motor Company, banks face growing competition in a market already saturated with cards.
Many new rivals have tried to make their cards more attractive to consumers by touting no annual fees, or low fees, discount-buying programs and slightly lower interest rates.
And if competition was not enough, bankers are feeling increased pressure from Washington. Just yesterday, President Bush, noting the declines in other interest rates, said, "I'd frankly like to see the credit card rates down."
In New York for a $1,000-a-plate Republican fund-raising luncheon, Mr. Bush said lower credit card rates could help the economy by encouraging more consumer spending. Until now, the strongest criticism in Washington of high credit card rates had come from Democratic members of Congress like Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts.
"A little over a year ago, our consumer research showed growing interest for lower-rate cards," said Ray S. Costner, a senior vice president of the Wachovia Corporation, a big banking company in Winston-Salem, N.C. Wachovia currently offers three types of cards, including one that charges the prime lending rate plus 2.9 percentage points, or 10.4 percent -- but a higher-than-usual fee of $39.
Mr. Costner added, "We think a lot of people are coming to realize that they had too darn many credit cards, and are deciding to keep just one or two instead of four or five."
David Robertson, vice president of the Nilson Report, a newsletter for the credit card industry, said some banks were losing more than 10 percent of their customers annually to cards offered by competitors. "Many large banks are suffering because the rate at which they are losing customers has nearly doubled," he said.
"The banks can make money at lower interest rates," Mr. Robertson added. "They just can't offer the lower rates to everybody." He noted that it was now much cheaper for banks to keep good customers by lowering rates than it was to replace them by advertising for new customers or buying the credit card businesses of other banks.
 
Increased Losses
 Bankers have said they need to keep rates high to compensate for increased losses from defaults during the recession. Losses are running at about 5 percent of all card loans this year, up from 3.8 percent last year, according to the Nilson Report.
Because banks are loath to give up more of their highly profitable card business than necessary, the low-rate cards are not being offered to all customers. In Chicago, First National selected its best customers -- those with the lowest risk of default and who frequently pay interest on the cards -- and notified them of the lower rate a few weeks ago. The bank, the nation's sixth-largest issuer of credit cards, did not announce its action, but it was reported by American Banker, a trade newspaper.
First National reduced the rate for its best customers to the prime rate plus 6.9 percent, or 14.4 percent, down three percentage points from its previous rate. The prime rate, which is currently 7 1/2 percent, is set by banks as a benchmark for various consumer and business loan rates.
Many other major banks have been adopting lower rates as an option. Bank One Wisconsin of Milwaukee recently announced a 13.9 percent rate for existing and new customers to replace its old 18 percent rate.
In North Carolina, the credit card affiliates of the two largest local banking companies, Wachovia and the NCNB Corporation, each announced lower interest rates this year. They report a strong consumer response.
Since the Federal Government phased out the deductions for credit card interest payments, which were completely eliminated last year, consumers have become more careful shoppers when it comes to credit cards and interest charges.
"Consumer awareness of credit cards is at an all-time high," said Robert B. McKinley, president of RAM Research, a Frederick, Md., firm that publishes newsletters about the card industry for consumers and bankers.
Fleet Bank of Massachusetts, which is owned by Fleet/Norstar Financial Group of Providence, R.I., offered a new card in September -- with no annual fee -- to all customers. The card carries an interest rate of 12 percent for cash advances, but 17.9 percent for purchases.
The bank had been charging 17.9 percent for both cash and purchases. The lower rate was intended to attract customers who could borrow from Fleet to pay off other cards charging higher rates.
John A. Russell, a vice president of Banc One, said there was enough variation in consumer preferences that Banc One was experimenting with more than 10 types of credit cards, which have different mixes of interset rates and fees.
Besides the 13.9 percent rate Banc One offers nationally through its bank in Wisconsin, it also has cards that charge an 18 percent rate. And it has cards with a credit line tied to a second mortgage on the card holder's home, offering interest rates as low as half a percentage point above the prime rate, or 8 percent.
In addition to the card that is currently charging 10.4 percent, Wachovia offers a 14.98 percent card with a $25 fee and a 17.98 percent card with a $15 fee. The bank says it freely lets customers apply for any of the cards and to switch from card to card.
The continued dominance of the 19.8 percent rate "is not a case of price gouging," said Scott P. Marks, president of F.C.C. National Bank, the credit card affiliate of First National of Chicago. He noted that some of the bank's customers had benefited from falling interest rates because their cards were pegged to the prime lending rate. "There are 6,000 different issuers of cards in the country," he said. "It's a free market where there is room for lots of variety."

HEADLINE: Kissinger Firm Denies Reports of B.C.C.I. Link

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
A senior associate of Kissinger Associates Inc. has denied a report in The Boston Globe that Henry A. Kissinger recommended that the Bank of Credit and Commerce International hire a Washington firm to initiate a "public relations offensive" a day after the bank was indicted on charges of money laundering.
The Globe said it based its account on B.C.C.I. documents it had obtained.
Alan Stoga, senior associate of the New York-based economic consulting firm, said Monday in a telephone interview that "Henry never met or talked with them," and that nobody in his firm gave B.C.C.I. that advice. 
 "They approached us in the fall of '88," Mr. Stoga said. "We considered it and had some conversations, and in the end, in early January '89, we said 'no, we're not interested.'
 
Millions for Influence
 "We were never employed by them, and we are not in the habit of giving free advice."
B.C.C.I.'s wooing of Kissinger Associates was consistent with the bank's policy of spending millions around the world in efforts to influence government policy by enlisting powerful present, former and future government officials.
Mr. Kissinger, chairman of the firm, served as both Secretary of State and national security adviser in the Nixon Administration, and two of his firm's principals joined the Bush Administration in early 1989. Lawrence S. Eagleburger, formerly president of the firm, who was a top national security aide to Mr. Kissinger, is now Deputy Secretary of State. Brent Scowcroft, who was the firm's vice president and was President Gerald Ford's national security adviser, now has that same role in the Bush White House.
The documents reported by The Globe include a letter, dated Oct. 7, 1988, from Mr. Stoga to Abol Fazl Helmy, head of the bank's New York office, saying, "I enjoyed lunch yesterday and, even more, your suggestion that B.C.C.I. might be interested in developing a relationship with Kissinger Associates." With the letter, Mr. Stoga enclosed biographical sketches of the principals of Kissinger Associates, and said that "I am reluctant to be more specific, at least on paper, about the kinds of consulting projects we undertake for clients."
 
After the Indictment
 A day after the bank was indicted in Tampa, Fla., on Oct. 11, 1988, Mr. Helmy wrote Swaleh Naqvi, a high B.C.C.I. executive, that "I received a call today from Mr. Stoga, who informed me that Dr. Kissinger recommends that a public relations offensive be made by us and in that context has suggested using Burson-Marsteller, a highly reputable public relations firm that successfully dealt with the First Chicago crises last year." He continued, "Kissinger Associates Inc., have indicated that they shall be happy to use their personal contacts with the firm and make the necessary recommendations."
Mr. Stoga acknowledged sending the Oct. 7 letter but denied ever saying that Mr. Kissinger had recommended a public relations offensive or that it be handled by Burson-Marsteller.
Gary Auxier, executive vice president in Burson-Marsteller's office, said in a telephone interview that his firm did not represent B.C.C.I. and that "as far as I know, we were never approached."

HEADLINE: MOSCOW AID PLAN DYING IN CONGRESS

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
A plan to divert up to $1 billion from the Pentagon budget to aid the Soviet Union appeared all but dead today, the victim of political miscalculations by two of the most powerful lawmakers in Congress and a growing public perception that Washington is putting foreign aid ahead of domestic problems.
Efforts to salvage the Soviet proposal, which seemed headed for approval two weeks ago, were virtually exhausted today as the Bush Administration failed to offer a public endorsement of the plan. Democratic leaders in Congress had said that without that public support from the White House, they would drop the proposal rather than bear the political heat alone. 
 The House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, said today that he expected the proposal to be "postponed," clearing the way for final passage of the Pentagon's $291 billion budget bill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.
 
Colleagues Not Fully Consulted
 Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin and Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the plan's main architects and usually among the most astute deal makers and power brokers in Washington, did not fully consult with Democratic colleagues until the last minute. More importantly, they evidently failed to anticipate the storm of bipartisan criticism against retraining Soviet officers, among other things, when Americans were homeless and out of work.
The demise of the Soviet aid plan is a rare political embarrassment for Mr. Nunn and Mr. Aspin, both Democrats. Mr. Nunn is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee; Mr. Aspin leads the corresponding committee in the House.
Although both contended that United States security would be enhanced by using $1 billion to help the Soviet Union avoid further political instability and keep control of its 30,000 nuclear weapons, they never showed that the plan could lead to direct financial savings for Washington.
 
'A Down Payment
 "I look at this as a down payment on greater savings, but those savings are only really possible if the reform elements stay in power in the Soviet Union and continue to unwind their military-industrial complex," Mr. Aspin said.
The idea was condemned, and eventually undone, by legislators from both parties who argued that any money the Pentagon could spare should be spent in the United States. Opposition to the plan gained strength after last week's elections, particularly the Pennsylvania Senate race in which the Republican candidate and heavy favorite, former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, was upset by Harris Wofford, a Democrat who called for tackling domestic problems.
"It was very unfortunately caught up in a very, very bad time," Mr. Aspin said in an interview. "It was at a time when Democrats saw a nice opening to take on Bush for having too much priority on foreign policy and not enough domestic policy, but the Republicans did not want to be caught up in that."
In a desperation move last Thursday, Democratic supporters in the House and the Senate frantically tried to shift responsibility for the plan's fate to the Administration, with Senator Nunn complaining that the proposal had received "tepid and ineffectual White House support."
"It's too bad we can't get out in front of problems for a change," Mr. Nunn said in an interview today, warning against the spread of Soviet weapons around the world. "We're facing the breakout of the largest arsenal in the world, and people in economic distress will be selling things."
But the effort to defuse Republican opposition in Congress and give Democrats political cover to support the measure failed. Democrats ended up singed by the same fire they have used to brand Mr. Bush as a leader more interested in global summit meetings than unemployment.
Coming only days after the failed Soviet coup in August, Mr. Aspin's idea initially appeared to have some appeal: Transfer up to a $1 billion from the Pentagon budget for humanitarian aid to the Soviet Union, and help avert chaos in a splintering nation that has more than 30,000 nuclear weapons.
Beginning in early September, Mr. Aspin and Mr. Nunn quietly worked with a small group of staff members to build on Mr. Aspin's original idea to forge a relief package that would also clean up environmental damage caused by Soviet weapons plants and subsidize American businesses that invested in Soviet military conversion to civilian industries.
 
Scowcroft Backed Idea
 The two lawmakers also consulted with senior Administration officials, including Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, who privately endorsed the proposal.
As envisioned by the lawmakers, the plan would use Air Force planes to transport food and medical aid to the Soviet people this winter. It also suggested giving American companies economic incentives to invest in Soviet defense industries that converted to commericial businesses, and earmarkeding money for a joint United States-Soviet program to destroy nuclear and chemical weapons in the Soviet Union.
By late October, even Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who called Mr. Aspin's original idea "a serious mistake," was grudgingly won over, but only on the condition that the Pentagon had the authority to make the budget cuts and to decide how the money would be spent on the Soviets.
Supporters of the measure sought to include the Soviet aid plan in a compromise military budget bill that House and Senate negotiators had been working on since early September. Since the House and the Senate had approved conflicting military budgets before the abortive coup, the aid plan was not considered in the normal budget authorizing process. Lawmakers on the negotiating teams did not see final details of the aid plan until Mr. Nunn and Mr. Aspin tried on Oct. 31 to wrap up the conference committee's last outstanding issues.
Initially, Senate Republicans balked, but the uproar quickly spread to Democrats in both chambers.
"I was not consulted and I felt I should have been," said Representative Earl Hutto, a Florida Democrat who heads the House Armed Services subcommittee on military readiness.
Mr. Aspin said today it was "hard to have full consultation" when the measure was included in neither House or Senate version.
By early last week, the measure had also drawn criticism that it infringed on the prerogatives of the Congressional committees normally responsible for foreign aid.
"It ought to run through the regular authorization process," Representative Dante B. Fascell, a Florida Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said in an interview.
By late last week, voices like those of Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, were rare. "An opportunity comes along every few decades to reduce the threats to our security interests," Mr. Levin said in an interview. "This is not a gift to the Russians. If a relatively small expenditure can reduce the number of missiles and nuclear weapons floating around the Soviet Union, the American people's security is advanced."

HEADLINE: AGREEMENT IS NEAR ON MEASURE TO AID LONG-TERM JOBLESS

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Lawmakers from both parties and the Bush Administration moved to the brink of an agreement today on legislation to provide up to 20 weeks of additional unemployment benefits for about three million Americans out of work at least half a year.
The $5.1 billion plan is intended to pay for itself. And it seems likely to end more than three months of partisan arguments over how to aid the long-term jobless who have been unable to find employment in the continuing economic downturn. 
 "We have the makings of a deal" if the numbers add up, said Representative Robert H. Michel, the House Republican leader.
 
A Case Against Bush
 The Illinois Republican, who estimated the measure's cost at "$5.1 billion or so," said the Labor Department was analyzing the figures to make sure the benefits did not cost more than the bill would raise in revenue.
Since the Democrats began pushing the legislation in July, the issue of unemployment benefits appears to have helped them make a case against President Bush, who has all but announced his plans to run for President again in 1992, as interested only in foreign affairs and unconcerned about suffering Americans.
But continued delays in agreeing to a bill appear to be blunting that advantage. And even as White House aides were working on the benefits bill in Washington, Mr. Bush was in New York lashing out at Democrats, whom he referred to as "liberals," and what he said was their yearning to raise taxes. [Page A20.]
 
'It's About Time'
 Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Long Island Democrat who has been the leading House sponsor of the legislation, said tonight that if agreement was reached, "It's about time."
"The only winners in all of this will be the three million who have been waiting for a lot longer than they needed to for us to get our act together," he added.
House leaders said that if an agreement could be reached that would bring the measure substantial backing from Republicans, this bill might be quickly adopted by the House and the Senate. Mr. Michel said he hoped the bill could be sent to the White House by the end of the week.
Unlike two previous versions of the measure, which President Bush killed in August and October after contending they would raise the deficit, this bill is intended to pay for itself. It would increase estimated tax payments by some high-income taxpayers, continue deducting payments on unpaid student loans from tax refunds, and continue in 1996 a two-tenths of one percent surcharge on unemployment taxes paid by employers.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, said he was optimistic that the costs could be matched to the benefits. He and Mr. Michel met with Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Treasury SecretaryNicholas F. Brady, after Mr. Michel had the plan laid out for him by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
"We're getting close enough that with a little more work we'll get there," Mr. Darman said.
The Senate Democrats did not appear deeply involved in the political equation today. Senators George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, and Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who is chairman of the Finance Committee, argued at their party caucus today for a bill they offered last week that would offer Mr. Bush three ways to pay for benefits. But one senator said there was considerable criticism of that proposal at the caucus.
The Mitchell measure would give Mr. Bush the choice of paying for benefits by increasing the deficit, holding down foreign aid or using a method to finance the benefits similar to the one in the latest House bill.
 
A Temporary Measure
 The measure proposed by Mr. Rostenkowski, which would expire next August, would supplant an existing program of extended benefits whose terms are so stringent that even though the national unemployment rate was 6.8 percent in October, no workers in any state now qualify for benefits. Ordinary jobless benefits, which average $170 per week and cover about half of all workers, are limited to 26 weeks in most states.
No written summary or detailed briefing on the measure was offered by any of its advocates tonight. But Mr. Michel, Mr. Downey and various aides discussed it generally.
They said it would provide up to 20 weeks of extended unemployment benefits for workers in states with the highest unemployment rates. Jobless workers in a second tier of states, including New York and California, the nation's two largest states, would be eligible for 13 weeks of benefits. In all other states, long-term jobless workers would qualify for 6 weeks.
In about 32 states, Mr. Downey said, workers who had exhausted their unemployment benefits since March 1 and were still unemployed would be eligible for whatever level of benefits was allowed newly unemployed workers in their states.
The formulas by which different states would fit into different categories were not made public.
 
Arguments Ahead?
 The financing provisions in the bill were also not outlined in detail, and may face some arguments in the Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday, especially from Republicans there. But Mr. Michel said the Republicans who objected "are going to basically have to back off."
Lawmakers and aides did describe the bill's financial provisions in general terms:
The extension of the surtax on employers' unemployment tax contributions would bring in $900 million. The student loan withholding provision would raise $1.7 billion.
Another $2.6 billion would be raised by a change in the rules for estimating income tax. Most taxpayers with adjusted gross incomes of $75,000 or more whose income increases by $30,000 or more would be required to estimate their tax and make quarterly payments on the basis of the increased income. Under current law, they can estimate their tax based on the previous year's taxes, and then pay the balance on April 15 of the following year. This change would be a one-time bonus for the Treasury.
The bill would also put people who leave the military on an equal footing with people who leave civilian jobs. Ex-servicemen and women would be eligible for 26 weeks of benefits, instead of the current 13, and would be able to start collecting after one week, instead of the current four.
