HEADLINE: Transit Agency Asks $1.40 Fare Or a Rise in Subway and Bus Aid

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
The New York City Transit Authority set the stage yesterday for what officials say is an inevitable increase in the subway and bus fare in January, and then began haggling with legislative leaders over how much the fare would go up.
The authority formally recommended a rise of 25 cents, to $1.40, but at the same time said the increase could be smaller if the state agreed to provide additional subsidies. 
 The announcement served to alert the riding public that the days of the $1.15 fare -- adopted two years ago -- were numbered and to pressure city and state officials for additional help.
 
At Least a Dime on Jan. 1
 The Transit Authority had already warned that the current fare might rise at least 10 cents on Jan. 1, and possibly as much as 35 cents.
One argument for a $1.25 fare is that it would help reduce the fumbling for change that now annoys riders and leads to delays at booths.
But the Transit Authority said yesterday that its budget would require an increase to $1.40 unless Albany intervened. The budget was submitted to the authority's parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
The M.T.A. board is expected to vote on the proposed fare increase at a meeting on Dec. 20, said Tito Davila, an agency spokesman. The increase would take effect Jan. 1.
Over the next five weeks, the Transit Authority and the M.T.A. are expected to joust with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the State Legislature and City Hall in an effort to hold down the size of the increase. The jockeying began in earnest after the budget announcement yesterday, with some politicians openly questioning the Transit Authority's credibility and its motives.
"The obvious concern," said Senator Norman J. Levy, the Republican chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee, "is whether they are creating a horror story to try to stampede a source of revenue to close a deficit that may or may not exist."
But Alan F. Kiepper, the Transit Authority president, insisted yesterday that the deficit was very real.
The authority had estimated as recently as this summer that its deficit in the 1992 fiscal year would be $460 million, because of a decline in riders and a drop in subsidies from taxes on corporate profits and real-estate transactions. But Mr. Kiepper said yesterday that the authority had trimmed that figure to $263 million, in part by reducing operating expenses and its payroll through attrition. That figure includes a $251 million budget deficit plus additional money set aside for future expenses.
"We think we've done a diligent job at cutting costs," Mr. Kiepper said at a news conference yesterday. "It's up to a higher power to determine how the budget shall be balanced."
Mr. Kiepper's superior, Peter E. Stangl, the M.T.A.'s chairman, endorsed the budget and raised the specter that the fare could go even higher. The M.T.A. previously proposed a five-year, $10.6 billion construction and improvement plan and the Legislature has yet to respond to it.
Mr. Stangl said yesterday that unless Albany acted on the construction proposal, the M.T.A. would be forced to finance more of the plan itself through fares even higher than $1.40.
"The Transit Authority has proposed a lean budget that cuts costs through significant reductions in personnel while preserving vital transportation services for our customers," Mr. Stangl said in a statement. "Without additional help from Albany, the increase could be more severe."
 
Cuomo Is Unconvinced
 Mary Ann Crotty, a spokeswoman for Governor Cuomo, said yesterday that the Governor was encouraged that the Transit Authority had reduced its estimated budget gap. But Ms. Crotty said the Governor did not endorse the $1.40 fare, saying other ways might be found to close the deficit further.
"They have to prove to him why they need the fare increase," she said.
Mayor David N. Dinkins is opposed to a $1.40 fare, said a spokesman, Jeff Maclin, who added that the Mayor would instruct his representatives on the M.T.A. board to find an alternative to such a large increase.
Groups representing subway and bus riders also opposed the 25-cent fare increase.
 
History of Fare Retreats
 "A $1.40 fare is too high because it's too much for people to pay, especially in this time of economic hardship," said Beverly Dolinsky, executive director of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee, a state-mandated oversight board for the M.T.A.
At least four times in the last nine years, the Transit Authority and the M.T.A. have proposed large fare increases, only to retreat after legislative action was taken or opposition was mounted.
In 1986, for example, the agencies were struggling to win support for a five-year, $8.6 billion capital plan for construction and improvement. The M.T.A. proposed raising the fare to as much as $1.35, from $1. Three days later, the Legislature extended an existing tax and agreed to the capital plan. The fare remained at $1.
In 1989, the Transit Authority asked the M.T.A. to raise the fare to $1.25, from $1, but it backed down in the face of fierce criticism from transit riders, the Governor and other political officials. The M.T.A. eventually approved an increase to $1.15, which took effect Jan. 1, 1990.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
FARE COULD RISE TO $1.40 NEXT YEAR
The battle over how much the New York City subway fare will increase next year moved into high gear as the Transit Authority recommended a rise of 25 cents, to $1.40, unless the state provides additional subsidies. Page A1.
 
DOCTORS WALK THE PICKET LINE
More than 300 senior doctors began walking picket lines at the Woodhull hospital in Brooklyn in what is believed to be the first strike by staff doctors anywhere in the country. At the heart of the walkout are two issues at the center of health care debates throughout the country: money and quality of care. Page A1.
 
FAR FROM HOME, 'FINALLY HOME'
To the buoyant greeting of a chorus of cleaning women and airport mechanics, Mayor David N. Dinkins landed on South African soil, embraced his hero, Nelson Mandela, and proclaimed himself "finally home." Page B3.
 
ILLEGAL SECURITY PATROLS IN THE BRONX
The Nighthawks Protection Agency, known for recruiting the city's toughest former gang members and some former convicts, was illegally patroling part of a South Bronx shopping plaza where a 17-year-old was fatally shot, officials say. Detectives say they are investigating whether the shooting was committed by a security guard -- possibly a Nighthawk. Page B3.
 
ASSEMBLY SPEAKER'S TRIAL BEGINS
Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and his longtime law partner "lined their own pockets at the expense of their own clients," a Federal prosecutor charged in his opening statement. Page B3.
 
JUDGE EXAMINES KAHANE JURY SELECTION
The judge in the Kahane murder trial said there was strong evidence that defense lawyers had deliberately excluded whites from the jury, and he ordered both the defense and the prosecution to demonstrate that race had not been a factor in choosing jurors. Page B2.

HEADLINE: Aide in Duke Campaign Resigns, Questioning the Candidate's Piety

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 12

 BODY:
As he tried to mobilize supporters in southern Louisiana today, State Representative David Duke found himself on the defensive. One of his top aides announced that he was quitting because he no longer believed Mr. Duke's assertions that a Christian conversion had caused him to reject views he held as a Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi leader.
Mr. Duke's opponent, former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, had only one public appearance on his schedule today, a speech before a women's group, as he continued to wage a campaign that relies heavily on television advertising. 
 The defection of the Duke aide, Bob Hawks, who had served as state coordinator for the campaign, insured that Mr. Duke's religious beliefs would remain a major issue in the race.
Before leaving for his home in Memphis this morning, Mr. Hawks, a former member of the Tennessee Legislature, told reporters, "I have thoroughly satisfied myself that David's relationship with Jesus is not as he portrays it to be when he is on stage center trying to obtain public support."
 
Doubts Arise on Sincerity
 Mr. Hawks said he began to doubt Mr. Duke's assertions when he realized that he had never seen the candidate read the Bible or pray. He said he became convinced that Mr. Duke's comments were false when Mr. Duke said he belonged to a church that did not exist.
As he campaigned in Jennings and Lake Charles today, Mr. Duke insisted that Mr. Hawks, who had volunteered his services to the campaign last summer, had no knowledge of his religious practices. Mr. Duke said Mr. Hawks was an agent of the Edwards campaign, an assertion that Mr. Edwards and Mr. Hawks denied.
Conservative Christians are a major element of the swing vote in this election. They accounted for most of the 5 percent of the vote that went to United States Representative Clyde C. Holloway in the nonpartisan primary on Oct. 19 as well as some supporters of the incumbent, Gov. Buddy Roemer.
Both Mr. Duke and Mr. Edwards find themselves in a situation in which they have to try to lure voters who are unenthusiastic about the choice that will be on the ballot Saturday. But the rivals are applying very different strategies to the same task.
Mr. Duke, a Republican, is repeatedly reminding voters of the scandals that once engulfed Mr. Edwards, while portraying himself as the hapless victim of a smear campaign.
In a television advertisement, Mr. Duke says, "Have you ever heard such weeping and gnashing of teeth?"
"The news media," he said, "have given up any pretense of fair play. The liberals have gone ballistic. The special interests have gone mad. The politicians who play to them are lining up on cue."
He continues: "Principles lie abandoned, and hypocrisy rules the day. I raise issues that must be discussed and get back venom instead. Try a little experiment. Next time you hear them accuse me of intolerance and hatred, notice who is doing the shouting."
Mr. Edwards, a Democrat who served three terms as Governor between 1971 and 1987, is relying on surrogates to constantly remind voters of Mr. Duke's past as a neo-Nazi and leader of the Ku Klux Klan. Mr. Edwards depicts himself, meanwhile, as the veteran politician come back to do battle once more for an array of constituencies that have come together because of their distaste for Mr. Duke and their fear of what his election would do to the state's economy.
A survey of television stations in six Louisiana cities showed that the Edwards campaign is spending at least twice as much on television advertisements as the Duke campaign.
Emphasizing the economy as an issue in one Edwards commercial, an announcer says, "Edwin Edwards has a proven record of attracting new jobs to Louisiana; the skills to work with business with labor and the legislature to help put Louisiana back to work again."
Then the commercial offers an implicit warning to those who might cast a protest vote for Mr. Duke, with the announcer saying, "So if we want to send a message to the world with our election let's make sure it is the message we want to send." It closes with the printed message: "Louisiana wants jobs."
 
Overflow Crowds
 With an appearance last Friday night in Monroe, Mr. Duke began a series of seven rallies in major cities. So far, he has drawn overflow crowds, each about 1,000 people, and he has been greeted with the wild exuberance normally accorded to a rock star.
Each rally begins with a long slide show that lacks the polish of a professional production. It alternates between pictures of the Louisiana countryside that could have come from a tourism promotion and snapshots of Mr. Duke posed in hunting gear and on the campaign trail.
While Mr. Duke has rallied his supporters in rented halls, Mr. Edwards has held a series of highly effective events to pay for his media campaign. Last Saturday, about 3,000 people filled a hotel ballroom at $500 a ticket and feasted on crab and roast beef.
Jeff Giles, a direct mail specialist with close ties to the Republican Party and conservative Christian leaders said that predicting the impact of Mr. Hawks's defection on conservative Christians is difficult because "Duke and Edwards are in the same boat."
He went on: "The Christian voters dislike Edwin Edwards because of his gambling and the corruption, but they are also uncomfortable with David Duke's past even though Duke speaks to their issues."

HEADLINE: BUSH STRIKES BACK AT 'TIRED LIBERALS'

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
The liberals are back, at least as far as George Bush is concerned.
Still battling troublesome public opinion polls and groping for ways to strike back at the Democrats, the President took up a weapon yesterday that had proved extremely potent in his 1988 campaign: painting himself as the guardian of the political center and the Democrats as far-out liberals. 
 In a speech at a $2.2 million fund-raising event at the New York Hilton that seemed to try out virtually every campaign theme the Republicans are preparing for 1992, Mr. Bush referred to the leadership in Congress and the Democrats in general as "liberals" more than 10 times in a 25-minute speech, and as "Democrats" only once or twice.
 
Can't Trust Democrats, He Says
 America, Mr. Bush declared, is "tired of hearing a liberal litany." The "liberal leadership" in Congress, he said, is blocking his efforts to bring the country out of an economic slowdown. Proponents of the "tired old liberal mindset" on Capitol Hill, the President asserted, carped and criticized while he made America into "the pre-eminent power" in the world.
The "liberals," said a President who is trying to overcome criticism that he spends too much time on diplomacy and not enough on fighting the economic downturn, do not understand that foreign policy and domestic concerns are linked. And they cannot be trusted to run the country while the President is abroad, he said.
"You see, I saw that movie, 'Home Alone' and I owe it to the American taxpayer to make sure Congress never stays home alone," Mr. Bush said, explaining his decision to cancel a trip to the Far East that had been scheduled for later this month.
The White House had come to New York trying to play down the importance of opinion surveys that suggest Mr. Bush was still politically vulnerable on domestic issues and has yet to recover from a slide in his approval rating that began after the flush of victory in the Persian Gulf. The luncheon speech was clearly intended as an old-fashioned tub-thumper to rally the party faithful.
Asserting that he had tried to extend a bipartisan hand to Capitol Hill, only to be met with a storm of criticism, Mr. Bush said, "I'm not going to be the javelin catcher for the liberals in Congress anymore."
But the speech, his third at a fund-raising event for his 1992 campaign in about 10 days, also left the impression of a candidate groping for effective themes, an impression bolstered by the relative lack of loud or sustained applause from a partisan crowd that paid $1,000 apiece to attend the event.
Outside the hotel, a small knot of protesters sought to remind Mr. Bush of two domestic political issues that are likely to trouble his re-election candidacy: abortion and AIDS.
Inside, Mr. Bush ran through a standard Republican list of accusations against the Democrats: They are soft on crime, weak on foreign policy, irresponsible on government spending and yearning to raise taxes.
Apart from the tension between domestic priorities and foreign policy, two other themes kept bobbing up like markers in the political currents of the 1992 race: the Persian Gulf and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York.
Although Mr. Bush and the other lunchtime speakers never mentioned him by name, they referred several times to the possibility that Mr. Cuomo might seek the Democratic Presidential nomination. Indeed, the President's schedule in New York, which included a meeting with prominent figures in the New York Jewish community, seemed at least in part aimed at shoring up the President's support here in anticipation of a Cuomo campaign.
Sounding one theme, the Persian Gulf, that the Republicans intend to use against Mr. Cuomo if he runs, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, said: "One unnamed Governor, who may or may not be running for President, said he thought we should be reasonable, give Saddam just a little oil or a little land. But everyone knows you can't appease a glutton with one piece of pie."
The President took up Mr. D'Amato's theme as he sought to turn the issue of foreign policy against the Democrats.
He said: "We have a Congress that is out of step with the times and out of touch with the heartbeat of the American people. They're pushing the same old tired liberal agenda to a country that is hungry to build on what we've done abroad and bring that to success here at home."

HEADLINE: Study Finds Heart Treatment Differs for Men and Women

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., Nov. 12

 BODY:
Men are twice as likely as women to receive newer life-saving treatments for heart attacks, a study that was reported here today has found.
The study involved nearly 5,000 men and women treated for heart attacks in 19 hospitals in the Seattle area since 1988. It was reported at a meeting of the American Heart Association. 
 In the study, 26 percent of the 3,232 men with heart attacks received injections of "clot buster" drugs like streptokinase and TPA that can stop heart attacks in progress. Of the 1,659 women, 14 percent received treatment with the drugs.
Also, more men underwent a procedure to open up coronary arteries that had been narrowed by deposits of fat. The procedure, known as angioplasty, involves inserting a tube with a balloon at the tip. The balloon is inflated to flatten the fatty deposits that block the arteries. Of the men, 27 percent received such treatment, as against 14 percent of the women.
 
Disturbing Findings
 Researchers from the University of Washington who conducted the study called the findings disturbing because they "call into question whether women are being appropriately treated for heart attacks."
The researchers said they could not explain why the gap between men and women existed and called for new studies to pinpoint the factors. One possible explanation is that the initial studies proving the value of the treatments were carried out chiefly in men.
The therapies are considered equally effective for men and women, however, and the study found no difference in survival rates between the men and women who received them.
Heart disease is the leading killer of Americans. Of the 500,000 Americans who die of heart attacks each year, about 48 percent are women.
 
Missing a Diagnosis
 The study reported today was intended to provide a profile of patients who were treated for heart attacks and the therapies they received.
"There may be a true bias," said Dr. Douglas Weaver, a co-author of the study. But, he added, "it may be that there is something different about the way women experience heart attacks, something that fools physicians into coming to the wrong conclusion, so that the diagnosis of heart attack is initially missed and thus not treated."
Cardiologists say that the symptoms of a heart attack are less apparent in many women; for example, fewer women than men in the Seattle study had angina. Women therefore may delay seeking medical treatment or the diagnosis may be delayed.
But clot-buster drugs are beneficial only if injected within the first few hours after a heart attack. If the diagnosis is delayed, the women may have missed the "window" for treatment, the researchers said.
The study found no difference for coronary bypass surgery. But it said women were twice as likely as men to die from the operation, in which an artery or vein is taken from elsewhere in the body to bypass the blocked coronary artery.
 
Benefit for Older Patients
 In a related report, researchers from Oxford, England, found that heart attack victims who are 70 years and older can benefit from clot-buster drugs. In the past, many doctors have not given such drugs to elderly patients because of the risks of bleeding and strokes. But Dr. Rory Collins of the Radcliffe Infirmary in Oxford said data from the studies showed that the drug was safe in the elderly and reduced the risk of death from heart attacks by 4 percent.
In another study, researchers from Emory University in Atlanta found that complications from balloon angioplasty occurred more often when the balloon was inflated more than twice. Doctors often do several inflations to remove as much blockage as possible. The study of 699 patients who underwent the procedure at Emory from 1985 to 1990 found that formation of a new blockage increased proportionately with the number of inflations. New blockages occurred in 42 percent of those receiving one or two inflations. For those receiving three or four inflations, new blockages occurred in 60 percent. More than six inflations led to a complication rate of 68 percent.
But repeated angioplasty did not significantly lower survival rates. A related study from Emory found that the five-year survival rate for 1,793 patients was 96 percent for those who did not experience a new blockage and was was 94 percent among 1,120 patients who underwent a second angioplasty.

HEADLINE: Business and Labor Call for Health Tax

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
A coalition of big businesses and labor unions proposed today to guarantee access to health care for all Americans by requiring employers either to provide health insurance or to pay a new Federal tax that would finance coverage for the uninsured.
The proposal adds to the growing debate on alternative forms of national health coverage and increases political pressure on the Bush Administration to come up with its own proposal to assist the 34 million Americans who have no health insurance. 
 Under the proposal, a new agency, with representatives from government, business and labor, would set an overall annual goal for national health spending and would set uniform rates to be paid to all suppliers of medical goods and services, including doctors and hospitals. The rates would have the force of law.
The proposal came from the National Leadership Coalition for Health Care Reform, which said its members included the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the Chrysler Corporation, the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the LTV Corporation, the Lockheed Corporation, Safeway Stores Inc., the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the Xerox Corporation.
 
Similar to Legislation
 The coalition's proposal resembles a bill introduced in June by Democratic Senators, including George J. Mitchell of Maine and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, but it has more stringent measures to control health costs.
Under the coalition's proposal, all employers would offer health insurance to their employees or would pay a tax equal to 7 percent of their payroll. The Federal Government would use the money from that tax to buy private health insurance for people who do not receive coverage through an employer.
Some businesses involved in the coalition's deliberations refused to endorse its recommendations, saying they objected to its price controls, Government mandates and new taxes.
Herb Linnen, a spokesman for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said the coalition had made a major contribution to discussion of the nation's health-care problems. But he said that A.T.&T. had withdrawn from the coalition because the company "does not support mandates on all employers to provide health insurance coverage to employees, or a mandatory level of employer financial support for such a program, or a mandatory design for covered services."
But heavy-manufacturing companies and some retailers say the proposal would relieve them from the crushing burden of health costs for employees and retirees. Such costs, they say, often make their goods uncompetitive in world markets.
"We must accept the need for a stronger Federal role in health care," Walter F. Williams, chairman of Bethlehem Steel, said today at a news conference announcing the coalition's proposal. He said that health costs for Bethlehem Steel shot up 26 percent from 1989 to 1990, reaching a total of $205 million, even though the company tried to control costs.
Former Presidents Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, were honorary co-chairmen of the coalition. In a letter of endorsement, Mr. Ford said its proposal "steers a middle course between drastic measures (such as national health insurance) and ineffective ones (such as just tinkering with the present system)."
The coalition said its recommendations were supported by the American Federation of Teachers, the American Nurses Association, the Service Employees International Union, the United Food and Commercial Workers Union and the United Steelworkers of America, among other groups.
But Carolyn E. Miller, a lobbyist for the National Federation of Independent Business, which represents 550,000 small businesses, criticized the coalition's proposal as "a very simplistic approach to a very complex problem." She said the proposal's new taxes and requirements would impose new costs on small businesses, forcing them to lay off employees and, in some cases, to cease operations.
"This proposal comes from tired old industries that gave away the store to their workers by providing health benefits in lieu of wages," Ms. Miller said. "Now they face stiff competition in this country and abroad. They're in trouble, and if their proposal were adopted, the rest of us would be in trouble, too."
Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,400 investor-owned hospitals, said: "Most members of the business community are well aware of the dangers of price controls, especially those on one sector of the economy."
"Such controls would inevitably have an adverse effect on the quality of health care," Mr. Bromberg said.

HEADLINE: Businesses in Louisiana Fear Duke

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Along with issues of race and religion, right and wrong, sin and redemption, the Louisiana gubernatorial race between Edwin W. Edwards and David Duke is increasingly focusing on something more mundane -- dollars and cents.
Among business people, particularly in New Orleans, which lives and dies on tourism, there is something approaching panic about what a victory by Mr. Duke, a Republican State Representative who is also a former Ku Klux Klan leader, could mean for the state's sagging economy. 
 "Some people said that David Duke will hurt the New Orleans convention industry," said Dave Dixon a French Quarter antiques and art dealer and civic promoter. "That's nonsense. He won't hurt the convention industry; he will eliminate it."
Beverly Gianna, director of public relations for the Greater New Orleans Tourist and Convention Commission, said 15 organizations, whose conventions would bring in about $87 million, have postponed their decisions until after Saturday's election.
 
Business Backs Edwards
 Tourism organizations and other business groups have mounted aggressive public relations efforts on behalf of Mr. Edwards, a former Governor who served three terms. Individual businessmen have organized letter-writing and phone-bank networks on his behalf.
Virtually all of the state's past and present major public officials, including former Gov. Dave Treen and Gov. Buddy Roemer, have called for a vote for Mr. Edwards, a Democrat, on economic grounds. Mr. Roemer, a Republican like Mr. Treen, said a victory by Mr. Duke would be "death for the state."
Mr. Duke and his supporters say that kind of talk is simply a scare tactic, which could aid his campaign in the end as voters rebel at the idea that their choice should be dictated by outsiders. And Mr. Duke's spokesman, Howie Farrell, said Mr. Edwards's long stewardship of Louisiana's economy is the best reason to cast a ballot for Mr. Duke.
"Fortune magazine said last month Louisiana was last for business opportunity of all the states in the U.S," Mr. Farrell said. "So can we do any worse than last?" The magazine ranked New Orleans 50th in business climate in a survey of 50 cities.
 
Economy Still Frail
 Many experts say Louisiana's fragile economy, which has still not stabilized after the collapse of the oil industry in the early 1980's, is precisely why a victory by Mr. Duke could have such impact. To many, the spectacle of the race between a lifelong racial extremist and a former Governor who survived two racketeering trials has already given the state an economic jolt. A victory by Mr. Duke, they say, would torpedo the recovery that has been starting to take hold.
"There are people who are going to redline our businesses," said Jim Bob Moffett, chairman of Freeport-McMoran, a New Orleans-based energy company. "We are going to be X-rated, and we're not going to get our fair shake to try to continue this economic recovery."
Much of what could happen after a victory by Mr. Duke is speculative. And Mr. Farrell said much of the state's economy base would be unaffected.
 
Waiting for the Election
 "We're still going to have the Port of New Orleans and the Mississippi River," he said. "We're still going to be centrally located on the Gulf of Mexico. We're still going to be one of the premier ports for import and export. That's not going to move to Utah if David Duke is elected."
But experts say New Orleans's $2.3 billion-dollar-a-year tourism industry is particularly vulnerable because it is overwhelmingly dominated by conventions, as opposed to a city like Orlando, Fla., which has a higher percentage of vacationing individuals and families.
Mr. Dixon, who is spending $35,000 to $40,000 of his own money on radio advertisements about the economic impact a Duke victory would have, said that New Orleans could lose 75 percent of its tourism business and that its Superdome would lose any chance of getting Super Bowls, college basketball championships and other big events.
Tim Ryan, an economist at the University of New Orleans, estimated the impact of a Duke victory at $1.8 billion -- $600 million in convention and tourism business and its ripple effects and "a $1.2 billion chilling effect on new investment."
The concern is statewide. Officials in Shreveport, who are bidding with eight other cities for a McDonnell-Douglas plant that would employ 7,000 workers, worry that Mr. Duke's election would ruin their chances of getting the plant.
Jack Shaffer, managing director of Sonnenblich Goldman Inc., the largest lender in the United States for major real estate projects, said his firm would stay out of Louisiana if Mr. Duke was elected.
Pres Kabacoff, president of Historic Restorations Inc., a New Orleans real estate development company, said a meeting last week with about 100 businessmen brought out stories about the impact just of Mr. Duke's presence in the runoff. "Several people told stories about projects that have been put on hold," he said.
 
Roemer's Loss Is Lamented
 Economic development experts say that neither candidate is likely to do as much for the state's image as Buddy Roemer, who failed to make the runoff after one term as Governor.
But most say the election of Mr. Duke, the signals it would send and the degree of turmoil that could ensue would have the most potential to scare off industry.
"You have the problem of corporations who simply take Louisiana off their list because it's too unpredictable, it's too controversial," said Doug Ross, senior consultant with the Corporation for Enterprise Development, a not-for-profit research organization dealing with economic development strategies. "Unless you're in the extraction of oil or in petrochemicals, where you need to be near the source, there are few other compelling reasons for being in Louisiana as opposed to some other part of the South."
 
What Arizona Lost
 But Mr. Farrell, Mr. Duke's spokesman, said talk of canceled conventions was "smoke and mirrors." Alluding to the controversy in Arizona, which was the target of boycott threats after Gov. Evan Meacham rescinded the state holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1987, he said: "The convention scare was used against Arizona. They had immediate cancellations of some conventions, and they were immediately replaced by other conventions. They had no net loss of conventions."
Arizona officials tell a different story. The state has lost the 1993 Super Bowl, originally scheduled for Tempe, whose effect on the state has been estimated at $125 million to $150 million. And officials say the state has also lost 148 conventions and gatherings, which would have brought in about $77 million.
"I can't tell you if Duke's election will have an impact on New Orleans," said Dave Radcliffe, chief executive officer of the Phoenix and Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau. "I can tell you the controversy in Arizona did have some impact."
Mr. Duke announced during an interview on "Larry King Live" that he had letters from billion-dollar corporations that said they were looking forward to doing business with him. But when asked to provide names, he declined, saying that the companies wanted their names left confidential.
 
The 'Outsider' Issue
 Still, it is not entirely clear which way the economic issue will cut. Mr. Duke has used criticism from outsiders in the past to mobilize support within the state. "People don't want outsiders coming in here and intimidating them, using terrorist tactics to try to coerce a vote," Mr. Farrell said.
Some critics see something unsettling in the idea that it may take an economic issue rather than a referendum on his ideology and background to defeat Mr. Duke. "I'd like to get a victory for the right reasons, but I think it's so important to defeat Duke, I'll take it whatever way it comes," said Lawrence Powell, a history professor at Tulane University.

HEADLINE: Sentiment Grows in Washington for Shift in U.S. Zaire Policy

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
In Congress and the Bush Administration there is now broad agreement that the United States must press for the installation of a transitional government in Zaire if the country is to be saved from further violence and economic ruin. There is also a consensus that the interim Government should be led by a newly unified political opposition.
Where Congress and the Administration differ is over the immediate fate of President Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's ruler for 26 years. Both sides agree, however, that his Government has lost all legitimacy and is out of step with the growth of democracy throughout Africa. 
 Today, Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on African affairs, sought to force the debate on President Mobutu's future into the open by asking the Administration to persuade him to leave Zaire, at least temporarily, after turning power over to an interim Government.
 
'Very Grim Times'
 "There is a general feeling that we're facing some very grim times in Zaire," Senator Simon said in an interview. "One of these days we're going to have people in the streets either celebrating an election or causing chaos. We have to be more firmly on the side of saying we need a new government. Let's get people into the streets for constructive reasons."
Senator Simon said Administration officials, and Republican legislators involved in African affairs, have been remarkably forthcoming in their critcism of the Mobutu Government.
"What I'm trying to do is push them a little further," the Senator said.
A resolution similar to Senator Simon's call is working its way through the House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee. A Congressional staff member said today that the moves in both houses are prompted by a sense that the Administration has allowed President Mobutu to believe that Washington will not press for his ouster or exile.
Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, told Senator Simon's subcommittee on Nov. 6 that "the best hope for Zaire is now genuine power-sharing between President Mobutu and the opposition." But he also said that the Mobutu Government "had lost the legitimacy to govern Zaire during the transition to democracy."
And he acknowledged that the situation in the central African nation was very critical, two months after rampaging troops ran wild in several cities, looting and killing at least 100, possibly more than 200, people.
"Zaire still does not have a functioning government, there is no consistent control over the military, the economic catastrophe continues and the threat of national disintegration looms larger every day," Mr. Cohen told the Senate subcommittee before leaving on a trip to Africa.
 
Foreigners Flee Country
 Thousands of foreigners have fled the country, leaving embassies operating with skeleton staffs, businesses abandoned and Zaire's copper and cobalt mining industries stripped of overseas experts. French and Belgian troops arrived to protect and evacuate their citizens. Zaire was formerly the Belgian Congo.
The violence that erupted in September came not long after Mobutu loyalists packed a conference called for August to allow all parties to discuss a new political order for Zaire. President Mobutu, bowing to opposition pressure, appointed a political foe, Etienne Tshisekedi, to the prime ministership in late September, but the experiment collapsed within a month. Bernardin Mungul-Diaka, named to replace him, was denounced and disowned by the opposition of which he said he was a member.
Mr. Mungul-Diaka has since announced that he will reconvene a national political conference. Mr. Tshisekedi's followers have since established an alternative government.
 
Military Aid Cut Off
 Congress took the lead in forcing policy changes on Zaire more than a year ago, when President Mobutu first showed signs of being unwilling to grant the political freedoms he promised in April 1990. Military aid was cut off, although economic and humanitarian assistance has continued to reach the country through nongovernmental organizations.
With further scope for action limited, and with Zaire becoming increasingly unstable, members of Congress say that their tactic now must be to force policy action from the Administration. Mr. Cohen in his testimony said American officials had been meeting with Belgian and other European officials to discuss possible action, while awaiting news of the promised reconvened national convention.
Criticism of Bush Administration policy statements on Zaire is not confined to Democrats. Today Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, said he had joined forces with those who think that President Mobutu must go immediately. Mr. Burton was once a supporter of President Mobutu, who was aiding Jonas Savimbi's United States-backed rebel faction against the leftist government of Angola. Mr. Burton says he still believes that the Mobutu Government helped bring peace to Angola, where Mr. Savimbi has put down arms and is now preparing to join in contesting national elections.
"But Mobutu's excesses and his obvious lack of concern for the people of his country have led me to the conclusion that he must go," Mr. Burton said. "The support we have given him in the past has got to end. His country is in chaos. The people want change."

HEADLINE: Interns See Washington as Key to Post-College Job

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
For an increasing number of college students, internships in Washington provide the crowbar to pry open access to shrinking job opportunities after graduation.
As a result, college-sponsored internship programs that give academic credit for jobs in Washington during the semester, at costs comparable to that of living and going to classes on campus, are growing in size and popularity. The programs help students avoid the problem of the cost of living in Washington while working for an intern's meager salary that in the past barred many students from being able to make acquaintances and get practical job experience during summer vacations, let alone during an academic term. 
 Some colleges and universities run programs offering students a semester in Washington when they live in a group setting and take classes from adjunct faculty members in addition to working for a Government office or private-interest organization. Other institutions, with fewer resources, arrange internships for credit through a group like The Washington Center, a not-for-profit organization that provides classes and finds jobs and housing for students from hundreds of colleges across the country.
Although no single organization keeps a count of the number of programs, all the program directors contacted agreed that internships for credit have become more popular in these harder economic times, a trend reflected in the growing numbers of applicants with better credentials. Judy Carbone, program coordinator for Boston University's Washington internship program, said, "For this spring, we're seeing students with much higher G.P.A.'s" as well as an increase in the number of students expressing interest in the program.
But some educators are concerned about the emphasis these programs place on practical experience over liberal arts education. Many also dispute the merits of giving academic credit to students who could end up faxing and filing for 40 hours a week.
Jeff Crawford, a senior from Stockton State College in Pomona, N.J., said his job with Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of New Jersey, entails "getting the mail, processing it, responding to constituents who have complaints and problems back home" and occasionally going to hearings to listen and take notes..
 
'Your Utmost Attention'
 And Rachelle St. Louis a senior psychology major at Montclair State College in Montclair, N.J., said that although she does take one class "your job definitely gets your utmost attention."
While Ms. Carbone said "getting full-time substantive work experience" was the main incentive for students to work in Washington for a semester, she added that Boston University's program was structured to avoid becoming purely a resume-building service. The 45 students in the program get a full semester's credit for a full-time internship plus three classes on policy-related topics.
Ms. Carbone said, "All in all, it's much more rigorous and more time-consuming than going to school on campus."
Mr. Crawford, the Stockton State student, said he was taking two classes on top of his full-time job: one class is about legal writing and trial advocacy, taught by an adjunct professor from a local law school; the other consists of writing a four-page paper once a week on difference places in Washington, like museums or monuments, and sending it to Stockton State for a professor to grade.
The Washington Center, through which his internship was arranged, promises that the 250 to 300 interns for whom the center finds jobs every semester will not spend more than 20 percent of their time doing clerical work.
But skepticism about clerical chores is a main reason that Georgetown University in Washington does not have an internship program, said Claire Carey, assistant dean of the College of Arts and Sciences. "We believe that just letting students go off on their own is not a good idea in terms of keeping track of an academic product," she said.
Many students argue that today's sagging economy demands that they be practical -- a strictly liberal arts education just does not leap out from a resume, they say, the way working in the Office of Management and Budget does. And then there are the contacts. As Mr. Crawford explained, "If you don't have access to people, doors get slammed, especially in this job market."
Figures are not available for the number of students who actually get job offers directly because of their experience in Washington, but anecdotal evidence suggests the numbers are high.
Amanda Fuchs, a Boston University senior who worked for Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, as an assistant to his press secretary, was asked to come back in the summer as a paid intern. She did, and when the professional press secretary left, Miss Fuchs filled in until Mr. Wyden hired someone else permanently.
Miss Fuchs said the experience and contacts she made were valuable and she was "hoping to go back to Washington" after graduating this spring.

Hughes entailed "getting the mail, processing it, responding to constituents who have complaints and problems back home" and occasionally going to hearings to listen and take notes. (Patrice Gilbert for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Missouri's Rejection of Education Plan Is Seen as Bad Omen

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Missouri voters used last week's elections to make a decisive statement about education spending, rejecting a $385 million package that would have been financed by higher taxes. But in the only other state with an education measure on the ballot, Texans approved a $300 million increase for a college loan program.
Education analysts saw the Missouri vote as a significant blow to the national movement to improve school programs by raising more money. Voter backlash toward higher taxes finally materialized in the voting in Missouri, analysts said, after two recent efforts to cut spending failed. Citizen groups in Nebraska last year and in Oklahoma last month got measures on the ballot to repeal expensive state education plans, but both measures lost. 
 Not only was the Missouri referendum's failure largely unexpected, but the margin of defeat, 34 percentage points, also surprised state education and elected officials. Many Missouri officials had said they expected the measure to pass narrowly.
"The measure was slaughtered," said Jim Morris, a spokesman for Robert Bartman, the Missouri Education Commissioner. "The sentiment seems to be people aren't interested in talking about taxes right now, even for education."
Several groups opposed to the Missouri plan said they were not against higher taxes for education but were protesting that state mental health programs and other state agencies, hobbled by recession-induced budget cuts, would not receive a share of the proposed tax increase. Others opposed the plan largely because it resulted in higher taxes. The plan won approval in only two of the state's 115 counties.
The proposal would have raised $385 million from increases in sales and personal income taxes and a ceiling on some state income tax deductions. The additional revenue would have gone for a variety of programs in public schools and state colleges and universities.
A bulk of the new tax revenue, about $150 million, would have gone toward a new formula for distributing state tax money to school districts. Missouri, like 21 other states, is currently being sued by school districts that contend the current formula favors property-rich districts. In Texas, voters approved, 65 percent to 35 percent, a plan to raise $300 million through the sale of state bonds. The money will be used to finance a popular student loan program, which would have run out of money without the extra funds.
The measure was defeated last August by voters because they confused the higher education loan program with one for students attending trade schools. This time, Texas officials conducted an aggressive campaign to educate voters and to clear up confusion over who is served by the program. Texas education officials said the campaign was the difference.

HEADLINE: Dinkins, in South Africa, Says He's 'Finally Home'

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 12

 BODY:
To the buoyant greeting of a chorus of cleaning women and airport mechanics, Mayor David N. Dinkins landed on South African soil today, embraced his hero, Nelson Mandela, and proclaimed himself "finally home." He then set off to tour a black hospital and shantytown, where he passed out Mets caps and crayons to poor children.
Accompanied by his wife, Joyce, and more than three dozen business and civic leaders and city officials, the Mayor began his six-day trip with high emotion and pride. While he received nothing like the blizzard of ticker-tape showered on Mr. Mandela, the African National Congress leader, in New York last year, the white-minority Government allowed him a clapping, dancing greeting on the tarmac by A.N.C. officials and workers that American diplomats said was rare. 
 "We're here," Mr. Dinkins told reporters at Jan Smuts Airport. "They said we weren't going to get here, but we are here, and we are delighted to be here. People say that I've come a long way from home, and it's true I have come a long way, but today I am finally home."
 
The Mayor Bristles
 But later the Mayor bristled when some New York reporters traveling with him asked if he saw any similarities between the disparity of health care for blacks and whites in this rich country and the disparities between rich and poor in his own backyard.
"For God's sake, you can't be serious," he told a reporter who asked about inadequacies in New York as Mr. Dinkins toured the Baragwanath Hospital, whose 3,000 beds must serve some three million black residents in Soweto Township.
Dr. John Pettifor, the head of the Government hospital's pediatric unit who guided the Mayor through a children's cancer ward and a neonatal intensive care unit, noted that mortality rates among black babies born there are about 40 per 1,000 births, perhaps three times the 12 to 16 per 1,000 rate for whites. Infant mortality rates in Central Harlem run in the mid-20's, more than three times the average in the upper-middle class neighborhood of Kips Bay.
But as Mr. Dinkins picked up an infant crying "Mama" and cuddled it into silence while television cameras panned the scene, he was not in the mood for thoughts of New York. A few minutes later, in a neighboring squatter settlement known as Mandela Village, where skinny dogs sat still in dusty courtyards and children fought over the hats and sweatbands mayoral aides passed out, Mr. Dinkins said no poverty in the United States was comparable.
 
Disadvantaged 'by law'
 "Nothing quite like this exists," Mr. Dinkins said. "We have Appalachia, we have the South, we have ghettos in cities. But the big difference here is that this is calculated to say that black folks will have nothing, and white folks will have everything, in a sense, by law."
Mr. Dinkins says he hopes his delegation of experts in fields from housing to health can help rectify that in an exchange of ideas with black South Africans at meetings this week.
The Mayor said that the inequity of the system is one reason why he is pressing to maintain economic sanctions against the regime and seeking an interim multiracial government to share power while a new constitution is drafted. It also explains, he said, why his delegation would be meeting with both black and white South African business leaders Wednesday to try to foster new investments.
Mr. Mandela said he hoped to pursue the idea, first broached to him last year in New York by Peter C. Goldmark, head of the Rockefeller Foundation, of establishing an economic development bank that could assist in the reconstruction of a post-apartheid economy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins visiting a squatter camp named after Nelson Mandela in Soweto, South Africa. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Democrats Court Labor By Hammering at Bush

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The six major Democratic Presidential contenders vied for support before the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention here today, pledging their commitment to the unemployed and the economically squeezed, hammering President Bush and promising drastic new measures to spur economic growth.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa seemed to be the emotional favorite of the crowd, judging from the frequency and decibel level of applause when he railed against "scab-hiring employers" and promised to be a friend of labor in the White House. But many officials here said the race for organized labor was still wide open, particularly since it is unclear whether Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York will seek the Democratic nomination. 
 What was clear was the elated mood among labor officials after last week's Democratic victory in the Pennsylvania Senate race. It was widely seen here as vindication for a labor-oriented message -- particularly the health-care issue -- and a sign of new possibilities in the 1992 Presidential race.
"We've got some very acceptable candidates and they're all singing from the hymn book now, since Pennsylvania -- middle-class, economic populism," said Frank Garrison, president of the Michigan A.F.L.-C.I.O., alluding to Senator Harris Wofford's sound defeat of former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh last Tuesday.
 
Videotaped for Membership
 Indeed, the candidates spent considerable time preaching to the choir today, assailing the Bush Administration's handling of the economy, calling for major investments in roads and bridges, for instance, and urging a new emphasis on education and job training. The candidates' forum was videotaped and will be circulated throughout the 89 affiliated unions of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations -- a crucial component of the Democratic nominating process.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas outlined a plan to "jump start the economy" that included extending unemployment benefits, cutting the interest rates on credit cards, expanding mortgage availability and cutting taxes on the middle class. Mr. Clinton has some critics among the ranks of organized labor, stemming, in part, from his days as head of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group that has often faulted the party for seeming out of touch with middle America and too much in thrall of constituent groups like organized labor.
Today, Mr. Clinton told the more than 700 labor delegates here, "We won't always agree, but if I'm your President, we'll be full partners in restoring the middle class and America's greatness." After the forum, David Wilhelm, the Clinton campaign manager, said, "We stayed true to our message, we didn't pander, and we made some friends."
Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former Governor of California, used the forum to highlight his message, turning nearly every question into a relentless attack on modern politics and the influence of special interest money upon it. While none matched him in vehemence, others candidates took time to rail against Washington today, reflecting the new popularity of outsider campaigns.
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who is trying to cast himself as the change-oriented candidate, argued that there was a "life and death struggle" occurring among working people increasingly squeezed by the recession. He used the forum to highlight his plan to provide universal health care, which he asserted was at the heart of much of the nation's economic strain.
 
Wilder on Fiscal Care
 Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, whose message often centers around fiscal responsibility, was striking a different tone today. He accused Republicans of conducting a "decade of code word politics" that has exacerbated racial divisions. But he also criticized Democrats who suggest the party has grown too close to minorities and labor.
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who is trying to position himself as a pro-business liberal, was the only candidate today who said he would oppose a bill now at the top of organized labor's agenda, a measure that would outlaw the hiring of permanent replacements for striking workers. Mr. Tsongas sought to use today's forum to present himself as the candidate with a detailed plan to rebuild the nation's manufacturing base and halt the country's economic decline.
It was Mr. Harkin who made the most full-throated appeal to labor today. "I come from labor," he said. "I'm proud of labor, and I'm proud of what labor's done for America. And I won't just take your money and your support and then treat you like some illegitimate cousin."
Many labor officials here said they were doubtful that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. would reach an early endorsement of a candidate for the nomination.

HEADLINE: President of University of Bridgeport Quits as Fiscal Woes Deepen

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 12

 BODY:
The president of the University of Bridgeport resigned on Monday as the struggling private university's financial crisis deepened.
The resignation of the president, Dr. Janet D. Greenwood, came a month after trustees rejected an offer from a group financed by the Unification Church to invest $50 million in the nonsectarian university and enroll 1,000 students a year. Control would have passed to the group, the Professors World Peace Academy. Dr. Greenwood said at the time that trustees had to consider the offer because of the university's financial condition.
 
'Very Difficult Period'
 Three days before Dr. Greenwood resigned Standard & Poor's lowered the rating on $3 million in bonds for the university from BB to CCC, a very speculative rating that carries significant risk, saying the university was nearly out of cash and "there is a possibility that U.B. may consider closing in the near future." 
 Dr. Greenwood was not available for comment today. The trustees, in announcing that she had resigned and would become a tenured faculty member and president emeritus, said she had joined Bridgeport in 1987 "during a very difficult period" and had faced conditions that placed "unusual burdens on her presidency."
A spokesman for the university, Walter Wager, said Dr. Greenwood had said recently that she was not in accord with some options being considered to deal with the university's fiscal crisis. Among other things, the university is considering a reduction in tuition, which totals more than $18,000, including room and board, and consolidating the 85-acre campus on Long Island Sound, where a third of the more than 50 buildings are unused.
The school now has 4,000 full-time and part-time students, Mr. Wager said, down from 9,100 in 1969. Full-time enrollment was hurt, he said, because parents balked at Bridgeport's high tuition, while part-time enrollment was suffering because many businesses were cutting back on tuition subsidies for employees.
But the university also faces an immediate financial threat. According to Standard & Poor's, it is in technical default on a $10.2 million loan from a group of local banks because it has not complied with the loan's conditions and has "exhausted all of its unrestricted monies."
Founded in 1927 when Bridgeport was a thriving industrial city, the University of Bridgeport grew rapidly in the 1960's as the baby-boom generation went to college. But its reputation did not grow in proportion, and the campus was already becoming isolated by poor neighborhoods around it. Enrollment began declining in the 1970's as the college-age population shrank and competition among colleges intensified.
The decline was well under way when Dr. Greenwood arrived from Longwood College, a state college in Farmville, Va., where she had been president for eight years. Conditions worsened as she immediately ran into a faculty strike and the university incurred $4 million deficits in both 1988 and 1989.
In 1990 the faculty struck again when Dr. Greenwood sought deep salary cuts and concessions on tenure. Seventy of the 157 faculty members at that time have remained out, keeping up a chorus of criticism of Dr. Greenwood and the trustees as the recession and publicity from the strike have cut further into enrollment.
"This has come too late to make any real difference as far as the survival of the university is concerned," Richard Tino, a spokesman for the striking faculty, said today. "It doesn't seem to me that anyone with any sense would extend credit to the university."

HEADLINE: And This Little Piggy Is Now on the Menu

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
STYLISH foods are supposed to have weird and unpronounceable names, like cherimoya, a custardy fruit from South America, or offer a new and exciting eating experience, like pizza with goat cheese.
But pork? Pork, a prosaic food if there ever was one, is finally getting some respect. According to several surveys, pork in all its guises, from spareribs to roast loin with five-chili chutney, is one of the most rapidly growing items on restaurant menus. Sales of pork have grown by 20 percent, from $25 billion to $30 billion, since the pork industry started a costly and intensive public relations campaign five years ago, emphasizing pork's leanness for consumers who are increasingly concerned about health. 
 Not only is more pork being sold, but as demand grows, it is fetching a higher price. Pork is even showing up in fancy places that once shunned it in favor of more stylish dishes like free-range chicken or rack of lamb.
"I never had pork on my menu until last year," said Gordon Sinclair, the owner of Gordon, an elegant American restaurant in Chicago. "I didn't think it was good enough." But Mr. Sinclair decided that pork's image had been changed by the industry's campaign and the news media's response to it.
In Dallas, Stephan Pyles never had pork on his menu at Routh Street. "I looked at pork as a humble dish," he said, "and would use wild boar instead." But a year or so ago, he began serving pork, using the tenderloin in a dried cherry and chipotle sauce.
That's not to say that pork has surmounted all of its image problems. Chefs at some fancy restaurants still refuse to put pork on their regular menus. "It's not that popular," said Christian Albin, one of the chefs of the Four Seasons in New York.
Nor does it lack detractors who question its health value. The Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer group in Washington, has complained to the Federal Trade Commission that the pork industry is misleading shoppers by implying that all pork -- "the other white meat," as the ad campaign puts it -- is low in fat; the truth is, only certain cuts are.
"The pork industry is running a nutrition disinformation campaign," said Bruce Silverglade, director of the center's legal affairs. "The last thing we need is to increase consumption of foods that are relatively high in fat and cholesterol."
Pork also has image problems completely unrelated to nutrition concerns. Its consumption is taboo in some religions, Judaism and Islam. Even some people with no tie to these traditions consider pork an unclean meat. Nevertheless, while beef and chicken are eaten more in this country than pork, worldwide, pork is the most widely consumed meat.
The mixed feelings about pork showed up in a survey last year of 1,304 households done for the National Pork Producers Council in Des Moines. For a large segment, pork did not have a special or fancy image: 38 percent said they were not likely to serve pork for a festive occasion. And, 93 percent of the respondents said pork must be overcooked to be safe to eat.
The conviction that pork must be overcooked is a big hurdle to greater acceptance. It is based on the fear of getting trichinosis from pork. But since the industry changed the way it raises pork in the 1960's and the Federal Government made it illegal in the 1970's to feed pigs untreated garbage, the trichina worm is rarely found in pork.
"Our own studies indicate that less than 1 percent of all pigs slaughtered contain the parasite," said James Greene, a spokesman for the food safety and inspection service of the United States Department of Agriculture. Trichinosis is now a rare illness that is less likely to occur than food poisoning from chicken or turkey. "We would characterize that as a very low public health problem," Mr. Greene said. If the parasite is present, it is killed when the meat is cooked to 137 degrees.
But the Federal Government recommends cooking to 160 degrees to assure that bacteria are also eliminated. At 160 degrees, the meat is slightly pink, or has just turned white, and is juicier and less well done than most people would expect pork to be. Cooks who do not use a thermometer should cook pork until it has turned white and the juice runs clear, according to Susan Conley, a home economist who oversees the meat and poultry consumer help line at the Agriculture Department.
The pork industry has not convinced the public that pork doesn't have to be overcooked, but its surveys show that its slogan, "the other white meat," has become widely known. And, although it is natural to assume that any industry that is trying to burnish its image has something to hide, some pork really is less fatty than it used to be.
The pig, the animal whose very name has long been synonymous with fat, has actually become, on average, about 31 percent leaner since 1983 because of changes in breeding and a lower-fat diet, according to a University of Wisconsin study released last year. The leanest cut, pork tenderloin, has four grams of fat in a three-ounce serving, compared to three grams in a skinless chicken breast, and far less than a beef tenderloin, with nine grams of fat. But tenderloin accounts for only a small part of the pork that is sold. The more popular kinds of fresh pork cuts, like spareribs, are still very fatty.
Nevertheless, because of the five-year-old campaign, the pork industry has avoided the taint that has hurt beef. Pork producers have stopped the decline in per capita consumption and have even managed to raise it somewhat, while the beef industry has seen a significant drop. Pork producers have spent $150 million on the research and promotion campaign, financed by a fee of 30 cents on each pig sold. The money is collected by the National Pork Board, which hires organizations like the Pork Producers to promote pork.
For producers, the program has paid off. The average farmer this year will get more than $49 for every 100 pounds of pork sold, said Michael Simpson, executive vice president of the pork board. "If we had the demand scenario of the early 80s, they would be getting between $37 and $39 on average," he said.
Besides producing leaner pork, producers have barraged consumers and restaurants with advertisements in publications and on television. Restaurants have responded to the overtures; according to the pork council, it has fulfilled 80,000 requests from restaurants in the last three years for pork recipes and promotional materials.
Culinary trends may have made it easier to sell the public on the virtue of pork. In the last decade, the growing popularity of Southwestern and Mexican cuisine, both quite dependent on pork, has stimulated its use. At the Granite Cafe in Austin, Tex., the chef, Luke Bibby, is serving two pork entrees: a boneless, butterflied pork chop stuffed with sweet potato and sage, and a smoked pork tenderloin in a peanut mole sauce. "It's much more versatile than chicken," he said. "It can take a heavier sauce."
But all kinds of restaurants, which often set the trends in home cooking, have been using more pork. A recent survey of 1,000 restaurants published by Restaurant Business magazine showed that of 21 meat, poultry and seafood items, pork had the greatest percentage growth as a menu item from 1988 to 1991.
And in a study released last year by the NPD Group, a research company in Chicago, pork was found to be one of the fastest growing menu items in all parts of the United States, except in the Midwest, from 1987 to 1989, along with items like frozen yogurt, pasta and pan pizzas.
Because pork is cheaper than beef, it is appealing to restaurants that are trying to keep entree prices low. "I can't sell something over $20," said Peter Hoffman, the chef of Savoy at 70 Prince Street in Manhattan, a new bistro. People don't want steak, but they might be interested in pork, he said; he just added it to his fall menu.
While fat-conscious consumers may now be more willing to eat pork than in the past, the thinner pigs are not an unmitigated boon. Chefs say they are much harder to make tasty because they have less fat. At the Coyote Cafe in Santa Fe, N.M., pork accounts for a quarter of meat sales. But it can't just be thrown on a grill. "By marinating and brining it, we give it more flavor," said Mark Miller, the chef and owner.
Though he has noticed an increase in the sale of pork dishes over the last three years, Mr. Miller is not sure that that points to an upsurge in pork's popularity. In Santa Fe, he said, most of the diners in his restaurant are visitors on vacation. "People tend not to think about their normal diets," he said.

HEADLINE: THE PURPOSEFUL COOK;
Re-creating a Four-Alarm Chili That Still Lingers in Memory

BYLINE: By JACQUES PEPIN

 BODY:
ONE-DISH meals are often our favorite way of eating at home, and when cold weather comes, I long for chili. Many years ago, a friend sent me a chili recipe that had been given her by the warden of San Quentin State Prison in California. It was hot, very hot, but my family liked it as much as I did. Even though I lost the recipe long ago, the taste of that chili remains in my memory, and I think this recipe is close to the one I remember.
My wife and I always serve our chili with boiled long-grain white rice and garnish it with shredded sharp Cheddar cheese and chopped red or white onion. In addition, I serve it with hot corn tortillas or dry tacos. Although "real" Texas chili doesn't accommodate beans, we make ours with red kidney beans or another variety of dried beans. We like it better that way, and the beans extend the dish greatly, make it healthier, more of a complete meal, and more economical, because the quantity of meat can be greatly reduced. 
 Although any type of beef can be used in this chili recipe, the best choice is chuck, shoulder or shank, all of which are moist and tender. I like my beef coarsely chopped, in 1/4-inch pieces, not finely chopped or ground.
The spice mixture includes dry mustard, cumin powder, red pepper flakes, chili powder and coriander seeds. I grind the seeds to a powder in a mini-chopper or small coffee grinder. If you don't have one of these small devices, use a mortar and pestle or the bottom of a heavy saucepan to crush the seeds.
Chili is an ideal dish to make ahead. It freezes well and will keep under refrigeration for four days to a week. It actually improves in flavor with reheating. Freeze the chili in small enough containers so that you can thaw it easily on short notice.
A simple green salad is a refreshing and cooling companion. And apple fritters make a delightful dessert. The fritters are made with a simple batter consisting of a cup of flour, a cup of ice-cold water and one egg.
Use the least expensive apples you can find for the fritters; any variety works well in this recipe. Notice that the apples are not peeled. They are stood upright and cut on all sides into 1/2-inch-thick slices as far as the core, which is then discarded. The apple slices are then stacked and cut into sticks, and these sticks are mixed into the batter. Large spoonfuls of the mixture cook in just a few minutes in hot oil.
If the fritters are made ahead, be sure to cook them until they are crisp and well browned. Then reheat and recrisp them in a toaster oven or under the broiler just before serving. Dust them heavily with granulated sugar.
With this hot, earthy chili, I suggest beer or an ordinary jug wine, perhaps a Gallo burgundy or an Almaden chablis.
 
Batter Up!
INSTEAD of making apple fritters, you can use the same batter for vegetable pancakes. Stir in some thinly sliced leftover vegetables -- anything from carrots to parsley, onions and zucchini. Pour large spoonfuls of the mixture into a very hot, heavy skillet that has been generously oiled with corn or canola oil, and cook the pancakes for 3 to 4 minutes on each side. Serve one large pancake per person as a vegetable side dish with a roast or stew.

A Meal In One Dish: Beef and Beans
 
Fiery Chili With Red Beans
 
Total time: 2 hours, 45 minutes
 
 2 pounds dried red kidney beans
 12 cups cold water
 3 teaspoons salt
 2 pounds stewing beef (chuck, shoulder or shank)
 1/2 pound ham rind or bacon, cut into 1/2-inch pieces
 1 pound onions, peeled and cut into 1-inch pieces, and for garnish, 1 cup chopped onion, washed in a sieve and pressed in a kitchen towel to prevent discoloration
 8 cloves garlic, crushed, peeled and chopped (2 tablespoons)
 2 tablespoons chopped jalapeno pepper (more or less to taste)
 1 large (1-pound, 12-ounce) can whole Italian tomatoes in juice
 2 teaspoons coriander seeds
 2 teaspoons cumin powder
 2 teaspoons dry mustard
 1 teaspoon red pepper flakes
 4 tablespoons chili powder
 Tabasco sauce
 1 cup grated Cheddar cheese
 Corn tortillas or tacos.
1. Rinse the beans under cool water, removing and discarding any damaged beans and any foreign material. Place the beans in a large pot with the cold water and 1 teaspoon of the salt, and bring to a boil. Cover, reduce the heat, and cook gently for 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 hours, until the beans are tender but not mushy. Set aside; do not drain.
2. Cut the beef into 1-inch pieces, and then chop coarsely by hand or in a food processor. When using a food processor, place about 1/2 pound of the chuck in the bowl at a time, and pulse the motor for about 10 seconds.
3. Place the pieces of ham rind or bacon in a saucepan, and cook over medium heat for about 10 minutes, until most of the fat has been rendered and the rind is dry and brown. Add the 1 pound of onion pieces and the beef, and cook, stirring, for about 5 minutes, until the meat separates and loses its red color. Stir in the garlic, jalapeno pepper and tomatoes.
4. Using a mini-chopper or small coffee grinder, process the coriander seeds, and add them to the saucepan, along with the cumin powder, mustard, red pepper flakes, chili powder and the remaining 2 teaspoons of salt. Bring the mixture to a boil. Combine the meat mixture and the beans (liquid and all), return to a boil, cover, reduce the heat to low, and simmer for 1 hour. (The mixture will be soupy.)
5. Spoon over boiled rice, and garnish with the Cheddar cheese and the chopped onion. Pass the Tabasco sauce and the corn tortillas or tacos.
Yield: 12 servings.
 
Boiled Rice
 
Total time: 25 minutes
 
 1 tablespoon corn oil
 2 cups white long-grain rice
 4 cups water
 1 teaspoon salt.
1. Place the oil and rice in a saucepan, and mix well. Add the water and salt, and bring to a boil, stirring occasionally, over high heat. Cover tightly, reduce the heat to very low, and simmer gently for 20 minutes.
2. Fluff with a fork, and serve with the chili.
Yield: 12 servings.
 
Apple Fritters
 
Total time: 12 minutes
 
 1 cup all-purpose flour
 1 egg
 1 cup ice-cold water
 1 pound apples (about 3), any variety
 1 1/2 cup canola oil
 1/2 cup granulated sugar for dusting the fritters.
1. Put the flour, egg and a third of the water into a bowl, and mix vigorously with a whisk. The mixture will be fairly thick. When smooth, add the remaining water, and mix again until the water is incorporated.
2. Stand the unpeeled apples upright on a board, and cut them vertically into 1/2-inch-thick slices, stopping when you reach the core. Pivot the apple, and cut again, until only the core remains. Discard the core, stack the apple slices, and cut them into 1/2-inch-wide sticks. You should have 4 cups. Stir the apple sticks into the batter.
3. In a large, heavy skillet heat the oil to 375 degrees. When hot, pour about 1/3 cup of the batter into the pan for each fritter, making four or five at a time. Using two forks, spread the batter so that it is not more than 1/2 inch thick. Cook for about 3 minutes on each side, until brown and crisp.
4. Drain the fritters on paper towels, and transfer them to a rack. Sprinkle liberally with the sugar, and serve immediately.
Yield: about 12 fritters.
