HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Lakers Slowly Adjust To Life Without Magic

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12

 BODY:
By the end of practice today, the players began to allow themselves a small luxury. They finally smiled.
It was a small step for the Los Angeles Lakers, who acknowledge that things will never really be the same without Magic Johnson. But they are slowly adjusting. 
 They have one victory and one loss since Johnson's announcement last Thursday that he was retiring after testing positive for the virus that causes AIDS. Now, they are trying to learn how to play without him.
"The guys are coming to grips with it," Coach Mike Dunleavy said after a morning workout at Loyola Marymount University. "They know he's not going to take part in practice; they know he's not going to be playing in games. There will always be a piece missing, but everybody understands what we're trying to do."
 
A Record of 2-3
 Five games, and only two victories, into the season, Dunleavy is attempting to reshape his team after losing its most important component. For 12 seasons, Johnson jump-started the offense, found seams in opposing defenses, took advantage of his height and made unfathomable passes.
"So much of what we did was predicated on his handling the ball," said Jerry West, the Lakers' general manager. "Give it to him, and he'll make a pass that nobody else can make. This team didn't win so many games simply because of Magic, but we did lose our team leader and best player, and that's something you don't replace."
In fact, the Lakers have no immediate plans to acquire another player. Tony Smith, a second-year guard from Marquette, is eligible to come off the injured list, but he was unable to scrimmage today because his injured right ankle remained tender. Even though he may not be available Thursday when the Lakers play at Golden State, West insists on caution.
"I don't think we'll do anything yet," West said. "We're hopeful of getting Tony back this week, which should give us depth in the backcourt and another ball-handler."
 
Salary-Cap Requirement
 From an economic standpoint, the Lakers will eventually have to sign someone or suffer for it next season. Under the rules of the salary cap, they can use half of Johnson's base salary of $2.5 million this season to acquire a replacement. If they don't, they lose the $1.25 million next season.
Even Dunleavy has said he would prefer to work with his current group rather than bring in a new player. But at the moment, with Smith out and with center Vlade Divac slow to recover from a back injury, the Lakers are short-handed and somewhat disjointed.
Finding a way to run their offense without the gifted Johnson remains their primary concern.
"We're definitely going to have to play a different brand of basketball," said Byron Scott, who was Johnson's backcourt mate for eight seasons. "Some of us will have to learn more things on a different level. It will call for individuals to give attention to playing a new type of game."
The loss of Johnson hurts the Lakers in two specific major ways, Dunleavy said.
"We can't post up the point guard like we used to, and we can't do some of the switching we did in the past to take advantage of the fact he was 6-foot-9," the coach said. "Almost every one of our plays has changed because they ended up with us throwing the ball into Earvin, who would take advantage of it in some way. That's all changed."
A lot of the new responsibility has fallen to Sedale Threatt, who was acquired from Seattle in October to be Johnson's backup. Now, Threatt is the Lakers' starting point guard.
"This team is used to winning," Threatt said. "The loss of Earvin is tough, but we have to get over it. He's still a part of the team, but now we have to find ways to win games."
 
'An Old Guy'
 Threatt, who is 6-2 and 30 years old, insists he is undaunted by his new role, even though he may be asked to do more within the offense. He is off to a creditable start, averaging 17.6 points and 7.6 assists a game.
"I'm an old guy," Threatt said. "I've been in this league for nine years. The biggest thing is learning the system."
And for the Lakers as a whole, the biggest thing is living without Johnson. The question now is: Are they just another basketball team?
"That could conceivably be," West said. "We don't know. People get hysterical when a tragedy strikes, and that's what has happened here. But we have to let this team see where it's going to go."
 
REBOUNDS
 Most of the players had already left when the Rev. JESSE JACKSON arrived unexpectedly. He spoke briefly with BYRON SCOTT and SAM PERKINS, then handed out a three-page statement to reporters that suggested that "the entire culture" must reassess its lifestyles and that called for a separate AIDS budget from the Government.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (90%);

HEADLINE: Son of Kemp-Roth: Still Wrong

 BODY:
Alarmed by recession, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp has broken ranks with President Bush and proposed cutting taxes to prod the economy. Coming from Mr. Kemp, the idea is no surprise; he is, after all, a true believer. He was a sponsor of the Kemp-Roth tax and budget reductions that slashed income tax rates 10 years ago.
What Washington did then was accumulate $2 trillion of debt, and mire itself in an endless budget quagmire. Washington -- including Mr. Kemp -- should have learned something indelible from the experience. Tax cuts didn't solve economic problems then, and won't solve them now. 
 What probably makes Mr. Kemp's sudden initiative all the more galling for President Bush is that it embraces Mr. Bush's benighted ideas for cutting taxes on capital gains -- profit from the sale of investments. Such cuts supposedly would ignite investment, and the economy.
Mr. Kemp's fervent faith defies the evidence. Even if Mr. Bush felt free, in the face of his budget agreement with Congress, to make his capital gains proposal again, the White House's own estimates look trivial. It would boost production by only about one-fifth of 1 percent.
Triviality is the least of it. The capital gains ideas now circulating would produce a windfall profit for rich families on past investment. That couldn't possibly spur future investment. Neither are they targeted on productive investments like equipment. Finally, these capital gains cuts will probably cost the Treasury revenue, adding to the deficit and siphoning money away from private investors.
Mr. Kemp also goes along with the idea of reinstating tax breaks for higher-income families who put money into individual retirement accounts. If such a plan were carefully tailored, and paid for with some other tax, it would be worth considering. But that's not what Mr. Kemp, or sponsors of other tax cut proposals, have in mind.
The 1990 budget law requires Congress, come 1994, to cut spending drastically or else raise taxes. To throw away tax revenues now -- as Mr. Kemp recklessly proposes -- would force Congress to hack at spending for job training, child nutrition and other investments for the future.
There are good reasons Congress might wish to consider targeted tax cuts -- if offset by tax increases. For example, the low-income tax credit costs only $300 million but it accounts for an astounding 90 percent of multi-family low income housing starts. This lifeline to the poor hangs in the balance even as the Housing Secretary calls grandly for sweeping tax reductions.
Costly tax cuts that empty Washington's coffers can only starve public programs. Again. One orgy of Reagan-era tax and spending cuts is enough.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: We Need a National Health Plan for Everyone

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The "solution" you suggest for the national health care crisis in "A Plausible Revolution in Health" (editorial, Oct. 29) would work about as well as a Band-Aid on a compound fracture. 
 "Managed competition, a combination of public and private managed care plans" would go only halfway toward fighting medical inflation. The costs of managed plans may be rising "only half as fast" as traditional health plans, but they're still growing at least twice as fast as the inflation rate. And managed-care plans don't provide the choice of doctors Americans overwhelmingly want to preserve, according to all surveys.
Having the uninsured buy their own insurance from a Government insurer "at a fee based on income" is an insurance industry dream: The Government takes the bad risks, for which the Treasury or insurance premium payers pay the freight. Care providers keep wasting labor and money billing for services and supplies, and filling out all kinds of forms for the 1,500 insurance companies that pay differently for the same services -- after they do their best to pay nothing at all. And all the while, the profits of insurers keep running in the billions.
A better answer is offered by H.R. 1300, the universal health insurance bill, which was introduced by Representative Marty Russo of Chicago, with 40 co-sponsors in the House. Establishing "global" budgets and reasonable fee schedules for providers and eliminating duplication of expensive high-tech equipment effectively controls costs, as proved in Canada. A single governmental payer affords enormous savings in administrative costs (the General Accounting Office says $67 billion a year; others predict much more).
These billions pay to extend health care to every man, woman and child in the country, without a penny in out-of-pocket costs. Everyone chooses physicians, hospitals and other providers. And, believe it or not, it costs almost everybody less than we're spending now, without reducing the quality or quantity of our health care.
Adoption of "managed competition" and other "incremental" reforms proposed by the health care industry wouldn't end the health care crisis, only deepen it at a slower rate. Worse, the day when we adopt a comprehensive plan like H.R. 1300 will be delayed.
 
JOHN GLASEL
President, Local 802
American Federation of Musicians
New York, Nov. 1, 1991

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Not a Yawn: Real Help

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
Technical assistance: that's what President Bush and Western allies typically offer when Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union plead for help. To most Americans, technical assistance is a yawner, about as enthralling as double-entry bookkeeping.
But as applied by Dan Arbess, who advises the Czechoslovak Government, and Peter Derby, who advises the Russian government, and dozens of other Western lawyers, accountants and investment bankers, technical assistance is economic sustenance, not pabulum. 
 Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary are rushing to market economies; the Soviet republics may soon do so. The key is to turn over state-owned enterprises to domestic and foreign investors. But that is a formidable task where there are no markets to signal fair, sensible purchase prices. Enter technical assistance.
In Poland, Western advisers have helped design an ingenious plan to give every adult citizen indirect title to hundreds of factories. In Czechoslovakia, they've appraised bids that foreign investors make for factories and have helped devise novel ways to auction hotels and other enterprises. In Russia, Mr. Derby, an American investment banker, is helping draft commercial codes and securities laws. Stephen Fuzesi, a New York lawyer born in Budapest, is doing the same in Hungary.
The stakes are huge. If securities laws are porous, ordinary citizens will lose their life's savings. That's why Poland has written, with Western help, intricate safeguards against exploitation of neophyte investors. And if foreign bids are inexpertly evaluated, countries will be fleeced of their most valuable property. That almost happened in Czechoslovakia, where the shoe industry was nearly given away to a foreign investor before Mr. Arbess and others found the offer full of debt, not equity, guaranteed to exploit consumers behind high tariff walls.
Foreign investment is not a zero-sum game: what's good for I.B.M. need not be bad for Eastern Europe. But when economic decisions are made by personal negotiation rather than impersonal markets, abuse can become rampant. And abuse could trigger public backlash against further market reforms.
Officials in former Communist governments need Western advice not because they're inept, but because they're inexperienced. In a matter of months they have been forced to drop what they know best -- centralized control -- and adopt what the West knows best -- capitalism. It will take years to develop their own experts.
The Westerners charge handsomely, but most aren't there for profit. If that were their primary motive, Mr. Arbess and company would have switched sides and only represented foreign investors. Western experts have made success more likely for newcomers to capitalism. It may sound lifeless when President Bush offers former Communist countries technical assistance. But technical assistance may well be the most precious gift America has to give them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
(Same Old) New Duke

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Some people wonder why so much has been made of David Duke's plastic surgery. The answer is simple. David Duke's new face is a symbol of what he seeks to do: turn back the clock and pretend to be something he is not.
For every avowal in the Louisiana gubernatorial race that he is a changed man, there is a revelation about his recent past that gives it the lie. Well into the 1980's he still had the standard racist/anti-Semite spiel: race mixing is ruining America, segregation is the ideal, the Holocaust didn't happen. Even the views of the new improved Duke are more of the same, couched in politicospeak with a nudge and a wink at his right radical supporters. 
 If you don't speak white supremacist, here's a handy guide: "the liberal social welfare system which encourages the rising illegitimate welfare birthrate" means "poor black people are having babies on your tax dollars." Mr. Duke has been confronted repeatedly with the fact that the average welfare family in Louisiana consists of only two children, and that the increased allotment for an additional child is a whopping $11 a week, just enough to afford a steady diet of cold cereal. But the rhetoric works better without the facts.
All over this country, among a substantial group of its citizens, there is longing, sometimes even organized support, for an era gone by. It was an era that saw the biggest, most pervasive, most extensive racial preference program in this nation's history, during which one group was routinely given preferred access to jobs, status, even votes.
That group was white men.
Things are in a mess in America right now: social problems that seem to have no simple solutions, economic problems that seem governed by nothing so much as the vagaries of fortune. And when things are tough there is always a temptation to go back: to go back to the days of illegal abortion as though that will make women stop trying to end pregnancies, to go back to the days of limited options as though that will soothe people overwhelmed by choices. Opponents of affirmative action say they want a return to a meritocracy. The meritocracy they evoke is the one in which, somehow, only white guys made the cut.
Ronald Reagan was the standard-bearer of the backward march; it was inevitable that someone, somewhere, would take Mr. Reagan's neglect of the poor and the disenfranchised and turn it into active hostility. No thoughtful conservative stepped up to the plate to talk about real inadequacies in the social welfare system; into the vacuum stepped a man who can have his face refashioned a dozen times and still have prejudice written all over him.
If this backwards ethos swept the United States, it would be a disaster. But it cannot. The most influential public figures in this country over the last month have all three been black, as though someone was trying to send a cosmic message to the David Dukes of the world, to counter them with Clarence Thomas, Anita Hill and Magic Johnson.
If the Duke ethos prevails in Louisiana, the state will suffer. Everyone has noted that millions of dollars in convention business will go elsewhere; in fact if David Duke loses, it will not be because he is a bigot but because he inspires fear that the Super Bowl will shun the Superdome. And perhaps some taxpayers will compute the cost of inept and inexperienced government. Mr. Duke's highest executive position has been as Grand Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan and his most intensive management training appears to have been at Est seminars. Demagogues make good dictators, but poor managers. Tax cuts are notoriously easy to promise and difficult to deliver.
People are angry in his state, as they are throughout this country, and it may relieve the pain for a short time simply to have someone personify their anger in rank prejudice. After that, people want results. They will want to know whether the man can run his state as well as his mouth, and I bet the answer is no. Mr. Duke cannot change the face of this country, or even of a part of it; it's not enough to take us back to the 19th century when what most of us seek is a road map for the 21st. It's not enough to foment simplistic hatreds when what we really need is some way to coexist in an increasingly complex world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Earnings Decline in Quarter At Several Large Retailers

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The J. C. Penney Company, the Limited Inc. and Nordstrom Inc. said yesterday that their earnings for the third quarter fell from depressed levels of a year earlier, while the May Department Stores Company said its profits edged up 1 percent.
 Another retailer, the Caldor Corporation, said its third-quarter loss narrowed from the corresponding period last year. The improvement reflected the company's stock sale, the proceeds of which were used to retire debt. 
The results provided further evidence of the consumer spending slump that has sliced into the earnings of many retailers. A predicted rebound in spending has not happened, as consumers are weighed down by concerns about the economy and their jobs.
 Penney, Nordstrom and May also reported earnings declines in 1990 quarter, in the early months of the Persian Gulf war and the recession. The Limited's results were little changed during the period.
 Following are details of the retailers' results.
 
Penney
 The Dallas-based Penney said its profits fell by 13.4 percent, to $116 million, or 93 cents a share, compared with $134 million, or $1.07 a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Its revenues fell slightly, to $4.20 billion from $4.24 billion.
 The retailer attributed its results to a sales drop. The consumer spending drought has taken a heavy toll on Penney.
 In the third quarter of last year, Penney's earnings plunged nearly 36 percent. The company's shares rose $1.875 yesterday, to $52, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Limited
 The nation's largest specialty apparel retailer said its earnings for the quarter that ended on Nov. 2 fell by 14 percent, to $72.8 million, or 20 cents a share, from $84.9 million, or 23 cents a share. Its sales rose by 15 percent, to $1.43 billion from $1.24 billion.
 Leslie H. Wexner, the chairman, cited the weak economy and slow store traffic in the quarter. But he said, "External factors are not an excuse for such mediocre performance."
 "I believe it is always our merchandising that produces success or failure," he said.
 The stock of the Limited, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, rose 75 cents yesterday, to $26.75, on the Big Board.
 
Nordstrom
 Nordstrom, based in Seattle, said its earnings fell by 4.9 percent, to $19.4 million, or 24 cents a share, in the quarter that ended on Oct. 31. That compared with $20.4 million, or 25 cents a share, in the 1990 quarter, when earnings fell by 7 percent.
 Its sales rose by 8.2 percent, to $687 million from $634.8 million.
 Nordstrom said its sales growth rate slowed during the quarter after improving in the first half of its fiscal year. The trend reflected the slowdown in consumer spending.
The company's stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $39.125, in over-the-counter trading.
 
May Department Stores
 May Department Stores, based in St. Louis, said it earned $91 million, or 70 cents a share, in the quarter that ended on Nov. 2, up slightly from $90 million, or 69 cents a share. Its revenues rose by 8 percent, to $2.56 billion from $2.37 billion.
 Department stores have been particularly hard-hit by the slide in consumer spending. May's stores include Lord & Taylor, May and Hecht's. It also owns the Payless Shoesource chain.
 May, whose stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday on the Big Board, to $51.875, said it was merging its Thalhimer Brothers division with its Hecht's operation.
 The move will close seven Thalhimer's stores in Virginia and North Carolina.
 
Caldor
 Caldor, the discount-store chain based in Norwalk, Conn., reported a $3.8 million loss, compared with a loss of $5.7 million, before adjustments and other items, in the 1990 period. The company's sales rose by 4.5 percent, to $417.8 million from $399.8 million.
 The retailer, which returned to public ownership earlier this year after a leveraged buyout, is still paying down the costs of the transaction.
 Caldor's stock rose 37.5 cents on the Big Board yesterday, to $14.625.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 14, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Company News column in some copies of Business Day yesterday misstated the reason for a fourth-quarter charge taken by the Phillips Petroleum Company against pretax earnings of $15 million. It results from previous staff cuts, announced in September.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Wave of Calls On Bonds Is Seen

BYLINE: By Jan Rosen

 BODY:
WITH interest rates on the skids, credit- market experts see a wave of bond calls not experienced for years. Just as many homeowners refinance mortgages when rates turn down, bond issuers call, or redeem, securities, so they can refinance at lower rates.
Even the Treasury recently called one issue for the first time in three decades. Although Treasury securities have been noncallable since November 1984, some $78 billion of older Treasury issues are outstanding. The call trend is most pronounced in the municipal market, where bonds are commonly issued with 10-year call protection, which is now expiring on many tax-exempts issued in the early 1980's at high interest rates. Corporate issues may also be called. 
 "Short-term rates are dropping so low that it may behoove issuers to refund the securities," said Stephen P. Rappaport, manager of municipal research for Prudential Securities.
John Breazeale, senior vice president and managing director of fixed-income securities at Mackenzie Investment Management Inc., the distributor and investment adviser of the Mackenzie Group of Funds, Boca Raton, Fla., said, "This may be wonderful for the issuer, but not for the investor."
Investors who have bonds on which call protection will expire in the next few years have a choice. They can hold onto their bonds to keep the income stream as long as possible, or, since bond prices go up as yields go down, and they are now holding appreciated securities, they can sell at a profit and reinvest the proceeds.
Deciding what to do "depends partly on your interest-rate forecast," Mr. Rappaport said, "because an investor who decides to hold the bonds may end up being forced to reinvest at much lower rates than he would have had he sold the bonds at the present time."
It also depends on whether the investor needs the bond income to pay for a current need like tuition bills, he added, or whether the holding is part of a portfolio whose total return will be affected if the bonds are sold before they are called.
The interest-rate forecast of most Wall Street analysts is for a continued downtrend. For example, Edward J. Campbell, senior economist with Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, expects interest rates to decline further before they turn back up. "This is a recovery that feels like a recession, a grudging, subpar recovery," he said. "Sideways movement in the economy is conducive to lower interest rates."
He foresees inflation remaining around 3.5 percent in the next year and the gross national product growing at a 2 to 2.5 percent annual rate. That could push the long bond down closer to 7 percent than its current 8 percent, he said. However, he expects short-term rates to turn back up in the next year.
"The yield curve now is over 300 basis points," or hundredths of a percentage point, "a very large amount," Mr. Campbell said. He anticipates "a less steep yield curve," with short-term rates climbing to 5.5 percent by spring from 4.5 percent now. Mr. Breazeale of Mackenzie said, "I've been concerned with this issue for a long time," and his general response as a portfolio manager has been to avoid bonds that lack call protection. However, he buys some callable issues if he sees a bargain.
But individual investors have not always been astute about call protection. Richard Ganz, president of the Fixed Income Management Group, Melville, L.I., which manages bond portfolios for the wealthy and advises brokers and financial planners, said: "It's a mistake to buy a bond and forget about it. You have to monitor that investment."
He gave these figures for call vulnerability in municipals. In 1981, $46.1 billion of munis were issued at an average rate of 11.3 percent, and with rates now closer to 6 percent, "the '81 issues are being called." In 1982, there were $77.2 billion issued at 11.7 percent; in 1983, $83.3 billion at 9.5 percent; in 1984, $101.8 billion at 10.1 percent, and in 1985, $204 billion at 9.1 percent.
"If I hold an issue today that is subject to call in 1995, I have a substantial gain in it," Mr. Ganz said. "I can sell it and buy a bond that will not be taken away." It could be worth $120 today, and would be called at $102 in 1995, he said.
"That bond is going down, but if the trend of rates is down, other bonds are going up in price," he said, so it can make sense to take the capital gain and buy an issue with a lower current yield to get the possibility of future price appreciation.
That entails some risk, he noted. "For income-intensive investors who need every dollar of yield, it may benefit them to stay with it," he said.
Mr. Ganz added two notes of caution for people who are reinvesting: Do not shop yield alone; buy quality, looking at the underlying bond, not just insurance. Also, look at total return on any bond -- that is, appreciation plus yield.

HEADLINE: Lawyers Now Learning Basics of Business

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Corporate lawyers are known to call upon many talents to get their client companies out of jams, but odd as it seems, basic business acumen is not usually among them.
In the last year, however, several law firms across the country have started to change that. 
 Some, like Winston & Strawn in Chicago, have hired outside consultants to teach associates and partners alike how to peruse balance sheets and annual reports to understand their clients better. Other firms, including Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher in Los Angeles, have taught their lawyers sophisticated budget techniques that have allowed them, among other things, to begin providing clients with monthly and quarterly estimates of their services and costs.
Still others, like Malouf Lynch Jackson Kessler & Collins in Dallas, have implored their lawyers to become experts on their clients' financial health, as well as that of their clients' competitors.
"Right now it's on the agenda of every major law firm in the country," Brad Hildebrandt, chairman of Hildebrandt Inc., an international legal consulting firm, said of the trend toward on-the-job business education. "They're waking up and realizing their lawyers don't have a clue about business-related topics."
In the 1980's, corporate lawyers were occupied with the legal details of a litany of mergers, acquisitions and real estate transactions that left many of them neither the time nor the inclination to examine those deals in the context of a bigger financial picture.
"They never needed to," said Gary L. Fairchild, the managing partner of Winston & Strawn, a 138-year-old firm that also has offices in New York and Washington. "The legal profession has had the luxury of being in such demand that clients would tolerate behavior which I think gained the profession the reputation of being arrogant and disrespectful to business."
But the sluggish economy and the steep decline in the number of major financial transactions have dried up that demand and rocked firms from inside and out.
Many prestigious firms that expanded wantonly in the 1980's have been forced in the 1990's to contract, through layoffs of associates and even partners, in some cases. Forty-four percent of the nation's 250 largest firms have shrunk in size this year, compared with 16.6 percent in 1990, according to a survey published last month in The National Law Journal.
 
Formal and Informal Approaches
 It is hard to say just how many firms are beefing up their business knowledge. Some offer classes on business literacy, while others ruminate more informally on such topics as balance sheets. But lawyers and legal consultants agree that such activity has picked up in the last year.
Their clients, also sapped by the recession, have less work to offer, further increasing the competition among the law firms. Not only are those clients seeking more cost-effective legal service, but they are also increasingly looking for an edge that differentiates one law office from another.
To that end, Winston & Strawn, whose clients include National Westminster Bank USA and Heller Financial Inc., a subsidiary of Fuji Bank of Japan, has inaugurated a program called Above Client Expectations, ACE. Through the program, the firm assembles small groups of its 500 lawyers and drills them in a four-day business course. The teacher is Wiliam J. Flannery, the president of WJF Institute, a consulting firm in Austin, Tex., that specializes in training lawyers.
 
Reading a Balance Sheet
 In a presentation on financial research, for example, Mr. Flannery, who has a degree from the University of Baltimore law school, teaches the lawyers how to use basic financial documents -- from balance sheets to annual reports to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
For a discussion of ways to improve service, Mr. Flannery videotapes the lawyers' interactions with mock clients, and then evaluates their performances.
The goal of such training, which most lawyers have not had in law school, is to make them comfortable discussing a client's overall strategy. That, Mr. Fairchild said, helps earn a client's confidence.
"We're not trying to make instant experts out of our attorneys," Mr. Fairchild said. "What we're trying to do is give them the resources to deal intelligently with the management of the company so they can help the company succeed."
 
Preparing Estimates of Fees
 At Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, which has 715 lawyers in 18 offices, an increase in clients' questions about legal costs over the last year prompted the firm to borrow a standard technique from the business world: for the first time, its partners are preparing detailed budgets of what a case might cost.
Like other firms, Gibson, Dunn had traditionally avoided all but the most cursory of budgets, because the twists and turns of litigation, for example, are difficult to anticipate. But a customized computer software program on budgets, which the firm developed with an outside consultant, has helped generate better estimates of the hours that may be spent on services like pleadings, depositions and case planning. Those hours are then translated into dollars.
"This gives you something to sit down with the client and discuss," said Robert E. Cooper, the firm's vice chairman.
 
Fewer Surprises
 And to account for the vagaries of the legal process, those discussions now take place monthly and quarterly, meaning there are fewer surprises along the way.
The procedures have pleased Harland Reid, assistant general counsel at Nissan Motor, which is a client of Gibson, Dunn.
"It makes you focus early, in a detailed way, on what it's going to take to get to the result you want," Mr. Reid said.
 
Literal Field Work
 Though Gibson, Dunn and Winston & Strawn are among the nation's largest firms, smaller corporate firms like Malouf Lynch in Dallas, have started playing closer attention to business issues.
In a fresh approach, Malouf Lynch has taught its 16 lawyers to immerse themselves not only in the businesses of their clients, but also in those of the competition.
Gary S. Kessler, a Malouf Lynch partner, has as a client Gustafson Inc., an agricultural chemical unit of the Uniroyal Chemical Company. Mr. Kessler took his firm's know-thy-client mandate to heart and traveled to Kansas, where he quizzed farmers about the products they use, including an agricultural pesticide made by Gustafson.
In response to the increasing globalization of business, some firms are including the corporate customs of other countries in their training.
At Schulte Roth & Zabel, a New York firm, the topic is Japan, where the firm is harnessing an increasing stable of banks and securities firms.
Nine months ago the firm hired Bonnie L. Dixon, an associate with three years' experience at a Japanese law firm, who has since conducted lectures and private consultations to educate Schulte Roth's lawyers on Japanese business.
Ms. Dixon has, for example, discussed Japanese corporate structure, explaining that a general manager is ranked higher than a senior manager, who is higher than a section chief. She has also touched on areas of etiquette -- such as how to give gifts and how to seat executives in order of importance -- so that the firm's lawyers will not offend their clients through ignorance.
"We want to avoid any possibility of being described as arrogant lawyers," Ms. Dixon said. "We're trying to make some accommodation to their business practices."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in U.S. Trading And Gold Is Up Moderately

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly lower in domestic trading yesterday in a muted reaction to a surge in inflation last month. It rose overseas.
Gold prices rose modestly, gaining 70 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, to $356.60 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $356.10, up 45 cents. 
 Analysts said the Government's announcement that wholesale prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in October took the foreign exchange markets by surprise but had little impact.
"Not much credence was put on it by the market," said Ronald H. Holzer, chief dealer with Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
Ordinarily, a surge in prices would be expected to move the dollar higher. Traders believe a unfavorable producer price report makes the Federal Reserve more likely to push interest rates up to control inflation. The dollar is supported by higher rates, which increase foreign demand for American investments.
But the Fed is seen as more concerned about the weak economy than a jump in inflation, so traders are shrugging off the one-month rise in prices.
Mr. Holzer said the dollar was locked in a narrow range. Traders are "continuing to look for evidence on the economy," he added.
More inflation news is scheduled for today, with the release of October consumer price figures. The Government will also announce real earnings figures for October, followed tomorrow by the October industrial production and September business inventories figures.
The British pound rose to $1.7745 in New York, from $1.7700 on Tuesday. But earlier in London, sterling cost $1.7715, down from $1.7730.
The dollar advanced against the Japanese yen, rising to 130.00 yen in New York, from 129.95 on Tuesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.03 yen, to 129.98. In London, it was quoted at 130.13.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.6360 German marks, down from 1.6400; 1.4515 Swiss francs, down from 1.4535; 5.5900 French francs, down from 5.6045; 1,231.00 Italian lire, down from 1,235.00, and 1.13145 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13475.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late on Tuesday, included: 1.6380 German marks, up from 1.6355; 1.4515 Swiss francs, up from 1.4508; 5.5960 French francs, up from 5.5880; 1.8455 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8425; 1,232.60 Italian lire, up from 1,231.50, and 1.1321 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1315.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Mercedes-Benz to Review Account With McCaffrey

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
IN a decision that left agency, and industry, executives stunned, Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc. said yesterday that it was putting up for review its estimated $90 million account that has been at McCaffrey & McCall since 1979.
The unexpected announcement came in a statement by Mike Jackson, the senior vice president for marketing and sales at the German automobile maker's American subsidiary in Montvale, N.J. 
 "McCaffrey & McCall continues to serve us well," he said. "However, we believe it is a prudent business decision to examine what other resources are available to insure we are receiving the best representation we can get, especially in today's difficult and competitive business climate."
A spokeswoman for Mercedes-Benz, Linda Paulmeno, said there would be no elaboration on the statement. She said, however, the decision to begin the review "is most definitely not a reflection on the work the agency is providing us with."
Ms. Paulmeno compared the review, which is to start later this month, to other steps by Mercedes-Benz to re-evaluate its business operations since 1988. The luxury car line has been under increasingly intense pressure to defend its territory from Japanese rivals -- Acura, Infiniti and Lexus -- as well as to cope with the continuing soft economy.
Through October, Mercedes-Benz's sales in the United States were down by 20.7 percent from the first 10 months of last year.
McCaffrey is being included in the review, which Mercedes-Benz expects to have completed in February.
"We're going to participate, absolutely," Bob Cherins, McCaffrey's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday, "with vim and vigor."
Agency executives are "disappointed" that Mercedes-Benz wants a review, Mr. Cherins said, "but we have every confidence that we will win, and win big."
McCaffrey has been turning out stylish, understated campaigns for Mercedes-Benz models, most recently under the theme "Engineered like no other car in the world," since it won the account 12 years ago from Ogilvy & Mather. McCaffrey is now running a significant campaign to introduce the redesigned Mercedes S-Class, the most expensive line of Mercedes-Benz automobiles ever.
Mercedes-Benz has retained a marketing and advertising consultant to advise it during the review. He is Bill Weilbacher of the Bismark Corporation in Dennis, Mass., who spent 30 years in the agency business at shops like Dancer Fitzgerald Sample.
Mr. Weilbacher said yesterday that he could not discuss his work for Mercedes-Benz. Among the recent reviews he has handled, he listed two in which the client changed agencies: Domino's Pizza Inc., which moved to Grey Advertising from Group 243 Inc., and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, which left Backer Spielvogel Bates for Lowe & Partners.
So far, no agencies other than McCaffrey will participate, or be invited to participate, in the review, Ms. Paulmeno said. Already, though, industry executives are rounding up the usual suspects -- the mid-sized and large creatively focused agencies that do not possess that badge of industry respectability, a car account.
Among those mentioned yesterday as possibilities were Altschiller Reitzfeld Tracy-Locke in New York; Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis; McCabe & Company in New York; McElligott Wright Morrison White in Minneapolis, and TBWA Advertising, also in New York.
The Mercedes-Benz announcement is the latest in an unprecedented skein of decisions by giant marketers to put their large ad accounts up for review. Among others now pending are those of Amoco Oil; Bacardi Imports, also currently handled by McCaffrey, and the Compaq Computer Corporation.
In the two most recent car-account reviews, both companies switched agencies: Subaru of America, which left Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver, for Wieden & Kennedy, and American Isuzu Motors, which left Della Femina, McNamee Inc. for Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Fund Yields Move Sharply Lower

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on both tax-exempt and taxable money market funds fell sharply in the week that ended yesterday, mostly in response to the Federal Reserve's recent easing of credit, according to IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues The Money Fund Report.
"We expect it will take a few weeks before we see any further action by the Federal Reserve," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/ Donoghue's. "The all-important Christmas season will determine the Fed's next move." 
 He reported that total assets of the tax-exempt funds had risen by $1.2 billion, to $91.1 billion. "That was a story for the week," he said, calling it a huge inflow of money. When yields on taxable funds are dropping fast, the tax-exempt funds become more attractive to investors, he explained.
 
Tax-Exempt Yield of 3.82%
 The average days to maturity of holdings in the tax-exempt portfolios slipped to 59 days from 60.
The seven-day compound average yield for tax-exempt funds was down to 3.82 percent, from 3.98 percent a week ago, while the seven-day simple yield dropped to 3.75 percent from 3.90 percent.
Meanwhile, the 30-day compound yield dropped to 3.89 percent from 3.93 percent, while the 30-day simple yield was 3.82 percent, down from 3.86 percent.
Among tax-exempt funds investing in individual state securities, the top New York fund was once again the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound of 4.50 percent this week, compared with 4.59 percent the previous week.
In Connecticut, the leader was Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, reporting a yield of 4.13 percent, down from 4.28 percent.
Calvert Tax Free Reserves New Jersey led the way in that state, with a yield of 4.33 percent, down from 4.54 percent.
 
More Assets at Taxable Funds
 The highest-yielding tax-exempt fund among those with assets greater than $100 million continued to be Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.84, down from 5.05 percent.
Assets of taxable funds, Mr. Frank said, rose by $500 million, to a total of $464.1 billion. "All of the rise and more came from the institutional investors, because fund assets from such sources rose by $1.3 billion, which means that the public withdrew $800 million from the funds," he said.
"This is a pattern that we have seen recently and is to be expected." Mr. Frank explained that the institutions holding cash want the highest yield on it and they often find it in money funds when interest rates are falling. The public, he believes, is investing in the stock market or going into bond funds.
Average maturities of portfolio holdings were unchanged at 63 days.
 
Taxable Yield of 4.92%
 The seven-day compound yield on taxable funds dropped to 4.92 cent from 5.05 percent, while the seven-day simple yield for the taxable funds dropped to 4.81 percent from 4.93 pecent.
Meanwhile, the average compound 30-day yield fell to 5.06 percent from 5.11 percent, and the 30-day simple yield was down to 4.94 percent from 4.99 percent.
The top-yielding fund for the week among the taxables was Riverside Capital of Columbus, Ohio, with a seven-day compound yield of 6.07 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped to a yield of 4.78 percent, from 4.86 a week earlier, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Credit Survey Hints of Easing

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
A survey of banks suggests that the worst of the cycle of credit tightening may be over, the Federal Reserve Board said today.
An October poll found that nearly all the banks surveyed said they had not changed their credit standards for approving business loan applications since an August survey. 
 "In light of the historical tendency of banks to report that they have tightened standards, the virtual absence of reported tightening of standards might be interpreted as indicating that standards actually have been eased," the central bank said in a footnote to the survey summary.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has said banks are partly responsible for a tightening of credit that has contributed greatly to the "demonstrably sluggish" condition of the economy.
The survey also found weakened business demand for loans from domestic banks in recent months, although there was some evidence of strength at foreign banks. The poll included both domestic and foreign banks operating in the United States.
"Demand for consumer installment loans also weakened recently, as did demand for home equity loans, though to a lesser extent," the summary said, while adding that "banks' willingness to provide consumer credit over the last three months appeared to increase some."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
An Ethnic Push In Credit Cards

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 13

 BODY:
A Connecticut bank and a Spanish-language television network are embarking on a nationwide effort to market credit cards to Hispanic customers.
People's Bank, based in Bridgeport, began offering the cards today through a special toll-free number, and will make applications and monthly statements available in Spanish and English. 
 Telemundo Group Inc., one of two major Hispanic television networks, is co-sponsoring the Mastercard and Visa cards. The New York-based company will promote the cards through its 42 owned and affiliated stations, which reach 6 million Spanish-speaking households.
Advertising for the promotion, which will run on the Telemundo network, begins later this month in Miami and the San Francisco-San Jose area, and is scheduled to start early next year nationwide.
People's Bank hopes the offer will increase its base of credit card customers, who now number 300,000 in all 50 states. Telemundo hopes the offer will heighten the network's prestige and improve the financial standing of Hispanic people, whose use of credit cards lags far behind the general population's.
Both companies said Telemundo chose People's for the offer largely because of the bank's low 13.9 percent interest rate on credit card balances.

HEADLINE: LARGE RISE POSTED IN PRODUCER PRICES

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
In an inflation report that startled analysts, prices received by American producers jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest increase in a year, Government figures showed today. But close examination found the report much less worrisome than it first appeared.
Given the weak economy -- and perhaps lulled by a string of favorable reports -- most specialists had expected little change in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which measures inflation in the cost of goods just before they reach retail shelves and showrooms. 
 Analysts said the report was likely to reduce the chances of a further easing of Federal Reserve monetary policy, a prospect that was not considered highly likely anyway because the central bank had moved just last week to lower interest rates.
 
Widespread Rise in Costs
 The surprise jump in producer prices, reflected in an array of products from energy to books, touched off quick declines in the securities markets. But then economists found the price data to be not so bad as the bottom line implied, and stock prices rebounded to finish with a modest gain for the day, while the bond market recovered about half its losses.
Most analysts, to one degree or another, regarded the October Producer Price Index as a fluke, a result of Labor Department difficulties in adjusting the figures to take account of seasonal variations. In addition, the October data gathered into one month a number of price increases, some of which seem unlikely to be sustained.
"I think it's an aberration," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Economics. "We simply have not seen any sign of consumer or corporate demand for products" that would be consistent with high inflation, he added. "There's surplus labor, surplus capital all over."
The price of new cars, for example, rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month and that of light trucks surged 1.2 percent, today's report showed, but the figures are at odds with all the evidence about car sales. Indeed, auto makers issued another grim report today, saying sales were down 13.4 percent for the first 10 days of this month.
 
A Decline in One Sector
 Analysts said they were encouraged by the price report's finding that costs at the intermediate stage of production -- a sack of flour, say, as compared with a loaf of bread -- posted a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent, offsetting a September advance.
"The producer price increase appears to be an inflationary red herring in the road of a relatively non-inflationary, weak economy," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade association whose members pay the prices recorded by the finished-goods index.
"Producers increased prices on a broad range of goods in October," he said, "but whether these increases will stick, in the face of continued hesitancy to spend by consumers and businesses, remains to be seen."
There were some specialists, however, who found little to cheer in today's report, which included a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in the so-called core inflation rate, the worst performance since January. The core rate, which omits the usually erratic food and energy components, was unchanged in September and monthly increases in the June-August period averaged just one-tenth of 1 percent.
 
A Negative Interpretation
 "A five-tenths of 1 percent core for finished goods is clearly a quantum difference from preceding months," said Joel Popkin, a former Labor Department price official who now runs a Washington consulting company.
Mr. Popkin, less inclined than many others to find significant improvement in the nation's price performance over the last year or two, described inflation as "intractable" and, though not accelerating, "not getting any better."
The increase in finished-goods prices, to a level 22.3 percent higher than its 1982 base but unchanged from its October 1990 level, was heavily influenced by a 1.7 percent gain in energy prices, twice the September increase, and a rise in food prices of four-tenths of 1 percent, which followed a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Electricity and gasoline rose sharply, and liquefied petroleum gas soared 17.1 percent. But the price of natural gas fell, and home heating oil rose much less than in the preceding months.
Beef and veal, pork and processed chickens all turned higher last month, while dairy products and fish rose considerably more than in September. Fresh and dried fruits and vegetables and processed turkeys each fell more than 10 percent, the department reported, and confectionery products also declined.
 
Drugs, Soap and Books
 Elsewhere, prescription drugs climbed 2.2 percent, soaps and synthetic detergents jumped 4.7 percent, tires rose 1.7 percent, books rose 3.1 percent and tobacco products rose eight-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month, after rising 1.1 percent in August.
Consumer durable goods, including cars, advanced eight-tenths of 1 percent in October after a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in September. The department said the October rise "may be somewhat overstated" because of statistical problems related to the index's being directly adjusted for seasonal variation and not calculated as the sum of its seasonally adjusted components.
Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, indicated that without the statistical problems the increase in the core rate, five-tenths of 1 percent, might have been one-tenth or two-tenths of a point less.
Among intermediate goods, the index for durable manufacturing materials, like aluminum and copper, fell six-tenths of 1 percent, while non-durable factory materials, like paperboard and paint, fell three-tenths.
Prices at the crude stage of production posted a rise of 1.8 percent, with energy prices accounting for most of that. The gain followed a drop of nine-tenths of 1 percent in September and unchanged readings in July and August.
Kevin Flanagan, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds, said that while he was not particularly worried by today's report, which is to be followed on Thursday by the Consumer Price Index for October, the big increase should not be disregarded.
"It rekindles the thought that inflation forces are still with us," he declared.

HEADLINE: Report Says U.S. Industry In a Decline

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
A new five-year Congressional study warns that American manufacturing has lost its competitive edge and recommends that the Government consider various strategies to halt the decline.
The Office of Technology Assessment, a Congressional research agency, said in its report that the Government could act in several areas: to help manufacturers obtain "patient capital" from investors who did not expect immediate rewards; to help upgrade education and training for managers, engineers and technicians; to help extend new technologies to companies throughout the manufacturing sector; to promote the development of new technologies, and to develop trade policies that protected infant industries."A protected home market can enable domestic firms to catch up with more advanced foreign companies without having to compete with them for domestic customers," the report said.
 
White House Opposition
 The Bush Administration has opposed such efforts as "industrial policy" that would reward industries with the most political influence, rather than those that would help America compete globally. Like the Reagan Administration, the Bush Administration has championed free markets and free trade, and has insisted that the market was better suited than Government to choose industries and technologies that would make aid the nation's welfare. 
 The report appeared to touch off a Democratic pep rally.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the Finance Committee chairman, noted last week's upset victory by Senator Harris L. Wofford, a Democrat, and said: "The message from Pennsylvania and from O.T.A. is the same -- it is time for change. It is time for policies that will put American manufacturers back in competition."
Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, the chairman of the Banking Committee, said, "Our Government has refused to recognize the problem."
 
'Behind the Competition'
 The Congressional report stated flatly that "U.S. manufacturing is falling behind the competition." It noted that America's share of world imports rose to 17.5 percent in 1986, from 12.9 percent in 1970, while the United States share of world exports fell to 10.3 percent, from 13.8 percent in the same period.

HEADLINE: Bill on Credit Card Rates Advances

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Senate approved a measure tonight to limit the interest rates that banks can charge credit card holders to 14 percent.
The measure passed 74 to 19. Some said it would help ease what they saw as a shortage of credit and others argued that it was pro-consumer. 
 The vote came a day after President Bush complained at a fund-raising luncheon in New York that credit card rates were too high and that lower rates would stimulate consumer confidence.
Although Mr. Bush's remarks were a result of a recent political strategy turn, an actual cap on interest rates is expected to be opposed by the Treasury Department, which views it as too restrictive on the banks.
Many banks charge customers rates of more than 19 percent, even though they pay far lower interest rates.
The measure approved today would limit interest to four points above the rate that the Internal Revenue Service charges to people who underpay their taxes.
The I.RR.S. rate is currently 10 percent.

HEADLINE: 13.4% Drop In Sales Of Vehicles

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 13.4 percent in early November, auto makers reported today. Some analysts said the figures confirmed their belief that the industry was in its second recession of 1991 after what had seemed a promising summer.
"It looks like it's a double-dip recession," said Ronald A. Glantz, an automotive analyst with Dean Witter in San Francisco. Many analysts had attributed sluggish sales through October to rebates and other big incentives in September, which helped raise the sales of leftover 1991 models. 
 But the continuing weak sales have cast doubt on that explanation, Mr. Glantz said. The industry can no longer talk itself into saying it was paying for the incentives in September with lost sales in November.
 
Showroom Traffic Drops
 Several dealers said showroom traffic and sales were down as much as 30 percent compared with 1990.
"We are dead in the water," said Joe Gentile, owner of Gentile Chrysler-Plymouth in Barrington, Ill., near Chicago. He said that after business soured further in the last two weeks, he started meeting with all customers before they left the showroom to give them a small gift. He has also doubled his direct mailings to former customers to drum up business. "You've got to do something to set yourself apart from other dealers," he said.
Maryann N. Keller, an analyst with Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney in New York, said the poor sales figures were consistent with other recent economic news. "Clearly something happened in late summer or early fall to change consumer attitudes," she added.
 
Annual Sales Rate Off
 Car sales declined 15.2 percent, to 116,848, from Nov. 1 to Nov. 10, the latest reporting period, when there were eight selling days, compared with nine selling days in the period last year. The seasonally adjusted sales rate of American-made cars was 5.7 million in early November, compared with 6.5 million at the corresponding time in 1990. Sales of light trucks, which includes pickups, mini-vans, and sport utility vehicles, dropped 10.1 percent, to 69,009.
Business is also down by roughly a third at Steven Mitchell's three dealerships near Hartford, which sell several lines of foreign and domestic cars. He estimates that his Subaru dealership, which sold 500 cars a year in the late 1980's, would not likely pass the 200 sales mark this year. In the last year, Mr. Mitchell has also trimmed his staff to 120 from 165, including telephone receptionists and sales managers.
But sales were roughly even with last year in recent weeks at Ackerman Chevrolet Geo in St. Louis, said Fred Sredl, general manager. Despite a drop in showroom traffic of roughly 25 percent, shoppers are generally interested in buying and have good credit, he said.
The Big Three's collective sales decline was 15.7 percent for cars in early November. Japanese companies that build cars in the United States reported an overall drop of 11.9 percent. These transplant manufacturers raised their share of the American car market to 13.5 percent in early November from 13 percent a year earlier. The Big Three saw their market share decline to 86.5 percent, from 87 percent a year earlier.
The General Motors Corporation's car sales dropped 7.7 percent, to 56,508, and light-truck sales dropped 20.7 percent, to 26,574.
The Ford Motor Company reported a drop of 22.5 percent in car sales to 32,466 and its light-truck sales fell 12.6 percent, to 24,439.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales dropped 27.6 percent, to 12,150, based on estimates by Ward's. Its truck sales rose 21.3 percent, to 15,700.
The Honda Motor Company sold 6,983 American-built cars, a drop of 18.2 percent. The Toyota Motor Corporation reported a sales drop of 12.1 percent in the period, to 4,711 cars.

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
Critics Want Fed Power Accountable

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve holds an anomalous position in the American system. An enormously powerful Government agency, it is only loosely accountable to the public and to elected officials, and it allows private citizens, basically a banking elite, to help set the Government's economic policy.
When the economy is sour, as it is now, this odd structure tends to become a focus of attention, a sponge that soaks up frustrations over the way the economy is going. 
 Critics of the central bank had a new twist this morning. At a Senate hearing, several prominent lawmakers, an economist who holds a Nobel Prize and a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board testified in favor of legislation to make the agency more politically accountable. The measure would prevent the presidents of regional Federal Reserve banks, who hold no Government office and answer to no Government official, from voting on Government policy as they do now.
The bill is not likely to be enacted, at least not any time soon, but the legislation has stirred up a new debate on the extent to which the Fed operates outside the bounds of an open society.
"Power without accountability does not fit the American system of democracy," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat who is a frequent critic of the Federal Reserve and one of the most widely respected members of Congress.
Using its power to raise or lower interest rates, the Federal Reserve has much more influence over the state of the economy than any other Government agency. That is especially true nowadays, when the large budget deficit has caused the White House and Congress to relinquish much of their grip on economic policy.
The Fed sets monetary policy on the basis of votes by the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board and five of the 12 presidents of the Federal Reserve banks, who vote on a rotating basis.
The governors are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. But the regional Federal Reserve banks are private institutions. Their presidents tend to be career employees of the Federal Reserve, steeped in its culture. They are selected by the banks' directors, who are mostly commercial bankers from the region and who pick officers likely to be sympathetic to their views.
 
Target of Politicians
 Many politicians blame the central bank for the current weakness of the economy, saying interest rates should have been driven down more quickly than they were. Reports in the last two years have said that Alan Greenspan, chairman of the board, and most of the other governors have been more inclined toward lower rates than the presidents of the regional banks.
For most of this year, there have been two vacancies on the board, meaning that the bank presidents had as many votes as the Fed governors. The published votes have shown few if any dissents from the policies adopted. But that may be because Mr. Greenspan is careful not to press matters to votes that would show a sharp split.
The legislation under discussion at today's hearing before the Senate Banking Committee would leave all voting on monetary policy to the members of the Federal Reserve Board and would relegate the bank presidents to an advisory capacity.
"Nowhere else in the Government," Mr. Hamilton said, "are private individuals similarly permitted to participate in decisions which have such an enormous influence over the prosperity and well-being of millions of Americans."
The central banks in the other leading democracies around the world vary in their independence from Government control. But in no other country, according to Prof. John B. Goodman, a student of the subject at the Harvard Business School, are votes on policy cast by people who are not appointed by the Government.
Some legal scholars believe the American system to be unconstitutional, a violation of the appointments clause of the Constitution, which requires policy-making officials to be nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. A lawsuit on the matter several years ago was dismissed on a technicality, and the main issue has never been addressed by the courts.
Meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee, where policy decisions are made, are held behind locked doors. No transcript or official notes are kept that would show who said what. The decisions are not announced for six weeks or more. Even then only a skeletal summary of what transpired is made public, and those who voted do not normally explain their votes the way, say, Supreme Court justices write opinions.
Further, no other branch of government can veto the central bank's decisions, and the Fed's accounts are not audited by any outside agency.
Over the years, Mr. Hamilton and his allies have offered legislation to change much of this, but the bills have never gotten past the hearings stage. In part, that is because monetary policy is so often unpopular that Presidents and legislators are happy to have those policy makers to criticize when the economy turns sour.
But another, perhaps more important reason is that the lawmakers and scholars who advocate changing the way the Federal Reserve works are almost always those who want lower interest rates. Preston Martin, who was vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board from 1982 to 1986, said at today's hearing that the regional bank presidents generally felt much more strongly about keeping interest rates high than did the members of the reserve board.
Many politicians say they favor low interest rates but believe in their hearts that higher rates are necessary to control inflation.
Mr. Greenspan has convinced lawmakers that changes in the Fed's operations would not only give the central bank less flexibility in setting monetary policy but could also cause instability in markets that are familiar with the current system.
Christopher Whalen, who runs an economic consulting firm here, told his clients in a recent newsletter that the bill to take voting power away from the Federal Reserve bank presidents would "vastly increase the exposure of U.S. monetary policy to overt political pressure."
But supporters of the legislation dismiss those fears. James Tobin, the Nobel Prize-winning economist, was a bit contemptuous of the political pressure argument in his testimony before the Banking Committee today. "Politics?" he said. "In a representative democracy? Think of it. Economic performance necessarily involves political choices."
Mr. Tobin said he knew of no instance when private bankers made use of inside information from the Federal Reserve. But he said in an interview during a break in the hearing that he worried about a potential conflict of interest.
He gave one example. Under the law, the Federal Reserve Board can change the discount rate, the rate the Fed charges commercial banks for loans, only at the request of the directors of at least one regional Federal Reserve bank. Sometimes, when the board wants to change the rate for economic policy reasons, it requests one regional bank or another to make an application. It can be days between the time the request is made and the time the Fed announces that the rate has been lowered.
During that time, Mr. Tobin observed, the commercial bankers who act as directors of the regional bank have potentially advantageous knowledge about the direction of monetary policy.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Comparing Central Banks in Some Industrial Economies"
In some large industrial democracies, the central bank is basically part of the elected Government. In others, the bank is more or less independent of the Government. Here is a rough ranking, from from the most independent to the least.
SWITZERLAND. Swiss National Bank. Completely independent. Members of Governing Board appointed by Cabinet, but private economic interests have considerable influence in the Board's direction.
GERMANY. Bundesbank. Almost totally independent. Government chooses members of the directorate, including the President. Other policy-makers chosen directly or indirectly by elected officials.
UNITED STATES. Federal Reserve. Has significant independence. Board members nominated by the President for fixed terms of office and confirmed by the Senate. They report regularly, by law, to Congress. The Federal Reserve bank presidents selected by private interests, have minority vote on the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee.
CANADA. Bank of Canada. Under law, the Finance Minister can order a specific course of action. Such a directive has never been issued.
ITALY. Bank of Italy. In theory, all important decisions made by the elected Government. In practice, it rarely if ever overrules the bank.
JAPAN. Bank of Japan. Two top officials of the Government sit on the Policy Board. Under law, the Finance Minister can direct the Bank to act. In practice, though, disagreements are worked out informally. Unlike the others, the Bank of Japan does not control its own budget.
BRITAIN. Bank of England. Subordinate to the Government, although a majority of directors are drawn from commercial banking. With policy disagreements resolved under law in favor of the Treasury, the Government has never had to issue a formal directive.
FRANCE. Bank of France. Subordinate to Government. Its officials can be dismissed at will. In practice, the Treasury and the Bank consult frequently. (Source: Joint Economic Committee; John B. Goodman)

HEADLINE: Midway Air Shuts Down After Buyout Is Abandoned

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Midway Airlines said it had ceased operations early this morning. The announcement came just hours after Northwest Airlines said it was abandoning its effort to acquire the small Chicago-based carrier.
Midway, which employs 4,000 people, had been trying to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code and will now probably have to liquidate. 
 A recording on Midway's reservations phone line advised ticket holders to contact their travel agents and credit card companies. In past airline shutdowns, other carriers have honored tickets.
Midway Airport in Chicago, the home base for the airline, said no flights were scheduled in or out of the airport around midnight central time, when the airline ceased operation. There were also no Midway flights scheduled at La Guardia Airport in New York at that hour.
The carrier's collapse is another significant blow to deregulation, which had sought to create several airlines able to compete with older, larger carriers.
If Midway liquidates, only one important airline created after the industry was deregulated in 1979 will be left, America West Airlines. But it has also had troubles and is operating under the protection of the bankruptcy code.
Midway was born shortly after deregulation began. It underwent several changes in strategy, becoming an airline that provided upgraded service at coach prices to attract the business flier. The strategy did not succeed since Midway could not match the frequency of flights of competitors like United Airlines and American Airlines. Unlike the big carriers, Midway was unable to offer the frequent-flier programs that attract business travelers.
The airline struggled along, however, by offering lower fares than its competitors. It also had advantage of flying into Midway Airport, which is closer to downtown Chicago than O'Hare International Airport, which handles most flights.
The carrier was already financially weakened before the Persian Gulf war cut traffic and caused fuel prices to double.
Midway issued a statement late last night from Chicago, saying: "As a result of Northwest Airlines' unilateral decision to withdraw from its commitment to acquire substantially all of Midway's assets, effective midnight, Wednesday, Nov. 13, Midway will cease operations.
"Midway deeply regrets the inconvenience caused to our loyal customers by the cancellation of all Midway service."
 
Analysts Speculate on Motives
 The collapse of the deal with Northwest prompted analysts to wonder whether Northwest wanted to get out of the deal for some hidden reason or whether it simply felt deceived by Midway, as Northwest's president, John H. Dasburg, contends.
On the surface the deal was small potatoes. Northwest agreed to acquire the carrier mostly by assuming debt of about $153 million. The agreement was approved by the Federal court overseeing Midway's bankruptcy reorganization.
There have been concerns about Northwest's viability, however, since Alfred Checchi and a group of investors took over the carrier's parent, NWA Inc., in a $3.6 billion leveraged buyout in July 1989.
But earlier this week, Northwest considerably strengthened its balance sheet. Minnesota agreed to provide the airline with a package of financial assistance worth about $740 million.
The package includes a $390 million loan to the airline backed by the Metropolitan Airport Commission. Another $350 million will be used to build two maintenance bases in Duluth and Hibbing.
Jeffrey W. Hamiel, the executive director of the airport commission, said the agency had been seeking to find out what kind of economic impact an acquisition of Midway would have on Northwest.
As such, the agreement to buy Midway could have threatened to unravel the financial package.
The package is a coup for the airline, which is getting the state and its agencies to help it pay off its debts. In return, the airline must put up some assets as collateral and promise that it will not move its headquarters from Minneapolis. The package still has to be approved by some state agencies.
Accompanying the good news, however, was a dose of bad news from Price Waterhouse, which did a financial analysis of the airline for the Metropolitan Airport Commission.
 
Large Losses, Large Debts
 "Northwest has recently incurred large losses, continues to hold a large portion of acquisition debt and has little equity," the accounting firm said. "In addition, its prospects for the future are dependent on many circumstances that it does not control."
Thus, the financing agreed to by the state, it said, "has significant elements of risk."
The analysis has caused an outcry among legislators and the public, some of whom see the state becoming involved in a Chrysler-style bailout.
In order to get the state to go along with the financial package, Northwest had to be on its best financial behavior to reassure nervous officials that its future was secure.
Acquiring a Midway was not the best deal to reassure these officials. Midway has been losing close to $1 million a day.
The feeling among Midway executives is that they have been made the fall guy here.
The executives, along with some analysts, believe that Northwest was looking for a way to back out of its agreement to buy Midway and that assertions that Midway had provided misleading information about its finances was a smokescreen to hide the real reason.
 
Midway's Point of View
 The Midway executives contend that they provided Northwest with their own internal data on revenue and yields -- the amount of revenue generated by a passenger flying one mile -- which gave Northwest accurate information of the airline's condition for the last year.
But Mr. Dasburg of Northwest said the airline had understated its traffic by about 13 percent and overstated its yields by about 25 percent.
Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, sees a connection between Northwest's getting the financing from the state and the airline's decision to drop the Midway deal.
He said Northwest appeared to be under pressure from Minnesota and the airport commission to be conservative in any acquisition.
As a result of the failed deal, Midway shut down. Midway was only able to keep operating as long as it did because it had received a loan from Northest.
Mr. Murphy also said Southwest Airlines, which had made an early bid for Midway, might now no longer be interested in the carrier.

HEADLINE: Bank of Japan Lowers Its Discount Rate Again

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 14

 BODY:
In a sign of increasing worry over the health of the Japanese economy, the Bank of Japan this morning announced the second reduction in its discount rate this year.
The central bank announced the reduction, from 5.5 percent to 5 percent, early this morning, effective immediately. The key rate, which influences deposit and lending rates at banks, was reduced on July 1 by a half a percentage point. 
 In addition, the Government reduced this fall the amount of cash banks must keep on deposit with the central bank, putting more cash into circulation and putting downward pressure on interest rates.
These measures confirm that the central bank has altered its basic policy from containing inflation to trying to spur the economy.
 
Stock Prices Decline
 As usual, the news had been leaked to Japanese newspapers, nearly all of which reported that the rate reduction was coming. Thus, the financial markets already reflected today's actions in their prices.
The Tokyo stock market shrugged off the rate cut. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell 239.69 points, or nearly 1 percent, to close at 24,176.54. The reaction in the bond and money markets was also disappointing.
"This cut was why people bought, so now they want to take some profits," Daniel Marull, a broker with Sanyo Securities, told Reuters.
But most economists and Government officials hailed the reduction, though many described it as possibly too little too late.
The new Finance Minister, Tsutomu Hata, called the move timely and said it would bolster domestic demand and improve the increasingly negative sentiment among corporate managers.
Yasushi Mieno, the central bank governor, also emphasized the impact the rate cut would have on the gloomy psychology of corporate Japan. Recent surveys have shown that corporations are slashing their investment budgets.
A slowdown in Japan could have a ripple effect worldwide, particularly in the United States. Japanese manufacturers might be tempted to increase their exports to the United States to make up for a slowdown at home. That could cause an swifter increase in the trade surplus with the United States and aggravate trade tensions.
Minoru Itoh, a managing director here with Smith Barney, Harris Upham International, was one of many private economists who said the central bank's move might not arrest the economy's slowdown enough to avert a modest recession.
"What you can say is that this may stop decline in the growth rate, but it may not do much more than that," Mr. Itoh said.
