HEADLINE: Three European Nations Propose U.N. Peace Force for Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 13

 BODY:
In an attempt to buttress European efforts to end the Yugoslav civil war, Britain, France and Belgium urged the United Nations Security Council today to dispatch a peacekeeping force to Yugoslavia if the warring Serbian and Croatian factions will agree to a lasting cease-fire.
These three countries -- the three European Community members of the Security Council -- are now drafting a new resolution asking Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to see whether the battling forces would agree to suspend the fighting and allow United Nations units to take up positions between their forces. 
 The proposed resolution, which is likely to be presented to the Council early next week, would also impose an oil embargo on Yugoslavia, requiring its principal suppliers, the Soviet Union and Libya, to cut off shipments to those portions of the old Yugoslav federation whose governments do not comply with the appeals for a cease-fire.
In addition, the resolution would seek to tighten the mandatory arms embargo the Security Council imposed on Yugoslavia just after the fighting started by creating a new mechanism to monitor compliance and seek ways to insure the blockade is effective.
Although the European Community has taken the lead so far in trying to end the Yugoslav civil war, it has little to show for its efforts. All 12 of the cease-fire agreements it has negotiated so far have collapsed, often within hours of their announcement. The Community has no armed forces, nor can it pressure countries that are not members, such as the Soviet Union and Libya, to join in the oil embargo it called to coerce Serbia into accepting and sustaining a cease-fire.
 
Experience in Peacekeeping
 As a result, diplomats say, the European Community is now seeking more solid backing for its peace efforts from the Security Council, which is the highest international body charged with insuring peace and order. Although the European Community has imposed its own trade and aid embargo on Yugoslavia, only the Security Council can order a mandatory oil embargo binding on all countries under international law.
In addition, no other regional organization has the same experience with peacekeeping operations as the United Nations, which is currently deploying over 10,000 soldiers in eight separate operations around the world. It is currently setting up another major peacekeeping and election-monitoring effort in Cambodia, involving several thousand soldiers and many thousands of civilians.
If the Secretary General recommends sending a peacekeeping force, the Security Council would then need to adopt a second, separate resolution dispatching it. European diplomats say they do not known what the likely size, composition or cost of such a force would be.
The new European initiative on Yugoslavia, which has United States backing, seeks to build on the surprise request made by both Serbia and Croatia in the last couple of days for the United Nations to consider sending peacekeeping troops to monitor a cease-fire between their forces.
This request has aroused a faint ray of hope among European politicians and diplomats, who wonder if both sides might finally be willing to accept mediation in their dispute.
Diplomats cautioned tonight that the new European proposal faces formidable political and technical difficulties.
One major problem is to determine where such a force should be deployed. Many diplomats fear Serbia will insist that the United Nations troops be stationed along the present front lines between the opposing forces, a way of asserting its right to keep the territory it has conquered from Croatia. Conversely, Croatia is likely to press for deployment of the forces along the traditional borders between the two republics, effectively returning lost territory to its rule.
 
Vance Backs Proposal
 The United Nations mediator in the conflict, Cyrus R. Vance, a former United States Secretary of State, gave his backing to the proposed new resolution when he briefed the Council on his latest trip to Yugoslavia today. But he stressed that United Nations peacekeeping forces could only play a role if they are invited in by all parties to the conflict and if the factions agreed to a meaningful cease-fire.
Afterwards, Mr. Vance painted a bleak picture of the Yugoslav situation, saying that "with the fighting increasing, winter approaching and the economy in free fall, time is running out for a settlement." But he said that neither he nor Lord Carrington, the European Community's mediator, have given up hope. "We have to get back to the table and start serious negotiations," he said.
Details of the proposed new Security Council peace initiative emerged as fierce fighting continued in Yugoslavia today, although there were some signs that developments are taking a more hopeful turn.
 
Talks in Belgrade
 After discussions in Belgrade with President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, which failed to produce any agreement, Lord Carrington said, "I still think there is a possibility, but keep your fingers crossed."
Meanwhile, France's Minister of Humanitarian Affairs, Bernard Kouchner, arrived in Yugoslavia to seek support for a European Community plan to set up "refugee corridors" out of the besieged city of Dubrovnik, which is surrounded by Serbian forces, so women and children can be evacuated safely. Their evacuation would be supervised by the United Nations Children's Fund.
One possible function of the peacekeeping force, mentioned by Mr. Vance tonight, would be to take control of the military heavy equipment belonging to units of the Yugoslav federal army that are currently beseiged inside their barracks in Croatia.
 
Fate of Heavy Arms
 The Croats refuse to let these soldiers leave unless they surrender this equipment, saying that otherwise they will use it to strengthen the Serbian forces arrayed against them.
But the Serbs fear that the Croats would then use their own heavy guns and tanks against them as they go.
Some third-world Security Council members are reluctant to endorse an oil embargo against Yugoslavia, saying this constitutes illegal interference in the country's internal affairs.
But Western diplomats point out that the Organization of American States has recently imposed a total trade embargo on Haiti in the hope of reversing the military coup that toppled its democratically elected President.

HEADLINE: U.S. Calls North Korea Atom Plan a Global Concern

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told South Korea today that Washington considered North Korea's suspected development of nuclear weapons a matter of urgent global concern and that it was now actively exploring with Japan, China and the Soviet Union ways to curtail the move.
South Korea's Foreign Minister, Lee Sang Ock, endorsed the American initiative to try to further isolate North Korea economically and diplomatically until it opened its nuclear installation to international inspection and halted work on what is suspected to be a reprocessing plant capable of producing hundreds of pounds of weapons-grade plutonimum, a senior Korean official said. 
 In his meeting with the South Korean Foreign Minister, Mr. Baker said Washington had come to see curtailment of the North Korean nuclear development as a "matter of urgency," and something that was "not just a Korean issue but a matter of global concern," according to a Korean official who attended the talks. The North Korean nuclear activity is at Yongbyon, a nuclear complex 60 miles north of Pyongyang.
While Mr. Baker is in Seoul for the annual meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, to discuss Asian trade issues, many of his private discussions have focused on how to generate pressures to halt the North Korean nuclear program before it sets off a nuclear arms race in Asia that could prompt South Korea and Japan to try to develop nuclear weapons.
 
Forcing Inspections
 Having been slow to react to the Iraqi nuclear bomb program, the Bush Administration is trying to make sure that it does not repeat the mistake by underestimating North Korea's moves.
For now, American officials say they are concentrating their efforts on finding ways to squeeze the North Koreans diplomatically and economically in order to force them to open their nuclear installation to the International Atomic Energy Agency for inspection, which the North is obliged to do as a signer of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
But a senior State Department official told reporters traveling with Mr. Baker today that while it is important to compel North Korea to open itself up to international inspection, "we need to go beyond that -- there should not be a reprocessing facility there at all."
Up to now, North Korea has refused to allow any inspection of its nuclear installations and has spurned a South Korean offer on Nov. 8 that both nations agree to forego development of any weapons of mass destruction.
 
Tokyo's Important Gesture
 The first sign of the multilateral American approach was manifested Tuesday when Japan, at Mr. Baker's behest, pledged that it would not go ahead with plans to establish diplomatic relations with North Korea unless it scrapped its center for reprocessing nuclear fuel. Japan's Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, who met Mr. Baker in Tokyo on Monday, made the pledge during a meeting in Seoul with his Korean counterpart.
That gesture was important to the South Koreans, who were annoyed by a visit to North Korea by senior members of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party. Privately, some South Korean diplomats suspect that the Japanese would prefer that the peninsula remain divided so they would never have to compete with a unified Korea -- much the way many European countries preferred a divided Germany.
In addition, on Tuesday Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo, formally requested China's help in halting the North Korean nuclear program. The request was made in Seoul during the first meeting between a Chinese Foreign Minister and a south Korean President. The two countries still do not have diplomatic relations.
The Korean pres agency quoted President Roh as telling Foreign Minister Qian Qichen that continued North Korean nuclear development "would endanger stability, not only on the Korean Peninsula, but also in northeast Asia and the whole world."
 
Last Major Benefactor
 American officials said that in their tentative discussions with the Chinese on the issue, Beijing had indicated some willingness to be helpful, but the extent of cooperation remained to be seen.
With the Soviet Union having already slashed its economic aid to Pyongyang, and demanding to be paid in hard currency for its oil exports to North Korea, China remains the last major benefactor to the isolated Government of Kim Il Sung.
Speaking generally of the evolving American strategy on the North Korean nuclear issue, a senior State Department official said: "What we are doing at this stage is first trying to raise the profile of the issue as a way of starting to build some multilateral diplomacy to deal with it. Second, we are starting to discuss specific steps people might take. The overall strategy is to heighten the sense of isolation of the North Koreans."
Korean officials said Foreign Minister Lee indicated to the Secretary that while his country wanted to see the North Korean nuclear program stopped immediately, it was ambivalent about involving outside powers in too formal a manner.
 
Role of 4 Powers
 While the Koreans recognize that without outside pressure there is little hope that the North Koreans will respond, they have long maintained that the fate of the Korean Peninsuala, particularly questions involving unification and relations between north and south, should be resolved in a direct dialogue between Seoul and Pyongyang.
That is because the North insists that the South is simply a colonial creation of the United States and therefore it will only discuss security issues with Washington and not Seoul. The North wants to conclude a peace treaty with Washington that would ultimately lead to a withdrawal of American forces from the South.
As The Korea Times said in a lead editorial today: "The two-plus-four formula, or German unification method, is not applicable to the Korean case, as the Korean question is fundamentally in the South and North's own hands, whereas German unification required the sanction of the four allied forces -- the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain. Yet, it is the stark reality that Korean problems will be hardly unravelled without assistance and guarantees of the four neighboring powers."
Mr. Baker, Korean officials said, assured Mr. Lee that while Washington sought to enlist the help of Japan, China and the Soviet Union, it would not be in any institutionalized form -- as with the German unification process -- and that the United States still believed that the political future of Korea should be determined in direct talks between the North and the South.
Korean officials quoted Mr. Baker as saying that neverthless, "because of the urgency of the matter all interested countries should be involved."

HEADLINE: Japan Pressures Pyongyang To Dismantle Nuclear Center

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Stepping up pressure against North Korea's efforts to develop atomic weapons, Japan's new Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, said today that Pyongyang must dismantle a key part of its secret nuclear center if it hoped to have normal relations with Tokyo and receive economic assistance.
Until now, Japan has insisted only that the North Korean Government of President Kim Il Sung allow international inspectors to examine the secret project at Yongbyon, a move Mr. Kim's Government has so far refused. A senior Japanese official said tonight that Mr. Miyazawa was now "hardening our position considerably," insisting for the first time that part of the suspected bomb-making complex be taken apart. 
 Japan's new demand seemed to reflect increasing fears that Mr. Kim's Government was getting dangerously close to producing several crude nuclear weapons. In his speech, Mr. Miyazawa focused on the single element of North Korea's program that most worries American and Japanese officials: A fuel reprocessing plant that would enable North Korea to turn its nuclear waste into weapons-grade plutonium.
The plant is expected to be operational within two years, according to Western intelligence experts, and after that would produce enough plutonium to build several nuclear weapons a year.
Meanwhile, in a dispatch from Pyongyang that was monitored in Tokyo, the North Korean Government accused a Pentagon official, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Carl Ford, of urging "forcible inspection" of the nuclear installations. It said such comments were "a downright threat of war to the Korean people."
Today, Mr. Miyazawa said that in a new round of talks with Pyongyang over creating normal relations, scheduled to take place in Beijing next week, Japan would "urge North Korea to comply with a request by the Seoul Government to scrap its nuclear fuel reprocessing plant."
He was referring to a call last week by President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea for a "nuclear-free Korean peninsula." Mr. Roh said that Seoul would renounce the manufacture or possession of nuclear fuel, and would not build a fuel reprocessing plant of its own.
But Mr. Miyazawa's position puts Japan in something of a difficult negotiating spot because Japan is building a giant fuel-reprocessing plant, one that is intended to feed its civilian nuclear power plants. Japanese officials conceded that it would be difficult to argue that North Korea must shut its plant while Japan moves ahead with its own.

HEADLINE: Doctors Reach Tentative Pact In Brooklyn

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
A tentative agreement has been reached between striking doctors at Woodhull hospital and the corporation that pays their salaries, apparently after pressure was applied by the Mayor's office.
The doctors, whose walkout on Tuesday halted all but the most urgent business at Brooklyn's second-busiest hospital, could return to work as early as this morning, their union said. 
 The union's negotiating committee approved the agreement in a 6-to-3 vote last night. Members are to vote on the accord today at noon.
The agreement includes a pledge by the corporation to restore some medical services that had been cut at the hospital in recent months, said Barry Liebowitz, president of the Doctors Council, the union that represents the 300 striking doctors. It also includes a 1.5 percent pay increase, far short of the 3.5 percent increase the doctors had sought.
 
30 Hours of Negotiation
 But Dr. Liebowitz said that proposed changes in the doctors' benefits package mean the total increase in salary and benefits is 4 percent.
"This is a contract that meets the economic needs of doctors as well as the patient care needs of the community," Dr. Liebowitz said. "It is a contract in which doctors gave up money in order to finance the health needs of the community."
The agreement was reached after 30 hours of negotiation between the Doctors Council and the Woodhull Medical Associates Professional Corporation, a private group that receives about $40 million annually from the city to provide medical staff for the Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center.
The doctors began their walkout at 8 A.M. Tuesday, citing issues of salary and quality of patient care.
Negotiations were held at the city's Office of Labor Relations. Dr. Liebowitz said the two sides never met directly but conveyed messages through Labor Commissioner James F. Hanley.
Other officials said that at first Medical Associates refused to negotiate if city officials were involved in the talks, saying that the city did not have jurisdiction over the affairs of a private corporation. It took direct intervention from people close to Mayor David N. Dinkins, these officials said, to bring Medical Associates to the table.
The city has affiliation agreements to staff all of its 11 municipal hospitals, but only two, Woodhull and Coney Island Hospital, are with private corporations. The rest are with medical schools.
Cyril Alcee, the president of Medical Associates, could not be reached for comment. His office said he was attending the contract talks.
John Beckman, a spokesman for the Mayor said: "All along we wanted everyone to negotiate in good faith and we made our views known to both parties."
Although the strike by attending physicians is unusual, there is no state or Federal law prohibiting doctors from unionizing. Because the salaries of the Woodhull doctors are paid by a private corporation, they are not covered by laws that prohibit strikes by government employees. Doctors and administrators said the strike was the first by attending doctors anywhere in the country.
 
Terms of the Agreement
 Among the provisions of the agreement is a commitment by Medical Associates to restore orthopedic services to Woodhull, Dr. Liebowitz said. There have been no orthopedists there in the two months since the remaining four were laid off.
The agreement also includes a promise of a "continuing dialogue" to restore other services that have been eliminated in recent months, including ophthalmology, urology and rehabilitation medicine.
Under the agreement, a five-member panel will be established to review the planned layoffs of 50 doctors. The panel will include two representatives of Medical Associates, two representatives chosen by the union, and one representative of the Williamsburg neighborhood that Woodhull serves.
In addition to the 1.5 percent pay increase, the proposed agreement requires Medical Associates to provide $550,000 to pay for time off for doctors to attend continuing education programs. It guarantees a $1,500 raise for every nine years worked at the hospital and establishes a $25,000 fund to equalize salaries between the doctors working at the hospital's Cumberland Neighborhood Family Care Clinic and those working at Woodhull proper.
The Doctors Council said the average salary of its members who work at Woodhull is $65,000. Doctors who work at Cumberland make an average of $60,000.
The proposed agreement also states that all retirement, medical and other benefits will remain at current levels. Medical Associates had been seeking to cut some retirement benefits.
The agreement, if approved, would expire on June 30, 1992.
Beginning four days before the strike, the Woodhull emergency room was closed, elective surgery was canceled and patients were transferred to other hospitals, reducing the number of patients to 320 from 550. During the strike, care was provided by the hospital's 80 doctors-in-training and 36 nonunion department chiefs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of Doctors Council, the union that represents 300 striking doctors at Woodhull hospital in Brooklyn, walking a picket line yesterday. A tentative agreement was reached that could have the doctors back as early as this morning. (Nancy Siesel for The New York Times) (pg. B10)

HEADLINE: For Philadelphia, a New Management

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Edward G. Rendell, who was elected Mayor of Philadelphia last week by the largest margin in 60 years, is looking for volunteers to help paint City Hall's dingy corridors after he takes office in January.
It's his way of telling people that the city government, which has been in sharp decline for the better part of two decades, is under new management. 
 "People are skeptical," Mr. Rendell, a former District Attorney, said in an interview before leaving for a vacation this week in South Carolina. "But when I came up with the idea of painting City Hall, you should have seen the letters I got. People loved it."
By all accounts, Mr. Rendell has only six months to a year to show state legislators and Wall Street that he can make lemonade out of this city's sour finances and serve it to Philadelphians without a revolt. If he fails, the legislators and financiers will assume that it is business as usual and the city, which already has a cash crisis, will continue to head toward insolvency.
 
They Call Him 'Fast Eddie'
 Many people think Mr. Rendell, who won 68 percent of the vote with a promise of austerity and efficiency, is up to the task. His nickname is "Fast Eddie," and while there is some ambiguity about its origins, it refers to his quick wit and tongue. Mr. Rendell has also shown a flair for setting an agenda and promoting it.
On Election Day, for example, Joseph M. Egan, the Republican candidate for mayor, lost 63 of the city's 66 wards and conceded at 10:05 P.M.. But Mr. Rendell waited until just after 11 P.M. to give his acceptance speech so television stations around the state could broadcast the speech live during the nightly news.
"The things that bind us together are so much greater than the things that separate us," he told his supporters amid thundering applause, "and if we channel that energy the sky's the limit for Philadelphia. I promise that we will hit the ground running and that the change that we talked about will begin almost immediately."
Edward Gene Rendell was born to a wealthy Jewish family on Manhattan's Upper West Side 47 years ago. His father, Jesse, owned a textile business in the garment district and one of his aunts, Stella Sloat, designed sportswear for Jackie Kennedy. His father died in 1958; his mother, Emma, still lives in Manhattan. His older brother, Robert, is a lawyer in Dallas.
 
A Two-Lawyer Family
 The future Mayor graduated from Riverdale Country School in the Bronx, the University of Pennsylvania and Villanova University's School of Law. His wife of 20 years, Marjorie, also went to Penn and Villanova law school, and specializes in bankruptcy cases at a Philadelphia law firm. The Rendells live in East Falls, an affluent neighborhood in northwest Philadelphia, with their 11-year-old son, Jesse.
After law school and a stint in the Army Reserve, Mr. Rendell became an assistant district attorney in Philadelphia. In 1977, at the age of 33, he ran for election as district attorney and won an upset victory over the incumbent. In his eight years as District Attorney, Mr. Rendell is credited with reforming the management of the department and making the judicial system more sensitive in its handling of rape cases.
In 1986 Mr. Rendell lost the Democratic primary for governor to Robert P. Casey, and in 1987 he lost the Democratic mayoral primary to the incumbent, W. Wilson Goode. Mr. Rendell returned to private practice, but spent most of the last four years preparing for this year's campaign.
 
Peace Offering to Unions
 Mr. Rendell has already hit the ground running. At his first news conference after the election he made a peace offering to municipal union leaders, asking them to join a transition committee in an effort to help streamline city operations.
The unions, representing 25,000 workers and 68 percent of the city's $2.3 billion budget this year, opposed Mr. Rendell's candidacy because he vowed to bring the wages and benefits of municipal workers into line with those in private industry, which are, by some estimates, more than 20 percent lower than those of city workers.
At his second news conference, Mr. Rendell scored a public relations victory with Wall Street by announcing that the city's chief financial adviser would be Sam Katz, an expert on municipal finances who was a Republican mayoral candidate in the spring primary. He won 28 percent of the vote, coming in third.
Mr. Katz is one of two chief executives of Public Financial Management, a Philadelphia-based company that is a leading adviser of cities and states on financial planning. The firm, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Marine Midland Bank of New York, has agreed to work without pay this fall as it develops a five-year financial plan for the city. After January, it will become a paid consultant to the city.
The state's newly created financial oversight agency, the Pennsylvania Intergovernmental Cooperation Authority, will review the plan and, if the authority approves it, will borrow about $230 million to pay off the city's accumulated deficits.
 
The Edge of Insolvency
 In an interview, Mr. Katz said the new Mayor would not be able to solve the city's severe financial problems without more state aid, but must quickly show that he is making the best of a bad situation.
Mayor Goode, who is completing his second four-year term and is forbidden by the city charter to seek a third consecutive term, watched the city edge toward insolvency, where it still stands. And in the 1970's, Frank L. Rizzo served two turbulent terms as Mayor, making Philadelphia notorious for police brutality and for giving city workers pay raises before elections.
"To restore confidence, the city needs to outline a clear road map of how we're going to get back to having balanced operating budgets and how we're going to rebuild confidence among the people who are here and the businesses that are here," Mr. Katz said. "It's going to be a very long and difficult undertaking, and it's going to require some pain and sacrifices on the part of a lot of Philadelphians."
Mr. Rendell agreed. "The obstacles are overwhelming," he said. "But I believe if people see sparks of change, they will react."
He also conceded that in trying to save the city, he may lose his job: "It may take a one-term mayor to set this city right. I may be that mayor."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

THE FACE OF UNEMPLOYMENT
In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the recession has been tenacious and indiscriminate, an equal opportunity un-employer that has struck the work force in virtually every job category, tightening its grip over the last two-and-a-half years. Layoffs continue to thin out factories, stores and office suites around the region, even reaching to the usually untouchable, civil servants. Five profiles in unemployment, page B8.

A superintendent hired to clean up a troubled Bronx school district has complained that he is the subject of a cloak-and-dagger "witch hunt" and "fishing expedition" by the city's chief school investigator. Page B3.
 
DEFENDING A DECISION
Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown defended his decision to send two police arson specialists to advise a friend of the Mayor's about a fire in the man's Long Island mansion. He added that he would do the same for anyone. Page B3.
 
THE TRIALS OF A TRAVELING MAYOR
Mayor David N. Dinkins may not be jinxed, but even in Johannesburg, half a world away from the problems that dog daily him in New York, he could be forgiven for wondering. Page B4.

HEADLINE: Pact Reached on Benefits for Jobless

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Congressional leaders and White House officials reached agreement tonight on a $5.1 billion bill to extend unemployment benefits, with some recipients expected to get their checks by Thanksgiving.
After another day of intense negotiations, the House Ways and Means Committee approved the measure tonight 29 to 7, with only Republicans voting against, and lawmakers said they hoped the full House and Senate would approve the legislation and send it to President Bush on Thursday. 
 The bill would extend 6, 13 or 20 weeks of additional unemployment benefits, depending on unemployment rates in individual states, for about three million Americans who have exhausted the standard 26 weeks of payments. It would be paid for largely by increasing estimated tax payments by some high-income taxpayers.
Lawmakers said they viewed the benefit program as the most even-handed way to dole out additional benefits. They said it was fair for workers in states with lower jobless rates to get a shorter extension of benefits because they would probably have less difficulty finding jobs.
The plan is projected to run a $895 million deficit in its first year, fiscal 1992, but would run modest surpluses in the remaining four years, with a total surplus of $241 million.
On a speaker phone from Kansas City, Mr. Bush called Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, and several other Senate Republicans, to praise them for the bill.
"I feel that the deal which you've been able to hammer out is a good one," Mr. Bush said. "And I think it's something I know I can enthusiastically support."
Mr. Dole told the President that the legislation "meets the criteria that you set out -- that you pay for it."
 
Help Those 'Really Hurting'
 Mr. Bush had twice vetoed earlier versions of the bill, asserting first that the recession had ended and then that the bill would add too much to the Federal debt. But tonight, facing pressure from lawmakers in his party to show concern for the jobless, Mr. Bush described the measure as essential to benefit those who have been hit hard by the economy.
"We can help people that are really hurting," the President said, "and do it without burdening every other taxpayer by busting this budget agreement."
Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Long Island Democrat who championed the measure in the House, criticized the Administration for not taking the leadership.
"I am pleased that the President and the Republicans in Congress have finally recognized the need to do something to ease the suffering of jobless Americans," he said. "For months, the Congress has attempted to do something to help the unemployed who are the innocent victims of a recession that is deeper and longer than expected."
Taking issue with such attacks on Republicans, Mr. Dole said the agreement would "take heat off the Democrats who are going to pay for something for a change."
By late Tuesday, officials from the Bush Administration and Congress declared that they were on the brink of an agreement. But the pact came only at the end of a day of negotiations on Capitol Hill between top Labor and Treasury Department officials and lawmakers in both parties.
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, said a major hurdle was whether to intensify collections of student loans to pay for the measure. Without citing him by name, Mr. Michel said that Representative William D. Ford, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Education and Labor Committee, resisted that provision. But he relented, Mr. Michel said, after Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and "the Speaker leaned on him."
Assuming the bill is signed by the President this week, Mr. Michel said there were "good prospects" that recipients would start receiving their chekcs by Thanksgiving.
While the financing would mostly be through speeding income tax collections from wealthy taxpayers with rising incomes who estimate their taxes quarterly, generating $2.6 billion, the bill calls for other tax changes.
 
Withholding Refunds
 In one provision, tax refunds would be withheld from people who are delinquent on Government loans. The legislation would also retain a 0.2 percent payroll tax paid by employers on the first $7,000 paid annually to each employee.
The high-income taxpayers would be forced to pay higher income taxes only if their adjusted gross income grew by more than $40,000 over the prior year, and if the taxpayer had an adjusted gross income over $75,000 in the current year.
People whose incomes were subject to witholding and do not now make estimated quarterly tax installments would not have to suddenly pay new estimated taxes.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, had pressed for giving Mr. Bush three alternatives to break the impasse.
But today Mr. Mitchell indicated that he would go along with the compromise. "I'm encouraged by the apparent breakthrough in providing unemployment insurance benefits to the millions of Americans who need them," he said hours before the agreement was reached.

HEADLINE: Bush Assails Democrats And Defends His Travels

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 13

 BODY:
President Bush today moved to counterattack Democrats who had made his extensive foreign travel a political issue, painting them as isolationist demagogues who were taking "cheap shots" at his global leadership.
In speeches to a group of young farmers in Kansas City and Republican contributors here, the President charged that his critics wanted to "turn their backs on the historic opportunities before us" in global trade and diplomacy that he said his travels sought to exploit. 
 The remarks were Mr. Bush's latest and strongest effort to defuse what had been the Democrats' most effective attack on his Presidency: that he had paid more heed to crises in Moscow and the Middle East than to the recession in his own country.
The President told the national convention of the Future Farmers of America in Kansas City that that accusation was "hogwash." Later, in St. Louis, he accused Democrats of adopting "the ignorance that inspires people to hide from the rest of the world, wishing our problems away instead of creating solutions."
In remarks prepared for delivery to a fund-raiser here for Senator Christopher S. Bond, the President said, "When I go abroad, it's to help America at home in an economic sense and to help our kids live in a more peaceful world."
Today's statewide jaunt fit an emerging pattern in Mr. Bush's nascent, unanounced re-election campaign: daylong swings across a state, mixing party politics with official, but politically photogenic White House business.
As polls suggest that Democratic attacks on his handling of domestic affairs are striking a political chord, Mr. Bush has begun to appear at events where he can play the role of a lone crusader, struggling against Washington's entrenched Democrats to restore the nation's economic well-being.
Today, addressing the high-school students in Kansas City, he cast his critics as head-in-the-sand politicians who would thwart his lonely battle to carry an American peace and prosperity to the far corners of the globe.
Recalling his trip last month to Madrid, where he helped open peace talks on the Middle East, Mr. Bush said: "Let the isolationists turn their backs on the historic opportunities before us. I cannot give up the quest for peace on earth."
 
Arguing for Fair Trade
 He said that he would "never apologize for a single minute I devote to promoting America's interests abroad."
He continued: "When I fight for free and fair trade in Latin America or east Asia or Europe, some will carp and claim I'm pursuing foreign instead of domestic policy. Well, to borrow a word you all understand -- I'll clean it up for you -- that's hogwash."
The President told the students that their future depended on a sound American educational system and on an economy that could compete in world markets.
The President parlayed his remarks on the need to keep American agriculture competitive into another demand that Congress enact a cut in the capital gains tax, the focus so far of the White House's own plans to help the economy out of a recession. He said that a cut in the capital gains tax "would boost investment and jobs in every sector and every industry in the nation" and that "I wish you would help me get that message to Congress."
In an interview here with television station KTVI, Mr. Bush said that he did not believe the nation was in a recession but that it did need "a boost of confidence" before the economy will begin to significantly revive.

HEADLINE: Two Soviet Dancers Want to Stay in the U.S.

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Federal immigration officials said today that two 20-year-old dancers with the Kirov ballet have asked for "immigration benefits," a phrase that usually means a foreigner has requested asylum in the United States.
But bizarre circumstances surrounding the request by the two women underscored how the changes in the Soviet Union and the end of the cold war had transformed the artistic and political landscape. 
 In 1974, the defection of a Kirov star, Mikhail Baryshnikov, was seen as a grand statement about the artistic and personal freedoms of the West. Recent moves by Soviet ballet artists to work with American troupes seem decidedly more prosaic, involving questions of money, visibility and opportunity.
Against this backdrop, the apparent asylum request made by Aleksandra Koltun and Zhanna Sinitsina seemed more a fumbling gesture of dissatisfaction with their other alternatives than a carefully considered statement about artistic freedom.
"The people who talked to them Tuesday night said they didn't really seem to know what they wanted," said one official of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, speaking on condition of anonymity.
 
Harder to Show Persecution
 While the collapse of the Soviet economy has given many more people a motive to leave, the demise of Soviet Communism has made it harder to prove a "well-founded fear of persecution," the customary reason for granting political asylum. As Soviet travel restrictions have eased over the past five years, the number of Soviet citizens requesting political asylum has grown exponentially, from 40 in fiscal year 1986 to 1,043 in fiscal year 1990 and 1,891 in the first half of fiscal 1991.
These requests are no longer granted routinely. Duke Austin, a spokesman for the immigration agency, said that 264 Soviets were granted asylum and about 100 were denied in 1990.
The two dancers left the Kirov on Oct. 26. They showed up at the New York City Ballet on Nov. 1, took some classes but received no job offers, City Ballet officials said.
Oleg Vinogradov, the Kirov's artistic director, said the two called his wife Nov. 7 asking to rejoin the troupe. Mr. Vinogradov's wife, Yelena, sent a car to meet them in New York and brought them back to the Vinogradovs' home in northeast Washington. The home is near the studios of the Universal Ballet Academy, a school founded by the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon. Mrs. Vinogradov supervises Soviet teachers there.
 
A Strange Confrontation
 The dancers' apparent request for asylum came after a strange confrontation outside the house Tuesday afternoon. As Mr. Vinogradov and his wife, accompanied by the two dancers and a Bolshoi ballet star, Vladimir Vassilyev, pulled out of his driveway in a van, a car driven by Alexei Avrin, an emigre who had apparently befriended the two before and during their time in New York, pulled over and blocked the driveway.
The argument was loud enough to prompt a call to the police, who responded to find "the subjects had various reasons for being there," according to a sergeant from the Washington Police, who was at the scene.
The two women, speaking through a translator, made a request for political asylum, the sergeant said, so the police called in the immigration agency and the State Department.
Over the past few years, several dozen ballet artists have found temporary employment with American companies, who usually obtain special work visas for them under a category designated for those with "distinguished merit and ability."
It is unclear whether the two Kirov dancers believed they could follow this pattern when they went to New York at the end of the Kirov's guest engagement in Washington.

HEADLINE: Democrat Sees a Way to Unload Revenue Burdens on the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 13

 BODY:
A leader in the lame-duck Democratic Legislature suggested today that the Democrats might devise a way to make their $2.8 billion tax increase survive until the end of the budget year in June, then expire, leaving it to the Republicans to come up with a way to pay the bills without that revenue next year.
The Assembly's top Republican countered that if the Democrats want to cut taxes, they should roll back Gov. Jim Florio's entire legislative package, particularly a $1.2 billion program to provide aid to poor and middle-income school districts, and reduce property taxes. 
 The escalation in partisan infighting came today at a post-election legislative forum here attended by John A. Lynch of Lyndhurst, a Democrat and the outgoing President of the Senate, and Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian of Independence, who will become Speaker of the Assembly when the Republicans take over the Legislature in January.
 
Talk of a 'Roll Back'
 Mr. Lynch suggested last week that the Democrats might "roll back" all of the $2.8 billion increase they pushed though the Legislature last year, thereby forcing the Republicans to make good on an implied election promise -- a promise they now deny they ever made -- to cut all the tax increases.
Voter anger over the increases led to a Republican rout of the Democrats last week and left the Republicans with majorities of 58-22 in the Assembly and 27-13 in the Senate.
Afterward, Republicans said that they would make good on their promise to rescind a one-cent increase in the sales tax that was pushed through by the Democrats. That would reduce taxes by about $550 million.
 
'Sunset Bill' Suggested
 But Mr. Lynch responded by saying that the Republicans, having invoked the $2.8 billion figure repeatedly in their legislative races, had an obligation to cut all of it.
Today, at the forum at the Ramada Renaissance Hotel here, Mr. Haytaian contended that Mr. Lynch had suggested cutting the money after the Democrats had spent it.
Mr. Lynch responded by saying that he was not suggesting "a rollback" of the $2.8 billion but rather a "sunset bill" that would let the increases expire at the end of the budget year, in June 1992. "That's what the people wanted, that's what they voted for, and that is what they should get," Mr. Lynch said.
That approach would leave the Republicans with enormous budget problems. They would have to replace not only the $2.8 billion provided by the lapsed taxes but also perhaps an additional billion dollars or more to make up for inflation and about $550 million in one-time revenues in this year's budget.
Mr. Haytaian denied that the Republicans had promised such a huge rollback and said that if the Democrats wanted to let the taxes to lapse, "they should roll back the whole program, the Quality Education Act, the insurance program, all of it."
Mr. Lynch said it was up to the Republicans to start with "a clean slate" in January.

HEADLINE: As Recession Tightens Its Grip, Hopes of Jobless Dwindle and Fears Mount

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM

 BODY:
Grandparents have stepped in to buy the children winter coats. Car payments and other loans have been stretched out, if they can be. For many of the unemployed in the New York metropolitan region, an evening's entertainment is now the television.
For Gary Eppich of Long Island, and for thousands of others in the region, the savings are dwindling and the fear is mounting but still there are no jobs in sight. Some pore over the classified ads in the newspapers. Others take courses to improve their skills. 
 "Every day we say, Maybe this will be the phone call," said Mr. Eppich, a plumber who was laid off more than a year ago and who has worked at lesser-paying jobs since, when he could find them.
For Roger Holmes, a 25-year-old construction worker in Newark, the pain is similar.
"I hate not working," he said. "I'd rather be busy."
 
Few Job Categories Spared
 In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, the recession has been tenacious and indiscriminate, an equal opportunity un-employer that has struck the work force in virtually every job category, tightening its grip over the last two and a half years. Fresh layoffs continue to thin out factories, stores and office suites; they have even reached the usually unreachable: civil servants.
Many who now find themselves jobless are not merely the marginal workers or the last hired. Many have been busy and successful for years. Now they share shock, frustration, bitterness and often something new -- self-doubt. In many cases they have begun to shrink their expectations.
Across the metropolitan region, more than 440,000 jobs have been lost in the last two years out of a total of 8 million, according to state labor departments and the Federal Department of Labor. In the last recession, a 16-month period in 1981-82, fewer than 50,000 jobs were lost, the overwhelming share in manufacturing.
The individual stories from a cross-section of workers, from one in construction to one in design, highlight the pain of the thousands. They are the ones who keep track of want ads and letters in job-search notebooks. Mostly they wait and mostly they hope.

HEADLINE: And on the Ninth Day of Gridlock . . .

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
There are the twelve days of Christmas, with partridges in pear trees, turtledoves and gold rings. There are the eight days of Hanukkah, with menorahs and dreidels and chocolate coins wrapped in gold foil. And then there are the nine days of gridlock, with Peter A. Pennica and about a million cursing, teeth-gnashing New York drivers.
Like that jolly old guy who ho-ho-ho's his way across the sky -- no traffic tieups there -- the 44-year-old Mr. Pennica has a beard. But his is mostly black, he is a good deal thinner than Santa and he is no bearer of glad tidings. As chief of the traffic analysis bureau in the city Department of Transportation, he is the person who decides when to declare gridlock alerts. 
 That means this $57,000-a-year official has the power to strike terror among motorists. A word from him, and the streets will either be agonizingly crowded, if they don't listen, or deserted, if they do.
"I wouldn't say he's the Wizard of Oz," said his boss, Commissioner Lucius J. Riccio, "but he's certainly the wizard as far as I'm concerned. Pete's numbers make the difference between a pleasant day for millions of people or a miserable day if they haven't gotten the message to expect extra-long traffic delays."
To get the message out for the nine holiday gridlock alerts, the Transportation Department recruited the Rockettes. There they were yesterday, high-kicking their way across the Avenue of the Americas with Mr. Riccio only a step or two behind. Between kicks, the dancers were handing out free subway tokens.
The message to those who drive was not to. But in case they do, the department is assigning 37 traffic agents to the busiest intersections in midtown Manhattan. And to turn traffic lemons into fiscal lemonade, almost twice as many agents -- 60 -- will be out issuing what the department calls "spillback summonses" to motorists who block heavily traveled intersections with "don't-block-the-box" signs.
Figuring out which days to declare gridlock alerts seems only slightly less complicated than the quadratic equations that have bedeviled algebra students for generations. It involves numbers, history and a sense of restraint -- declaring too many alerts would lessen the sense of doom that makes them effective.
For numbers, Mr. Pennica looks at past vehicle counts for the tunnels into Manhattan -- the Holland, Lincoln, Brooklyn Battery and Queens-Midtown.
He cannot factor in a precise count for the East River bridges because no one counts the traffic there every day; the toll collections at the tunnels make counting easy. And although there are tolls at the George Washington Bridge, it is a special case -- the busiest of the Hudson River crossings, but also the one that carries cars bound not only for Manhattan but also for New England.
Is what he does art, or science? Mr. Pennica said it involved a bit of both. Motorists would say it is a dismal science, even more dismal than economics. And if it's art, the one it comes closest to is that of sawing a lady in half -- without the mirror.
"We look at volumes over the entire day," he said. "A lot of people get the perception that this only involves congestion from commuter traffic. But traffic hasn't gone down throughout the day. The latest report we have shows that volumes from 7 to 9 A.M. have reached a saturation point. Volume from 4 A.M. to 7 A.M. is up, which shows that the morning rush is expanding."
 
Predictably Awful
 And now, the envelope, please: the gridlock-alert days Mr. Pennica has nominated for 1991.
The gridlock season officially begins on Nov. 22, the Friday before Thanksgiving, with an expected traffic volume 8 percent higher than an average day. Mr. Pennica is betting that 955,000 vehicles will head into Manhattan that day. There is ample precedent for such a prediction: the Friday before Thanksgiving has been one of the 5 heaviest volume days for 5 of the last 10 years.
Between then and Christmas, he predicts, traffic volume will run between 9 and 13 percent above normal.
On Wednesday, Nov. 27, he is expecting 97,000 more vehicles than usual. Tuesday, Dec. 3, is on his list because that is the day the Christmas tree is to be lit in Rockefeller Center. Also on the list: Thursday, Dec. 12 (7 percent more traffic than usual), Wednesday, Dec. 18 (a street-clogging matinee day in midtown Manhattan) and Thursday, Dec. 19.
And Fridays? No easy rides: Dec. 6 and Dec. 13 are on the list, and he expects Friday, Dec. 20 to be the busiest day of all, with 106,000 additional vehicles in Manhattan.
Here is another prediction: unlike the motorists whose habits he knows only too well, Mr. Pennica will not be in stuck in holiday traffic. He takes the subway.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gridlock season begins Nov. 22, the Friday before Thanksgiving, said Peter A. Pennica, head of the city's traffic analysis bureau, who stood yesterday near the grid-box at Canal Street and West Broadway. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rio Journal;
Add to Economic Disaster, a Bankrupt Love Affair

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The most powerful woman in modern Brazilian history, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, broke all the rules by freezing $115 billion in bank accounts last year.
Out of power today, the 38-year-old former Economy Minister has again broken the rules, this time by agreeing to be the prime source of a book chronicling her seduction and abandonment by a fellow Cabinet member. 
 Breaking with a tradition of stale political memoirs, the book recalls one Cabinet meeting where Miss Cardoso's lover, Justice Minister Bernardo Cabral, passed her a note reading, "Your short skirt is delicious."
Peppered with such spice, "Zelia, a Passion" by Fernando Sabino, has rocketed to the top of Brazilian bestseller lists, selling 200,000 copies within 10 days of its release. A national sensation, the book has become a welcome distraction from the economic wreckage that Miss Cardoso is widely acknowledged to have left behind when she resigned her post in May.
 
'The Love of My Life'
 Indeed, the 6,500 cruzeiro cover price of "Zelia" is enough to refute Miss Cardoso's claim to economic wizardry. When the economist was named to the Cabinet in March 1990, 6,500 cruzeiros were worth $170. Today, prices are jumping 23 percent monthly, Brazil, Latin America's largest nation, is lagging further behind in Latin America's economic recovery, and 6,500 cruzeiros is worth $7.
Most of the 270-page book is devoted not to economics but to romance. But in contrast to dime-store dramas, the villain of "Zelia" is not the sleek Brazilian playboy of stereotypes, but a 59-year-old grandfather whom she described as "a gentleman a good deal older than I, fat and balding."
In New York, foreign bankers often complained that Miss Cardoso was brusque and arrogant when discussing repayment terms for Brazil's $115 billion foreign debt. But according to the book, Mr. Cabral expertly cultivated a hidden, softer side to Miss Cardoso. One day, he filled her suite in the Regency Hotel in New York with love notes.
"You are the love of my life," he wrote. "I am going to separate and marry you."
This authorized biography makes little mention of Mr. Cabral's wife of 30 years, Zuleide.
"His relationship with his wife was very old fashioned," Mr. Sabino wrote of Miss Cardoso's few encounters with Mrs. Cabral at the Cabral home in Brasilia. "She only appeared in the living room to serve coffee or food."
But Brazil's President, Fernando Collor de Mello, who is not related to Miss Cardoso, evidently did not take lightly the fact that a married Cabinet minister was having an affair with an unmarried minister.
"This is pure nitroglycerin!" the President reportedly exclaimed when his two ministers confronted him with the news in mid-1990. After the affair became public in October 1990, Mr. Collor accepted his Justice Minister's resignation, which was attributed not only to the affair but also to his perceived poor performance as the President's top legal adviser.
But according to "Zelia" the love affair continued full tilt. It says that the lovers picked names for children they hoped to conceive, and that during a debt negotiating trip to New York, Miss Cardoso met with Mr. Cabral at St. Patrick's Cathedral, where they play-acted their wedding.
But mired in the deepest recession of a decade, Brazil's economy was not faring as well as Miss Cardoso's romance. On May 9 she resigned. The next week, she flew to Paris for a secret rendezvous with Mr. Cabral.
"It was perhaps the happiest period of her life," Mr. Sabino wrote. But the book says that soon, Mr. Cabral alleged tooth trouble and flew back to Rio, promising to return after a day at the dentist. One day stretched into two and soon Miss Cardoso realized, as Mr. Sabino put it, that she had fallen victim to "a professor in the art of seducing, cheating, faking and taking advantage."
The book hit Brazil like a bomb. Many middle- and upper-class Brazilians were angered by the book's assertion that Miss Cardoso essentially drew a number out of a hat to decide the minimum size of checking and savings accounts subject to temporary confiscation. Less than a quarter of the money has so far been formally returned.
"While I was running a business, taking care of my children and working 14 hours a day, the minister was passing love notes," Eloy Farah fumed to a Sao Paulo newspaper.
 
Feminists Are Divided
 Mr. Cabral, an undeclared candidate for Senator from Amazonas State, told reporters, "The book has the gift of making the unity of my family more solid." But when pressed, he snapped that the book should have been titled "Zelia, the Revenge" and that he was working on his own memoirs.
Brazilian feminists are divided over the intimate confessions of a woman who only last year was a national role model.
Moema Toscano, a sociologist who is president of Rio's State Council of Women's Rights, pronounced the book "an ugly defeat for Brazilian women."
But some feminists have hailed Miss Cardoso's denunciation of abuse by a lover.
"For millennia, women have suffered silently in the recesses of their houses all kinds of violence and coercion," Rose Marie Muraro, a prominent Rio feminist wrote in the Rio newspaper Jornal do Brasil. "The women's liberation movement was made so that all women would be able to communicate to society the manipulations that victimize them."
While the debate continues, it is unlikely that Miss Cardoso will fade away quietly. The former minister, who has formed a new economic research group, hinted recently that she would run next year for the post of Mayor of Sao Paulo, South America's largest city.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the 38-year-old former Economy Minister of Brazil, broke the rules by agreeing to be the prime source of a book chronicling her seduction and abandonment by a fellow Cabinet member. "Zelia, a Passion," by Fernando Sabino, right, has rocketed to the top of Brazilian best-seller lists. (Sonia d'Almeida/Agencia JB for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
Dinkins in South Africa: It's Not Quite Clockwork

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins may not be jinxed, but even half a world away from the problems that dog him daily in New York, he could be forgiven for wondering. First he had to postpone this trip to South Africa for lack of money. Then he failed to win an audience with the Pope in Rome on the way over.
Today, he could not manage to get an appointment -- already listed on his public schedule -- with the white-minority Government's acting President, Gerrit N. Viljoen, who is running the country while President F. W. de Klerk is traveling in Taiwan this week. 
 "From our side, there was never such a meeting on the cards," said Hannes de Wet, a spokesman for Mr. Viljoen, who is the Minister of Constitutional Development and a leading architect of the Government's moves toward dismantling apartheid. But it was understood from other Government officials that Mr. Dinkins's hosts, the African National Congress, had requested the meeting with too little advance notice to schedule an appointment.
"I accept at face value their explanation that they were unable to meet with us," said the Mayor, who stiffly criticized the Government for failing to quell factional violence as he toured the nearby black township of Alexandra today and later spoke to a committee of black groups seeking peace.
Mr. Dinkins said he did not believe the Government had refused to see him because of such comments, or because he is a guest of the African National Congress, or because he continued to press, in a meeting with business executives this morning, for economic sanctions until there is "tangible, fundamental political change, the cornerstone of which will be a democratic South Africa."
 
An Unhealthy Rumor
 If the Mayor's day did not go exactly as planned, it did not go as badly as suggested at one point. In late afternoon, a report briefly swept the Johannesburg press corps that Mr. Dinkins had suffered a heart attack.
Indeed he did -- about six years ago -- which is what the city's acting Health Commissioner, Dr. Margaret A. Hamburg, mentioned in passing to Michael Cottman of New York Newsday, explaining the elaborate first-aid kit brought along on the trip. But local reporters apparently overheard the exchange and it became garbled in the retelling, and the African National Congress began receiving queries about the Mayor's health. The rumor may also have been fed when Mr. Dinkins went to a hospital to visit Oliver Tambo, the ailing former A.N.C. leader.
But except for a nascent cold and plenty of jet lag, Mr. Dinkins is fit, and protected not only by Dr. Hamburg but also by more than a dozen police bodyguards from New York, their fares paid by the city. But only two of the bodyguards are being allowed to carry guns by arrangement with the South African Police.
That does not mean the bodyguards do not have their hands full. On Tuesday, Deputy Inspector Jules A. Martin carried a sack of Mets sweatbands to hand out to children, and today a detective unloaded boxes of used high school math and physics textbooks -- donated by the Hunter College campus schools -- at a black elementary school. For the bodyguards, this was not that unusual. They sometimes pitch in with similar tasks while accompanying the Mayor around New York City's boroughs.
 
Sharing the Spotlight
 Mr. Dinkins's picture made page one of the Sowetan, the main newspaper aimed at blacks, under the headline, "Welcome Home, Comrade," and the Mayor's visit prompted inside coverage in other papers, but he is not getting all the attention on the trip. H. Carl McCall, the lanky president of the New York City Board of Education, was mobbed by children at the Gordon Combined Primary School in Alexandra as he tried to pass out free pens.
Dr. Betty Shabazz, director of Institutional Advancement at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn, is given special treatment everywhere and invariably introduced by Mr. Dinkins as the widow of Malcom X. Also in the Mayor's party is Lee Dunham, owner of a string of McDonald's franchises in Harlem, who is hoping to plant some golden arches in this land of gold mines in a post-apartheid economy.
"A lot of possibilities," he said today. "The highways! That's where you make your money, on the highways. You can landscape it, and make it attractive, and people feel better there than going into the congestion of the cities. And most of those stores are given to favorite sons in every city."
But the person who may stick closest of all to the Mayor is the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, the fiery pastor of the House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn, who manages to place himself squarely in camera range whenever the Mayor is photographed. Today, Mr. Daughtry was spied shooting some suspiciously professional-looking pool in the taproom of the Lethabong Restaurant in Alexandra.
Asked what his congregation would think, he smiled sheepishly and said, "Oh, I learned this a long time ago."
 
A Two-Faced View
 If the Mayor's tour often seem a surreal tangle of contradictions, so does South Africa. This morning, his dozen-car motorcade of Mercedeses and Volkswagen vans left the Mayor's suite at the Carlton Hotel for a township where shack dwellers grow gardens on top of graves because there is so little land, and saw where A.N.C. supporters were slain in attacks by rival blacks. Tonight, city officials took snapshots of each other and their new friends at a reception in the American Ambassador's rambling villa on a lush hill overlooking Pretoria.
This two-faced view was summed up in the immigration airport-landing cards that members of the Mayor's party, like all other visitors, were required to fill out upon arriving on Tuesday.
A marketing survey inside the three-page form asks whether tourists have come more for the scenery or the wildlife, and "trusts you will have a most enjoyable visit."
But the first page is more stark: "Temporary residence permits are issued to visitors on arrival. The permit determines the purpose and period of stay in South Africa, and the conditions may not be changed without the permission of the Department of Home Affairs."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
About the Lifelong Love Of a Lubber for Boats

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Small Craft Advisory
A Book About the Building of a Boat
By Louis D. Rubin Jr.
394 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.95
Despite what its title implies, Louis D. Rubin Jr.'s "Small Craft Advisory: A Book About the Building of a Boat" is not an instruction manual. Rather, it is the author's entertaining, if slightly quixotic, attempt to understand a lifelong obsession with boats that has hummed like a pedal note beneath his many other interests. 
 As Mr. Rubin presents it, this obsession seems to have had three faces. One was a preference for power over sail. He has nothing much against sailboats, having even owned a few of them. But in an amusing early chapter he explains why sailboats take too much energy while power boats allow you to go places and do things.
More important, the category of power boats includes what Mr. Rubin calls workboats, and workboats served to reconcile the two worlds of his childhood in Charleston, S.C. One was Downtown Charleston, "patrician and cultured and historical and scenic and romantic and literary."The other was Uptown Charleston, "middle-class and democratic and everyday and practical, and very, very Real."
Mr. Rubin lived Uptown, but his dreams were of Downtown, and would be fulfilled when he grew up to become a teacher of literature and creative writing, the author of more than 40 books and the founding publisher of Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, N.C., which would launch a number of Southern writers to prominence.
For Mr. Rubin as a child, the one concrete thing about Downtown Charleston was the workboats at Adger's Wharf. So: "To be associated with a workboat was to unite those two realms of existence. They were almost the only part of my experience back then that I could identify as representing what I hoped someday to attain: a place for grounding my imagination in actuality."
The second face of his obsession was owning a new boat. As he recounts his maritime career, he was forever taking friends out on second-hand tubs, only to turn back to shore when the motor or the steering broke down. Once on a family outing his boat actually sank. On the drive home that night his wife broke down sobbing.
Of course, his income as a teacher dictated economy, but that was only a rationalization. Twenty-five years earlier, when he dared to order a new boat custom-built, his mother's health suddenly deteriorated, his boatwright came down with a bad back and he himself suffered a mild nervous breakdown. He was hesitant to try again.
Finally, his obsession with boats involved an aversion to traveling any place significant in them. He dreamed of setting off for the Caribbean, but his father's traumatic bankruptcy during the Depression had instilled in him a deep fear of risk. He believes this is why he could never learn to swim. Boats were as close as he could come to what he reminds us the character Stein, in Joseph Conrad's novel "Lord Jim," called the "destructive element" in which a man must "immerse" himself.
When Mr. Rubin reached his late 60's and found himself with more free time and money, he at last made up his mind to build the new boat of his dreams. It would be made of wood, with a hull configured like a workboat and a cabin roomy enough to live in for days. It would be built by an expert; the author was too clumsy and out of shape to do the work himself.
This decision to build is announced at the opening of "Small Craft Advisory." There follows the description of his obsession, interspersed with reports of the new boat's progress. The resulting narrative turns alternately inward and outward. In one chapter he will describe a cruise along the waters of North Carolina, where he now makes his home.
In the next he will observe, "We do not ever eradicate the early patterns of our experience; they remain with us all our lives. What we can hope is to be able to learn to identify such patterns when they occur, and to understand why they exist and what they mean, so that we will not be at the mercy of forces whose existence we do not recognize, and so be unable to prevent those forces from distorting our perception of reality."
This mixture of scenery and psyche gives the book a somewhat cluttered aspect, like one of those old shipyards that the author is so fond of puttering around. You wish at times that he had found a single journey to capture his complex ideas, like the trip down the Mississippi that he admires Mark Twain for having dramatized in a section of "Life on the Mississippi."
Still, one can't help warming to the portrait Mr. Rubin draws of himself. His hero is Rat in Kenneth Grahame's "Wind in the Willows," who made that famous remark about the joy of "messing about in boats," and then added: "In or out of 'em, it doesn't matter. Nothing seems really to matter, that's the charm of it."
But Rat is too sleek and efficient to be a model for Mr. Rubin, who describes himself as overweight and sedentary and not very good with tools. In the middle of messing about on a winter day in the cabin of his brand new boat, which he ended up naming "The Algonquin," fatigue would sometimes overwhelm him and he would lie down on his comfortable bunk and take a nap.
In doing so he reminds one of another likable character in "The Wind in the Willows," wise old Badger, whose habit it was after lunch to announce that he had important work to do and retire to his study. There, he could be spied on a little later leaning back in a chair with a handkerchief over his face.
This is really Badger's book, not Rat's. If Badger wrote a book about boating, it would be "Small Craft Advisory."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Louis D. Rubin Jr. (John A. Redfield/Atlantic Monthly Press)

HEADLINE: Behind the Numbers: Voices of the Unemployed

 BODY:
 The numbers climbed in the tough economic times of the last two years.
 Although some areas like the health-care and social-service industries have shows gains, 160,000 jobs were lost in manufacturing. In department stores, food shops, automobile dealers, lumber, furniture, office equipment - wholesale and retail trades - 150,000 jobs were lost. In finance, insurance and real estate, 50,000 were lost, and in construction and other industries, 92,000.
 Behind the numbers are personal stories of the unemployed - people who wait and people who hope. A look at their struggles appears on page B8.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It used to be that you could talk yourself into a job," says Karen L. Johansen, an unemployed commodities trader from Chappaqua, N.Y. "Now, even if they need someone who has sold lightbulbs for 3.5 years, there are hundreds of people out there who have done that."
 Out of work for almost a year now, Mrs. Johansen is one of the thousands of unemployed in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut who have seen weeks turn into months with still no job on the horizon. With savings dwindling, $7.50 movies are a luxury. Many have rewritten resumes, gone back to school, leaned on parents. Mostly they wait.

HEADLINE: As Recession Tightens Its Grip, Hopes of Jobless Dwindle and Fears Mount: Newark;
A Familiar Pattern For a Brick Mason

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

 BODY:
The lines at the New Jersey Department of Labor's branch in Newark tend to snake out the doors and around the squat building on Broad Street. Roger Holmes, a 25-year-old construction worker, has learned to get there early.
In two years as a brick mason Mr. Holmes has been laid off "lots of times," perhaps half a dozen or more, he said. Three months ago it happened again. In each instance Mr. Holmes has waited six weeks or more before applying for unemployment insurance, partly because he has expected work to come along, mostly because he dreads the process. 
 "You get here after 9, you might get out at 3:30," he said one morning as he waited to complete his application.
 
Disdain for 'Idle Money'
 By the time he arrived at 8:25, the office, as dreary as a dingy bus terminal, was already crowded and the faces of the waiting men and women already looked weary. It was his second trip to the office for the latest round of unemployment benefits. He was scheduled to see a film, as required of all applicants, on the rules of filing for benefits.
Mr. Holmes said he does not want to sit around and wait for unemployment checks -- and not just because the checks amount to only a fraction of what he would make in his $16.50-an-hour union job. A strapping, energetic man, he finds the tedium of joblessness intolerable. Some people he knows have told him that he has it made -- good work when he can get it and money even when he can't. But he calls the unemployment checks "idle money."
"I hate not working," he said. "I'd rather be busy."
 
A Different Line of Work
 He calls his union delegate almost every day to see if he is needed at a construction site. Sometimes he is, and then he finds bricklaying rewarding, he said; he likes what he does.
Mr. Holmes is single and lives rent-free with his mother. But even with his relatively few obligations, he finds it hard to abide the insecurity of the construction field. He would like to get his own apartment, he said, but is wary of signing a lease in financially uncertain times.
So Mr. Holmes plans to do what many have done to ride out the recession: go back to school. In January he plans to enroll part-time in Essex County Community College and major in criminal justice. Then he can pursue a job for which there is always a need, he said. His brother is a state trooper in Virginia and has never been laid off.
But Mr. Holmes is also thinking about law.
"I figure," he said, "people will always need a lawyer."

HEADLINE: As Recession Tightens Its Grip, Hopes of Jobless Dwindle and Fears Mount: Chappaqua, N.Y.;
Trader Still Waits After 400 Letters

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Karen L. Johansen, a commodities trader, found herself jobless four times during the 1980's. Each time she found a new job within weeks or, at most, a couple of months.
This time is different. 
 A metals and grains specialist who was making $38,000 a year when she was laid off last December, Mrs. Johansen has sent out some 400 letters, expanded her search to more than an hour's commute and attended networking seminars and church support groups. She is even taking a course at New York University on environmental management in the hope of broadening her professional appeal. But commodities firms are still cutting, not hiring, and there have been no offers.
"It used to be that you could talk yourself into a job," said Mrs. Johansen, a 44-year-old native of Buffalo who moved here with her husband in 1981 when his job was transferred. "Now, even if they need someone who has sold light bulbs for 3.5 years, there are hundreds of people out there who have done that."
 
From Two Incomes to One
 Mrs. Johansen's husband, Dick, has a secure job as an environmental engineer, and their 11-year-old daughter, Erin, they say, is still too young for the one-upmanship that underlies so much teen-age consumerism in Chappaqua, a wealthy Westchester County suburb. But while Mrs. Johansen's work is undeniably her passion, it is also a necessity. "We're a two-income family," she said. "I don't have the luxury of saying I can or cannot work if I want."
With her unemployment checks about to stop in two months, the Johansens are taking steps, big and small, to ward off financial injury. They have all but stopped going to concerts, a particular love of hers, and have cut back on dining out. They stretched out their payments on one loan from three years to five and met with their mortgage lender to discuss options. Mr. Johansen has begun to work weekends to make extra money. And Erin did not go to camp this summer, saving the family $2,200.
 
Tales of Selling Shoes
 Yet Mrs. Johansen has remained upbeat, exercising each day and trying to think positively. "If I get 10 rejections, I'm that much closer to getting an offer," she said.
Besides, she said, from having attended support groups she knows her situation could be much worse. She has listened to the pain of high-paid executives who are now "selling shoes at Lord & Taylor and driving limousines."
Ideally, she said, she would like to parlay her experience as a trader into a job in recycling. But if not, she'll survive, she said.
"I could probably get a job at $25,000 if I downgrade my resume, but I've decided to keep going until I'm up against a wall," Mrs. Johansen said. "I can go out and do two jobs if I have to."

HEADLINE: As Recession Tightens Its Grip, Hopes of Jobless Dwindle and Fears Mount: Forest Hills;
Back to School, To Learn Software

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
With 15 years of experience as an administrative assistant, Phyllis Goldberg has enough confidence to describe herself as a "good worker." She spent 12 of those years at the same electronics exporting company and earned a bachelor's degree from Baruch College in Manhattan at night while working full-time.
But those qualifications have been of little help to her since April, when her most recent employer, a catering company in Manhattan, laid her off after only two months on the job. She has been unemployed ever since, though not for lack of trying. 
 "The competition was tremendous," said Ms. Goldberg, who is single, in her 30's and lives in Forest Hills, Queens. "There just weren't any jobs out there."
 
'You Get Down on Yourself'
 So Ms. Goldberg signed up for unemployment insurance, which she said pays her less than $200 a week. Her catering job paid an annual salary in the "high 20's," she said.
She also decided to enhance her skills. At the suggestion of a counselor at the state Department of Labor, Ms. Goldberg enrolled in July in a 20-week computer-training program, financed by the Federal Government, at La Guardia Community College in Long Island City.
Ms. Goldberg can now use Word Perfect, a word-processing software, and Lotus, a business spread-sheet program.
"When you get laid off, you get down on yourself; you forget you're a good worker," Ms. Goldberg said in a recent interview at the Labor Department's Long Island City branch, where she met with her counselor, Fred Roth. "I feel much better about myself now. I know I've done very well in the program."
Ms. Goldberg, who prides herself on being independent, said she had not asked her friends for financial support, though her savings account has shrunk. Instead she has cut costs, like passing up off-Broadway shows and movies.
"I just don't want to pay that kind of money," she said of movie ticket prices. "Seven dollars and 50 cents is too big a chunk when you're unemployed."
 
Drinking Carrot Juice
 Though she continues to "eat right," Ms. Goldberg said, her meals are far from extravagant. "I've been eating a lot of tofu," she said, "and drinking a lot of carrot juice."
Her only release, she said, comes in the aerobics classes that she attends on the weekends at a health club.
But Ms. Goldberg conceded that as the winter approaches she is getting edgy: Both her class and her unemployment benefits end at the end of November.
But she hopes her newfound skills have made her more marketable. "I'm trying to remember to think positive," Ms. Goldberg said. "Sometimes it's very hard to do."
