HEADLINE: As Recession Tightens Its Grip, Hopes of Jobless Dwindle and Fears Mount: Manhattan;
A Fashion Designer Is 'Overqualified'

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Barbara Kerin owns an elegant one-bedroom apartment in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan. Her savings account alone could support her for at least a year. And her resume details her more than 20 years' experience as a fashion designer, working with companies like Macy's.
But those assets are of little comfort these days. Like many other high-level professionals -- from corporate vice presidents to academic deans -- she is out of work. 
 In June, Ms. Kerin, 47 years old, lost her job in an extensive round of cutbacks at the Wool Bureau Inc., the American marketing organization for wool growers in the Southern Hemisphere. She had taken a marketing position with the organization a year and a half ago.
 
Diligent Job Search
 Since being laid off she has sent dozens of letters to potential employers in the fashion industry. She has clipped want ads, taping them in a special job-search notebook. And she has begun reading about other industries, hoping to find one less damaged by the drop in consumer spending.
But so far there have been only dead ends.
"I've heard the word 'overqualified' so many times, I don't ever want to hear it again," Ms. Kerin said. "There are so many people like me who just want to work again, who just want to be productive."
Frustration has not been the only byproduct of unemployment for Ms. Kerin. As days of joblessness have turned into weeks, then months, she has had to cut back. Though she is still financially secure, her co-op maintenance payment of $1,100 a month looms ever larger, and her list of "no more's" has grown.
No more clothes-shopping ("only stockings and shoes for interviews"); no more movies ("I rent videos or watch TV"); no more restaurant meals two or three times each week ("I eat in. If I eat with a friend, we eat in and split the cost"); no more cab rides around New York City. ("I walk.")
 
Joining a Support Group
 Ms. Kerin has looked for ways to lift her morale. Though a regular churchgoer before, "church is more valuable than ever when you are going through a crisis," she said. "Now I don't miss. I need to get my spiritual energies recharged." When she calls her parents in Arlington, Va., she said, she hopes to hear encouragement and support and not just family news.
This summer she joined a support group at her church, Marble Collegiate Church on Fifth Avenue at 29th Street, for people who have lost jobs or are changing careers. She has stepped up her volunteer work for the New York Pops orchestra at Carnegie Hall. "And," she said with the delight of rediscovery, "I've begun baking again."
But like her savings account, Ms. Kerin's hopes have a limit.
"You can only be optimistic so long," she said. "When seasoned professionals in this field describe what is happening as 'scary,' you have to struggle to remain positive. Not everyone who has been out of work is going back to jobs in the fashion industry. So where do I go?"

HEADLINE: Bush Should Have Visited Japan

BYLINE: By Mario Cuomo; Mario Cuomo, the Governor of New York, visited Japan on a trade mission in October.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Of all of President Bush's countless foreign journeys, few were more important to America than the one he recently canceled, with damaging effects: his trip to Japan, the world's No. 2 economic power.
The visit would have provided a rare opportunity to make headway in closing the huge U.S.-Japan trade imbalance, which makes our limping economy even weaker. Japan's new Prime Minister is even more hard line on trade than his predecessor. Mr. Bush should have understood his ascent as a signal that we must pursue trade issues more vigorously with Japan. Instead, it inspired a retreat. 
 Perhaps it is no coincidence that when the trip suddenly loomed as more challenging than a photo opportunity, Mr. Bush declared he needed to spend more time at home. His timing was off, as are his priorities.
Leadership is urgently needed to mend this relationship: our own economic future may depend on it. We can take the easy path and embrace self-destructive tariff restrictions likely to worsen trade relations. Or we can undertake a major effort abroad and at home to make our own economy more competitive and our relations with Japan more equitable.
Until Americans make a clear national commitment to domestic economic renewal, the Japanese will not take us seriously when we insist that they correct the trade disparity, but we must continue to insist on quick good-faith steps to open markets to American goods.
Soon we should jointly develop a timetable to eliminate the trade imbalance, particularly in the auto and auto parts sectors, which account for a staggering 75 percent of the imbalance. In addition, Japan's distribution and Government procurement systems need far more liberalization to open up markets to U.S. competition.
Exports and investment, not trade restraints, can best rectify the imbalance. But if both countries do not find ways to adjust this imbalance, political pressure will mount to make "blame Japan" slogans part of the U.S. Presidential campaign.
In Japan, I found corporate and Government leaders as worried as we are about America's weakening economy, not to mention the trend toward scapegoating Japan for our own domestic failures. Still, as unemployment and underemployment here soar, understandably frightened, frustrated Americans are searching for answers and scapegoats.
Much of the fear gripping Americans results not from Japan's success but from our failed economic policies of the past decade. Through fiscal irresponsibility, chronic neglect and absence of political will, we have allowed America to descend from the world's largest creditor to the largest debtor. Our workforce is undereducated, our infrastructure is deteriorating, industry invests inadequately in research and development, and, perhaps worst of all, Washington seems unwilling to address the crisis.
While we were falling into debt, the Japanese created the world's most efficient economy by building a national consensus on investing in people, production and technologies. We must do the same. Such unilateral action, along with concurrent action by Japan, could accelerate mutual cooperation in technology, the environment, telecommunications, health care and promoting economic growth in less-developed nations.
Dec. 7 marks the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor. By Dec. 8, we should be focusing on 1991, not 1941, committing ourselves to a new timetable to eliminate the trade imbalance and open a new era of mutual economic prosperity.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Rails Move People Better Than Highways

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell's Economic Scene column for Oct. 30, "Transit Green, Gridlock Blues," leaves the impression that investment in rail projects is a waste of taxpayer money. 
 The column quotes the views on mass transit of Peter Gordon, an associate dean of urban planning at the University of Southern California, in a position paper for the libertarian Reason Foundation. Perhaps Mr. Gordon's immediate environment of urban sprawl and asphalt has insulated his views concerning mass transit.
It is very easy to arrive at dollar figures for "cost per ride" or point to an underused system such as Miami's to cast a negative light on all new investment. This mind-set is the main reason most Americans are physically and financially tethered to their automobiles, while once-thriving downtowns have empty store windows as suburban shopping malls sap their business.
Here on the South Shore of Boston, ground will be broken next spring for the revitalized Old Colony commuter rail system, which was discontinued in 1959 at the opening of the Southeast Expressway connecting Boston with Cape Cod. The abandonment of these lines is universally recognized as a blunder by Massachusetts, with traffic jams of 10 miles to 15 miles commonplace and worsening.
Mr. Gordon may arrive at a dollar figure for the cost of every Old Colony rider while claiming that "most roads cost nothing to use." Who built these roads? Who pays for their maintenance? Over the long term, mass transit moves people more efficiently and cheaply than highways.
The efficient use of mass-transit dollars will provide benefits for all Americans through cleaner air and energy independence. The difficult part will be to get our elected representatives thinking independently of the powerful highway lobby as pressure grows for alternatives to the automobile.
 
RICHARD S. PRONE
Weymouth, Mass., Nov. 1, 1991
 
The writer is director of public relations for Back on Track (South Shore Citizens to Restore Commuter Rail).

HEADLINE: At Last, Aid for the Jobless

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats were slow to spot the need for additional aid to the long-term jobless this year, but President Bush was even slower. For four months, since July, he resisted extra unemployment insurance as unnecessary and too costly. The economy's weak recovery and his own weakness in recent polls have finally driven him to accept what he rejected only a few weeks ago. It's high time.
The unemployment insurance bill that he now seems likely to accept will provide essentially the same benefits the Democrats proposed and the President opposed from the start. The big difference is that this bill nominally includes revenue to pay for the extra benefits, which the others did not. The estimates of anticipated revenue include some typical Washington bookkeeping artistry. 
 Basic unemployment benefits cover an insured worker for a maximum of 26 weeks. The Government already has a program to provide additional benefits beyond the 26 weeks, but its terms are so strict that no one currently qualifies. The new program, less strict but temporary, would add 6 to 20 weeks more, depending on the level of unemployment in each state. Workers who exhaust their basic benefits and are still unemployed would be eligible for extra payments until the new program expires next July 1; so would more than a million workers who have exhausted their basic benefits since March 1.
These supplementary benefits will cost an estimated $5.2 billion. That's roughly $1 billion less than the earlier Democratic bills but far more than Mr. Bush wanted. The "new" revenue to pay for it comes mostly from old sources.
Some upper-income taxpayers will have to pay their taxes a few months earlier than now required. Businesses will keep on paying an unemployment insurance surcharge scheduled to expire in 1996. And the Government will continue to collect on defaulted student loans by tapping the tax refunds of defaulters -- which it would have done anyway.
All this could have been negotiated months ago. While politicians have been posturing, the long-term jobless have suffered.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed, With Dow Ahead by 11.19

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
After trading lower most of the day on a worrisome inflation report, stock prices made a strong comeback yesterday to finish mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.19 points to finish at 3,065.30.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderately heavy at 184.5 million shares, down from 199.5 million on Tuesday. The Big Board composite was up 0.37, to 219.37, with losing issues narrowly outpacing gainers by 833 to 778. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.67 to finish at 397.41, a new high for the second consecutive day, while the American Stock Exchange composite slipped 0.56, to 391.81.
A late surge of buying narrowly helped the Nasdaq index to its fifth record high in five days, to 556.17, up 0.49. Similarly, the Russell 2,000 was up 0.2, to 188.04.
 
Stocks Off Most of Day
 Stocks were down for most of the day after the Bureau of Labor Statistics released October producer prices that showed the highest monthly increase in a year. The news immediately touched off investor concern about rising inflation and put investors on the defensive ahead of today's consumer price numbers.
A sharply lower bond market weighed heavily on stocks early, but they recouped some of their losses after the Bureau of Labor Statistics Commissioner, Janet Norwood, said the core Producer Price Index may have been overstated by one-tenth to two-tenths of 1 percent.
Peter Labe, chief investment strategist for Josephthal Lyon & Ross, said the market's initial reaction to the producer prices data, and then the turnaround, was a typical reaction.
He noted the across-the-board activity where just about every issue was hit, and was mildly impressed with the day's volume that showed there was widespread participation. "There is probably no case yet for an up market, or down market, in the near term," he said. "But staying in a narrow range does afford investors the opportunity to wade into the market to pick some good stocks."
In trading yesterday, Immune Response said the clinical trials of its HIV therapeutic vaccine seemed to show the drug safe, but had not yet shown whether it was effective. The stock fell 15 3/4, to 46, after a Food and Drug Administration panel meeting reduced hopes of a quick approval of the vaccine, as a number of analysts lowered their ratings.
Nike shares fell 1 1/8, to 62 1/4 yesterday, as Josie Esquivel, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, lowered her rating on the athletic shoe maker after the stock reached her 1992 price target. She noted that no further adjustments were made on the stock, like earnings estimates, and expects the stock to appreciate from 10 to 25 percent over the next 12 months.
According to an Oppenheimer analyst, George Krug, Tuesday's Department of Agriculture crop report of low grain inventories looks good for increased plantings next year, with an increased demand for fertilizer. IMC Fertilizer stock rose 3/8 to close at 51 3/4.
After telling analysts on Tuesday that it would probably not meet 1992 earnings projections, Kimberly-Clark shares fell 6 3/8 yesterday, to 94, as several analysts reduced their earnings estimates and a few, their ratings. The company held a two-day meeting with analysts, which started on Tuesday, and said analysts' 1991 forecasts were in the ballpark, and their 1992 estimates were possible, but highly doubtful unless market conditions changed fast.
Nordstrom, the shoe and apparel retailer, was down 1 5/8, to 37 1/2, as analysts lowered year-end earnings estimates, after the retailer reported disappointing third-quarter results.
On the other side of the coin, Campbell Soup reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter earnings, to $1.02 a share, compared to 82 cents a share, and the stock responded by rising 1 7/8, to 81 3/8.
Analysts said that United Technologies is likely to take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of at least $500 million to pay for its efforts to reduce annual costs by $1 billion, as the stock rose 1/2 to close at 50 1/8.
Except for concern about dilution, analysts who follow Goodyear could not find a specific reason for the price decline in the stock, as the tire maker's secondary offering of 12 million shares, priced at $50 a share, began trading. The stock was off 1 1/8, to 49 3/8.
Traders said after Scimed Life Systems told analysts at a meeting in California that it was not on the verge of pulling its Express Catheters from the United States because of patent challenges, the stock rose 6 1/4, to 58 1/2.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:

An Opportunity, But
With theater attendance falling and the weak economy forcing many studios to scale back their film making, video distributors are looking for alternative programming, from old television series to cable movies, to fill any future shortage of big films flowing into video stores. 
 In theory, this situation could be an opportunity for directors and screenwriters to get involved in more video-related projects. One such film maker is James Toback, who wrote "The Gambler" and the coming "Bugsy," starring Warren Beatty, and directed "Fingers," "Love and Money," "Exposed" and "The Big Bang," just released on tape by Fox Lorber.
Mr. Toback has a high regard for video. "The Big Bang," a documentary-style feature in which people talk about the meaning of life, did not do well in theaters this year, but a subsequent broadcast of the film on PBS drew attention, and the director hopes for a good run on cassette. "Video helps get the gospel out," he said.
Yet Mr. Toback still prefers film and movie theaters. "On a practical level there will be a proliferation of films and film makers who will work on video much more cheaply, so the idea of who is a film maker has expanded radically," he said. On the technical side there are new tools, like the high-definition video camera, that may cut costs, but, in Mr. Toback's view they fall short in esthetic value. "There's something in the luminosity of film that projects the unconscious," he said. "Tape is flatter, more straightforward, less appealing."
Mr. Toback acknowledges the advantages of distribution by television and video. "It's cheaper and more open and there's more of a fair game atmosphere," he said. But he leans to tradition. "With films, everything starts in the theaters," he said. "Theaters have that event quality."
 
Yiddish Exhibition
 "Yiddish Film Between Two Worlds," which opens today at the Museum of Modern Art, is a two-month exhibition of films, most of which were made in the 1920's and 30's. Eleven of the more than 60 films are also available on video from the National Center for Jewish Film at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., which provided many of the films for the museum's program. The video titles, which range in price from $54 to $90, include "Tevye" (1939), the Maurice Schwartz film that is the basis for "Fiddler on the Roof"; "The Dybbuk" (1937), a Polish occult classic; "Uncle Moses" (1932), Schwartz's portrait of tenement and sweatshop life on the Lower East Side. Information: (617) 899-7044. Another source for some of the films and more than 100 Yiddish and Israeli films is Ergo Home Video of Teaneck, N.J. Information: (800) 695-3746.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 A movie director with a string of credits, David Merrill (Robert De Niro) finds himself blacklisted when, more for private reasons than political conviction, he refuses to answer questions before the House Committee on Un-American Activities. Suddenly gone are the private screenings with Darryl F. Zanuck, the house in the hills and, worst for a stunned but resolute Merrill, the chance to make movies. Avoiding self-righteousness, Irwin Winkler's film is a "stirring and tragic evocation of terrible times" (Janet Maslin).
 
The Boat Is Full
1981. First Run Features. $59.95. 1:44. German and French with English subtitles. No rating.
In World War II, a desperate group of refugees, all previously unacquainted with one another, cross the German border into a Swiss town in which they must pose as a family to qualify for sanctuary. Clandestine strategies evolve to evade detection by the Swiss townspeople, who seem more interested in catching rule breakers than in saving people from the Nazis. Depicting the situation with a spare, gentle force, Mark Imhoof's film is "fresh, purposeful and surprising at every turn" (Maslin).
 
Impromptu
1990. Hemdale. $92.95. LD, $39.95. 1:48. CC. PG-13.
It's the 19th century and the celebrities -- George Sand, Liszt, Chopin, Delacroix -- are getting into all the rifts and intrigues celebrities usually do. James Lapine's film, which stars Judy Davis as George Sand, is "so merrily and unapologetically contemporary that all of these events might easily be taking place in the present day, most likely on 'Dallas' " (Maslin).
 
20,000 Leagues Under the Sea
1916. Kino. $29.95. 1:45. No rating.
Stuart Paton's silent takes the Jules Verne story into strange seas. No brooding James Mason of the 1954 film, the exotic Captain Nemo (Allan Holubar) resembles a gaunt Santa Claus as he races around his submarine rescuing a steady stream of unfortunates, victims of myriad boating disasters, who wash ashore on Mysterious Island. Underwater scenes are diverting, as are plot manipulations that at one point transport the whole yarn to an Arabian desert.
 
Scary Stories
Tall Tales, Yarns and Whoppers
1991. Atlas Video. Two tapes, $14.95 each. 35 minutes each. No rating.
With all the animated children's features these days, it's refreshing to come across stories told the very old-fashioned way: on one's feet with no props or graphics whatever. Four storytellers tell tales from various traditions, including Hispanic and Afro-American. There's the story of the nasty uncle who sleeps all day to prepare for his duties as a skeleton at night. Then there's the one about the mosquito as big as an airplane, as well as six other stories suitable for young children. Information: (800) 999-0212.
 
FONDA'S SAGAS
 Among the better films Darryl F. Zanuck produced in his decades with 20th Century-Fox are several robust sagas made in the 1930's starring Henry Fonda. Here are some of these and a few other Zanuck productions available on tape. All are from Fox, and all are in black and white.
YOUNG MR. LINCOLN. As a beginning back-country lawyer, Henry Fonda draws on Lincolnian common sense to defend two brothers accused of murder. John Ford directed. 1934. $19.98. 1 hour 40 minutes. No rating.
DRUMS ALONG THE MOHAWK. A refined bride (Claudette Colbert) follows her husband (Fonda) into the upstate New York wilderness. Edna May Oliver and John Carradine also star. 1939. 1:43. No rating.
JESSE JAMES. With Tyrone Power in the title role, Fonda is the other James (brother Frank) in a story about how they strayed into a life of crime. 1939. 1:46. No rating.
GRAPES OF WRATH. Jane Darwell and Fonda won Oscars as Steinbeck's refugees from the Oklahoma dust bowl in the John Ford classic. 1940. $19.98. 2:09. No rating.
THE RAZOR'S EDGE. In an adaptation of the Somerset Maugham story, Tyrone Power stars as a war-ravaged idealist trying to regain control of his life. Gene Tierney and Anne Baxter also star, along with Herbert Marshall as Maugham. 1946. $59.95. 2:26. No rating.
VIVA ZAPATA! Marlon Brando is the Mexican revolutionary, Elia Kazan directed and John Steinbeck wrote the screenplay. 1952. $19.98. 1:53. No rating.
THE MAN IN THE GRAY FLANNEL SUIT. Gregory Peck brings some wartime guilt home to suburbia and Madison Avenue. Jennifer Jones and Fredric March also star. 1956. $39.98. 2:33.
THE LONGEST DAY. Fonda, Robert Ryan, John Wayne, Robert Mitchum, Richard Burton and Rod Steiger do duty with Allied forces during the Normandy invasion. 1962. $29.95. 3:00.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Caterpillar Sees a Loss Exceeding $86 Million

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 14

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the maker of construction equipment that has been losing more than $2 million a week, warned investors today that it would report a large fourth-quarter loss.
The company said the amount would likely exceed the $86 million that Caterpillar lost during the first nine months of the year. It could not make a precise estimate of the expected shortfall. 
 The announcement sent Caterpillar's stock plunging on the New York Stock Exchange today, to $44.875, down $3.125.
Caterpillar, based in Peoria, attributed the the loss to deteriorating business conditions and a strike and lockout involving the United Automobile Workers union that has idled 8,000 workers.
The company also said it would have to take a charge of $1.7 billion to $2.4 billion when it put into effect a new accounting rule related to projected health-care costs for retirees.
Caterpillar can write off the costs in one lump, which would wipe out half the company's $4.5 billion in equity, or it can spread the cost over 20 years, reducing earnings by $100 million to $300 million a year, said a spokesman, Dick Stober.
He said the accounting change would not affect fourth-quarter results. Caterpillar has until 1993 to decide how to put the new rule into effect.
Caterpillar has struggled all year as demand plummeted because of a worldwide recession.
"While leading economic indicators are signaling the beginning of a recovery in the United States, improvements in the markets Caterpillar serves are expected to lag any upturn in the economy," Caterpillar said.
The company said its prospects for 1992 were clouded by the labor strife. The strike at Caterpillar's plants in East Peoria and Decatur started on Nov. 3, and the company locked employees out of its plants in Aurora and East Peoria on Nov. 7.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Old Issue Back With a Bang

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
"GET our economy moving again," President Bush said this week, echoing the theme of John F. Kennedy's successful campaign against Richard M. Nixon in 1960. Mr. Nixon blamed the Eisenhower Administration's failure to take strong enough action to wipe out the recession for his defeat.
A myth exists that Mr. Kennedy, soon after he took over the White House, swiftly delivered on his pledge to get the country moving again by a big tax cut. Actually, Mr. Kennedy was slow. Although the economy began to recover a month after he took office, the unemployment rate, which had been 5.6 percent in 1960, rose to 6.7 percent in 1961 and held at 5.6 percent in 1962 and 5.7 percent in 1963. 
 President Kennedy finally accepted the advice of his economic advisers, headed by Walter W. Heller, and began to campaign for a big tax cut in 1963. He was assassinated before Congress acted on the proposal. President Lyndon B. Johnson pushed the $14 billion tax cut through in 1964, and the economy surged. But the Vietnam buildup thrust it into inflation, which the tax increase of 1967 was too late to prevent.
When Mr. Nixon gained the Presidency in 1968, defeating Hubert H. Humphrey, he sought to stop the inflation with a policy of "gradualism," relying on the Federal Reserve to keep the money supply -- and the economy -- growing slowly. But recession struck in 1971, and Mr. Nixon, worried about the 1972 election, pressed the Fed to jazz up the money supply; he also threw in tax cuts, spending increases and a devalued dollar to drive the economy up and price and wage controls to hold the inflation down. In 1972, Mr. Nixon was re-elected in a landslide over George McGovern. But after the election, with price controls lifted, inflation broke out. The political business cycle rolls on and on. With last week's elections demonstrating voters' anger over the stagnating economy, the old issue is back with a bang for 1992: How to stimulate economic growth without germinating inflation or other economic ills?
Here are the main policy options now:
* Monetary policy. With chronic budget deficits having swollen the national debt by over $2.5 trillion during the Reagan and Bush years, and fiscal policy tightly constrained, monetary policy has looked like the only wheel in town. The Bush Administration has been leaning on the Fed for easier money and credit. Short-term interest rates are down a lot, long-term rates much less. The money supply has grown sluggishly, and so has the economy.
Some economists think that thanks to the enormous hangover of public and private debt, and business and consumer confidence impaired, monetary policy is not working. The air is full of gloomy metaphors: monetary policy is "pushing on a string," "driving into a 50-mile-an-hour headwind," "caught in a liquidity trap." But most economists -- including those around Mr. Bush -- still insist easier money will work, in time for the election.
* Fiscal policy. Supply-siders are still calling for tax cuts. Anti-supply-siders say the big Reagan tax cut of 1981, which was turned into a Christmas tree with the help of Democrats, is the root of the economy's ills, undermining savings, investment and productivity growth.
President Bush has taken a hesitant line on tax cuts, because of the huge budget deficit and the budget agreement -- to the loud annoyance of the supply-siders. But he has urged Congress to enact "I.R.A.'s that are tailored to boost home ownership," "enterprise zones to spawn a new generation of urban entrepreneurs" -- and a capital gains tax cut."I believe if it could be done without getting a lot of baggage on it coming out of the Congress," he said, it "would unleash investment and get our economy moving again."
* Cheerleading and jawboning. Some critics of Mr. Bush say he should be restoring business and consumer confidence -- by acting more like Mr. Reagan. Mr. Bush has, in fact, been jawboning the banks to cut interest rates on credit cards, urging regulators to take it easy on the banks, coaxing business and consumers to cheer up.
* Benefits for the hard-hit. Mr. Bush has decided to work with the Democrats for an extension of unemployment benefits without breaking the budget agreement.
* Restructuring national priorities. The end of the cold war and virtual disappearance of the Soviet military threat open up the possibility of a bigger "peace dividend" -- either a bigger cut in the deficit that would reduce capital costs and spur investment or new civilian programs to improve "human capital," increase investment in technology, raise productivity and clean up the environment. Cutting wasteful "entitlements" or inefficient and costly health-care policies could make funds available to augment economic growth and raise living standards. But such shifts in national priorities would take years to carry out, and would be opposed by strong interest groups.
Yet a serious effort to tackle the nation's long-term social and economic problems could have a short-run electoral payoff for the candidate who could articulate it.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Weak Data on Economy Bring Losses for the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against other currencies yesterday amid new evidence of economic weakness. Gold prices also dropped.
The dollar slipped after two Government reports indicated the economy continued to waver. 
 The Labor Department said the number of Americans filing new unemployment claims reached the highest level in six months. The Commerce Department said retail sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent in October as nervous consumers continued to be reluctant to spend.
A further depressant was the Labor Department's report that consumer prices edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in October. The report, coming one day after word that wholesale prices surged seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, eased concerns about inflation.
Analysts said foreign exchange traders read all the reports as signs pointing to another decline in interest rates. That would send the dollar lower because it, like all currencies, is supported by higher rates.
Kevin Logan, the chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation, said the dollar remained in a tight range despite the negative economic news.
"We're not getting new information; we're getting confirmation in a sense of what we already know," he said of the latest data.
But he said the dollar was winning some support from traders who thought that with the current level so low, now was a good time to buy.
The dollar fell against the German mark, dropping to 1.62975 marks in New York from 1.6350 late Wednesday. In earlier European trading, the dollar slipped to 1.6305 marks from 1.6380.
The dollar fell to 129.62 Japanese yen in New York from late Wednesday's 130.10. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell 0.33 yen, to 129.65 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 129.85 yen.
The British pound gained against the dollar, climbing to $1.7765 in New York, from $1.7745 on Tuesday. In London, the pound rose to $1.7755 from $1.7715.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4460 Swiss francs, down from 1.4515; 5.5685 French francs, down from 5.5900; 1,227.75 Italian lire, down from 1,231.00, and 1.12995 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13145.

HEADLINE: Stocks Move Lower in Heavy Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed lower in heavy trading yesterday after receiving mixed signals about the economy in the October consumer price and retail sales data. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 1.79 points to finish at 3,063.51.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 200 million, up from 184.5 million on Wednesday, as losing issues narrowly outpaced gainers by 853 to 804. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was off 0.26, to 397.15 and the Big Board composite was off 0.15, to 219.22. Trading on the American Stock Exchange caused the composite to slip 0.12, to 391.69.
And after setting records on five consecutive days, the Nasdaq composite fell 1.33, to 554.84, as the Russell 2,000 similarly saw its streak snapped, declining by 0.22 to close at 187.82.
Hugh A. Johnson, a senior vice president with First Albany, said: "If there is a word to describe yesterday's market it is 'disappointment.' It looked as though it would be a good day and started with good news. The October Consumer Price Index was below expectations and suggested that inflation may not be the problem as we thought Wednesday when the producer prices shocked the market with an unexpected surge."
A good consumer price report implies that the Fed still has room to lower short-term interest rates, without compromising its credibility as an inflation fighter, he said.
The impact on stocks and bonds was positive, but it did not last in the stock market because the principal focus right now is the economy and earnings, he noted.
 
Concern About the Recovery
 "When you see a divergence of the bond market from the stock market, which we saw, it signals a deepening concern about the strength of the recovery," he said. "And you see noncyclical stocks like drugs, insurance, savings and loans and holding companies do well. Cyclical stocks like aluminums, chemicals and paper do poorly." Right now the message is very clear and hard to miss: Investors are concerned that the payoff of interest rate cuts, for the recovery, economy and corporate earnings is still a ways off, he said.
In the stock market yesterday, Caterpillar, the well-known manufacturer of earth-moving equipment and a Dow component, forecast a loss in the fourth quarter that would be larger than the first nine months combined. The stock fell 3 1/8, to 44 7/8.
Michael Lauer, a Kidder, Peabody analyst, said he had cut his rating on Perkin-Elmer, which fell by 1 1/4, to 32 5/8, and raised his rating on Varian Associates, which rose 2 1/8, to 38 7/8, based partly on the stock valuation. Both companies make electronic devices. Mr. Lauer noted that Perkin-Elmer's stock has been up sharply since September on takeover speculation, which may not happen, while Varian, whose stock is down 30 percent since the summer, may announce a share buyback since it has drastically reduced its debt.
The Senate vote to cap interest rates on credit cards weighed on a number of stock issues yesterday. Advanta, fell 8, to 30 1/2, while MBNA, another credit card company, fell 5, to 31 3/4. Analysts said bank stocks were also down as a result, with First Chicago, off 1 1/8, to 25 7/8; Chase Manhattan, off 1/4, to 17 7/8, and Citicorp, off 1/2, to 11.
A below analysts' estimate of first-quarter earnings was all it took to send Humana stock down 4, to 23 3/8 yesterday. The hospital and health maintenance company said profits would likely be about 48 cents a share, while the mean estimate by analysts was 55 cents a share.

HEADLINE: FRESH DATA OFFER MORE INDICATIONS OF AILING ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Signs of economic woe mounted today, as Government agencies reported that retail sales edged down in October while average earnings slumped and the ranks of people applying for state unemployment benefits rose to the highest weekly level since May.
Still another batch of figures showed surprisingly little consumer-level inflation last month, in sharp contrast to yesterday's report of a large rise in prices at the producer level. But the favorable news on consumer prices was tempered by the realization that they, too, pointed toward an economic recovery that has all but come to a halt.
 
No Signs of Strength
 "The economy seems to have lost steam no matter where you turn," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist for the First Boston Corporation. He called retail sales, which declined one-tenth of 1 percent last month after a sizable rise in September, "decidedly punk." 
 The first signs from this month have also been discouraging. The auto industry reported Wednesday that sales of American-made vehicles were down 13.4 percent in the first 10 days of November, compared with the corresponding period last year.
Since retail spending accounts for one-third of economic activity, sales must rebound during the holiday season if the recovery is to regain momentum anytime soon, analysts said. Many merchants earn 50 percent of their annual profits during this period, and poor results would further limit the restocking of shelves that economists are counting upon to spur overall economic recovery.
But consumers' purchases of clothing and other nondurable goods eased two-tenths of 1 percent last month, while purchases of durables like mobile homes were unchanged. These figures are adjusted for seasonal and holiday differences but not for inflation. So, taking higher prices into account, retailers whose cash registers show the same revenues this year as last are actually moving fewer goods.
During the last 12 months, retail sales rose six-tenths of 1 percent, slightly less than the increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent in commodity prices during this period.
 
Prices Held in Check
 The Labor Department's report today that the Consumer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in October -- the best performance since a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in March -- was accompanied by more evidence of consumers' inability to buy.
Real average weekly earnings fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, reflecting declines in hours worked and hourly earnings and a rise in prices.
Pinched incomes have combined with job insecurity to drain confidence and thereby erode the recovery, economists say.
"Very few people out there are spending money on anything," said Gilbert Benz, an economist at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
The figures on initial claims for jobless benefits tend to gyrate from week to week. But today's report showing an increase of 33,000, to 454,000, for the week ended Nov. 2 was reason for concern. It was the second straight rise after a plunge in the week that included the Columbus Day holiday, and it carried the pace of new claims back to the recession levels of late winter.
Store sales last month totaled $152.9 billion, with nondurables accounting for $98.3 billion, or just under two-thirds, and durables for $54.6 billion.
Compared with September, sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in general merchandise stores, eight-tenths of 1 percent in apparel and accessory stores and 1 percent at gasoline service stations. Sales were higher by two-tenths of 1 percent at food stores and 1 percent each at restaurants and bars and at drugstores.
In durable goods, which are intended to last at least three years, a hefty nine-tenths of 1 percent advance for dealers in building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes was nullified by declines of three-tenths of 1 percent for both automotive dealers and those handling furniture, home furnishings and equipment.
When the entire automotive group is disregarded, retail sales were unchanged last month, the report showed.
Figures on retail sales, which are compiled by the Commerce Department, were revised today to show slightly weaker results for the two preceding months than first estimated. September's advance is now put at six-tenths of 1 percent instead of seven-tenths, while August's decline was seven-tenths of 1 percent instead of six-tenths.
"There's this flatness, this sense of stagnation," said Mr. Soss of First Boston, noting that sales had been going nowhere since July. He said that even though the Federal Reserve had been easing monetary policy for the better part of two years, it had been guilty of excessive "gradualism." He said shock treatment was now required to revive growth. "Inflation has stabilized," he added.
Analysts generally considered today's good report on consumer prices -- though perhaps somewhat overstated itself -- as confirming suspicions of an anomaly in yesterday's report that producer prices jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest rise in a year. Consumer prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in October, and for the year, they have been rising at an annual rate of just 2.7 percent.
The discrepancy between the consumer and producer indexes is mainly attributed to difficulties with adjusting the figures for seasonal factors. For example, the consumer index phases in the effects of new automobile models over several months, whereas the producer index captures this development all at once.
Another partial explanation involves the difference between posted prices and the prices at which business is transacted, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up 0.1% in October

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose a modest one-tenth of 1 percent in October, the Labor Department said today, the smallest increase in the last seven months. The slight gain put the annual rate of inflation at 2.7 percent.
The report was in contrast to a surprising jump of seven-tenths of 1 percent in producer prices for the month, reported Wednesday. That figure had distressed Wall Street analysts and traders. 
 "The October C.P.I. should allay the fears of those who thought that yesterday's P.P.I. figures signaled the start of a new round of inflation," said John Albertine of Albertine Enterprises in Washington.
 
Bond Prices Gain
 The slight rise in the Consumer Price Index, along with a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in retail sales reported by the Commerce Department, sent bond prices sharply higher. Traders said low inflation and the fall in consumer spending rekindled the possibility of further cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
"It's clear that the recovery has lost all of its momentum," said Russell Sheldon, an economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
The Bush Administration, however, put a more positive interpretation on the reports. "The figures tend to suggest that we are coming out of recession; today's figures on inflation are very good," Marlin Fitzwater, the Administration spokesman, said at a news conference.
The consumer price report also lifted stock prices in early trading, although the Dow Jones industrial average later closed 1.79 points lower, at 3,063.51.
 
Core Rate Barely Rises
 Today's report said the so-called core rate of inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy costs, also rose one-tenth of 1 percent after a gain of four-tenths in September.
Many on Wall Street had expected the overall index to rise by two-tenths of 1 percent and the core rate to rise three-tenths.
The overall October increase of one-tenth of 1 percent was the weakest showing for prices since March, when they declined one-tenth of 1 percent.
The department said the contrast in the consumer and wholesale price reports reflected, in part, different methods of calculating auto prices, which were largely responsible for the rise in the Producer Price Index.
Producer prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, while the core rate climbed five-tenths.
Although the producer price figures seemed to catch Wall Street off guard, analysts have generally concluded that the numbers did not necessarily mean a new period of higher inflation. Today's report that retail sales declined one-tenth of 1 percent last month after a sizable rise in September should bolster that belief.
October's slim gain in consumer prices followed an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in September. The Government said the slowdown was broad based, reflecting declines in food prices and a moderation in energy costs.
Food prices, which rose one-tenth of 1 percent in September after falling in the two preceding months, turned down again, falling one-tenth of 1 percent in October.
Medical costs continued to move up briskly, rising six-tenths of 1 percent after increasing seven-tenths in the prior month. Energy prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent after a jump of 1 percent the previous month. The department said a drop in gasoline prices partly offset an increase in the costs of household fuels.
New-car prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent after rising the same amount in September, while services, which account for more than half the Consumer Price Index, increased three-tenths of 1 percent. Services rose by five-tenths in September.
Over all, the Consumer Price Index stood at 137.4 in October, meaning that a basket of goods and services that cost an average of $100 in 1982-84 cost $137.40 last month.

HEADLINE: The War of the Christmas Catalogues

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The next six weeks of Christmas shopping will be critical to the sales of many retailers, but none more so than mail-order catalogue merchants.
While department stores generate up to 50 percent of their profits in the final two months of the year, many cataloguers count on the same period for 60 percent to 75 percent of their earnings. 
 "The holiday season is going to mean the difference between profit and loss for most of the cataloguers this year," said Robert F. DeLay, an expert on the mail-order business. "This year is terribly important because things have been so flat."
Hoping to put shoppers in the buying mood, Spiegel and some other mail-order companies sent out their Christmas catalogue weeks earlier than usual. Experts say some companies are also likely to re-send their catalogues, with new covers, after Thanksgiving.
Cataloguers are also emphasizing their discounted merchandise and promising to deliver products in time for Christmas, even if orders are placed in late December.
For much of the 1980's, mail-order sales grew by about 15 percent a year. That was triple the growth rate of most department stores and other retailers that depend on face-to-face sales.
But the bleak economy and rising costs have caught up with many catalogue companies. The good news, at least for consumers, is lower prices from a few companies and a reduction in the 12 billion or so catalogues stuffed annually into the nation's mailboxes.
Mail-order experts say that weaker companies are starting to be weeded out -- some merging with larger ones, others folding altogether. Most survivors will have to cope with permanently lower profit margins, analysts and industry executives say.
As if the tough retailing climate were not enough, the catalogue companies have also been hit by a confluence of cost increases imposed by the United States Postal Service, which delivers the catalogues, and by shippers like United Parcel Service that deliver the goods.
Even harder blows may yet land. The industry is feeling pressure from courts and state legislatures on issues that range from sales taxes to proposed privacy laws that would make it hard to send catalogues to people who did not request them. Most catalogue companies do not charge sales tax to customers who live outside the state or states where the company has offices. But revenue-hungry states are trying to change that.
The various rising costs "could have some impact on the basic economics of the industry," said Richard C. Anderson, chief executive of Lands' End Inc., a mail-order retailer based in Dodgeville, Wis. "With these fierce price increases, it becomes rather difficult to survive if you are a smaller company."
 
'A Question of Size'
 The recent casualties include Royal Silk Ltd., which had offered popular moderately priced silk apparel through its catalogue. The company went out of business this summer after a costly expansion into retail stores.
Sensing opportunity in the industry's plight, Montgomery Ward & Company said last month that it planned to re-enter the mail-order business with a line of speciality catalogues. Company executives said the pressures on weaker players made it "perfect timing" to start the new business.
"In this business, it's very much a question of size," said Sharon E. Rappaport, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. "It's all dependent on volume," she said. "The larger you are, the better you are able to take advantage of discounts," in postal rates and buying merchandise.
 
Mining the Niches
 But size is not everything. Two of the nation's largest cataloguers, Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J. C. Penney Company are struggling to breathe life into their "big book" catalogues, which try to be many things to many people.
Several companies, however, are doing a brisk business in more narrowly focused areas. A fresh-flower catalogue, Calyx & Corolla, for example, is attracting a lot of attention and customers with its offerings of orchids, anthuriams and birds of paradise.
Children's clothing is another hot area. Hanna Andersson, a Portland, Ore., cataloguer that specializes in cotton clothing made in Sweden, is attracting legions of parents.
Not all successful catalogues are aimed at the affluent. Fingerhut Companies, based in Minnetonka, Minn., is growing quickly by selling a wide range of goods on credit, primarily to lower-income families.
Analysts said there is no true catalogue equivalent of the discount stores, which have revolutionized retailing by offering name-brand merchandise at lower prices than are found in department stores. But the new Ward venture, analysts said, may be taking aim at that market. And other mail-order merchants, including Lands' End, have been placing added emphasis on their lower-priced offerings and beefing up sections that feature discounted goods.
The current cost pressures are forcing companies to alter their basic approach to the business.
In April, after much agonizing, L. L. Bean Inc. reversed a 79-year tradition of free shipping and began charging its catalogue customers a $3.50 fee for each order.
"It was something we were very reluctant to do," said Catharine Hartnett, a spokeswoman for the Freeport, Me., company, which mails 100 million catalogues a year. "We waited as long as possible before making the decision."
Companies are also revising their blanket approach to mailing. Infrequent buyers are quickly dropped from mailing lists because they do not support the cost of paper and postage. Producing and mailing each catalogue costs about a dollar, according to industry estimates.
And while it may not be apparent yet, mailers are also sending out fewer catalogues.
 
Smaller Books, Shorter Lists
 Some merchants are even shrinking their offerings to save money.
"The next catalogue will be smaller," said Kevin Sweeney, a spokesman for Patagonia Inc., a Ventura, Calif., retailer of outdoor clothing. Patagonia recently laid off 120 people, or about one-fifth of its work force, because of a slowing sales. This year's holiday catalogue pages will be the size of an 8 1/2-by-11-inch business letter, in contrast to the Patagonia's previous oversized offerings. "Cost is the primary reason," Mr. Sweeney said.
Responding to the same pressures, the Lillian Vernon Corporation decided to cut its catalogue circulation by 10 percent. The company also took steps to more carefully direct its mailing to proven catalogue shoppers, a move that paid off with higher revenue per catalogue mailed.
Despite such measures, the Mount Vernon, N.Y., company recently reported reduced revenues and a loss for the first six months of its fiscal year.
 
Impact of Rate Increases
 It was in February that the United States Postal Service increased the third-class rates used by mailers by 40 percent. In the case of Lands' End, the increase will translate to $7 million more in expenses this year.
Yet, even after the United Parcel Service added its own rate increase, many catalogue companies have been reluctant to pass along the price increases to already skittish consumers.
The tax issue continues to hang over the industry. State governments are currently barred from charging taxes on sales by out-of-state companies that have no stores in a state. But last month, the Supreme Court agreed to hear a case that could overturn the prohibition on sales taxes for most catalogue purchases.
 
Two Views on Taxes
 Catalogue companies express concern that having to charge and administer state taxes will hurt sales and increase operating costs.
But Ms. Rappaport of Morgan Stanley noted that several large cataloguers already charge sales tax, because they have retail stores as well. "I don't think that it threatens the viability of the mail order business," she said.
Privacy laws, though, could be more damaging than either taxes or postal increases, said Mr. DeLay, publisher of The DeLay Letter, an industry publication in New York. He said that a California proposal would effectively require companies to obtain permission from consumers before sending them catalogues. Even if the proposal does not become law, he said, "down the road, there are going to be some restrictions."
Which is why many cataloguers are afraid that the years of easy growth may be over. "When we got started," said Mr. Anderson of Lands' End, "we didn't have these problems."

HEADLINE: Credit Card Rate Caps Draw Fire

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Bankers warned yesterday that a measure approved by the Senate to limit credit card interest rates to 14 percent would bring a sharp reduction in the availability of credit cards that would disrupt the economy.
Although the credit card business has been highly lucrative for several years, the bankers said the profit margin was not so great that they could afford to cut interest rates to 14 percent from the current average of 18 percent or 19 percent and still earn a profit. 
 "Our average member makes $1.90 for every $100 of card loans," said Alex W. Hart, president of Mastercard International. "If the interest rate is reduced to 14 percent, you take $5 from that profit, and the business becomes uneconomical" or a loss. Mastercard, like Visa, helps banks advertise credit cards and arranges for payments to merchants who accept the cards, but the cards themselves are issued by banks and savings institutions.
 
Accused of Gouging
 Proponents of the rate ceiling, including Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who introduced the measure as an amendment to a broader banking bill that is pending in the Senate, say banks are gouging consumers by keeping credit card rates high even while rates on consumer deposits have fallen. A companion banking bill was defeated in the House yesterday.
Robert R. Douglas, vice chairman at Chase Manhattan Bank, which has more than $9.3 billion of credit card loans outstanding, warned yesterday that an interest rate ceiling "would undoubtedly result in a cutback of billions of dollars in consumer credit, especially to lower- and middle-income consumers."
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said that while the Administration favored lower credit card rates, "we should let the marketplace determine the rates." He said the Administration would oppose legislation calling for an interest rate ceiling, and he repeated a warning from the American Bankers Association that a rate limit could lead banks to eliminate one-third to two-thirds of all outstanding credit cards.
Several members of the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Consumer Affairs are expected to introduce a 14 percent ceiling on card rates in a bill on Monday.
Edward L. Yingling, executive director of government relations at the American Bankers Association, said that similar legislation was defeated in the House by a wide margin in 1987. But he added that the environment was now different as legislators were looking for scapegoats for the weak economy and were unhappy over the need to appropriate money to support the bank deposit insurance fund. "If the House voted on a credit card limit today, it would pass," he said.
The possibility of a rate ceiling was worrisome enough yesterday to depress the stock prices of several companies in the card business.
Citicorp fell 50 cents, to $11, on the Big Board. It has relied heavily on estimated profits of $600 million or more from its 21 million credit card customers while it copes with heavy losses from real estate loans.
Mark Lynch, banking analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company, estimated that with a 14 percent interest rate, Citicorp's revenues would fall by as much as $1.9 billion, and the company could post a big loss next year rather than the modest profit analysts now expect.
"They would not actually lose that much," Mr. Lynch added, "because they would compensate for a lower rate by raising fees, kick out people who pose a credit risk and eliminate the grace period," the interest-free period between the time of the purchase and when the first payment is due.
Shares of the MBNA Corporation, a Baltimore company that specalizes in the credit card business, fell $5 yesterday, to $31.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Although many banks have been introducing cards with interest rates below 14 percent, they are alarmed by the legislative moves because the low-rate cards have been offered only to their least risky customers. With losses on delinquent cards rising to 5 percent of total credit card balances this year from 3.5 percent last year, bankers say they cannot afford to offer lower rates to all their customers.

HEADLINE: Trump's Bank Talks May Trim Plaza Stake

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump is negotiating a deal with bankers that could result in his giving up part-ownership of the jewel of his empire, the Plaza Hotel, people involved in the talks said yesterday.
The negotiations, aimed at changing the terms on about $430 million in bank debt, were forced by Mr. Trump after he refused to pay $1.6 million in interest due on the $300 million first mortgage he used to purchase the hotel. 
 His decision not to pay did not result from lack of money: The Plaza has almost $6 million in its bank account. Rather, Mr. Trump is trying to force the banks to give him more lenient terms on the $300 million first mortgage and an additional $125 million loan that he used to acquire the hotel. (With accrued interest, the debt now tops $430 million.)
Mr. Trump has said repeatedly that he will not sell the Plaza, and by forcing a renegotiation now he increases his chances of keeping the hotel under his control. The banks cannot simply foreclose because that would certainly hurt the hotel's business, impairing the value of one of Mr. Trump's better-performing assets.
The Plaza negotiations are separate from the broader restructuring of Mr. Trump's debt-laden empire. The general overhaul of the financing on most of his assets was played out over the last 18 months in a series of high-stakes negotiations with about 100 banks and thousands of bondholders.
The broader bank agreements are nearly complete and include all of the developer's assets, except for the Plaza, Trump Tower, his Atlantic City casinos and the railyards on the West Side of Manhattan. For each of those assets, Mr. Trump and several banks have cobbled together separate agreements.
"The overall Trump restructuring is 90 percent done," said one banker, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Trump had planned earlier this year to convert most of the Plaza's rooms to condominiums, but a conversion plan has yet to be filed with regulators, and the idea is widely thought to be unworkable. Last year, the cash from operations on the Plaza fell short of interest expenses by about $20 million, even though the hotel had positive cash flow of about $21 million before expenses.
But last year in an effort to help the property meet its obligations, the annual interest payments of nearly $8 million on the $125 million loan were deferred and will accrue for several years. So Mr. Trump is now obligated to pay only about $19.5 million a year on the first mortgage.
The Plaza, which is doing a brisk business and has occupancy rates of about 80 percent, can afford to pay the $19.5 million in remaining yearly interest. But Mr. Trump is hoping to get an extension on the maturity of both loans on the Plaza and lower interest rates. If the 26 banks that hold the first mortgage grant him those concessions, it is likely that Mr. Trump will have to give up some of his ownership stake.

Trump Casino Results
 ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 )AP) -- One of Mr. Trump's three casinos posted a profit in the third quarter, another lost money and the third recorded a loss before an extraordinary gain.
The Taj Mahal Casino Resort posted a $12.5 million loss in the third quarter before extraordinary gains from its reorganization.
The Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino recorded a profit of $7.1 million, and the Trump Castle Casino Resort a loss of $7.2 million.
According to figures released today, the Taj had net revenues of $125.2 million for the third quarter ended Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rexene, Awash in Debts, Turns Up as Golf Sponsor

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
William J. Gilliam, chairman of the Rexene Corporation, has walked tall as a deal maker on Wall Street, especially after he and some employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert led a buyout of the Dallas-based petrochemical company in 1988, then took it public four months later at a huge profit.
But last month, Rexene, which Mr. Gilliam has headed since the buyout, crash-landed in a Delaware bankruptcy court in a way that made it more than just another victim of too much debt piled atop an inefficient, cyclical business. 
 For more than a year, Mr. Gilliam knew that Rexene would have trouble repaying $403 million in debt due in July 1992. So he leaned on his creditors for months to make concessions. The agreement in principle they finally reached allowed Rexene to outline a reorganization plan that it filed in court on Oct. 18 and gave the company some financial relief.
Yet, just 19 days before the expected court filing, and without the bondholders' knowledge, Rexene turned up as a sponsor of the prestigious Ryder Cup golf tournament.
That put highly indebted Rexene in the company of the International Business Machines Corporation, the Coca-Cola Company and 14 other well-heeled sponsors. The companies reached into their deep pockets to spend at least $125,000 apiece -- $100,000 for the private tent and at least $25,000 for food and drink -- for the privilege of showing their guests some Southern hospitality apart from the throngs of spectators.
The guests began arriving on Kiawah Island, S.C., in late September, a few days before the final round. As a resident of both Kiawah and nearby Charleston, Mr. Gilliam should not have had far to come, but his company did pick up his guests' hotel bills and air fare.
By day, Mr. Gilliam and his guests enjoyed free food and drinks in a homey, air-conditioned place, while watching the competition on three television sets. By night, the group did the town, including a stop at the four-star Restaurante Million in Charleston, which Mr. Gilliam owns.
Rexene's spokesman, Neil J. Devroy, declined to say how much the entire affair cost, and accused a reporter of "trying to undermine the company" by asking.
 
Estimate of Cost
 Mr. Gilliam, through Mr. Devroy, declined several times in the last week to be interviewed.
Tournament officials estimate the event cost each sponsor $200,000 to $300,000, though Rexene, they say, may have spent less. Mr. Gilliam's New York-based investment firm, Gilliam & Company, promised to pick up half the tab in exchange for half the spots on the guest list.
Corporations often use such sponsorships to woo clients, reward employees and burnish their image. Still, some bondholders, corporate governance specialists and others who follow troubled businesses are asking, what was a financially pressed and little-known chemical company doing as a sponsor of a major golf tournament?
"Probably what was spent on the golf tournament wouldn't really move up anybody's share in the bondholders' settlement," said Kevin Foley, who, as deputy insurance superintendent for New York State, controls the $40 million of Rexene bonds owned by Executive Life of New York, a troubled insurance company. "On the other hand, if it's 50 cents, it's 50 cents that should go to the bondholders, and I don't see how sponsoring a golf tournament substantially helps a chemical company."
Gregg Jarrell, a former chief economist of the Securities and Exchange Commission who now teaches finance at the University of Rochester, went further.
"Not only is it not appropriate, it's shameful," he said. "There's a mentality unfortunately at some firms to take what you can get and run."
Many bondholders said they, too, were dismayed by Mr. Gilliam's business-as-usual attitude. They said they never thought they had to ask him explicitly not to spend the company's money in dubious ways.
"We're not forensic accountants," said one person involved in the negotiations, who like many declined to be quoted out of fear of upsetting the tentative agreement. "You don't go in and say, 'No Ryder Cup,' and the other side says, 'O.K., I'll do the U.S. Open.' "
 
Rexene's Views
 The Rexene spokesman, Mr. Devroy, said the commitment to be a sponsor was made last year, and the money paid in advance. He explained that the company decided it would reduce costs, say, by not inviting spouses, rather than withdraw and forfeit the money. And Mr. Devroy said that Rexene has canceled all sponsorships for 1992.
"There certainly was an opportunity to control the expenditures," Mr. Devroy said. "But there was not an opportunity to walk away."
But Kathy Boles, the 1991 tournament manager, said Rexene put down just 10 percent of the $100,000 rental fee a year ago, 40 percent in January, and the rest in June.
Moreover, the signing of the contract was held up until February. The hitch: Mr. Gilliam, who enjoys the sport of negotiating deals, haggled with the event's organizers to allow his Restaurante Million to cater his tent. He was rebuffed.
The Ryder Cup was not the first time that Mr. Gilliam's perquisities have stood out from the background of Rexene's modest business:
*Mr. Gilliam has taken out $23.2 million in profits from the company since the buyout and has $4 million more of paper profits on his 12.6 percent stake.
*Up until the day before the formal bankruptcy filing, he was charging Rexene $1 million a year in management fees.
*Also before the filing, he was charging Rexene more than $4,000 an hour -- the full charter market rate -- for use of his private Falcon jet for company business.
Outside investors have less to show for their forbearance. The proposed restructuring gives bondholders 55 to 65 percent of the company's equity. But they will have to wait 7 to 10 years beyond 1992 for their money, and they are taking an interest-rate cut.
As for shareholders, stock they paid as much as $24.875 a share for in 1988 traded yesterday at $1, unchanged.

GRAPHIC: Photo: William J. Gilliam, chairman of the Rexene Corporation, riding in his Falcon 100 airplane. Rexene, a Dallas-based petrochemical company, filed a reorganization plan in bankruptcy court last month. (Mark Perlstein for The New York Times) (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Midway Set To Sell Off Its Property

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Midway Airlines, the troubled Chicago-based airline that symbolized the successful upstart carrier of the 1980's, stopped flying yesterday -- for good.
"There's no choice -- we don't have any money," said David Hinson, chairman of the airline. A credit line of $40 million that had been available under an agreement in which Northwest Airlines would take over the carrier dried up after Northwest backed out of the deal on Wednesday. 
 The end of Midway, the nation's 12th-largest carrier at the beginning of the year, cost 4,300 workers their jobs and disrupted the flight plans of thousands of travelers on its almost 200 daily flights. Several airlines, including United, American, Continental, Southwest and Northwest itself, said they would honor Midway tickets, with various restrictions applied.
 
Frequent Flier
 Mr. Hinson said the 670,000 members of Midway's frequent-flier club would be unable to redeem their mileage because no other carrier would honor them.
Mr. Hinson said in an interview that the only issue left was whether the Bankruptcy Court would let the airline's management sell off its planes, airport gates and other assets under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code or put the case under Chapter 7, under which a court-appointed trustee would take over the liquidation.
Mr. Hinson said that after the airline sold its assets some money might be left for the unsecured creditors.
The unsecured creditors said they would work with Midway to pursue legal options against Northwest. While Northwest contended that Midway had given it misleading information and thus the deal to take over the carrier for $153 million could not be completed, Midway denied the accusation and said Northwest had accurate information. Its executives were puzzled yesterday by Northwest's action and felt that the carrier had pulled back for some other reason.
Midway was founded in 1979 just after the industry was deregulated. Operating out of a hub at Midway Airport in Chicago, Midway flew to 40 cities, including New York, Boston and Washington. In 1989 it added a second hub in Philadelphia, but it sold it a year later to USAir. And last March it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The immediate reasons were the decline in traffic during the Persian Gulf war and the recession, and higher fuel prices.
The airline was also being humbled by larger competitors that offered more frequent flights to more destinations, had their own computer reservation systems and greater incentives for travel agents to book their flights, and offered more attractive frequent-flier plans.
Midway's last flight, from Las Vegas, Nev., arrived yesterday at Midway Airport, where the carrier accounted for 75 percent of the daily flights. The fate of the airport, which is closer to downtown than O'Hare International, is uncertain.
Mr. Hinson said that other carriers, including Southwest Airlines, had expressed an interest in expanding their flights there. Northwest Airlines has 23 gates there, including 21 acquired from Midway for $20 million, and is in a good position to increase the number of flights there.
Some of the airline's passengers were bused from the airport to O'Hare yesterday to get flights.
The way that Midway was suddenly left out in the cold raised the ire of Midway executives and its creditors.
Thomas A. Schick, the president and chief executive of Midway, in a letter to Northwest's general counsel, Richard B. Hirst, said Northwest "has obviously decided that it does not want to do this deal and instead of acknowledging that in an honest and forthright manner, Northwest has adopted classic damage control and litigation tactics in an effort to divert attention and cover up its actions and motivations."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Passengers waiting in the baggage pickup area on Wednesday night at Midway Airport in Chicago after Midway Airlines announced it was halting operations. The announcement came after Northwest Airlines backed out of a deal to take over the carrier. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Disney's Net Down by 25.2%

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company reported today that its earnings fell 25.2 percent in the three months ended Sept. 30, largely because of a sharp downturn in its theme park business.
The results for the quarter, the fourth of Disney's fiscal year, reflected the effects of the recession on vacation travel to Walt Disney World in Florida and Disneyland in California, Disney executives and analysts said. The company's earnings, which were in line with analysts' expectations, were also depressed by a downturn in profitability in Disney's film and television business. 
 Net income for the quarter was $174.05 million, or $1.31 a share, compared with $232.66 million, or $1.72 a share, in the corresponding period last year. Revenues increased 2 percent, to $1.74 billion.
The fourth-quarter results capped one of the worst years for Disney since it was revived by a management team headed by Michael D. Eisner in 1984. For Disney's fiscal year, net income fell to $636.6 million, or $4.78 a share, from $824 million, or $6 a share, a decline of 22.7 percent. It was the first full-year decline in earnings under Mr. Eisner's team.
Disney said that the downturn reflected "lower levels of domestic travel and tourism caused by the current economic recession and the gulf war in the spring."
Disney stock gained $1.50 a share today on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $111.875.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
New signs of economic woe: Retail sales edged down in October, while average earnings slumped and the ranks of people applying for state unemployment benefits rose to the highest weekly level since May. [Page A1.] Consumer prices rose a modest 0.1 percent in October. [D17.] 
Legislation to change the nation's 60-year-old banking laws was overwhelmingly defeated by the House. The vote was a defeat for the White House and the House Democratic leadership. [A1.]
A Senate-approved measure to limit credit card interest rates to 14 percent would result in a sharp reduction in the availability of credit cards, bankers warned. [D1.]
A $5.3 billion measure to provide up to 20 weeks of extended unemployment benefits stalled in the Senate after overwhelming approval in the House. [A16.]
For mail-order catalogue merchants, the next six weeks of Christmas shopping will be critical. While department stores generate up to 50 percent of profits in the final two months of the year, many cataloguers count on 60 to 75 percent. [D1.]
An F.D.A. panel voted to recommend that breast implants remain on the market temporarily, under limited conditions. [A14.]
 
Companies
A French consortium won the bidding for Executive Life. The decision by California regulators moved efforts to rescue the failed insurer a big step closer to completion. [D1.]
Midway stopped flying. A $40 million credit line linked to the Northwest deal dried up after Northwest backed out. [D1.]
Donald J. Trump could give up part of the Plaza Hotel in a deal he is said to be negotiating with bankers. The negotiations, aimed at changing the terms on about $430 million in bank debt, were forced by Mr. Trump after he refused to pay $1.6 million in interest. [D6.]
Rexene is more than just another victim of too much debt piled atop an inefficient, cyclical business. [D1.]
Gregory G. Coleman has been named group publisher of Reader's Digest's U.S. edition and the special-interest magazines. [D15.]
Caterpillar warned investors that it would report a large fourth-quarter loss. [D4.]
 
International
A debate on whether the Soviet Union will default soon on payment of its foreign debt is occurring in Germany. [D6.]
 
Markets
Stocks closed lower in heavy trading on mixed signals about the economy. The Dow was off 1.79, to 3,063.51. [D6.]
Treasury note and bond prices rose, helped by a raft of statistics showing that economic conditions remain soft. [D12.]
The dollar fell amid new evidence of economic weakness. Gold prices also dropped. [D13.]
Platinum futures fell, erasing most of their recent gains. A refiner said supplies would greatly exceed consumption. [D13.]
 
Today's Columns
An old issue is back with a bang for 1992: How to stimulate economic growth without germinating inflation or other economic ills. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Toys "R" Us must confront a formidable group of challengers -- the discounters that have changed the rules of retailing over the last decade. Market Place. [D6.]
