HEADLINE: On Eve of Louisiana Vote, Nothing Is Certain

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The polls say Edwin Edwards, but the voices in the air say don't count out David Duke.
After coming from behind and building an unusual coalition of blacks and business interests, Mr. Edwards now appears within reach of victory, perhaps by a comfortable margin, political experts say. The question is whose voters will get to the polls, and there are more questions about Mr. Edwards's supporters than about Mr. Duke's. 
 "The Duke vote is impenetrable," said Stanley R. Tiner, a longtime newspaper editor and political analyst in Shreveport who is now public affairs director for a gas company there. "It's going to be there even if a tidal wave rolls across the state. Edwards is dependent on the Roemer voters who despised him four years ago -- he was the dragon Buddy Roemer promised to slay. That's a pretty scary prospect if you're sitting in Edwards's seat."
Still, questions about the sincerity of Mr. Duke's recently professed Christianity and whether he has shed the racist views he espoused when he was a grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan are dogging his campaign in the election's final days.
How the issues play out will not be known until Saturday, when a record turnout is expected in the last act of a searing political drama that has at turns entranced, mesmerized and sickened voters here and around the nation.
In its final week, the campaigns are as different as the candidates, one, Mr. Edwards, a three-time Democratic Governor twice tried and acquitted on racketeering charges, the other, Mr. Duke, a lifelong racial extremist now running as a mainstream conservative Republican.
Mr. Edwards, Louisiana's only three-term Governor, is concentrating his energy in New Orleans, spending heavily on television commercials and coordinating a well-oiled old-style political machine and get-out-the vote operation. He exudes confidence, perhaps too much confidence.
Some supporters and analysts say Mr. Edwards is sending a questionable message when he tells voters that his polls and three public polls released this week indicate he has the race won. "It's a very dangerous thing for him to do," said Joe Walker, a New Orleans poll taker. "He's used to politics as they've always been: if you're winning you're on the bandwagon. But that doesn't apply in this kind of election where you've got two candidates that more than half the people don't want."
 
Large Rallies for Both
 Mr. Duke, whose racially charged history has dominated the campaign, is racing across the state, from Lafayette in Cajun south Louisiana to Bossier City in conservative north Louisiana to his base in Metairie in suburban New Orleans. Outspent at least 3 to 1 on television, he is rallying his voters with a message that is more personal crusade than campaign. After a rally before 2,500 supporters near Lafayette Wednesday night, he lingered, signing autographs and hoisting babies for more than an hour like a ballplayer basking in the glow of adoring fans.
"I know why you're here," Mr. Duke told the crowd, which was waving blue and white Duke signs and wearing Duke baseball caps and T-shirts. "This is a much more than a political rally. This is a celebration of a new day coming in Louisiana."
Mr. Edwards drew the largest crowd of his runoff campaign, about 3,000 people, at a rally tonight at The Rivergate, a convention center in New Orleans. "Forty-eight hours from now we are going to send a message to the rest of America that we are too smart, too compassionate and too progressive to elect a David Duke to be governor of Louisiana," he said.
By all indications Mr. Edwards, once a giant of Louisiana politics who left office in near disgrace in 1987 despite escaping conviction in two racketeering trials, has built an unprecedented coalition that has put him within reach of an improbable political comeback.
 
'A Brilliant Campaign'
 Few doubt that Mr. Duke was in the lead after the October primary that eliminated Governor Roemer, the expected front-runner. Since then Mr. Edwards has joined his longtime allies among blacks and his longtime enemies in the business community into a coalition united by a common fear of Mr. Duke's extremist history.
"Edwards is running a brilliant campaign," said Lawrence Powell, a history professor at Tulane University. "He's gone after the Roemer voters and has found a way to appeal to the better angels of their nature. They're afraid they might wake up after a Duke victory and see an economic Jonestown, and they realize the divisiveness out there now is just frightening."
If Mr. Edwards wins it will be because of people like Clay Farnet, a New Orleans restaurateur, and Peg Murison, a New Orleans artist. Like many Roemer voters, both first vowed to sit out the runoff. Now both feel they have no choice but to vote for Mr. Edwards. Mrs. Murison is campaigning door to door. Mr. Farnet still has strong reservations about Mr. Edwards but thinks a Duke victory would be a moral and financial disaster. "I don't like pulling the switch for Edwards, but I'm going to do it because I'm convinced Duke is going to mean a lot of negative things for the state," he said.
After reaching a high just after the primary, Mr. Duke's campaign has come under fire from numerous directions over the past week.
Last night and tonight, WVUE-TV in New Orleans broadcast an interview with a woman whose name was not revealed but who was identified by the station as a former worker for Mr. Duke after his election to the State Legislature in 1989. She said Mr. Duke still voiced the racist and anti-Semitic views he has publicly renounced and still kept in touch with racial extremists.
She said his hatred for blacks and Jews was still apparent. "He would exterminate every one of them if he could," she said, adding, "It's Hitler's mind in David Duke's body."
In a front-page article Wednesday The New Orleans Times-Picayune quoted a Scottish journalist as saying Mr. Duke made blatant anti-Semitic statements to him in an interview last year. Mr. Duke later denied making those statements.
More damaging could be criticism from some Christian conservatives that Mr. Duke's professed born-again Christianity, a staple of his campaign, is also suspect.
Neil Curran, one of five conservative Christian leaders who interviewed Mr. Duke about his spiritual beliefs last week, said he believed Mr. Duke was not sincere about his religious views and was using them as a political ploy -- the same assertion made by the former state coordinator for the Duke campaign, Bob Hawks, when he quit Mr. Duke's campaign this week.
Mr. Curran said: "I think there's a backlash. I think when he used the name of Christ initially, he had some success because people wanted to believe it, but the investigation of the pastors and the denouncement by his own campaign aide who walked out on him have exposed him to evangelical Christians. It's proof."
Mr. Edwards's top priority now is making sure his voters, particularly black voters, turn out. Blacks are expected to make up about 28 percent of the electorate with virtually all of them supporting Mr. Edwards.
 
Fighting Complacency
 In Shreveport today a coalition of black ministers, representing all the major denominations among blacks, endorsed Mr. Edwards and urged a maximum turnout. Leaders said 200 churches in and around Shreveport will be helping to get out the vote. "Everything we have back there in the parking lot that will run is avaailable," said the group's spokesman, the Rev. Dr. E. Edward Jones of Galilee Baptist Church. "We don't want to lose ground we have already gained."
Despite the fear and anger engendered by Mr. Duke's candidacy, some prominent blacks are still worried about getting high turnout. "The problem is many felt Edwards was clearly going to win, because there is such unanimity in the black community, and they're all talking to each other," said Kenneth Carter, tax assessor for the central business district of New Orleans. "That's why I'm concerned about Edwin Edwards mentioning this landslide."
For the Duke campaign, organizing to increase turnout is not a worry.
"This race, it's a waste of time," said David Touchstone, a Shreveport lawyer and active Duke backer. "It's going to be a tremendous effort" by Duke voters, he said, regardless.
The reason is the evangelical fervor of the Duke supporters. At a rally near Lafayette on Wednesday they listened with approval as Mr. Duke blasted the news media, saying all the negative allegations against him were part of a biased media effort against him.
 
'We're Not Dumb'
 For many, the appeal worked.
"All the commentators are telling us we're dumb for voting for Duke," said Lee Castille of Breaux Bridge. "We're not dumb. We just want a change."
For many, the visceral appeal of Mr. Duke's issues was paramount.
" 'Tax, tax, tax, tax, tax,' that's all we ever hear from politicians," said Wendell Martin of Crowley. "And affirmative action? I was working offshore. I applied for a job with Union Pacific Resources. Who got the job? A bunch of Mexicans got it. I didn't get it because I was white. Affirmative action is racism big time."
Although the national and state Republican leaders have disavowed Mr. Duke, he has won the support of a handful of prominent Republicans here. Among them is the chairman of George Bush's 1988 campaign in northwest Louisiana, David Broussard.
"My primary motivation is an anti-Edwin Edwards vote," he said. "I don't see how anybody, even if David Duke is as bad as he may be, could be as bad a Governor as Edwin Edwards will be."

HEADLINE: Salvador Rebels to Halt Attacks; Government Sees an End to War

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 14

 BODY:
With the Salvadoran peace talks approaching their expected successful conclusion, the guerrilla front announced today that it was unilaterally suspending "offensive actions" after nearly a dozen years of civil war.
President Alfredo F. Cristiani immediately responded to what he termed a "signal of good will" and said that the Government and army would take "corresponding unilateral measures" when the rebel measure goes into effect Saturday. 
 "We expect that peace will begin in El Salvador on the 16th with the cessation of armed activities," the President said at a news conference minutes after the leaders of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front made their announcement in Mexico.
"The fighting is over," one of the guerrilla leaders, Shafik Handal, said, "although the end of the war is more complicated."
As Mr. Handal indicated, some important points to negotiate remain on the agenda of the peace talks under way in Mexico City. They include the organization of a new national police force with guerrilla participation and the changes in the army, including a reduction of its size.
Nevertheless, both sides as well as diplomats close to the negotiations continued to predict the signing of a formal, monitored cease-fire before the end of the year, probably at the United Nations in New York.
By their separate actions today, the two sides got around a longstanding roadblock to a temporary cease-fire, which was the guerrillas' demand that the army agree to stay out of predominantly rebel zones until formal peace takes hold.
That question was left unaddressed today. Mr. Cristiani did not specifically declare a cease-fire or an end to actions by the army, but his reference to corresponding measures and the end to armed activities in general implied that.
A senior Mexican official who has followed the talks closely said Mr. Cristiani's declaration was "not very clear, but our understanding is that the Government will observe the truce."
The communique by the five guerrilla commanders said they had decided to suspend "offensive actions, urban operations and economic sabotage" in the war, which has claimed an estimated 75,000 lives. They promised to make the efforts necessary to prolong the suspension until a cease-fire is signed.
"Not one more Salvadoran should die in this war that has already touched bottom and which only lacks the signing of a final, global accord," the guerrilla radio station declared in this morning's regular broadcast.
Mr. Cristiani avoided directly answering questions about whether the army would withdraw elite battalions from guerrilla strongholds like the upper parts of the departments of Chalatenango and Morazan.
"We would be disposed to order what is necessary in accord with how things are advancing," Mr. Cristiani said.
The guerrillas, long claiming that some zones are virtually their liberated territory, say the particularly intense assaults they have made in recent months on electric power plants, bridges and other economic infrastucture has been in response to the army's increased incursions into their areas.
Mr. Cristiani's rightist Government and the leftist guerrillas are nearing the end of a peace process that began early last year under the direction of Alvaro de Soto, a Peruvian diplomat and aide to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations.
Although a member of the strongly anti-Communist Nationalist Republican Alliance that is led by Roberto d'Aubuisson, Mr. Cristiani made clear after his election in 1989 that he intended to seek peace and to concentrate on the country's economic development.
Guerrilla leaders also decided in 1989 that the war could not be won and opted for negotiations. They say the major offensive they began in November 1989 was intended to convince the army of that as well.
The negotiations have been particularly complicated and detailed because they entail not only a cease-fire and the question of security for former combatants but also an effort by the guerrillas to bring about political and military reforms that will permit them an active role in a country.
Over the last year and a half a series of partial accords have emerged that cover matters like human rights verification, changes in the electoral system to permit more pluralism, judicial reform and general agreement on military reform.
When the talks seemed deadlocked over the military reform question and the related question of how to guarantee the guerrillas' security after they lay down their arms, the discussions talks were moved to New York in September for eight days of almost around-the-clock negotiations in which Mr. Cristiani himself took part.
That broke the stalemate and produced a general agreement that the guerrillas would be incorporated into a new national police but would give up their demand to put some members into the army.
The accord reached in New York called for a reduction of the size of the army, although the numbers and details remained to be negotiated.
The two sides also agreed that the army would be "purified" on the basis of an evaluation of its members by an ad hoc commission. The guerrillas agreed to a Government request that two army officers take part in the deliberations, without a vote.
The pact also allows guerrillas' family members and sympathizers to hold onto lands they have occupied in rebel-dominated areas since early in the war.
Under the terms of the agreement, a peace commission consisting of two members each from the Government and guerrilla front, plus representatives of the political parties, the church and the United Nations, is to supervise the carrying out of the accords.

HEADLINE: Real-Life Courtroom Drama May Play on Broadway Stage

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Nearly 80 years after it premiered on Broadway with an ill-fated show called "Are You a Crook?," a darkened Times Square theater is auditioning for a new role -- as a real-life criminal courtroom.
Under an unusual plan being advanced by top judges and other New York State and City officials and business executives, a section of the New York City Criminal Court now centralized in downtown Manhattan would be moved into the donated West 48th Street theater, the Longacre, for a three-year trial of a "community based" court, the city's first. 
 The aim, say proponents like Matthew T. Crosson, the state's chief court administrator, is to speed the handling of so-called quality of life offenses that victimize a community but that are often played down in the welter of violent felonies.
By some estimates the court, sitting five or six days a week from 2 P.M. to 10 P.M., would hear about 55 such cases a day, some 15,000 a year out of the nearly 70,000 misdemeanor and 40,000 felony cases a year in Manhattan.
The plan appears to have caught the imagination of some important players. Standing yesterday in the cloth-draped theater, Milton Mollen, deputy mayor for public safety, and a judge, strode to the footlights and intoned, "Life is a stage."
Some, however, including M. L. Henry, of the Committee for Modern Courts, a watchdog group, questioned the plan's usefulness and its fairness to poor communities that cannot afford to sponsor such an innovation. "Will simply moving the court from one location to another make it operate better?" he asked.
The court, to be set up on stage, with the orchestra rows of red plush seats open to spectators, would arraign only misdemeanor offenders arrested or given summonses in the midtown area -- no violent felons. A dozen or so Legal Aid lawyers and social-service counselors would be on hand, literally in the wings and in the balcony, to expedite pleas and sentences of vandals, petty thieves, low-level drug possessors, prostitutes, subway fare-beaters, three-card-monte cheats and other convicted offenders.
Some would be remanded to treatment programs, others ordered to make restitution or work on community improvement projects. A relative few might be sent to jail. But in all cases the aim would be immediate dispositions, a rarity now in the overburdened court system. Accused felons, including violent criminals, would continue to be processed at 100 Centre Street. Pleas of not guilty would also continue to be adjudicated downtown and trials, too, would be held downtown.
With a Times Square court, offenders would be booked, not at Central Booking downtown, but at a midtown precinct where a complaint would be drawn and fingerprints checked. They would then be taken to the theater to plead, cutting hours off a process that now can consume a full day. Minor offenders pleading guilty would also not have to wait for complex felony cases to be heard, and felony cases themselves may be speeded.
The plan, which faces some financial and other hurdles but appears likely to be adopted, has won many plaudits along with some mixed notices. The theater would be loaned, rent free, by its owner, the Shubert Organization, which would also renovate upstairs office space. The redesign would be drawn up by an architect, pro bono. Start-up costs not financed by the city are estimated at close to $1 million the first year, perhaps half that for following years. Some grants have already been given.
"We're enthusiastic; there are great possibilities," said Justice Milton L. Williams, deputy chief administrative judge for New York City Courts. He said he envisioned the Times Square court as a place where law schools might stage moot courts for the public's education, where judges might drop in for community forums. But he added: "The whole thing is money."
Judge Mollen, who has advocated a broader system of community courts staffed by lay judges, said the experiment could demonstrate the effectiveness of such decentralization. But he cautioned that it would have to be done without extra cost to the city, that District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau was still studying the plan and that Mayor David N. Dinkins "is not yet fully committed to it."
Judge Robert G. M. Keating, administrative judge of the Criminal Court, lauded the plan as likely to restore a community component to the court system that, he said, would "mesh" with the Police Department's community policing strategy of attacking quality of life problems as precursors to violent crime.
Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown, who has made community policing his signature program, called the court plan "a natural extension of what we're doing.
Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission, a business-sponsored watchdog group that last year called for a system of community courts throughout the city.
The plan has been strongly pushed by Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, and one of its early advocates. Crime, he said, has had a "devastating" impact on the theater district. It was time, he said, that the courts recognized the rights of the community, particularly now that a multibillion-dollar Times Square redevelopment plan has been stalled by a bad real-estate market.
Speaking for the Times Square Business Improvement District, a self-taxing association of commercial interests in the area, Arthur O. Sulzberger Jr., the group's chairman and deputy publisher of The New York Times, also applauded the plan. "It could be the longest running show on Broadway," he said.
 
Enough Cases?
 Mr. Morgenthau, whose support for the plan is widely considered important if not crucial, said he was still examining it. His figures, he said, suggested that there may not be enough cases in just the midtown area to justify moving one of the two day parts -- there are five parts, or sections, altogether -- of the Manhattan Criminal Court to Times Square. The court would handle cases roughly from 30th to 60th Streets, Fifth Avenue to the Hudson River.
Still, he said, he was not "a key player," was not out to block the experiment and would staff the court with a prosecutor as required.
But even advocates like Judge Mollen said he was concerned that the plan might be seen as "elitist," favoring a vocal business lobby or powerful Manhattan constituency. "On the other hand," he said, referring to crime in Times Square, "we have a problem. Shall we not be concerned?"
As for Mr. Morgenthau's reservations about the allocation of resources, Judge Keating and Judge Williams said their figures showed that the court part that would be moved uptown would handle the same 55 or so daily cases it was now handling downtown. There would be no shortage of work, they insisted.
The court plan grew out of a breakfast meeting at the Pierre Hotel last spring between Mr. Schoenfeld, Carl Weisbrod of the city's Economic Development Commission and Herbert Sturz, a real-estate executive who is a former chairman of the City Planning Commission and former Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice. Mr. Schoenfeld at that occasion offered to donate the Longacre.
The theater had been dark since May 1990 when its last show, "Truly Blessed," closed after a month of regular performances. Built in 1913, the Longacre, named for the square that pre-dated Times Square, opened with "Are You a Crook?" a farce about a woman crime buff who plots a stickup only to find she has robbed one of her own friends. The play closed after 12 performances.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Offers to Jump-Start Long Island

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 14

 BODY:
Saying that Long Island had been severely damaged by local and national economic forces, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today unveiled an economic revitalization package that he said should breathe some life into its distressed economy.
Among the initiatives in the program are a $35 million fund for Long Island's parks and a proposal to accelerate hundreds of millions of dollars worth of road projects to jump-start the economy by putting people to work as early as next year. 
 But at a time when the state's own finances are so shaky that Mr. Cuomo said its budget deficit would probably rise past the current projection of $700 million, the Governor had to acknowledge that he had no new money to spend here and that the plan does not include new appropriations.
In a region beset by economic bad times, Long Island is hurting even more than most places. Today, while some Long Island business people grumbled that the Governor's program represented little more than a new packaging of old ideas -- some of the road projects, for example, have been on the back burner for years -- they added that it was at the very least symbolically important that the Governor had ventured here to show his support.
 
Sooner Is Better
 "I think it's a package constrained by limits on government now to do more spending," said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association, the business group that sponsored Mr. Cuomo's address at a breakfast meeting today. "But many of the public works elements, by being moved up in time, become genuine economic development boosts. If you have something moved up by a year or two, it's a real initiative."
Long Island's package was similar to a proposal presented by the Governor for New York City in September. Mr. Cuomo said he planned to present similar plans in Syracuse, the Hudson Valley and the Albany area as pieces of a statewide program called "New, New York."
On Long Island, where property taxes continue to climb, unemployment has reached a 20-year high of 6.8 percent and businesses are failing at record rates, the Governor's visit was seen as a fairly successful effort to mend fences with the business community, which has been miffed at what it perceives as a lack of attention from the state.
The Governor said the plan would represent more than $900 million in new investment that would create more than 25,000 permanent and construction jobs.
"It is a plan to help to diversify and spur the region's economy, to improve its transit system, to create more affordable housing and to insure safe, reliable energy supplies; to preserve the island's natural resources," Mr. Cuomo said.
 
How Many Planes?
 Among other projects mentioned by the Governor are a high-speed ferry to carry cargo and people between New Haven and the Shoreham power plant, the establishment of a Long Island Global Assistance Unit to help encourage foreign trade and new strategies to help move away from a reliance on defense and to encourage a fledgling biotechnology industry.
Mr. Cuomo also mentioned, as he has before, that he is pushing the Legislature to help relieve local governments of some state mandates, and for the state to assume Medicaid costs. And he renewed his commitment to reforming school aid formulas to make them more equitable from district to district.
"Long Island, like the rest of our state and the rest of this country, has problems," Mr. Cuomo said. "Some of them are homegrown, the result of past growth, overlapping government jurisdictions, proliferations of school districts and taxing entities. Those are problems we can handle and the state can assist with."
The money for all this is to come from a variety of sources, including leftover money from the 1988 transportation bond act and money from the state's dedicated highway fund, which is expected to begin generating more than $93 million a year in 1993. Money for the new park fund will be provided by using park fees as leverage for borrowing.
Mr. Cuomo emphasized that he wanted to revitalize the economy while preserving Long Island's environment. But one major part of his proposal -- a plan to study development at Calverton Airport in Brookhaven, a property that Mr. Cuomo said "holds out the greatest promise for creating new jobs on the Island, with the least threat to the surrounding environment" -- provoked dismay from the Island's vocal environmentalists. The development possibilities include turning Calverton into a major hub for freight or passenger air traffic.
"This is a retread of everything that has failed economically and environmentally on Long Island for the last 40 years," said Richard Amper, executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society. "You would be hard-pressed to find a more environmentally sensitive place on Long Island to site a jetport."
Mr. Cuomo pointed out, however, that the 7,000-acre site includes 3,500 acres of open space. Of the 1,000 acres on the property that are zoned for commercial use, only a small portion would be needed for any development scheme, he said.

HEADLINE: China Undercuts U.S. Anti-Atom Effort on Korea

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 14

 BODY:
American efforts to mount an international campaign to persuade North Korea to halt its nuclear-weapons program were dealt a setback today when North Korea's main backer, China, declared that "dialogue," not pressure, was the way to deal with Pyongyang.
The Chinese pronouncement was made at a news conference by Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, at the close of a two-day meeting of the 15-nation Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. It was certainly not the kind of public position that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who was also attending the Asian-Pacific meeting, was hoping to hear from Beijing -- especially coming on the eve of his first official visit to China. 
 Asked for China's view on the Korean nuclear question, Mr. Qian told reporters at his own news conference, "We do not want to see the existence of nuclear weapons on the Korean Peninsula."
But he quickly continued, "We hope to see the parties concerned engaged in effective consultation to find a solution to this problem, but we do not wish to see any international pressure."
 
Fear of United Korea
 A senior American official based in Seoul, trying to explain the Chinese position, said Beijing had consistently taken the view that the North Koreans should not be pushed into a corner and that their leader, Kim Il Sung, always needed to save face. The Chinese believe the Americans are too impatient in wanting to deal with the matter, the official said, even though estimates are that North Korea could have a crude nuclear bomb within two years.
The official said the Chinese continue to feel protective of North Korea, particularly since they prefer that the division of the North and South be maintained, as they do not want to have to compete with a "vigorous united Korea, with some 60 or 70 million people."
The Bush Administration actually has gone out of its way in recent weeks to give North Korea a face-saving opening to abandon its nuclear-weapons program. President Bush's decision to withdraw the United States' tactical nuclear weapons from South Korea, coupled with last week's announcement by Seoul that it was ready to forgo development of any weapons of mass destruction, were specifically intended to provide Pyongyang with a justification for scrapping its nuclear project.
But North Korea dismissed those moves as empty gestures. That response was one of the reasons that Washington believed only a serious multilateral campaign might have any effect in swaying the economically strapped Pyongyang Government. The fact that North Korea's biggest benefactor, China, appears to want to water down such an effort does not bode well for its success, and again raises questions about what exactly the Bush Administration is getting out of its policy of constructive engagement with the hard-line Beijing leadership.
 
Baker's News Conference
 North Korea has consistantly refused to open its nuclear complex 60 miles north of Pyongyang to international inspection, even though it signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and in September agreed with the International Atomic Energy Agency on a program of safeguards, which it refused to begin at the last minute. That is apparently because the installation contains a suspected reprocessing plant that could produce hundreds of pounds of weapons-grade plutonium.
A few hours after Mr. Qian's morning news conference, Mr. Baker held a joint news conference with other Asian-Pacific ministers, including Mr. Qian, and began by repeating his call for international diplomatic and political efforts to press North Korea until it halts its nuclear-weapons program. From the start of his Asian tour in Tokyo, Mr. Baker has been speaking out about the need for American, Soviet, Japanese and Chinese cooperation toward that end.
"We think the greatest threat to regional security and stability in this area is the threat of nuclear-arms development by North Korea," said Mr. Baker, striking a markedly different tone from his Chinese counterpart. "It is a threat that we think needs to be addressed. We see it as a major regional issue, but also see it as a global issue. I think the United States is joined by some other countries in wanting this matter to be dealt with politically and diplomatically."

HEADLINE: 7 Soviet Republics Agree to Seek New Union

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 14

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the leaders of seven republics agreed today to work toward a new confederated "Union of Sovereign States," with the central authorities exercising powers delegated by sovereign republics.
There was no immediate indication exactly what powers would be delegated to the center, and participants said the agreement was still subject to approval by the parliaments of all the republics. 
 The absence of several republics -- most notably the Ukraine, which is abstaining from any such discussions until after the republic holds a referendum on Dec. 1 on its future -- raised further questions about the prospects of the agreement.
But all participants at the meeting, including President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian republic, seemed heartened at least by the fact that agreement had been reached to pursue some form of political union.
The very site of the meeting, a Government retreat in the suburb of Novo-Ogaryovo, was the one at which republic leaders first met in April to shape a new association. The agreement they reached then collapsed with the coup attempt in August, and officials said the new project was totally different from the federation envisioned then.
The key difference is the wariness of most republic leaders of creating any central structures that could eventually reanimate the dictatorial center of the past.
Speaking briefly to reporters after their eight-hour meeting, Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin and leaders of Byelorussia, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Kirghizia, Tadzhikistan and Turkmenistan indicated that more than half the discussion had been dedicated to the basic shape of the new association.
Mr. Yeltsin said the participants finally had agreed that the future union should be a "Union of Sovereign States -- Confederated State, fulfilling functions delegated by states participating in the agreement."
The formula seemed to accept both Mr. Gorbachev's call for a state that could be a genuine subject of international law, and insistence of the republicans on a confederation in which they would determine and limit the powers of the central Government. A confederation is a league of independent states joined by negotiated bonds.
Mr. Yeltsin said after the meeting that it was still difficult to say how many republics would join the union, but added, "After today's discussions, I am firmly convinced there will be a union."
Declining to take part in the meeting, besides the Ukraine, were Georgia and Moldavia. The Armenian leader is now in the United States and did not send a deputy, and the leader of Uzbekistan reportedly missed the session because of transportation problems. The three Baltic republics, their independence now internationally recognized, no longer take part in such discussions.
 
10 Signed Economic Pact
 The move toward a political association follows the signing of a draft economic pact by 10 republics to create a free-market zone in place of the former command economy. That agreement was intended to prevent the chaotic disintegration of complex economic ties among the republics, but a final agreement has not yet been reached.
Leaders of the Ukraine at first balked, but finally also joined in the economic agreement. But the republic's Prime Minister, Vitold Fokin, today threatened to resign unless the Ukrainian Parliament lifted its resistance to ratifying the agreement.
Nursultan Nazarbayev, the President of Kazakhstan, who has been among the strongest advocates of negotiating a new political union, said after today's meeting that the economic treaty "was constantly balking in the absence of a political union."
The heads of the republics gathered as the State Council, the collective federal executive formed after the August coup. They also named Ivan Silayev as the new national Prime Minister. The appointment formalized a function that Mr. Silayev, formerly Prime Minister of the Russian republic, had been filling as head of the interim Inter-State Economic Committee.

HEADLINE: Argentine Proclaims His Country Stable

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina swept through Washington today, boasting that his country had finally put its economic and political house in order and was set to claim a high-visibility role in the new international order.
"We have credibility," he told reporters this afternoon as the first hectic day of his state visit began to wind down. "We have stability." 
 One of his first tasks, he said, will be to find a way to bring democracy to Cuba, working beside his "sisters and brothers of America." He intends to meet Cuban exiles in the United States.
"Without exaggeration," he told a joint meeting of Congress triumphantly, "I can say that I come here at the best moment in our relations."
 
Pleasant Message for U.S.
 As if to underline his point, Congressional staff members said his appearance before both houses, usually an honor reserved for very high-profile foreign dignitaries, had been arranged almost at the last minute, to the delight of Buenos Aires. Until early this week, a few members of Congress had been expecting him for coffee with a committee.
From a welcoming ceremony on the White House lawns, to Congress and all around town, the 61-year-old Mr. Menem brought a message the Bush Administration was pleased to hear. Argentina, he said, had put its irresponsible, anti-American nationalist past behind it. It was now committed to free enterprise at home and the dream of a Western Hemisphere trading community stretching "from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego."
The visit was well timed to follow good news in the Argentine economy. When Mr. Menem took office in 1989, he inherited four-digit inflation, a bloated state enterprise system and the remnants of a protectionist policy that scared away investors. Inflation is now down to about 2 percent a month, and the erratic local currency is stabilizing.
The Argentine President -- who is remaking the Peronist movement he heads nearly half a century after it was given its nationalistic stamp by its founder, Juan Domingo Peron -- today became the first leader of a major Latin American country to sign an investment-protection treaty with the United States.
The treaty provides guarantees against arbitrary confiscation of assets and assurances that there will be no limits on repatriation of profits. Where expropriations occur, legally enforceable compensation standards would be expected to be met. The treaty also includes provisions for international arbitration of investment disputes.
 
16th Country to Sign
 Argentina is the 16th country to sign a treaty with the United States since the Bilateral Investment Program was begun in 1981, though only eight of the treaties have been put into force: in Bangladesh, Cameroon, Grenada, Morocco, Panama, Senegal, Turkey and Zaire. Treaties awaiting ratification or aother action in Washington or abroad have been signed with Congo, Czechosllovakia, Egypt, Haiti, Poland, Sri Lanka and Tunisia. The Argentine treaty is also subject to ratification.
President Menem told the heads of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund that he was confident Argentina could resolve its foreign debt problem sometime in 1992. He told Congress that his sweeping privatization plan, which is turning over to private enterprise everything from airlines to road maintenance, would be completed by 1993.

HEADLINE: Sockeye Salmon Listed as Endangered Species

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The Federal Government listed the Snake River sockeye salmon an endangered species today, making it likely that some Columbia River water will be diverted from generating electricity, farming and shipping.
Just four of the fish returned to their ancestral spawning ground in Idaho this year. 
 "What this means now is that the region is going to be held accountable for protection of the sockeye salmon, and that is a legal accountability," said Bill Bakke of Oregon Trout, which has petitioned for listing other salmon species as well.
The National Marine Fisheries Service listed the Snake River sockeye as endangered under the Endangered Species Act, forcing the Government to act to save the fish from extinction.
"At one time, these fish were so abundant that Native Americans and early miners depended on them for food in several locations within the Snake River basin," the agency said in a statement in Washington, D.C.
 
Long Trek Blocked by Dams
 The designation of the salmon was not unexpected.
"The good news is that the region has been preparing itself for this listing for nearly a year and a half, and we are way ahead of the game," said Senator Mark Hatfield, Republican of Oregon.
Historically, more than 11 million salmon and steelhead swam the Columbia system each year, but the runs have dwindled to about 2.5 million fish. Many of them are now from hatcheries, and wild fish are at only 2 percent of their former levels.
Thousands of sockeye used to complete the 900-mile trek up the Columbia from the Pacific Ocean to spawn in Redfish Lake Creek in Idaho's Sawtooth Mountains, but now eight Federally operated dams stand in their way.
The dams create hurdles for salmon migrating upstream. They also slow the water flows that once carried young salmon downstream to the Pacific Ocean in about two weeks. Now the trip takes much longer and the smolts' gills prematurely begin their adaptation from fresh to salt water before they reach the ocean.
Roddy Moscoso, a spokesman for the fisheries service, said only three females and one male returned to Redfish Lake Creek this year. None completed the trip last year, although others may still be living as the migration occurs in four- to five-year cycles.
Protection costs will remain unknown until the Government adopts a formal recovery plan, but efforts to save the sockeye will probably require increasing river flows by diverting water from current uses.
The Northwest Power Planning Council, which plans the power needs for Washington, Oregon, Idaho and Montana, is considering its salmon-recovery plan this week during a meeting in Helena, Mont., and is expected to produce a final plan by mid-December.
Ed Mosey of the Columbia River Alliance, which represents dam operators, shippers, irrigators and industrial water users, said the salmon runs could be protected "without dramatic and widespread economic impacts." He said the recovery plan should be spread across all parties having an effect on the wild salmon, including commercial fisheries as well as water users.
Industry officials have recently said altering operation of the hydroelectric dams could mean electricity rates at the household level would rise 10 percent.
However, the power council estimates that $70 million worth of water flow would be dedicated to fish annually, meaning rate increases would be limited to about 2 percent.

HEADLINE: House Approves Extended Benefits For Those Out of Work Six Months

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
A $5.3 billion measure to provide up to 20 weeks of extended unemployment benefits to about 3 million people out of work at least half a year stalled in the Senate tonight after overwhelming approval in the House earlier in the day.
Some senators contended that workers in their states were getting short-changed by the complex formulas determining the number of weeks people would get unemployment benefits. Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, spoke for many when he called it "the most cockamamie formula I've ever seen." 
 Except for Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, whose state did well in the formula, senators had taken a back seat in negotiations over the bill in the last two weeks. The Administration had dealt largely with members of the House. Democratic senators had pressed to pay for the bill by cutting foreign aid, and neither House leaders nor the Administration wanted to discuss that approach.
 
Struggle in Senate
 President Bush, who killed two earlier versions of the legislation, has said he will sign this one. Unlike its predecessors, which would have been financed by increasing the Federal deficit, this measure would raise as much money, through a variety of provisions, as it would spend.
The vote in the House was 396 to 30. But the Senate wrangled into the night, and it was not clear when the Senate adjourned tonight whether the measure would come to a vote before the weekend.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader and the author of the proposal to pay for benefits by cutting foreign aid, pleaded with angry Senators not to propose amendments that would delay sending the bill to the President. He said any delay risked "a Thanksgiving with nobody getting any benefits."
But he was challenged, among others, by his own party's whip, Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, who contended that his state would get less in benefits than under the bill Mr. Bush vetoed in October, and that no Senate Democrat had been involved in working out the compromise before them.
The breadth of support in the Housereflected an overwhelming sense of Congressional relief that nearly four months of political battles over the issue were giving way to action on a plan to get checks to the jobless.
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader who pushed President Bush toward compromise last month, said, "Unemployed Americans need help, not more rhetoric, not posturing, not partisan sniping from both sides."
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democratic who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said: "We have waited far too long to pass this essential bill. Now is the time for the politics to stop and for us to act."
Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk, said, "People from Bayport, L.I., to Burbank, Calif., today are breathing a sigh of relief." He said they were relieved "because we have finally, here in the House, gotten our act together."
But politics was only submerged, not eliminated. Representative Les AuCoin, Democrat of Oregon, renewed a familiar Democratic theme when he said, "While Oregonians have been to the unemployment office, the President has been on an all-expense-paid world tour."
David Bonior of Michigan, the House Democratic whip, attacked Mr. Bush for refusing to help jobless Americans while declaring emergencies to allow deficit spending to aid Turks, Kurds and Bangladeshis.
 
More Disputes Expected
 And lawmakers in both Houses expected continuing problems in the economy and the fact that unemployment remains severe, even when the economy begins to improve, to bring the issue back before them again next year, closer to the election. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, predicted more disputes "the next time we bring this up, in June."
This bill would take effect this month and expire next July 4, making the approximately 300,000 workers who exhaust the normal state limit of 26 weeks of benefits each month eligible for additional benefits.
Workers in 34 states who exhausted their benefits since March 1 and were still out of work would also be eligible for additional benefits. Isaac Shapiro, a senior research analyst at the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities and an expert on unemployment, said that about one million workers would be covered by that provision.
Under several complicated formulas involving the unemployment rate among workers covered by unemployment insurance, the unemployment rate among all workers, and the rate at which benefits have been exhausted, workers in different states are eligible for either 6, 13 or 20 weeks of additional benefits.
The 10 states in which workers could get 20 weeks of benefits include Connecticut and New Jersey. The 19 states where workers could get 13 weeks of benefits include New York and California, the two largest states in the nation. Workers in all other states would get six weeks. People who live in one state and worked in another would apply for benefits in the employer's state.
A major and permanent change that the bill would make in existing law would make people who leave the armed services eligible for 26 weeks of regular benefits, instead of 13 weeks, and to be able to claim them after one week, instead of four. Both changes would put them on an equal footing with people who leave civilian jobs.
Until tonight, when the Senate began arguing over the fairness of the formulas for weeks of coverage and the "reachback" for people who had exhausted their benefits earlier this year, the main controversy over the bill had been over its financing.
Democrats have insisted that costs for this sort of "emergency" should be paid for by increasing the deficit.
President Bush has said that approach will "bust the budget."
This bill is supposed to be paid for by a variety of measures in five years' time. It would not, as Mr. Dole had insisted earlier, have paid for itself in each year.
That was one complaint from Representative Bill Archer, the senior Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee today. He said the bill would cost $910 million more in the current year than it would take in.
Mr. Archer also objected sharply to a provision to make taxpayers with incomes of $75,000 or more and whose incomes soared by at least $40,000, pay higher estimated taxes. That provision is expected to bring in $2.6 billion.
Another $878 million would come from extending for one year the surtax, of two-tenths of 1 percent that employers pay on the first $7,000 of wages of a covered employee. That tax is now expected to expire at the end of 1995.
The rest of the costs of the program would be paid by provisions to continue procedures under which the Internal Revenue Service withholds unpaid student loans from tax refunds.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Representative Thomas J. Downey, who was pivotal leader in putting together the extended benefits bill.; Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, left, pushed President Bush toward a compromise last month. Representative Dan Rostenkowski said, "We have waited far too long to pass this essential bill." (Associated Press; Paul Conklin)
 
Chart: "EXTENDING UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFITS: THREE BILLS"
Under current law, jobless workers who file for unemployment compensation get it for 26 weeks in most states. Benefits can be extended for 13 weeks in states where unemployment among covered workers. Taxes on employers pay for the benefits. In no state are extended benefits now being paid.
 
AUGUST BILL
 
STATUS: Signed but prevented from going into effect
 
BENCHMARK: Total unemployment, instead of the insured unemployment figures used under current law.
 
EXTENSION OF BENEFITS: Additional 20 weeks in states with average of 8 percent unemployment over the last six months; 13 weeks in states with 7 percent; 7 weeks in states with 6 weeks percent; 4 weeks in all other states.
 
5-YEAR COST: $5.8 billion
 
FINANCING: No budget cuts or revenue increases were included in the bill. For it to take effect, a separate declaration of a budget emergency by the President was needed to exempt the bill from the pay-as-you-go provisions of the 1990 Budget Agreement. The President refused to sign such a declaration.
 
OCTOBER BILL
 
STATUS: President Bush's veto was sustained.
 
BENCHMARK: Same as the August bill.
 
EXTENTION OF BENEFITS: Same as the August bill, except that eligibility would be retroactive to March 1 in certain states.
 
5-YEAR COST: $6.4 billion.
 
FINANCING: Same as the August bill, except that the declaration of a budget emergency would have been automatic when the bill was signed by the President. No separate declaration would have been needed.
 
NOVEMBER BILL
 
STATUS: Presdient Bush has said he will sign it.
 
BENCHMARK: Insured unemployment rate plus workers who have exhausted their regular benefits.
 
EXTENSION OF BENEFITS: All states get at least 6 weeks; 19 states get at least 13 weeks; 10 states get 20 weeks. Retroactivity provision similar to the October bill.
 
5-YEAR COST: $5.3 billion.
 
FINANCING: Includes various provision to pay for new benefits, so it does not require an emergency exemption from the Budget Agreement. Funding provisions include increasing estimated tax payments by some high income taxpayers, extending an unemployment tax surcharge on employers and improving collection of non-tax debts owed to Federal agencies, like student loans. HEADLINE: BUCHANAN WEIGHS PRESIDENTIAL RACE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist and commentator, is edging closer toward a challenge to President Bush for the 1992 Republican nomination, friends and associates said today.
Mr. Buchanan, who served in the Nixon and Reagan Administrations, is "very excited about it," said Angela Bay Buchanan, the commentator's sister, who is a former United States Treasurer and the organizer of his exploratory campaign. "But he wants to make that final determination over Thanksgiving." 
 Mr. Buchanan, who did not return a reporter's telephone calls today, would focus his efforts on New Hampshire, the scene of the first Presidential primary and an area wracked by the recession, Ms. Buchanan said. Top Republicans brushed aside his chances of seriously challenging Mr. Bush, but some in the party said Mr. Buchanan could be a troublesome distraction for the President and a rallying point for disaffected conservatives.
Clayton K. Yeutter, chairman of the Republican National Committee, told reporters in Albany today: "We live in a democratic society where anybody has the prerogative of filing on either the Democratic or Republican side. As a practical matter, I don't see that having a significant electoral impact."
Kendall Lane, the assistant chairman of the New Hampshire Republican Committee, said, "For those people on the right wing of the party who feel they need a voice, Pat Buchanan will give them that voice." But Mr. Lane predicted that Mr. Buchanan would get, at most, 15 to 20 percent of the Republican primary vote there.
Mr. Buchanan, a speech writer for President Richard M. Nixon and the director of White House communications under President Ronald Reagan, considered a Presidential campaign in 1987 but ultimately backed off. The Washington Times reported today that Mr. Buchanan had decided to run in 1992, but a top Republican strategist, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, predicted that Mr. Buchanan would pull back once again.
"I think this is born of frustration," the strategist said. "This is an effort to put rightward pressure on Bush, and it could very well have that effect." There was similar talk of a conservative challenge to Mr. Bush in 1990, after he reneged on his "no new taxes" pledge, but it dissolved when the crisis erupted in the Persian Gulf.
Several conservatives today were cheering for Mr. Buchanan. "Conservatives right now feel leaderless," said Richard Viguerie, a conservative organizer and fund-raiser, ticking off the issues that have rankled many on the right. The economic issue has gained power in recent weeks, as dismayed conservatives watched Democrats cast themselves as the champions of tax cuts for the middle class.
 
Hostile Climate
 Adding to the nervousness in the White House is the climate in New Hampshire, where the economy is at the top of the agenda. Moreover, some analysts detect a general anti-incumbent mood around the country.
Craig Shirley, a Republican consultant who supports Mr. Bush, added, "Given the economic climate out there, I think anybody would have to take any credible conservative challenger seriously."
Ms. Buchanan said her brother's message would be: "America first -- let's focus on America's problems now, and not the world's problems. Let's bring our attention home to our nation and reduce taxes and give people an opportunity once again to make a living out there."
Ms. Buchanan said she had begun the logistical work on a campaign so that if the commentator gives the nod, "We'll be ready to go."

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
In Tribute to a Dedicated Scholar and Ambassador of New York's Highest Court.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
Walter Mordaunt never sat on the New York Court of Appeals, or argued before it or parsed its decisions for a law school class. But no one ever cared for it more, or studied it more lovingly, or knew so well its every alcove or imparted his erudition about it so enthusiastically. When he died last week, at the age of 72, New York's highest court lost one of its most authentic scholars as well as its most effective ambassador.
Benjamin N. Cardozo, who served as Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals from 1926 to 1932, when he was named to the United States Supreme Court, once defined the mission of New York's highest court to be "translating into law the social and economic forces that throb and clamor for expression." Too often, however, the expressions emanating from it or any other court are unintelligible to the naked eye, and the process by which they are reached incomprehensible. Sometimes, it seems, lawyers and judges prefer it that way. 
 It was to combat that tendency that, in 1973, Charles D. Breitel, one of Cardozo's most distinguished successors, overcame his instinctive aversion to hype and, for the first time, hired a spokesman for the court: Mr. Mordaunt, who had been a reporter for The Albany Times-Union and served as deputy press secretary to Gov. Averill Harriman. From that moment on, Mr. Mordaunt proved that to demystify need not mean to degrade or debunk.
From 7:30 or so five mornings a week for the next 17 years, until his retirement in September 1990, Mr. Mordaunt toiled away in his small office in the court's southwest corner. He took phone calls from anxious reporters, explaining a convoluted court system like New York's, in which an appeals court is supreme and a Supreme Court is inferior.
It was Mr. Mordaunt who parceled out the court's decisions, placing them on Greyhound buses for some downstate newspapers. He kept reporters apprised of the court's caseload, a task that required him to comprehend the legalese of lawyers from Tonawanda to Montauk, as well as the judges' own often impenetrable prose. Mr. Mordaunt never got a law degree -- World War II precluded that -- but his grasp of legal issues would have shamed many who had.
A tall and elegant man with a mellifluousness inherited from his thespian parents, he went about his work with modesty and gentlemanliness, no mean feat in the cloistered, egocentric world of the judiciary. Some spokesmen for important courts take on the coloration of the institutions they serve -- the higher and more prestigious the tribunal, the more begrudgingly these people help, the more self-importantly they say no.
Mr. Mordaunt took it upon himself to explain the court's past as well as its present. A history buff who spent his spare time touring Civil War battlefields, he schooled himself in the court's law and lore, then imparted what he learned about it to thousands of schoolchildren and ordinary citizens who took his court tours.
He could tell you how the portrait of John Jay, New York's first Chief Judge, hung directly behind the seat reserved for his most recent successor, and how, from that position, Jay stares in perpetuity at Robert Livingston, New York's first chancellor, whose statue stands on the other side of the room. He would explain how the hand-carved courtroom had been designed by Henry Hobson Richardson, and been moved over piece by piece from the old state capital in 1916, and would point out the seven brass spittoons that still sit under the bench.
Shortly before he retired he gave one last tour to a peculiarly attentive audience: the seven judges themselves, none of whom knew nearly as much about the place as he. It was, said one of the judges, Joseph W. Bellacosa, "a showstopping finale."
So great was Mr. Mordaunt's love for the institution that even the milestones of others working there gave him personal pleasure. Sept. 12, for instance, marked the date that Judith S. Kaye, the court's first woman, had been named to the bench. Mr. Mordaunt observed the anniversary each year by bringing Judge Kaye a sprig from a florabunda rose bush in his front yard, containing the appropriate number of blossoms. Sure enough, when Judge Kaye arrived in her chambers shortly before 7 A.M. last Sept. 12, she discovered that Walter Mordaunt had preceded her. "Now, Judge!" the accompanying note scolded her, "I hope you did not think I'd forget."
All seven members of the court attended a memorial service for Mr. Mordaunt on Wednesday night in East Greenbush, across the river from Albany. "He could deal with governors or schoolchildren and show them the same concern and grace and dignity," said Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, who spoke at the service. "He opened up the court, and our process lost a lot of its mysteries. He showed them that this was not simply a sterile courthouse, but a part of history."

HEADLINE: In Louisiana, Both Edwards and Duke Are Sending Voters a Message of Fear

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Instead of engaging in the usual mudslinging, the candidates in the Louisiana's governor's race have used their televison commercials to turn up the emotional volume among voters who are making their choices on the basis of fear and resentment.
The contest between State Representative David Duke and former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards is unusual in many respects, not the least of which is the fact that both candidates started the race as very familiar figures here. 
 Neither man has had to use television the way most politicians do, improving their name recognition and framing an identity. Nor did they have to highlight their opponent's weaknesses -- Mr. Duke's activities in the Ku Klux Klan and as a neo-Nazi are well known, as are the accusations of corruption that have dogged the 64-year-old former Governor for years.
Rather than a back and forth exchange between candidates, the television campaign here has been like the final act of a minor operetta, with one character after another appearing on the screen to bellow, laugh or shriek.
 
A Political Cacophony
 More than anything else, the cacophony has broadcast a message of fear -- fear of liberals, blacks and big government on one side, and fear of Mr. Duke on the other.
Mr. Duke has been plying the alienations of his white middle-class voters while projecting himself as the cool voice of conservatism.
All of his advertisements show him standing alone and talking into the camera. In a new ad that was being broadcast today the message from Mr. Duke is: "I say what must be said. I don't promise jobs to get endorsement. I owe no special interests. My entire campaign is funded by little gifts from lots of people."
Douglas Rose, a professor of political science at Tulane University, said: "Duke acts out on screen what his supporters are feeling. He's up there alone and embattled, expressing all their resentments toward the powers that be."
Larry Sabato, a professor of government at the University of Virginia, said: "He's been compared to George Wallace, but Wallace was hot on the tube and Duke is cool. He's mastered the medium. He smiles and his anger is implicit."
Mr. Edwards has used his commercials to reassure the state that he is now a model of propriety and a paragon of economic leadership.
Today his campaign announced that on Friday night it will broadcast a 30-minute program, called "The Decision of Our Lives," in all seven of the state's media markets. It will be broadcast a total of 16 times.
Emphasizing the economic issue, the show moves through each major city in the state, listing businesses that Mr. Edwards is said to have recruited to Louisiana in his previous terms as Governor.
Ordinary people identified by their first names are interviewed on how they have decided to vote for Mr. Edwards. Terry in Baton Rouge says that after "tossing and turning" she decided that even though she likes some of Mr. Duke's message, "Edwin Edwards will make the difference in me keeping my job." A portly man in overalls identified as Stanley in Shreveport concurs and says, "That Duke, he ain't too swift."
At the end Mr. Edwards offers a grandfatherly lecture on good government and reviews his proposals for economic recovery and tax reform.
 
Third-Party Commercials
 William Morgan, media consultant to the Edwards campaign, said the goal of the half-hour show was "to add some momentum to the final day of the campaign with a major event that explores Edwards's positive message in contrast to the danger Duke poses."
Besides Mr. Edwards, the Democratic Party and a number of ad hoc groups and individual citizens have also been buying advertising time to attack Mr. Duke, most of them warning that his election would spell economic disaster.
"Anybody with three red cents has been buying air time in this campaign," said Kathy Vick, secretary of the Democratic National Committee and a leader of the state party. "No one has ever seen anything like it, and no one is sure how it's going to play out."
For example, a group called the Republican Challengers Election Committee, which Ms. Vick and officials of the Edwards campaign said is unknown to them, has paid for the campaign commercial most often cited in dinner party chatter. A man in a cowboy hat and string tie identifies himself as a Texan and offers a gleeful "hot damn" to news that Mr. Duke might be elected and cause an economic exodus. In an exagerated drawl the "Texan" says, "Good luck to you David Duke, and all those jobs in Louisiana, come on down."
 
A Lopsided Ad Contest
 With at least a 2-to-1 advantage in fund raising, the Edwards campaign has been able to outgun Mr. Duke on the airwaves. And the contest has been even more lopsided because of all the third parties putting out their own anti-Duke commercials.
The Edwards campaign alone has spent $585,000 on television and $105,00 on radio advertising, according to Mr. Morgan, and has broadcast seven different 30-second commercials in the last 12 days.
Interviews with television station executives across the state show that the Edwards campaign has bought at least twice as many advertisements in most major cities and that it has spent heavily in New Orleans and Baton Rouge. Nonetheless, Mr. Duke has made himself heard in every major media market. He appears to have concentrated his efforts in southwestern Louisiana, where he showed growing strength in the Oct. 19 primary.
For example, one station in Lake Charles had booked 60 advertisements for Mr. Edwards compared to 45 for Mr. Duke, but more typical was a station in Alexandria, in central Louisiana, where 85 Edwards ads were scheduled, but only 35 Duke ads.
 
Some Fear a Backlash
 Rusty Cantelli, a television producer who has occasionally served as a consultant to Mr. Duke, said the overwhelming number of ads attacking Mr. Duke could rebound to his advantage. A similar view has been expressed by some in the Edwards camp.
"When there's this kind of overkill it can turn people off," Mr. Cantelli said. "It seems so hysterical at times that it might even be causing a backlash."
While Mr. Edwards has relied heavily on his advertisments and those of his allies to get his message across, Mr. Duke has found other means to use television. He has appeared extensively on local and national talk shows, and has been interviewed this week on three network news shows.
"By just appearing on these broadcasts Duke gains credibility no matter how he's questioned or how even-handed the report may be," said Ms. Vick, the state Democratic leader. "The media have made him a legitimate candidate."


GRAPHIC: Advertisements from David Duke, running as a Republican without his party's endorsement, and the Democrat, Edwin W. Edwards. The state Democratic Party is one of several groups also running ads.
 
DAVID DUKE
 
BACKGROUND: State Representative David Duke has campaigned in the Louisiana governor's race as an outsider and a conservative who is waging a lonely battle against powerful liberal forces.
 
TEXT: "Have you ever heard such weeping and gnashing of teeth. The news media have given up any pretense of fair play. The liberals have gone ballistic. The special interests have gone mad. The politicians who play up to them are lining up on cue. Principles lie abandoned and hypocrisy rules the day. I raise issues that must be discussed and get back venom instead. Try a little experiment. Next time you hear them accuse me of intolerance and hatred, notice who is doing the shouting."
 
PRODUCER: David Duke
 
ANALYSIS: Virtually all the newspapers in Louisiana have endorsed Mr. Duke's opponent, former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, and Mr. Edwards has received vigorous backing from the Democratic Party as well as a variety of business groups and women's organizations. In this ad Mr. Duke stares into the camera and issues a highly emotional appeal to voters who feel alienated from politics as usual. He portrays himself as an underdog and a victim. Finally, he tries to turn criticism of his own controversial past into attack on his critics.
 
EDWIN W. EDWARDS
 
BACKGROUND: Edwin W. Edwards served three terms as governor of Louisiana between 1971 and 1987. He claims his records proves he can help pull the state out of its long recession while Mr. Duke's election would be an economic disaster.
 
TEXT: "The way to bring jobs to Louisiana today is the way that Edwin Edwards created jobs for us before. Edwin Edwards built the vocational and technical school system, and he'll build it again, by opening closed institutes and upgrading all the others. That means we can get the job skills that new and growing industries want and need. And Edwin Edwards will create a $32 million loan fund to help the children of middle income families to go to college. Education, to get the skills. Edwin Edwards to get the jobs."
 
PRODUCER: William Morgan & Co.
 
ANALYSIS: Against pictures of workers and schools the announcer promotes Mr. Edwards' record in office and highlights a campaign promise to boost funding of a school loan program. Mr. Duke has repeatedly complained that racial preferences in scholarships discriminate against middle class whites. In this ad Mr. Edwards makes a positive statement on that point, and appeals to voters both on economic and education issues.
 
DEMOCRATIC PARTY
 
BACKGROUND: While the Edwards campaign has explicitly attacked David Duke in its advertisements, the Democratic Party has produced commercials reminding voters of Mr. Duke's neo-Nazi views.
 
TEXT: "In 1969 David Duke said, 'I am a National Socialist, you can call me a Nazi.' In 1976 he organized a meeting of Nazi groups which called for the release of all Nazi war criminals. In 1988 he hired a former American Nazi Party captain to manage his presidential campaign and in 1989 David Duke was caught selling Nazi books and tapes from his legislative office."
 
PRODUCER: Politics Incorporated
 
ANALYSIS: All the episodes mentioned have been extensively reported before, but they are given added punch in the ad with newsreel footage of from Nazi Germany, martial music and shouts of "Sieg Hiel." The commercial ends with a picture of Adolph Hitler.
Chart: "The 1991 Campaign: On Television Outsider vs. a Former Governor of Louisiana"
 In this campaign Mr. Duke's foes have dwelled on his neo-Nazi activities much more than his leadership of the Ku Klux Klan. This ad seeks to hit voters who may be attracted to Mr. Duke politically but have moral reservations about supporting him.

HEADLINE: Milton Farber, 81, Retired Head Of Farberware Company, Is Dead

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Milton H. Farber, the retired president of the Bronx company that manufactures Farberware pots, pans and appliances, died on Tuesday at his home in Atlantis, Fla.
He was 81 years old and died of heart failure, his family said. 
 Mr. Farber joined the family business as a teen-ager. The company, S. W. Farber Inc., which manufactured gift trays and racks, was founded in 1897 by his father, Simon, a Russian emigrant who started as a match peddler on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. The family opened a plant in Brooklyn next to the Williamsburg Bridge. A clamp-on light invented so Mr. Farber could sleep while his wife read in bed propelled the company's success.
The second generation took the reins of the enterprise during the 1940's, with Milton becoming vice president for production while his brother, Isadore, became president and head of sales. Two brothers-in-law were also executives.
The company moved to the Bronx in 1944 and expanded into a new line of stainless steel pots and pans with bonded aluminum bottoms for better heat conduction. Dubbed Farberware, it became a leading brand of cookware. Next came a line of electrical appliances.
 
Small Arms During the War
 During World War II, the company made small arms, and the Federal Government honored Milton Farber for serving as chairman of production engineering and of the Small Business Mobilization Committee.
When Isadore retired as president, Milton succeeded him. The company was sold to Hanson Industries, but he remained with the operation until he retired in 1973. He also designed and supervised the building of a factory in Israel to produce Farberware.
Mr. Farber was born in Brooklyn and was captain of the football team at Erasmus Hall High School. He graduated with honors in industrial engineering at the University of Pennsylvania and in economics from the Wharton School.
He lived for 25 years in New Rochelle and 18 years in Bronxville. He served as a board member of the Merchants Bank of New York for 17 years and of Shopwell Inc. for 11 years. He was president of Vernon Hills Country Club in Eastchester and class A club champion in golf there in 1947. He was also a partner of Sherbrooke Country Club in Lake Worth, Fla., where he designed and oversaw the building of its clubhouse. He was on the board of Curry College in Milton, Mass.
He is survived by his wife, the former Sylvia Gold; a daughter, Marilyn Jacobs of New Rochelle; a son, Alan, of Mount Vernon; a sister, Dorothy Shanok of New Rochelle; a brother, Isadore, of Woodlands, Fla., and four grandchildren.
