HEADLINE: Pop/Jazz;
3 Women Singing The Blues

BYLINE: By KAREN SCHOEMER

 BODY:
Truly wild women are a scarce commodity in pop music. One can only imagine the day when a diva like Whitney Houston struts onto a video screen, opens her mouth and belts out an ode to the pleasures of being sloppy drunk or when a songstress like Debbie Gibson sits down at a piano and, gripped by the sudden fever of inspiration, kicks over her stool and lays into a hellacious Jerry Lee Lewis-style boogie riff. Unspoken laws of behavior abound. Most women choose to stay respectable.
Outside the mainstream, though, women are more willing to bend the rules. The members of Saffire, the Uppity Blues Women, a trio from Fredericksburg, Va., who are to perform tomorrow night at the Lone Star Roadhouse in Manhattan, have made it their career agenda to put across an alternative perspective. 
 Saffire's raunchy blues extol the virtues of gratifying sex, nights on the town and the benefits of nonmonogamous relationships; the group's songs are laced with double-entendres and bawdy language. "Hot Flash" (Alligator Records), the group's third album, includes numbers like "One Good Man": "I got a macho man who puts my pleasure last/I got a nervous man who moves much too fast. . . . They call me a tramp, they don't understand/I just want one good man."
Underneath the humor, Saffire is really preaching independence and the right to satisfaction, and the group's ideology becomes even more potent in the context of traditional down-home blues. The music is lively but low-key: Gaye Adegbalola, 47 years old, plays acoustic guitar; Ann Rabson, 46, plays rollicking boogie-blues piano, and Earlene Lewis, also 46, provides rhythm on an upright bass. All three women trade off lead vocals, and they mix classic numbers like Bessie Smith's "Do Your Duty" with straight blues originals.
"We play traditional blues, but it has current content," Ms. Adegbalola said in a recent phone interview from Fredericksburg. "I don't know other women our age singing and playing the blues who are also writers. These things haven't been said because maybe this perspective hasn't been there."
As unusual as the group's sentiments seem in today's pop context, Saffire is actually working within a long tradition of outspoken women, including urban blues singers like Smith, Ma Rainey and Memphis Minnie in the 1920's and 30's, the jazz legend Billie Holiday in the 1940's and 50's, soul and rhythm-and-blues performers like Aretha Franklin and Etta James in the 1960's.
"I feel very much like a griot of sorts, like I'm on a mission to carry on a legacy," Ms. Adegbalola said. "Vocalists tend to be two types: they're either musical vocalists like Billie Holiday, or storytelling vocalists like Bessie Smith. I see myself as a storyteller. Consequently I've studied storytelling techniques and the meaning of the double-entendre. When I do 'Do Your Duty,' Bessie did it, Billie Holiday did it, and now I take the two pieces of each one that I like and I put them into a new format."
Ms. Adegbalola, Ms. Rabson and Ms. Lewis started performing as a trio in 1984. The fact that they started their musical career together at relatively late ages has to do with social and economic constraints, they said. Although each grew up loving music, only Ms. Lewis managed to pursue it full time.
Ms. Adegbalola said: "All of our fathers played music, and they introduced it to us in one way or another. When I was in high school, I made all-state band three years and I loved music, but it wasn't something that a black woman did at that point. Ann did a solo act in her late teens and 20's, but then she had to raise a child by herself."
By the time the three came together, each had a day job. Ms. Adegbalola, who was a single mother, was a schoolteacher; Ms. Rabson was a computer programmer who also taught at a local community college. Ms. Lewis was a data programmer who happened to enroll in one of Ms. Rabson's classes, and the three decided to start playing as a trio.
"All we were doing was getting together and playing music," Ms. Adegbalola said. "The fact is that we had our dreams deferred. We bounced back as women who've raised children and had families to pursue our dream."
 
A Gimmick or for Real?
 In 1987, the women recorded a demo record and released it on their own label, Saffire; in 1988, they quit their day jobs. Soon after, they got the attention of the Chicago-based blues label Alligator Records. While the album "Saffire, the Uppity Blues Women," released in 1990, earned the group instant recognition on the contemporary blues scene, some people saw the trio as a novelty act.
"A lot of times people focus on our gimmick -- our ages, our sex -- and they don't focus on our music," Ms. Adegbalola said. "They'll say it's folk, not blues. But Bessie Smith recorded 59 times with no drums. Our instrumentation isn't that unusual when you listen to traditional blues.
"When I first heard this music, I fell in love it. It speaks to me. The drums are not there pumping over every nuance; every syllable is audible. And I just want to carry on that tradition."
Saffire, the Uppity Blues Women, are to perform tomorrow night at the Lone Star Roadhouse, 240 West 52d Street, Manhattan. Show times are 9:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets cost $12. Information: (212) 245-2950.

HEADLINE: Cable TV Customers, Gouged Again

 BODY:
The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, and Hollywood's Jack Valenti have just buried a bill to prevent monopolistic cable companies from gouging their customers. The sponsors expected a Senate vote this week, but Mr. Mitchell scheduled no floor time and has excluded the proposal from the list of bills to be considered before the Senate adjourns for the year.
Unless the bill is promptly disinterred, cable customers around the country will know who's to blame for the next outrageous cable price hike. 
 A 1984 bill freed cable television companies from local regulation. Since then cable costs have soared, rising three times faster than inflation. Some of the increases made up for punitively low fees set by local regulators. But studies suggest that by now, cable companies are earning exorbitant monopoly profits.
The Senate bill offers responsible re-regulation, with a light touch. It is directed at bad actors -- empowering the Federal Communications Commission to set rates only where prices are outrageous and competition is lacking.
What makes the bill's sudden burial especially galling is Mr. Mitchell's excuse: the crush of end-of-session business. The cable bill was introduced on the earliest possible day and was one of the first bills this session to clear committee -- in May. Putting off a vote until next year won't help consumers but it would guarantee a continued flow of campaign contributions to committee members from lobbyists for the studios, broadcasters and cable companies.
Mr. Valenti, who represents film and television producers, attacks a provision that would require cable companies to pay fees to retransmit the programs of over-the-air television stations. He cries foul, contending that that arrangement would jeopardize royalties of the Hollywood producers who make programs.
Mr. Valenti has a point, but it's a belated one. The cable companies have stalled negotiations for months and are using confusion over this provision as a pretext to scuttle the bill.
The best way to break the impasse and serve the public is for the Senate to pass the bill soon. The House, which overwhelmingly passed a similar bill last year, would quickly follow. Once Congress even comes close to action, watch how quickly Mr. Valenti and the cable companies figure out a way to resolve retransmission rights to everyone's satisfaction.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Hate Against Hate

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Two years ago, we celebrated the fall of the Berlin wall and then of totalitarian rule in Czechoslovakia. As recently as this past summer, we gloried in the overthrow of Communism in the Soviet Union.
Those victories for freedom remain. But the joy we felt in them has been overtaken by renewed realization that there is a human instinct as deep as the desire for freedom -- and that it may have terrible consequences. That is racial and national feeling. 
 In Czechoslovakia today, some Slovaks are demanding the division of the country and the establishment of a separate Slovak state. There was a Slovak Republic once: a Nazi puppet state during World War II. And today there is some vicious anti-Semitism. The man who led the Slovak end of the movement that overthrew Communism in Czechoslovakia, Fedor Gal, has left Slovakia after being attacked because he is Jewish. His parents were murdered by the Nazis.
In Vienna this week, a far-right party headed by a man who praises Hitler's economic policies won 23 percent of the vote in city elections. A Gallup poll in Austria found that nearly a third of those polled disliked Jews and a fifth thought Jews should be dismissed from their jobs.
In France, Jean-Marie Le Pen and his National Front Party are gaining significant support. Mr. Le Pen campaigns against Arab immigration and Jewish influence. In a poll by Le Monde, 32 percent said they broadly agreed with his ideas.
Then there is the situation in Yugoslavia: not some gloomy portent of a poll or political campaign but the present reality of human disaster produced by ethnic conflict. Serbia, undeterred by threatened European and American economic sanctions, intensified its military assaults on Croatia.
Americans like to think of themselves as having left behind the bloody conflicts of the old country. But ethnic consciousness is the hot new phenomenon in this country, and with it comes conflict. In any event, we have our own special wound of race.
Anyone naive enough to think that racism was history in this country has had to think again. The possibility that Louisiana may elect as governor this weekend a man who has spent most of his adult life denouncing Jews and blacks says enough about where we are.
David Duke says he is a Christian who repents his record as a Nazi and a leader of the Ku Klux Klan. His campaign plays on Louisiana's economic distress, says it is time to "get government off the back of business" and attacks welfare. Those are familiar right-wing themes, used successfully by Ronald Reagan among others. But the voters are hearing something else: race.
"Without his racial past," a political observer in Shreveport says, "Duke wouldn't be playing. Down deep, most whites like the message: finally, after 30 years, somebody's going to put the niggers down."
Economic and social distress always have been the seedbeds for demagogy. They were in Weimar Germany. They were in Huey Long's Louisiana in the 1930's. They are today in Austria and France and Germany, countries that are dealing with large numbers of refugees.
That is what makes the rise of David Duke so worrisome for us. People are feeling economic pain right across America. Social disorder is a central fact of life in all our major cities and suburbs, and even small towns. In such circumstances, people are ready to listen to someone who blames the troubles on some scapegoat.
George Wallace won a lot of votes, North and South, when times were not so bad as now. And he was far less smooth an article than David Duke.
Win or lose, David Duke is going to be on the national political stage. He may well run for President next year, opposing President Bush in Republican primaries or running as a third-party candidate.
What solace can we find in all this, what hope for some solution to the racial and ethnic conflicts in the world? Sir Isaiah Berlin, the great English philosopher, discusses the question in an interview in the fall issue of New Perspectives Quarterly, and he offers no solace.
"Nationalism is not resurgent," Sir Isaiah says. "It never died. Neither did racism. They are the most powerful movements in the world today."

HEADLINE: Culture Is a Very Big Deal ($6 Billion)

BYLINE: By David N. Dinkins

 BODY:
The following article is adapted from remarks made recently by the Mayor of New York to leaders of the city's major cultural institutions.
This week, the City Council Finance Committee held hearings on legislation to dismantle the Department of Cultural Affairs. What a foolish idea in a city that is a beacon to all artists and home to the premier cultural institutions in the nation!
Last year, some members of our budget staff, thinking that they were helping me, made such a proposal. I thought it was a terrible idea and immediately buried it. I wish the City Council had let it rest in peace. 
 New York is the cultural capital of the world, and the arts make an incalculable social and economic contribution to our city. Culture in New York City is a $6 billion industry -- larger in this region than the advertising business, hotel-motel business and the computer industry.
It is labor intensive, providing jobs not only for artists but also for carpenters, painters, ushers, guards, seamstresses and other skilled and less-skilled workers. Thirty-five thousand jobs are estimated to be directly attributable to New York's cultural activity, and an additional 117,000 jobs are generated indirectly.
Approximately 60 percent of the tourists coming to New York City list some type of art or culture as the prime reason for their visit. New York's nonprofit arts industry alone is responsible for more than $1.4 billion in economic activity.
The creation of the Department of Cultural Affairs in 1977 gave this huge industry a platform and standing in municipal affairs. Since then, through the department we have steadily built up our funding and investment in this vital industry. And as the dividends poured into our local economy, the department saw to it that a fair share was reinvested in the arts. This simple formula worked -- until the national recession of 1990-1991 made money scarce again.
The recession has hit our city budget deeply. But we need the department even more when resources are limited and the competition for funds is more intense. And when our city bounces back, as we know it must, who will look after our investment in the arts, if not this department?
Very little would be saved by eliminating it. The costs of running the department are about $3 million per year. I find it hard to believe that you could cut that amount and still have the capacity to process $68 million worth of contracts each year with the arts organizations of our city.
Let us remember that the Federal contribution to our city's budget has been cut in half over the last 10 years. Those funds would have covered almost our entire budget gap this year.
To break up the Department of Cultural Affairs and to scatter the pieces among other agencies would cripple our ability to fulfill our cultural dreams when our city is flush again.
The long-range interests of the city -- and the arts community -- are best served with a strong, energized and unthreatened Department of Cultural Affairs.

HEADLINE: Tappan Zee Traffic Enrages Commuters, Worries Planners

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 14

 BODY:
With more than three miles of pavement soaring across the Hudson River at one of the waterway's widest junctures, the Tappan Zee Bridge offers the motorist a majestic drive. But lately that drive has brought more misery than majesty.
Traffic congestion has grown so severe on the bridge and on the connecting Cross Westchester Expressway (Interstate 287) that some business leaders fear it might thwart economic growth in Westchester County. Many commuters, especially Rockland County residents traveling to work in Westchester, have started to lambaste politicians and transportation officials in public forums and on the telephone. 
 "The big problem is the unpredictability of the commute," said Richard A. Peters, a civil engineer with the New York State Department of Transportation. "One day it may take 20 minutes to get to work, the next day it may take an hour and the next day 40 minutes."
 
The Crucial Corridor
 The unabashed construction of office space in recent years in Westchester, Rockland and Orange Counties has made the Hudson Valley the fastest growing region in the state. The valley takes in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties on the east side of the river, and Rockland, Sullivan, Orange and Ulster Counties on the west. Mindful that the Tappan Zee Bridge and the Cross Westchester Expressway serve as the valley's crucial corridor, transportation officials are devoting themselves to relieving traffic congestion.
For financial and environmental reasons, simply building a new bridge or highway is not a serious option at the moment. Rather, the state's Department of Transportation and the New York State Thruway Authority are struggling to make do with what they have. Creative solutions include the installation, next year, of a movable barrier across the bridge to improve traffic flow and a program to encourage companies to offer flexible hours to help ease the rush hours.
Throughout the country, planners are dealing with similar problems. The building of beltways, the rise of suburban office parks and the emergence of the two-career couple have all conspired to put booming areas on the fringe of cities in a traffic vice.
"We had a baby boom that was born and raised in the suburbs that now wants to live and work in the suburbs," said James W. Hughes, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University. "And suburban gridlock and traffic jams that were once the province of the city have been dispersed to remote locations."
 
A Spur to Growth
 Built in 1955, the Tappan Zee Bridge was a heroic public works project, becoming one of the last legs of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, linking Rockland and Westchester Counties and creating the opportunity for commercial development in the Hudson Valley. Annual traffic on the bridge rose from 10.5 million vehicles in 1960 to 39.5 million last year.
A few years after the completion of the bridge, the Cross Westchester Expressway opened, connecting the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway (Interstate 87) with the New England Thruway (Interstate 95). Cutting through Westchester just north of White Plains, the Cross Westchester, together with the Tappan Zee, sparked enormous development in the county.
The Cross Westchester Expressway became known as the Platinum Mile with its curves punctuated by polished-glass office complexes. But in the 1980's, as office development continued at a furious pace, so did traffic. On an average weekday in 1980, 77,000 vehicles used the expressway. Ten years later, the number jumped to 129,000.
 
A 68-Minute Trip
 While Rockland County saw substantial economic growth in the 1980's, it still has only a quarter of Westchester's 406,000 jobs, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Almost twice as many cars head toward Westchester County in the morning rush hour as head toward Rockland.
R. Clinton Roswell, an analyst for the New York City School Construction Authority, lives in the hamlet of Nanuet in Rockland County and works in the Bronx. On one occasion, he said, it took him 68 minutes to traverse the bridge.
"It's monstrous," he said. "Coming home at night, I know that as soon as I pass the toll barrier and head toward the center of the bridge, the traffic just stops."
Westchester County continues to attract new companies, but transportation is a key ingredient in decisions about corporate relocation. "We don't want economic growth to be stifled by traffic congestion," said David Murray, a spokesman for the State Transportation Department. "It's a definite threat."
The Metro-North Commuter Railroad recently studied the possibility of running a new railroad track across the Hudson River, near the Tappan Zee, up to Stewart International Airport in Orange County. But the price tag was about $1 billion, and the project would take 20 years.
 
A Movable Barrier
 In the short term, the Thruway Authority holds out hope that traffic congestion on the Tappan Zee Bridge will be eased. The movable barrier, for example, will make it possible to respond to the changing volume of traffic. And in a few years the Thruway Authority plans to resurface the bridge's deck and possibly add an eighth lane. The State Department of Transportation, responsible for any major changes on the Cross Westchester Expressway, is studying the possibility of creating a reversible or two-way "high-occupancy vehicle" lane in the highway's median to encourage car pooling. A similar lane may be created on the bridge.
The Thruway Authority is also adding electronic toll collection so that cars can breeze through the bridge's single toll barrier on the eastern leg. Commuters would buy stickers, embedded with computer chips, for their windshields; an electronic device at the toll barrier would let the car pass after reading the sticker.
"The Tappan Zee Bridge is our highest priority," Peter Tufo, the Thruway Authority chairman, said, "and we're going to spend $120 million over the next four or five years to deal with it."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Traders Reassured by Weak Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A raft of Government statistics yesterday showing soft economic conditions and no problem from inflation reassured credit market participants and helped lift prices of Treasury notes and bonds.
The data showed retail sales lackluster in October. Weekly claims for unemployment insurance moved back to their highest level in six months. And inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index rose by a modest tenth of a percent last month. 
 The fresh statistics, particularly on inflation, soothed fears that developed on Wednesday, when the Government shocked traders and analysts with a report that producer prices had risen by a whopping seven-tenths of 1 percent in October.
Even though analysts called the producer price rise an aberration, the report ignited fears of inflation and prompted a sharp selloff in the market.
Those fears were assuaged yesterday.
"The market is breathing a sigh of relief that these numbers turned out the way they did," one government bond trader said. "These numbers tell you the Fed is going to be back," easing monetary policy, the trader said.
 
Decline in 4th Quarter?
 Analysts said the poor showing for retail sales, which declined one-tenth of 1 percent last month following a sizable rise in September, not only cast doubt on how healthy the coming Christmas season would be for retailers, but also raised the possibility that the economy might contract in the fourth quarter.
"We are still working with the projection of positive growth in the fourth quarter, but we are nervous," said Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. "If we don't see an improvement in the numbers soon, we could see a decline in the fourth quarter."
A resolution approved by the Senate late Wednesday night to require lower interest rates on credit cards, a move that might stimulate consumer spending, sent shock waves through the $65 billion market in securities that are backed by credit-card receivables.
Market participants said the Senate resolution raised the possibility that such a sharp reduction in the borrowing rate could lead to early prepayment of the securities.
News of the vote pushed prices of credit-card issues outstanding down by as much as a full point early in the day. But by late in the session some of those losses had been recouped. Traders said that prices of most issues ended 1/4 point to 1/2 point lower.
By late in the day, the new benchmark 30-year bonds, the 8 percent issue of 2021, were offered at a price of 102 1/8, up 1/2 point, to yield 7.81 percent, down from 8.87 percent Wednesday in when-issued trading. On Wednesday the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2021, the old benchmark issue, were offered at a price to yield 7.90 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 1/8, up 3/8, to yield 7.33 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 21/32, up 2/ 32, to yield 5.58 percent.
Demand at an auction of new one-year Treasury bills was strong.
The new securities were sold at an average discount rate of 4.72 percent, down from an average rate of 5.12 percent at the last one-year note auction on Oct. 17.
Rates on outstanding Treasury bills were unchanged to down slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at an average discount rate of 4.61 percent, down two basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at a late offered rate of 4.67 percent.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Nov. 4. The broadest measure, M-3, fell by $3.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Fed Official's Inflation View

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C. Nov. 15

 BODY:
Wayne D. Angell, a Federal Reserve Board governor, said today that he was "pretty optimistic about the inflation outlook" for the United States.
Speaking to reporters after giving a private speech to executives here, Mr. Angell said the report earlier this week that producer prices surged seven-tenths of 1 percent in October should not be taken out of context. 
 "Clearly, there is a stickiness in certain prices that make up the wholesale index," he said. But the Federal Reserve, he said, should concentrate on long-run targets, rather than monthly statistics. He said he preferred to look at 3-month and 12-month rates of change.
Mr. Angell said he saw continued improvement in the Consumer Price Index, which is now rising at a 2.7 percent annual rate, down from a rate of 6.4 percent at the end of 1990. Mr. Angell said the 6.4 percent rate was abnormal.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Snags in System On Withholding

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hershey Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A new Internal Revenue Service procedure is subjecting thousands of investors to backup income-tax withholding, many of them improperly, because of difficulties in verifying identification.
Anyone opening a brokerage, bank, mutual fund or other investment account must supply a Social Security number, which the I.R.S. checks to be sure it will get its own record of the interest, dividends and proceeds paid to that person. If the number is deemed incorrect, the I.R.S. notifies, say, Merrill Lynch of this discrepancy, and the broker in turn sends its customer a letter explaining what has happened. A second notification by the I.R.S. within three years requires backupwithholding of 20 percent, meaning that Merrill Lynch pays its customer only 80 percent of the amount due. 
 Under the new I.R.S. procedure, the withholding may be stopped only when the broker receives Form SSA-7028, which the customer asks the Social Security Administration to send directly to the broker or bank. The problem is that many Social Security offices seem neither to be aware of their role in this process nor to have the forms in stock.
"Several of our member firms report that they are deluged with calls from customers who are unnecessarily being subjected to backup withholding as a result of a bureaucratic snafu by the Social Security Administration," complained Edward I. O'Brien, head of the Securities Industry Association. He urged the Treasury to postpone the new procedure until next year.
In Baltimore, a Social Security spokesman acknowledged a "small problem," but said it had been brought under control. The agency sent reminder notices to 1,300 field offices this week.
An I.R.S. official, meanwhile, told an industry gathering in Los Angeles yesterday that the agency was inclined to accept taxpayer verification on documents other than Form 7028. But Keith Lawson, associate tax counsel for the Investment Company Institute, a mutual-fund group, said he was not certain this approach would be sufficiently far-reaching or prompt.
 
New Dose of Complexity
 In deciding to pay for extended jobless benefits by speeding up collections from people with rapidly rising incomes, Congress will have again added to tax code complexity despite months of so-far fruitless debate about how to make it simpler.
The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants charged that compliance would be particularly difficult for proprietors of small businesses, partnerships and small corporations. Losing the ability to base quarterly estimated payments on the preceding year's liability, many taxpayers will need to calculate their estimated payments "four times a year -- often with incomplete or inadequate information," said Donald H. Skadden, the group's vice president for taxation.
Another A.I.C.P.A. official said contractors, small truck lines and professionals would have "immense" problems calculating their annual income by Jan. 15 of the following year, "let alone their income by the required dates each quarter." About 400,000 taxpayers will be directly affected by the change, and multiples of that figure will face uncertainty and cumbersome calculations.
 
Footnotes
 With a concession on the highway bill by Senate conferees this week, the odds rose for a four-year extension of half of the 5-cent rise in gasoline taxes imposed under the 1990 Federal budget agreement. This means the 14-cent levy would fall to 11 1/2 cents in 1995. The other 2 1/2 cents being applied to reduce the deficit would expire.
Supporters of the dozen tax breaks due to expire at year-end -- including the low-income housing, research and development, and targeted jobs incentives -- invoked the weak economy in mounting a last-ditch effort this week to have them renewed. But with time running out, passage this year is increasingly unlikely. "If I could get 50-50 odds on this, I'd take it," acknowledged Representative Frank J. Guarini, a New Jersey Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee.
States have enacted tax increases of $16.2 billion for the fiscal year 1992, the biggest dollar amount on record. At 5.4 percent of 1990 collections, the increases were the biggest by this gauge since 1971, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.

HEADLINE: Home Builders Throw In the Extras

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FISHKILL, N.Y.

 BODY:
A survivor like David Stenger, with 20-odd years of watching the starts and stops of the home-building industry, knows that selling a house in a near-comatose market can require flexibility. This time, his notion of flexibility is being stretched.
"We're bending over backward all right," said Mr. Stenger, a 39-year-old builder with a can-do smile. "Way over." 
 One previously unthinkable method of securing a sale, about which Mr. Stenger and others like him will now readily resort, goes like this: If someone wants to buy a house but is holding back because he or she cannot sell an existing home, Mr. Stenger will buy the customer's home himself to make the deal. He's done so twice this year.
This year, for the first time since 1945, the number of housing starts nationwide is expected to fall below one million. The National Association of Home Builders projects the total at 990,000, down from 1.2 million last year and 1.38 million in 1989, as falling confidence in the economy leads the housing industry into a deeper contraction.
While no part of the country has escaped the drop-off in number of houses built and sold, cities like Denver, Dallas and Phoenix have seen minor rebounds, and the previously breakneck speed of urban construction in Southern cities like Atlanta has been blunted. The Northeast housing market continues to limp along at a pace among the nation's slowest.
The main obstacle to greater home sales, several builders agreed, is the lack of consumer confidence. Mr. Stenger said it seemed to be uncertainty about their jobs that caused buyers to waver before signing on the dotted line. He has gotten nearly as many inquiries about houses this year as ever, he said, but few of those translate into sales.
"Time and again, people come and look," he said. "But then they get cold feet."
In New York State, "It's still a very bleak situation," said Robert Wieboldt, executive vice president of the New York State Home Builders Association. Beyond the sluggish rate of building single-family houses, there is now little construction of condominums in the state.
Ever optimistic, Mr. Wieboldt said he thought the slow pace of construction would eventually lead to a pent-up demand that would spur the housing market by the middle of 1992. But for this year, monthly home sales figures in New York have risen and fallen, dropping 17.5 percent in September compared with August.
 
Making Concessions
 Surviving home builders know that the essential ingredients of a house sale -- quality, price and location -- are each scrutinized carefully by any potential customer. But it is additional creativity -- with price, extras, or financing -- that is now essential.
"We're all making concessions to get sales," said Craig O'Donnell, a builder in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., who will throw in extras like a black-top driveway or an enlarged fireplace without hesitation. "Problem is, there aren't many of us left."
In the Hudson Valley, the broad stretch of land north of Westchester County, the attractions of scenic beauty and proximity to New York City have kept the home-building industry from stalling completely. Yet the decline seems more painful because of the giddy, intoxicating nature of the 1980's boom that preceded it.
Mr. O'Donnell estimates that as many as 80 percent of the home builders in the valley have either gone out of business or into hibernation until the market revives. Many who started building during the boom included doctors and lawyers, who invested in the industry with little if any experience in construction. Many of them were among the first to be forced out of the market when the crunch came.
Mr. O'Donnell said that because New York State does not require any registration for a builder, it is difficult to gauge the number of active builders, and the level of their activity.
"Everybody has scaled down their operation," said Jean Rowe, executive director of the Building Association of Hudson Valley. Remodeling and small-scale construction have become common for builders who built only single-family houses in the past, she said.
Mr. Stenger, the builder who offered to buy the houses of his customers, recently took this buy-to-sell arrangement to another level. A buyer, Kevin Carswell, wanted Mr. Stenger to build him a $284,000 home, but only after he had sold his own $181,500 home. Mr. Carswell had a buyer on the hook but he was having trouble selling his $123,000 condominium. The solution: Mr. Stenger offered to buy the condo and make it a three-way transaction. He plans to sell the condo as quickly as possible, at a loss if necessary but at a profit if possible.
"In a good market, I'd never have gotten near one of these," said Mr. Stenger, who is navigating the complexities of closing all three deals on the same day, scheduled for January. It will actually be a four-way deal, he added, if he can unload the condominium on the same day. A loss of several thousand dollars on one sale, he said, will be acceptable if he can make it up on the other.
Thomas Carroll, who sold the condominium to Mr. Stenger as part of the three-way deal, said he had not expected to be approached by a builder as a buyer.
"I was surprised, to say the least," said Mr. Carroll, who works for the International Business Machines Corporation. He received less than his asking price from Mr. Stenger, but felt lucky that he had found a buyer at all.
"I've heard horror stories about people unable to sell their houses for the longest time," he said. "This situation helped me out."
Few builders see any end soon to the ever-lengthening slump.
"I don't see any upturn coming soon," said Raymond Croniser Jr., another builder who has survived, despite watching his sales drop from 72 homes in 1987 to 26 last year. He has built and sold 23 houses so far this year.
 
Tries Personal Touch
 For Mr. Croniser, a personal touch with a customer -- taking extra time to go over floor-plan details, making an unexpected appearance at an open house -- can sometimes nudge buyers past doubts and into purchases.
"We've had to improve our bedside manner," he said.
Peter Elenius, who bought a house built by Croniser Construction, said he found his builder refreshingly flexible about modifications. For a fireplace expansion that would ordinarily cost up to $1,000, he said, Croniser only charged him $50.
"They listened to what I wanted, and they did it," he said.
In the last housing slump, a decade ago, high interest rates discouraged many ordinary home buyers from a long-term obligation. These days, an ordinary home buyer can obtain a 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage at less than 9 percent.
"You haven't seen rates like that since 1977, 1978," said Jay Shackford, vice president of the National Association of Home Builders. "You have a lot of people afraid of job loss, a lot of uncertainty."
Banks, suffering their own crises, have all but halted loans for acquisition, development and construction projects, builders said.
For builders without the financial resources to pull off a buy-to-sell arrangement like Mr. Stenger's, an essential like the price of the home can be the difference between the success and failure of a project.
Dan Amatuzzo has been able to sell 90 of 116 town houses he and two partners built in Cedar Woods, a project in Highland Mills, N.Y., because the base price remained at $99,000 for a two-bedroom home.
 
Prices Lowered Again

"We tried raising the price about $5,000 last June," Mr. Amatuzzo said, "and the sales stopped, boom, just like that." After a few weeks, prices were lowered to $99,000 again, and the sales resumed.
Mr. Amatuzzo said his project had been possible only because of a partnership he formed. Armed with land he bought more than 10 years ago, but lacking the cash to build, he teamed with two other well-financed builders, Bob Hankin and Ruby Shafran.
Over all, prices in the area are down 15 to 20 percent from their peak in 1987-88, his partner, Mr. Hankin, said.
But as a survivor, he has not given up looking for affordable land for future projects.
"We tell people: 'If it's a good deal, we're not interested. Only if it's a steal are we interested,' " Mr. Hankin said.

HEADLINE: American Airlines Details Its Plans to Cut Spending

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
American Airlines, which for the last five years has been a leader in expansion, is cutting its capital expenditures by $8 billion.
The company has already announced plans to reduce its five-year, $22 billion capital spending program but until now has given no details. On Thursday, Robert L. Crandall, chairman, president and chief executive of American's parent, the AMR Corporation, said the airline's fleet of 602 planes would increase to 682 by 1995 instead of the 775 planned originally. 
 Addressing a group of airline analysts at a New York transportation conference sponsored by Salomon Brothers, Mr. Crandall said that American would postpone or pass on almost all its options to buy new airplanes, which have a total value of $5.2 billion. He also said that deliveries of some aircraft already ordered would be slowed down for a saving of $3 billion from 1991 to 1995.
"The outlook is very uncertain," he said, "and although I am optimistic that over time, left to its own devices, the industry will make the needed course corrections, neither my colleagues nor I are willing to bet American's balance sheet that it will do so soon."
American said that for now it had decided not to buy 11 MD-ll's from McDonnell Douglas, 12 Boeing 767's and 33 Boeing 757's and 37 smaller jets from Fokker.
Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers, said the cutback by American, while large, did not necessarily mean that American would fall behind such rivals as United and Delta in growth.
He said that the cut by American brought it closer to the level of United's airplane orders, which total about $15.6 billion over the next five years.
"American is reducing its explosive growth rate to the more modest levels of United," he added. "What we have is a leveling of the playing field."
Mr. Crandall began to worry about the rate of expansion last fall when the Persian Gulf war doubled aviation fuel prices and brought a sudden drop in traffic that did not recover until last summer. American and most major carriers suffered major losses.
 
Others Haven't Cut Back

Both United Airlines and Delta Air Lines, American's biggest rivals, have not cut back on the pace of new plane deliveries.
Mr. Crandall said that if conditions changed the airline could decide to exercise some of its options on planes.
"We have never sought to be the largest airline in either the United States, the world or even Texas," he said. "We have sought and still seek to be solidly profitable."
Mr. Crandall set the stage for rapid expansion in 1983 when he persuaded unions to agree to a two-tier wage structure under which new employees were hired at lower wages.
As Mr. Crandall expanded the airline's staff from 42,500 workers in 1983 to 92,800 today, most of them were hired at much lower wages, greatly reducing labor costs.
American has a lot to digest, having acquired the London routes of Trans World Airlines. It began operating them in July.
American has also acquired Latin American routes from Eastern Airlines.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
GTE-Led Group Wins Venezuela Phone Stake

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Venezuela today accepted a $1.9 billion bid from a consortium led by the GTE Corporation for a 40 percent stake in the state telephone company.
GTE's partners include the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Telefonica Internationale de Espana and C.A. la Electricidad de Caracas. A representative of GTE said the Stamford, Conn., company would finance at least 51 percent of the purchase price itself. 
 James L. Johnson, chairman and chief executive officer of GTE, said the Venezuelan venture supported the company's "strategy to seek international opportunities" in telecommunications.
The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the losing finalist in a bidding process that began earlier this year with offers by 12 international consortiums, had offered $1.4 billion.
Mike Haughton, a spokesman for Bell Atlantic, said the Venezuelan experience was "not the end of our international efforts."
As part of the Government's privatization for the telephone company, employees will be offered an 11 percent stake, with the remaining shares to be sold in the near future on the domestic stock exchange.
GTE will have broad managerial control over the telephone company, which has for years been criticized for inadequate service and outdated equipment.
Dorea Akers, a spokeswoman for GTE, said the company would install two new digital switchers in Caracas that would improve service.
The telephone company now has a backlog of 500,000 orders for new telephone lines and has long been considered a drag on the economy.
GTE's shares lost $1.625 cents each today, closing at $32.25 on the New York Stock Exchange; Bell Atlantic lost $1.50, to $45.125, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Heavy Losses: Big Drop in Stocks a Factor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled yesterday against most currencies in trading in the United States in reaction to strength in the German mark, worries about the economy and a sharp decline in stock prices. The dollar had risen in Europe.
Gold prices rose in New York after falling overseas. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a bid for gold of $359 an ounce late yesterday, up $4 from Thursday's late bid. 
 "The dollar took a fair pounding this afternoon," said Jerry Egan, chief foreign exchange dealer for the Bank of Boston.
Michael Guarino, vice president and senior manager of foreign exchange trading at A.B.N.-Amro Bank in New York, said the dollar was hurt by deepening gloom over the American economy and the relative strength of the German mark.
"Most assuredly, the United States dollar is weak on its own accord," he said. "As the gloom and doom continues to persist, with interest rates low and the bleak economic picture, the dollar should take it further on the chin."
The dollar suffered in part because of comments by the president of Germany's central bank, Helmut Schlesinger, who said current inflation rates in western Germany were unacceptable. The remarks helped strengthen the mark.
The dollar dropped to 1.6190 marks in New York from 1.62975 marks late Thursday. Earlier in Europe, the dollar had risen to 1.6375 marks, from 1.6305 marks late Thursday.
Mr. Egan of the Bank of Boston said traders were also alarmed by the sharp decline in the stock market that saw the Dow Jones industrial average tumble by more than 120 points.
The dollar dropped to 129.40 Japanese yen in New York, from 129.62 yen late Thursday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar had risen 0.12 yen to finish at 129.77 yen. It was quoted later in London at 130.00 yen.
The decline in stock prices helped lift prices of gold, which could offer an alternative to stock investors looking for havens for their money. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $4.50 an ounce, to $359.50.

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Was Flat in October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Industrial production, which appeared to be pointing toward recovery through midsummer, showed no growth in October, the Federal Reserve Board said today. It was the third straight month of virtual stagnation.
Production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities was unchanged last month after edging up two-tenths of 1 percent in September and slipping one-tenth of 1 percent in August. 
 In an accompanying report on capacity utilization, the Federal Reserve said American industry operated at 79.6 percent of capacity in October, down from 79.8 percent in each of the two previous months.
The weak performance suggests more factory layoffs could be coming amid a faltering economic recovery, analysts said.
"It's hard to find any real pocket of strength," said Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said business inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent in September. It was the first gain since January and the largest since August 1990.
Today's reports, after Thursday's negative reports on retail sales and unemployment, offer "further evidence that the recovery is in tatters," said John M. Albertine, who heads a forecasting firm in Washington.
While industrial production accounts for only about one-third of the economy, this is the sector that is traditionally most subject to swings in the business cycle and is thus a good indicator of current economic conditions. Economists were especially disappointed that manufacturing, which had led the faltering recovery, had flattened.
President Bush, speaking by telephone to a meeting in Charleston, S.C., of executives representing the nation's 500 largest industrial companies, acknowledged that "we've got some short-term problems here." He added that "they're significant," but he insisted that the fundamental conditions exist "for the best growth we've seen in years," starting in 1992.
Hints that the manufacturing data would be discouraging came earlier this month when the Labor Department reported that 32,000 factory jobs had been lost in October on top of September's loss of 31,000.
 
Operating Rates Fall
 The Federal Reserve report today showed that all sectors -- factories, utilities and mines -- posted declines in their operating rates.
The rate at factories was 78.6 percent, down two-tenths of a percentage point from August. The rate at plants making durable goods fell to 76.0 percent from 76.4 percent.
An exception was automobile production, where utilization rose one percentage point, to 73.5 percent. Still, auto sales have been falling, suggesting the increase might not last.
And at plants making nondurable goods, the rate slipped to 82.0 percent, from 82.1 percent. It was off two-tenths of a percentage point, to 87.7 percent, at mines, and down one-tenth, to 84.1 percent, at utilities.
In the industrial production section of the report, the Federal Reserve said output at manufacturing plants remained unchanged in October, after posting a gain of five-tenths of 1 percent a month earlier.
 
Widespread Declines
 Output of durable goods -- relatively expensive items expected to last more than three years -- fell two-tenths of 1 percent after a rise of six-tenths in September. The report cited a decline in the output of both automobiles and consumer appliances.
Production of nondurable goods, like chemicals and clothing, increased two-tenths of 1 percent after rising three-tenths in September.
Mining output fell for the third straight month, down two-tenths of 1 percent after drops of 1.5 percent in September and seven-tenths in August. Utility production edged up one-tenth of 1 percent after plunging 1.5 percent in September.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Russian Republic Imposes Ban on Some Oil Exports

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The Russian republic sent a shudder through the oil market yesterday, announcing that it was suspending permission to export some cargoes of oil. But outside experts were not certain whether this was a symptom of the continuing decline in production in the Soviet Union, which is the world's largest producer, or part of an internal power struggle or the restructuring of the Soviet economy.
The announcement, the kind of news that the market has been more or less anticipating for two years, pushed crude prices up 60 cents a barrel early in the day on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but prices declined later, with oil for December delivery closing at $22.79, up 27 cents on the day. 
 "Clearly it is a major source of concern going into the winter," said Nauman Barakat, an oil expert at Merrill Lynch. But he said that while exports might fall, "they won't entirely suspend them, because of their desperate need for foreign exchange."
While the price move yesterday was not large, it was a reverse in direction, pointed out Vahan Zanoyan of the Petroleum Finance Corporation, a consulting firm in Washington. Oil prices are down $1.50 from recent highs, and the price would have gone down yesterday but for the Soviet announcement, he said. "The market is terribly oversupplied," he said. "There's far too much crude; we're swimming in it."
Several analysts said that while the announcement could be a symptom of declining production, it might also reflect a general loss of control in the Soviet economy. Thane Gustafson of Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Cambridge, Mass., said Soviet refineries were making private deals with foreign companies, and so were some production units, so that crude oil and refined products were flowing out of the country in an unaccustomed way.
In addition, he pointed out, control over export licenses is now being transferred from the central Government to the republics. The Russian republic may have decided to block some exports until it can figure out what is going on, he said.
Mr. Zanoyan said that oil was trading within the Soviet Union at about 70 rubles a ton, but that with rubles selling on the street for 110 to the dollar, the world price is about 9,000 rubles a ton, creating great inducement for producers and refiners to export.
George Friesen of Deutsche Bank Group in New York said it would take a severe drop in Soviet production to create problems on world markets.

HEADLINE: Credit Card Rate Cap In Doubt

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
With a politically popular move to cap the interest rates on credit cards spreading through Congress like a shipboard fire, the White House and banking lobbyists began damage control today, and the prevailing view by nightfall was that the measure probably would not be enacted.
Democrats see the issue as an embarrassing one for President Bush and want to keep it alive as long as possible. But many lawmakers, insisting on anonymity, said they would vote against it if they thought it stood a chance of becoming law. 
 Lobbyists for Citibank and other big banks were in offices all across Capitol Hill today arguing that if the caps were enacted, shaky banks might go under and millions of Americans whose credit ratings are less than ideal would have their credit cards recalled.
 
Opposition From the Fed

The White House denounced the measure with a vigor meant to suggest that President Bush would veto it if Congress approved it, but no veto threat was made outright.
Tonight, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, threw his weight against the legislation. If the bill passes, he wrote Congress, "The negative effect on banks' earnings will put further pressure on their ability to generate or raise capital at a time when concerns about capital positions are already contributing to restraint on bank lending."
Some legislators said the stock market's plunge today might give them pause about voting for a bill that could hurt already weak bank stocks.
The notion of the interest-rate cap began to spread this week after President Bush gave a speech on Tuesday urging banks to lower their credit card rates, now usually 18 to 20 percent, as a way to lift consumer spending and give the economy a jolt.
 
Amendment to Banking Bill
 The next day, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a New York Republican who has long favored a ceiling, without warning offered an amendment to banking legislation under consideration on the Senate floor. The amendment would have the effect of putting a 14 percent limit on credit card interest. Without much debate, it was passed by a vote of 74 to 19.
By Thursday, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady was saying that the Administration did not think such a law was a good idea. And today, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said, "When you do it by legislation, you impose artificial constraints that could be quite disastrous to the banking industry."
Mr. D'Amato's quick strike took the banking industry by surprise, but by today, their message was dominating Congressional telephones and fax machines.
Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, a senior Democrat on the Banking Committee, expressed sympathy with the view that banks were vastly overcharging their credit card customers. But in the end, he said, the measure probably would not pass.
 
Marvelous Issue for Democrats

"The thought around here," Mr. Sasser said in an interview, "is that Citicorp might go under, and that millions of folks would lose their credit cards, and that is causing a lot of wringing of hands and gnashing of teeth."
Still, it was a marvelous issue for Democrats, who are striving to position themselves as the party of the middle class. Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, said he hoped a vote on the matter could come in the House next week.
The House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Consumer Affairs plans to try on Monday to draft a companion measure to Senator D'Amato's amendment. The subcommittee is closely divided between those who normally support and those who usually oppose the banking industry.
At a House Banking Committee staff meeting this morning, according to one account, several Republican aides seemed worried about the credit card legislation. The Democrats laughed that they were just backing the President and would begin next week's bill-drafting session with a video of Mr. Bush's speech.
 
No Apology From D'Amato

Senator D'Amato, who is up for re-election next year, said he had no apology for handing the Democrats a good political issue. He said he would never have acted if banks really competed on credit card rates. But he noted that Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover, First Chicago and many other large banks charged exactly 19.8 percent, "the same rate right down to the decimal point."
Unlike the Senate, the House does not intend to tie its credit card bill to the overall banking legislation, and that could give the lawmakers a way out of a ticklish situation.
Senator Sasser suggested that perhaps "the two bills will just miss in the night."
But Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, said in an interview that such a tightwire approach could prove risky. The political attractiveness of such a measure and the irritation at banks for not competing on credit card rates could prove irresistible, Mr. Schumer said.
 
Further Action Next Week

Further action on the overall banking legislation was put off until next week. On Thursday night, for the second time in 10 days, the House rejected a measure that would have modernized the Depression-era laws that govern the banking system. A new and narrower approach will be tried next week.
In a closed-circuit television address to business leaders in South Carolina, President Bush said he would continue to press for "fundamental reforms."

HEADLINE: Mortgage Rates Dip to 8.69%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The average interest rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages dropped to 8.69 percent this week, the lowest level in nearly 15 years, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today.
The last time rates stood so low was in the winter of 1977, when they were 8.65 percent. A year ago, the 30-year fixed rate charged by lenders stood at 10.02 percent. Last week it was 8.76 percent. 
 The new low levels reflect moves by the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates to get the faltering economy and the housing market moving.
But analysts said the low rates had attracted few buyers so far. They did note a surge in the number of homeowners seeking to refinance their houses, purchased when rates were much higher.
Dick Peach, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association, said there had been some increase in applications for mortages, although refinancing accounted for about 50 percent of those applications, far above the traditional 15 percent.
"We are seeing things moving very gradually," he said.
Other analysts say the low interests rates will help ease problems in the housing market, but will not cure them.
Mark Obrinksy, an analyst at the Federal National Mortgage Association, said that home buyers were worried about their jobs, and were holding back from making the kind of financial commitment a home represented.
"Rates are not the main problem confronting home buyers," he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Plunge, With the Dow Falling 120.31

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market, which has scored sharp gains for more than a year, came unraveled yesterday, with the market's most closely watched barometer, the Dow Jones industrial average, taking its largest plunge in more than two years.
When the dust settled, the Dow, which tracks 30 of the nation's leading companies, was down nearly 4 percent, closing at 2,943.20, off 120.31 points. It was the fifth-largest point loss ever. The largest drop was in 1987, when the Dow index fell 508 points. The second largest was in October 1989, when the it fell 190.58 points. 
 The losses were not limited to blue chips. Other measures of the markets were also sharply lower.
Investors looked nervously toward Monday, fearful of how the market might respond, although Wall Street professionals said that they had seenlittle sign of widespread investor panic yesterday, either among big money managers or individuals who buy mutual funds.
While many analysts had been predicting for several weeks that the market was vulnerable to a setback, they offered various explanations as to why the precipitous decline occurred yesterday. These were the reasons most commonly cited:
*An abrupt downturn in biotechnology stocks, which had reached levels that seemed overpriced to many professionals.
*The sudden reports of real estate problems at several leading insurers, including Aetna Life.
*Widespread alarm over the possible effects of moves in Washington to restrict interest rates on consumer credit cards.
Yesterday's steep drop cracked a market that had widely been perceived as fragile, as investors worried about the continued weakness in the economy and the impact that would have on corporate profits.
Even as evidence has mounted that the nation was struggling to recover from recession, the Dow since Oct. 11, 1990, has gained 698.41 points, nearly 30 percent.
But while traders agreed that the market was vulnerable, there was less agreement on exactly what pushed it into a tailspin.
One clear source of distress was the high-flying biotechnology sector. Pushed in part by the reaction last week to the news that Magic Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers basketball star, was infected with the AIDS virus, some of these stocks had made double- and triple-digit gains, in the expectations of additional funds for AIDS research. All of the 10 largest losers in the over-the-counter market were biotechnology research and health-related companies.
 
Some Gave Warnings
 James McCamant, editor of the widely followed California Medical Technology Stock Letter, has been advising investors for weeks that overly optimistic buyers were bidding the biotechnology stocks up to unrealistic levels.
"I've been gradually getting more concerned," Mr. McCamant said. "We expected a decline, but we didn't expect it to be quite so much in one day." Despite the heavy selling and sharp declines yesterday, Mr. McCamant said he still found few attractive bargains. "But still I think this will be a short decline," he said. "Typically, panics like this tend to not last very long. Often a bubble will end in a panic, and recover before beginning a slower decline."
Another source of concern was the moves in Washington, led by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, to curtail consumer credit card interest rates. The threat this poses to the financial system is twofold, economists said. First, it threatens to impair profits at already troubled large banks; second, it could force banks to be more stringent in issuing cards, leaving some consumers less able to buy goods on credit. That, in turn, could curtail consumer spending, adding to the nation's weak retail sales.
David Shulman, managing director and head of the economics unit at Salomon Brothers, said: "People are very nervous about the whole credit card thing. If the banks pull back on consumer credit, it would impact disastrously on the consumer sector."
 
Watch on Washington
 Traders, too, cited the credit card developments, and warned that Wall Street would be watching Washington over the weekend to see whether the issue could be resolved.
The last volley to hit the market was the news that the Aetna Life and Casualty Company expected an increase of up to $1.3 billion in problem loans in its mortgage portfolio. Although reports of real estate weakness is nothing new, even in the insurance sector, Aetna was hit hard by heavy selling at yesterday's opening bell. That indicated to Mr. Shulman, the Salomon Brothers executive, that the stock market had not yet fully absorbed the potential ramifications of those developments.
Traders said Aetna Life fell sharply in London trading because of investor concern there that the insurance group might have more than a billion dollars in nonperforming mortgage loans. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, the stock was down $3, to $38.50.
These shocks hit the market at a time when most investors have been increasingly concerned about the economy, and what an aborted recovery might portend for corporate earnings and employment.
Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president at Lehman Brothers, said: "Investors and the market are showing impatience with the Government in bringing about an economic recovery. The market has been patient for months, on the assumption that lower interest rates will do the job, and investors are now starting to doubt that."
Those doubts culminated yesterday in a broad-based selloff that began gently, continued through lunchtime, and then sharply gathered speed in the afternoon. By the end of the day, virtually the only set of stocks that had managed to gain in the downdraft were the gold-mining companies, the classic haven for agitated investors. Gold itself closed at $360.10 an ounce, up $4.40.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
Markets
 
The Dow recorded its largest drop in more than two years. The average fell 120.31, to 2,943.20. The losses were not limited to blue chips as other measures of the market were also sharply lower. An abrupt downturn in biotechnology stocks was among the explanations for the decline as was the sudden reports of real estate problems at several leading insurers, including Aetna Life. [Page 1.] 
 Investors fleeing the stock market piled money into Treasury bills and notes, and short-term interest rates fell sharply. [33.]
The dollar tumbled in the U.S. in reaction to strength in the German mark, worries about the economy and a sharp decline in stock prices. The dollar had risen in Europe. [42.]
Russia is suspending permission to export some cargoes of oil, sending crude prices up 60 cents a barrel early in the day on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but prices declined later, with oil for December delivery closing at $22.79, up 27 cents. [42.]
 
 The Economy
The Justice Department indicted two B.C.C.I. officials and a major shareholder on fraud and racketeering charges. [1.]
The F.D.I.C. has been wasting a significant portion of its outside legal expenses, which are expected to reach $700 million this year, two studies show. [1.]
The White House and banking lobbyists began damage control regarding a move to cap the interest rates on credit cards, and the prevailing view so far is that the measure probably would not be enacted. [33.]
Industrial production showed no growth in October, the Fed said. It was the third straight month of virtual stagnation. [34.]
Business inventories rose 0.6 percent in September, the first increase in eight months and the largest in more than a year, the Commerce Department said. Sales lagged behind, rising four-tenths of 1 percent. [34.]
People already out of work at least 26 weeks will receive up to 20 weeks of additional benefits under legislation passed by the Senate. The measure will now go to President Bush. [46.]
 
 Companies
American Airlines cut its capital expenditures by $8 billion. The airline's fleet of 602 planes will rise to 682 by 1995 instead of the 775 planned originally. [33.]
Charles Keating Jr. has been widely portrayed -- unjustly in his view -- as an embodiment of all that went wrong with the savings and loan industry. Now a jury gets the chance to decide, albeit on a somewhat narrower issue. [33.]
A plan to rescue Executive Life Insurance was thrown into turmoil after a judge ruled that the company's new owners must give the same consideration to municipal bond investors that insurance policyholders will receive. [33.]
Some of R. H. Macy's suppliers were told by Heller Financial that it was no longer assuming the risk of payment for new merchandise they shipped to the department store chain. [35.]
USAir agreed to buy from Continental 108 arrival and departure slots at La Guardia Airport for $61 million. [35.]
McDonnell Douglas and Taiwan Aerospace are holding talks regarding Taiwan's buying up to 40 percent of McDonnell's aircraft manufacturing business. [35.]
Venezuela accepted a $1.9 billion bid from a group led by GTE for a 40 percent stake in the state telephone company. GTE's partners include A.T.&T., Telefonica Internationale de Espana, and C.A. la Eletricidad de Caracas. [35.]

A new I.R.S. procedure is subjecting thousands of investors to backup income-tax withholding, many of them improperly, because of difficulties in verifying identification. Your Taxes. [34.]
A radio that displays written information about songs as they are being broadcast has received a patent. Patents [34.]

HEADLINE: Louisiana Politics Dances to Music of Rage

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Cajun music still rockets through the night in clubs from Bourbon Street to Breaux Bridge, but there's no big fun on the bayou these days in Louisiana.
One day before Saturday's runoff for governor between former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards and State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader and neo-Nazi, this is a state full of rage, fear and frustration. Instead of politics as loopy theater, it's politics as primal scream. 
 The race has not been fun for Margot Garon of New Orleans, who says she cannot help but hear recurring, insistent reminders of her childhood when her family fled Nazi Germany. It is not fun for Danny Braud of Gonzales, who wonders if the good times will ever roll again and blames government for everything from welfare cheaters to his bad luck in fishing.
It was not fun for Duke supporters at a rally in Lafayette on Wednesday night, bitter that what they see as their scream of rage against a decade of corruption and economic decay is interpreted by outsiders as racism. It is not fun for business people throughout the state who fear that by electing Mr. Duke, Louisiana could be committing economic suicide.
And after Mr. Duke's emphasis on racial issues in this campaign and two other campaigns in the last two years, for the State Legislature and the United States Senate, voters here -- black and white, Jew and Christian -- are looking at each other in a way they have not for years.
"When the civil rights movement started they said, 'We just want to go to school with whites,' " said Louis Otto, a 76-year-old New Orleans landlord, who is white. "Now there's no stopping the demands. There's no end to it all. The morning paper said there's no black owners of baseball teams. What do they want? To give them a baseball team? That's why I tend to Duke."
Ted Quant, the director of the Institute for Human Relations at Loyola University, who is black, said he was still stunned by Mr. Duke's strength and the fact he could get two-thirds of the white vote. "Every time I shake hands with three white people," he said, "I shake hands with two Nazis."
As his critics and admirers are quick to point out, Mr. Duke's issues attract a national following. But he is also a product of the state's politics and its economic morass over the past decade.
From the Depression-era days of Huey P. Long, whose "every man a king" populism created one-man rule, Louisiana's politics has always inhabited its own distinctive universe. That universe reflected the state's poverty, its dependence on oil to pay the bills and its Balkanized politics, divided geographically by north and south and culturally by blacks, whites and Cajuns, descendants of the French settlers expelled from Nova Scotia by the British in 1755.
In the past, these divisions have pitted Protestant and conservative northern Louisiana against Roman Catholic and free-wheeling southern Louisiana in a Byzantine political grid that the writer A. J. Liebling once described as America's answer to Lebanon.
But the old alliances and divisions are now utterly scrambled, broken down by race and exacerbated by an economic slide that began when oil prices dropped in the early 1980's.
Tim Ryan, director of the Division of Business and Economic Research at the University of New Orleans, said Louisiana's economy peaked in 1981, when employment reached 1.63 million. The economy then stalled, and went into a free fall in 1985 and 1986, when the state lost 72,000 jobs. In 1987 it lost 40,000 more, a cumulative loss of more than 8 percent of the state's jobs.
 
'That Recession Psychology'
 Since then the economy has inched its way back, finally nearing the peak employment of 1981. But that gradual recovery, coming under Gov. Buddy Roemer, who finished third behind Mr. Edwards and Mr. Duke in last month's primary, failed to register with voters, Mr. Ryan said, adding, "It obviously wasn't fast enough to do away with or change that recession psychology that seemed to plague the voters."
It certainly did not change the psychology of Mr. Braud, a 46-year-old electrician who was drinking a Budweiser and fishing in a roadside bayou on Tuesday afternoon near Sorrento, between New Orleans and Baton Rouge, and began talking about the campaign with a flurry of racial slurs.
"We have gone through depression, suppression, repression and everything else, and it's time for a change like David Duke," he said as he watched the murky bayou waters from a folding chair.
"Back in Earl Long's day, the politicians could take their cut because they put a chicken in every pot," he continued, referring to Huey Long's brother, who also served as Governor. "Those days are gone. Now to get something to eat, I've got to catch a fish, and I can't do it because Buddy Roemer has got the channel going the wrong way."
The channel, off Blind River, was flowing the way it always has. But Mr. Braud's comment may have epitomized the special sense of political betrayal here.
In the past, voters winked at much of the political corruption in Louisiana, largely because the oil companies were footing most of the bill. But with the depression of the 1980's, the winking has ended. In Mr. Edwards, the three-term Governor who was twice tried but not convicted of racketeering, many voters here see a symbol of the old order that is now despised. Thus, Mr. Duke's support includes both hard-core followers and those who cannot bring themselves to vote for Mr. Edwards.
"They feel like Edwards burned them," said John Maginnis, editor of the Louisiana Political Review and author of "The Last Hayride" (Gris Gris Press, 1984). "They take it personally, that he did something to them, and they don't feel the same way about Duke unless they're Jews or blacks."
To many, Mr. Edwards represents everything that is wrong with the old political order, and Mr. Duke represents the radical change they want.
Ronnie Daigle and Roy Torres, who were hanging out at a gas station in Napoleonville, down the road from giant refineries that sit in the middle of endless fields of sugar cane, have no doubt about who they support. For them, Mr. Duke has become a lightning rod for resentments on race, on the economy and even on the environment in a state with some of the nation's worst pollution problems.
The stories come out in animated profusion: of the state environmental officials who turn a deaf ear to reports of chemical spills, of the shady deals in local politics, of the black woman who cursed and yelled when an elderly white woman tried to quiet her child at a local social services office. They all point in one direction.
"Duke -- I'd vote for him 150 times if I could," said Mr. Torres, who is 23 years old. "He's the only one willing to stand up and tell the truth."
 
Some Raw Emotions
 For Mr. Duke's critics, the emotions are at least as raw.
Katherine Davis, a 67-year-old black woman who was fishing a few miles downstream from Mr. Braud, saw something very different in the murky waters. "I know these people," she said. "I know about the Ku Klux Klan, how they'd burn down your house, burn down everything you have to get what they want."
Mrs. Garon, project director for a retirement village in New Orleans, fled Nazi Germany with her parents in 1937 when she was 10 years old.
"I see the Duke people holding up those banners and see them mesmerized," she said. "And if that doesn't remind me of the mesmerization that went on in those early days of Hitler, I don't know what does."
 
Taking Cues From Duke
 If race pervades this election, religion has also been ever present, with Mr. Duke playing up his professions of Christianity and accusing Mr. Edwards of mocking Christianity.
In ways both subtle and not, voters have taken their cues from Mr. Duke.
"I don't know why this one little man has frightened them so," Priscilla Bolyard, a retired social worker in New Orleans, said of Mr. Duke. "The blacks have the votes but they don't have the money. The Jews have the money, and the politicians and the business people need both the votes and the money, so they're getting the Jews and the blacks on their side and making a lot of noise."
There is also fear on the part of Duke supporters. Some say they are afraid to put up Duke signs in their yard or express their support publicly. Many say they fear reprisals from blacks.
"No one has to worry about putting up an Edwards sign," said Bill Lee, a 64-year-old Duke supporter from Westwego. "But if you put up a Duke sign in your yard, you're asking for it."
One night last week things seemed normal at Mulate's Restaurant in Breaux Bridge, billed as the "The World's Most Famous Cajun Restaurant," with its flamboyant bayou posters, thousands of business cards tacked to the ceiling and couples shimmying across the dance floor to the Cajun music of the Breaux Bridge Playboys.
But when the music stopped and the musicians were asked to name the candidate they would vote for, their smiles froze and they mumbled disclaimers that made their choice clear.
"He's the one saying what people want to hear," said one musician without mentioning Mr. Duke's name.
At one table were Tricia Siebert and John Anderson, newlyweds from Minnesota who had a Cajun band at their wedding and spoke fondly about the Cajun culture and hospitality they had found in their visit here. But after talking about Mr. Duke's support they found themselves confused.
They said they enjoyed their trip but probably would not return if Mr. Duke was elected. "It's not acceptable to vote for a Nazi," Ms. Siebert said.
At another table, when the subject turned to the race for governor, a young woman started telling a story of driving through the backroads between Lafayette and St. Martinville recently. The woman, who would speak only if she were not identified, said she saw in the distance what she took to be the lights of a gas well being tested, but as she got closer she realized it was not a well, but a Klan rally illuminated by burning crosses.
"What does that have to do with David Duke?" her companion, Polly Enloe of Lafayette, asked angrily.
"It has everything to do with David Duke," the first woman replied.
"We have no choice," Mrs. Enloe said. "We have two bad choices in Louisiana. We know what Edwards would do. All I say is give Duke a chance."
