HEADLINE: Accord on Ending Haiti Crisis Reported

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Haitian Parliament and a delegation from the Organization of American States have agreed on a process to restore constitutional government to Haiti that officials say could pave the way for a return of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was deposed in a military coup on Sept. 30.
Diplomats and officials cautioned, however, that restoring the Aristide Government would not be easy to accomplish in the present, volatile atmosphere in Haiti. 
 The accord, which stops short of calling directly for the return of President Aristide, who still has many opponents in Haiti, was signed in Port-au-Prince on Wednesday and made public there by the leaders of the Haitian Parliament and members of the O.A.S. delegation. The agreement has not yet been formally announced by the O.A.S. headquarters here, where the organization's leadership and member nations are being briefed on the document and the discussions that led to it, and where efforts are being made to get talks started.
 
Accord Signed in Haiti
 The negotiators returned Thursday to present the document to the O.A.S. leadership and member nations for review. Copies of the document, in French from Haiti, are circulating here, despite the fact that it has not been officially released.
With tensions high and the effects of a hemispheric economic embargo beginning to be felt in Haiti, many Haitians are continuing to flee the island by boat. About 200 were picked up Thursday night, American officials said, bringing to nearly 1,000 the number in custody this afternoon. About 480 Haitians are at the American base in Guantanamo, Cuba, and 500 more are being held on Coast Guard vessels at sea.
American officials and representatives of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees have been making urgent efforts to resettle Haitians in other Caribbean Basin nations. Belize has agreed to accept about 200 of the exiles, and there have been reports that Honduras and Venezuela are about to make similar offers. Reuters reported from Port of Spain, Trinidad, tonight that Trinidad and Tobago had agreed to accept an unspecified number of refugees held aboard the Coast Guard ships.
With Haiti in crisis, the United States has refrained from returning people picked up at sea. But it continues to advise Haitians not to set sail on uncertain seas where many have perished over the years.
The seven-member O.A.S. delegation that negotiated the agreement with Haiti's de facto government under an interim Prime Minister, Jean-Jacques Honorat, was an unusual group of prominent citizens of the hemisphere, led by a former Colombian Foreign Minister, Augusto Ramirez Ocampo. His team came from Canada, Chile, Costa Rica, Trinidad and Tobago, the United States and Venezuela. The American delegate was Lawrence Harrison, a writer and former official of the United States Agency for International Development.
The accord, reached after meetings with many prominent Haitians, in and out of government and the armed forces -- including labor leaders, industrialists, merchants and members of the clergy -- calls for talks outside Haiti to find a way to restore civilian government in line with the 1987 Haitian constitution. The Haitian legislators apparently did not press for the exclusion of President Aristide from politics. He was elected last December in Haiti's first democratic vote in a generation.
When the O.A.S. delegation first arrived, they were met with accusations that Father Aristide, a Catholic priest with a populist appeal, had been moving toward authoritarian rule, neglecting Parliament and other government institutions. His supporters countered that the persistent danger of a military coup called for unusually tough measures. They say that hundreds of Haitians have been killed since the Sept. 30 coup.
As part of the agreement, the O.A.S. is to send an international mission to Haiti to monitor civil rights and a restoration of democracy. The accord also calls for a visit by the Inter-American Human Rights Commission to investigate conditions before and after the departure of President Aristide, now in exile in Venezuela.
John Kozyn, associate director of the Washington Office on Haiti, a private group monitoring human rights and the political situation there, said in an interview today that there are still obstacles to Father Aristide's return, especially among the rich. Officials here add that there is also apprehension in the military that if the deposed President were to return while the atmosphere is still volatile, his supporters might form lynch mobs to attack those they perceive as enemies of the President.

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Bill to Extend Jobless Aid and Bush Signs It

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Senate tonight passed and President Bush signed legislation to provide up to 20 weeks of additional unemployment benefits to people already out of work at least 26 weeks.
The 91-to-2 vote quieted four months of intense partisan debate over the effect of the recession. The action also ended a furious 24 hours of arguments from some senators that their states were treated unfairly by the bill, which the House passed 396 to 30 on Thursday. 
 The compromise that calmed the storm provided for passage of the House bill, which provides either 6, 13 or 20 weeks of additional benefits, first. Then the Senate passed and sent to the House another bill that would shift all 23 states in the 6-week category to the 13-week category.
 
'Happy Thanksgiving Indeed'

 The benefits program was based on states rather than individuals because, lawmakers said, it was the most even-handed way to dole out additional benefits. They said it was fair for workers in states with higher jobless rates to get a longer extension of benefits because they would probably have more difficulty finding jobs.
Expressing the relief that filled the chamber after tense hours of debate and back-room meetings, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the Democratic chairman of the Finance Committee, said, "We can have the checks in the mail before Thanksgiving in many cases, and that will be a happy Thanksgiving indeed."
Both bills had White House approval, said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader. He said that the additional benefits in the second bill would add only $95 million to the $5.3 billion price tag of the House bill.
This cost increase, which surprised some Congressional aides who worked on the bill, was based on analyses prepared by the Bush Administration, Senator Dole said. The Administration has worked actively to get this bill adopted after killing two earlier versions on the grounds that they would increase the deficit.
 
Bush Calls Bill Responsible
 Within an hour of passage, the House bill was signed here by Congressional officials. And after Mr. Bush signed the bill, he issued a statement calling the bill "responsible." He said it would help the unemployed while maintaining budget discipline.
Mr. Bush said he had been deeply concerned about the plight of the unemployed and "my only regret is that the Congress did not earlier send me a bill that I could sign." In September, his aides had said that extended benefits were unnecessary because the economy was improving and more benefits would only encourage the unemployed to stay unemployed.
If the second bill is enacted, probably next week, jobless workers in Puerto Rico and nine states, including Connecticut and New Jersey, would be eligible for up to 20 weeks of benefits after exhausting the 26 weeks most states allow. In the other 41 states, the District of Columbia and the Virgin Islands, up to 13 weeks would be paid.
The second bill is also more generous than the House bill in paying benefits to people whose unemployment payments were exhausted some time ago, so-called "reachback benefits." Under the Senate bill, unemployed people in any state would be eligible for the reachback benefits if their regular benefits ran out any time between March 1 and now. Under a provision of the House bill, which stirred anger in the Senate, workers in 18 states would have been ineligible for the reachback benefits.
Under the legislation, if economic conditions in a state worsen it can move into the 20-week category. That would happen if a state's total unemployment rate, averaged over six months, reached 9 percent, or the unemployment rate among workers covered by unemployment insurance reached 5 percent.
A state could also move down from the 20-week to the 13-week category if conditions improved under a complicated formula, but individual workers who qualified for the 20 weeks would remain eligible.
The deal provides a higher level of benefits than any version of the measure previously considered in the House or Senate.
 
 
'Vote for American Workers'
 Earlier in the day a caustic debate was waged over the bill. Senator Robert C. Smith, Republican of New Hampshire, who wanted to tap foreign aid to provide more benefits, said, "You're either going to vote for aid for Somalia and Kenya, or you're going to vote for American workers."
Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, said, "This formula is a fraud," and threatened a filibuster.
Senators Conrad and Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, cast the only votes against the bill; all of the Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut voted for it.
The 71-to-24 defeat of the Smith proposal indicated the leadership could have forced the House bill through without change, but it might have taken several days, and Congress, which took the lead on the issue, would have faced criticism for its delays.
 
Bush Objected
 The two previous versions of the legislation would have paid the costs of extra benefits by tapping a trust fund established to pay extended benefits, but under a formula so strict that no worker in any state is now collecting them. That would have increased the Federal deficit and President Bush had objected.
The measure passed today provides for revenues by speeding up collection of estimated taxes on some wealthy taxpayers, and continues provisions for deducting unpaid student loans from tax refunds. It also extends for 1996 a two-tenths of 1 percent surcharge on the unemployment tax employers pay on the first $7,000 workers earn.
A big savings in the program was made by providing that the legislation expire June 13, instead of on July 4 as in the House bill. That was estimated to save $285 million. But most lawmakers expect new legislation next spring unless the economy suddenly improves.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aides Worry About Spread of Arms From Sales by the Soviets

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Pentagon and Western intelligence officials are expressing growing alarm that aggressive new efforts by the Soviet Union to sell weapons and advanced technology for badly needed cash are setting off a new wave of arms proliferation.
Advanced Soviet MIG-31 fighter jets were on the block at a weapons trade fair in Dubai this month, an American intelligence officer said. Syria is buying upgraded Soviet T-72 tanks, while Iran is acquiring advanced Soviet fighter planes, Western intelligence officials say. The Pentagon is investigating suspected sales of improved Soviet-made Scud missiles to third-world countries. 
 As the Soviet Union sinks deeper into economic turmoil, American officials also fear that thousands of Soviet scientists trained in building nuclear and chemical weapons are likely to lose their jobs soon, and then to try selling their talents to the highest bidder.
The Soviet Union has about 30,000 nuclear weapons, and American officials say Soviet weapons experts could be tempted by high salaries to join the nuclear programs of nations like North Korea and Iraq.
"I'm very much concerned about the sale of that technology," Deputy Defense Secretary Donald J. Atwood said in an interview with reporters today. "What we do want to stop is their selling arms to countries that have unstable governments or have a history of aggression or a history of terrorism."
"In particular we want to stop the flow of technology that could later give them the ability to make weapons of mass destruction," he said.
Mr. Atwood recently returned from an eight-day visit to Soviet military factories, where he and seven American industrialists studied the prospects of American assistance in converting Soviet military industries into commercial businesses.
The Soviet Union has been one of the world's largest arms merchants for years, largely building the Syrian and Iraqi armies, among others. The Bush Administration has made it clear to Moscow and the newly assertive republics that secret arms sales could jeopardize future Western economic aid.
That may curb official government-to-government sales, but senior Pentagon officials voice concern that thousands of newly unemployed Soviet officers and soldiers, discharged from the shrinking Soviet military, could try to sell weapons or technology in the world's black-market arms bazaar.
 
Some Superior Technology
 The Bush Administration is torn between wanting to buy a vast array of formerly secret Soviet weapons at bargain prices, and wanting to wean Soviet military industries off their missile and space businesses into peaceful ventures.
While most Soviet industries lag far behind their Western counterparts, a few others, including space and missile technologies, are equal to or surpass Western technology, American experts say. The Soviets, for instance, have put on sale rocket engines, space stations, nuclear reactors and other parts of their space program, in hopes of fetching badly needed hard currency.
Pentagon technical teams have visited the Soviet Union in recent weeks to evaluate the newly available weaponry and technology. In a sign those visits might inadvertently be encouraging Soviet policy makers to avoid conversion to peaceful industries, Mr. Atwood this week directed all Defense Department officials traveling to the Soviet Union to clear their visits with him or Mr. Cheney.
In addition to arms sales, American officials are worried about the migration of the thousands of experts who built the vast Soviet conventional and nuclear weapons arsenals.
"We could witness an equally threatening proliferation of scientific know-how, a bidding war, if you will, by third-world regimes for Soviet weapons experts that would dwarf the U.S.-Soviet competition to recruit German V-2 scientists after World War II," Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, said in a Senate floor speech this week.
Mr. Atwood and American intelligence officials say that there is no hard evidence yet to suggest a "brain drain" from the Soviet Union, but that the disintegrating economy could set off an exodus.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Try Diplomatic Action Before a Military Strike on Libya

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The White House indicated today that it would pursue diplomatic means before considering military retaliation against Libya for its role in the 1988 bombing of a Pan American World Airways jet that killed 270 people, but officials stressed they have ruled out nothing in their efforts to obtain two Libyan intelligence agents indicted in the crime.
One option gaining early support, the White House officians said, is an embargo of Libya's oil exports, which account for about 2.5 percent of the world's 60 million barrel a day average production. 
 To be effective, such an action would require either the cooperation of America's European allies, some of whom are major consumers of Libyan oil, or United Nations support for naval action to prevent tankers from docking at Libya's five seaside pipeline terminals.
It would also probably trigger an increase in world oil prices, a consequence the White House almost certainly would hope to avoid in an election year already plagued by economic troubles.
The United States has barred imports of Libyan oil since 1982, but that embargo has had only a marginal effect. A wider embargo that included western Europe, the buyer of more than 90 percent of the oil Libya exports, would have a far greater impact.
Another opition is an international effort to shut down Libya's diplomatic missions and to revoke the landing rights for Libya's airline. Libya's embassies and its airlines have long been suspected key elements in the terrorist network of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.
The Libyan Embassy in Washington has been closed since 1981 in reaction to an attempt by Colonel Qaddafi's agents to assassinate a Libyan dissident in the United States.
The United States will first deliver to Libya the indictments handed down Thursday accusing two Libyan intelligence agents with conspiring to plant the bomb that demolished Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in December 1988, the State Department said today. The explosion killed 259 persons in the plane and 11 more on the ground.
 
Libya Denies Charge
 Libya said today that it "categorically denies" the American charges, and suggested in a prepared statement that they be submitted to the International Court of Justice or some other neutral body for adjudication. The State Department rejected that suggestion outright, saying the indictments were a matter for United States courts to settle.
The United States has no extradition treaty with Libya, but will probably ask Belgian authorities to relay the indictments and formally ask the two agents to be handed over for prosection, the State Department's spokesman, Richard Boucher, said.
It was not clear today whether America's allies could be counted on to take united action against Libya. The Administration was said today to be preparing to lay out the evidence of Libyan involvement in the Pan Am case to European and Arab states, and then to measure the response.
 
Quick Military Action Unlikely
 Both Administration officials and outside experts agreed that the United States is unlikely to make a quick military strike against Libya, despite a warning from the White House today that it reserves the right to take such an action.
Any military action akin to the 1986 bombing raid by American warplanes on Tripoli could provoke a strong reaction from Arab countries at a time when Middle East peace negotiations are just beginning, they said. Egypt said today that it had warned President Bush that any military action against Libya would endanger "security and stability" in the region.
But an Administration official who asked not to be identified said that President Bush had privately discussed the Libyan situation with President Francois Mitterrand of France, and possibly with other European leaders, at the recent NATO summit meeting in Rome.
The French have previously shied from punishing Libya for terrorist acts, but recent charges in another airline bombing have roused growing public anger there. In that case, a French magistrate accused four Libyan intelligence officers, including the brother-in-law of Colonel Qaddafi, of plotting the September 1989 bombing of a French DC-10 airliner over Chad, killing 170 persons.
 
Praise for Detective Work
 At a reception Thursday evening, the outgoing head of the F.B.I.'s criminal investigative division, William M. Baker, praised the Central Intelligence Agency and other espionage services for what he called their unheralded work in the Pan Am inquiry.
Others said today that Mr. Baker was referring in part to a previously undisclosed intelligence operation last fall that produced a key element of the case: the diary of a Libyan agent containing references to the Pan Am plot.
That agent, Lamen Khalifa Fhimah, had previously served as a station manager for Libyan Arab Airlines in Malta. He returned there from Libya on Dec. 21, 1989, the day the bomb that destroyed the Pan Am jet was first planted in suitcase aboard an Air Malta feeder flight from that island.
Mr. Lamin's indictment charges that he used his access to the airport to steal luggage tags for Air Malta flights, one of which was placed on the suitcase that held the bomb.
That evidence came from Mr. Lamin's private diary. In an entry dated Dec. 15, 1988, a week before the bombing, he wrote, "Abdel Basset is coming from Zurich with Salvu," and added, "bring the taggs (sic) from the Airport." Abdel Basset is one of the two Libyan agents indicted in the case.

HEADLINE: To Jobless on Gary's Streets, Sense of Too Little Too Late

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., Nov. 15

 BODY:
This city, haunted by long-silent steel mills and boarded-up stores, is a deep pocket of unemployment in a state where the overall level of joblessness is below the national average of 6.4 percent.
In Gary, the unemployment rate is at least 15 percent, officials say. Knots of out-of-work men, young and old, while away the days on street corners or in unemployment offices, hurt and disgust etched on their faces like scars. 
 Today one of those men, Jerry Rowell, 36 years old, laughed bitterly at the Federal Government plan to extend unemployment benefits for those who have been out of work for more than six months. It would provide as much as 20 weeks of extra payments to people in states with the highest unemployment rates, but only six weeks to states like Indiana, where joblessness is generally less severe.
 
'It's a Joke'
 Mr. Rowell has been out of work since the summer. His unemployment benefits will run out in January, and then he can apply for the extra six weeks. He is afraid and angry.
"Six weeks, that's nothing," he said. "These benefits don't pay any bills as it is. It's a joke. Six more weeks isn't going to take care of nothing, especially with a man with a family."
Mr. Rowell said he has a wife and two children. He was laid off last summer from a fast-food restaurant, a job he took after he lost his job of 10 years at an auto dealership.
His first job was in a steel mill when he was 19 years old. He lost that job three years later when the mills that built this city began to close.
The Senate tonight passed a separate bill that would increase the extra benefits to 13 weeks from 6 weeks for states in Indiana's category. But the House still must consider that measure.
 
$171 a Week in Aid
State officials said that in Indiana, the maximum amount a qualified unemployed person with three dependents like Mr. Rowell could receive was $171 a week.
Luvenia Felders, 42, said she would take any kind of job. She said she had been looking for work for a year and was barely surviving on the kindness of her family and friends.
Chuck Oliver, 51, lost his job as an assistant manager at a food company in October. He said it was unfair that the unemployed in Indiana were only entitled to a six-week extension while workers in other states were entitled to up to 20 weeks.
"All Americans should be treated the same," he said.
In a few hours at the state unemployment office in Gary today, a cross-section of Indiana life walked in and out, illustrating how widespread the economic slump here is. There were police officers, maids, construction workers and word processors.
"I still believe in that flag over there in the corner," said Stanley Smith, a 35-year-old veteran of the Navy who was laid off from a Veterans Administration hospital a few days ago. "But I'm not going to let my kids starve."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Luvenia Felders, out of work for a year, was looking for any kind of job as she filled out forms at an unemployment office in Gary, Ind. (Jonathan Kirn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Battle for Votes, and Emotions, as Louisiana Governor's Race Is Concluded

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The brawl between Edwin W. Edwards and David Duke for Louisiana Governor staggered to a close today, and voters go to the polls on Saturday to decide a racially charged contest that has attracted national attention like few other races for governor in history.
The final day of a campaign that has defied many of the normal laws of politics was dominated by Mr. Duke's airing of 20-year-old accusations that Mr. Edwards sold state jobs to campaign contributors in his first term in 1971. 
 Political analysts said last-minute salvos, particularly concerning old issues, usually have little effect. But the strong emotions stirred by the campaign led some analysts to say that in an extremely tight race actions on the final day could help Mr. Duke.
 
Few Laments for Day's End
 Few voters will rue the campaign's end. The race between Mr. Edwards, a three-time Governor twice tried but never convicted on racketeering charges, and Mr. Duke, a state representative who is a longtime white supremacist and former Ku Klux Klan leader, has left the state polarized, dispirited and exhausted.
"The dynamics of this campaign are unlike anything I've ever lived through or even studied about, just the raw emotion of it," said Lawrence Powell, a history professor at Tulane University. "It's clearly the politics of unreason we're witnessing here."
Public opinion polls, in which statisticians have tried to adjust for the reluctance of voters to state their preference for Mr. Duke, show Mr. Edwards in the lead. But almost no analysts are willing to make a prediction about the race because of the difficulty of gauging Mr. Duke's support and because of the mixed emotions expressed by many voters Mr. Edwards needs.
The two candidates began the day by appearing one after the other on a local television show, fielding calls and appealing for votes.
Mr. Duke tried to deflect fears that his victory could bring economic ruin to Louisiana. Opponents and others have widely asserted that Mr. Duke's election would result in canceled conventions and a business boycott.
"If you're going to vote for your Governor by what outside liberals will say or do, then you might as well forget about having a governor's race and let them decide who our governor is," Mr. Duke said.
 
Using the Publicity
 Mr. Edwards said his first priority would be to capitalize on the national reaction to what he predicted would be Mr. Duke's defeat. "The first thing we're going to do is capitalize on the good publicity we're going to get after tomorrow when the rest of the nation finds out we are not dumb enough, racist enough or divisive enough to elect David Duke governor," he said.
The day's campaign news was dominated by Mr. Duke's unveiling of a last-minute television advertisement using excerpts from a 1983 report on "60 Minutes" in which Mr. Edwards was interviewed about accusations that campaign contributors were given state jobs after his first election in 1971. "Edwin Edwards said he would quit this campaign if we could prove he'd ever sold a position in state government," said an agitated Mr. Duke.
Mr. Edwards said that the "60 Minutes" interview, taken out of context, was not about selling jobs but that back then it was not uncommon for campaign contributors to expect to be considered for positions. He said it was not illegal at the time, and that he had helped to change the law to make such practices illegal.
CBS said today that the footage had been improperly used in the Duke campaign commercial and that it was taken out of context.
Some analysts said the accusations were so well known they would have little effect. But the accusations were used prominently on local television news programs, often with little indication they were old and well-aired. Ed Renwick, a Loyola University poll taker, said that in an extremely tight race it is possible they could affect the outcome.
Both candidates concluded the day by restating now-familiar themes.
At an American Legion hall in Metairie, Mr. Duke drew cheers from about 700 supporters rhythmically repeating his name when he vehemently criticized news coverage. "We said we're not going to be dictated to by outside forces," he said. He asserted later in his final campaign appearance, 'We are the cutting edge of the new conservative politics in America."
Mr. Edwards, after riding on a float topped by a papier-mache crown at Mardi Gras World, where floats are built and displayed, told a gathering of about 1,000 people, "We're going to tell the nation Louisiana is better than David Duke."
Apart from last-minute maneuvering, the outcome of the race is likely to depend on turnout and the battle for the supporters of Gov. Buddy Roemer, who finished third in last month's runoff. Secretary of State Fox McKeithen has estimated that between 72 percent and 75 percent of the state's more than 2.2 million voters will go to the polls, rivalling the highest turnouts in recent decades.

HEADLINE: R. M. Paiewonsky, 84, Virgin Islands Leader

 BODY:
Ralph M. Paiewonsky, who served eight years as Governor of the Virgin Islands in the 1960's, died Nov. 9, on his 84th birthday, at St. Thomas Hospital in St. Thomas, V.I.
Mr. Paiewonsky died of congestive heart failure, said his daughter, Joyce Adolfsen. 
 Born into one of the territory's most prominent families, Mr. Paiewonsky became successful in his own right as a leading businessman and as a politician with strong ties to the Democratic Party. President John F. Kennedy appointed him Governor of the territory in 1961, inaugurating a period of substantial growth in tourism and economic development.
His ties to Washington in the admininstrations of Presidents Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson helped win the island a far greater measure of autonomy. Mr. Paiewonsky led the successful efforts to provide fresh water and electrical power to homes throughout the island and to build low- and moderate-income housing for island residents.
Mr. Paiewonsky, who earned a bachelor's degree from New York University in 1930, was proudest of his role in founding the University of the Virgin Islands in 1962. The university library now bears his name.
In addition to his daughter, who lives in New York City, Mr. Paiewonsky is survived by his wife, Ethel, of St. Thomas; a son, Dr. Bernard Paiewonsky, of Bethesda, Md.; a brother, Isidor, and a sister, Paulina Puritze, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Panel Orders A Settlement In Police Pact

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A three-member arbitration panel handed down a binding decision last night under which New York City's 18,000-member police union will have to accept contact concessions to help pay for wage increases, city officials said.
The officials said the decision grants the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association a 4.5 percent wage increase for the last 15 months. But they said that it calls for no more city funds than the city had already allocated, which amounts to a 3 percent raise. The union would be required to make up the difference by agreeing to changes in work rules and the pension plan and by accepting lower salaries for new officers, high-ranking city officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said. 
 The 70-page report of the panel is likely to set the tone for negotiations with corrections officers, sanitation workers, firefighters and other police unions, known collectively as the uniformed services. The unions representing these workers have been awaiting the outcome of the arbitration -- which comes after 18 months of talks -- before going back to the table.
A P.B.A. spokesman, Dennis Sheehan, said last night that he had not yet seen the ruling and would not comment on it.
"This is big-ticket stuff," a city labor negotiator said. "It says to the unions that anything you want over and above what's available you have to fund yourself through productivity or through hard dollars."
Few details of the decision were available last night because both sides had agreed not to release it until the union delegates are allowed to review it this morning. A meeting of the delegates was scheduled for today.
James F. Hanley, the City Labor Commissioner, said he could not comment on the details of the pact because of the agreement with the union to wait until after their membership had read it. "It certainly looks fine to me," he said. "We're not unhappy."
Paradoxically, the 15-month contract that was awarded by the arbitrators yesterday covers a period that expired on Nov. 1, which means a new round of bargaining must begin immediately. The wage increases will be paid retroactively, officials said, but it was unclear last night exactly how the financing of the raises would be accomplished. .
Throughout the process, the police sought a raise comparable to the 5.5 percent raise Mayor David N. Dinkins granted the teachers in 1990. But the city, rocked by the recession, argued it could not afford that. Much of the teachers' raise was financed by changing calculations for its union's pension fund, allowing the city to reduce its contribution to the fund and use the money for raises instead.
Like other uniformed services, the police have historically won wage settlements higher than other municipal employees, so the arbitrators' decision bodes ill for the other uniformed unions' attempts to match the teachers' raise.
The settlement also strengthens Mayor Dinkins's hand in his negotiations over a five-year finanical plan the administration released last week.
A major element of the plan to close $7 billion in budget gaps over the five years depends on a pledge by the Mayor not to grant any wage increases through mid-1994 except to unions that agree to compensate for those raises by making their workers more productive.
Negotiations with the P.B.A., one of the city's most powerful unions, were thrown into arbitration after the union and city could not agree on a new settlement.
The union had contended that it deserved bigger raises to stay competitive with officers in Nassau County, who can earn nearly $10,000 more a year than officers in New York City. Keeping teachers' salaries competitive with the surrounding region was one of the Mayor's chief reasons for granting them raises last year.
Before the talks went to arbitration, the city had relatively little leverage over the police union, because the Mayor's ambitious anti-crime plan means that the city is continuing to hire thousands of officers while laying off other employees. As a result, the police had little incentive to make concessions.
In an unusual move in September, the Mayor testified at the final day of arbitration hearings, arguing that the city could not afford a raise greater than it had offered unless the union agreed to save money in other ways.

HEADLINE: Sports Authority Nurtures a $416 Million Plan

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK Nov. 15

 BODY:
The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority plans to ask the state for $416 million and permission to use it to restructure its debt, to build the proposed Atlantic City Convention Center and to upgrade Rutgers University's football stadium.
The Authority wants the state to float bonds to pay for all this, according to authority officials who worked on the plan and who agreed to be interviewed on the condition they not be identified. The proposal is being circulated among members of the Florio administration and the Legislature to try to elicit support. 
 The debt restructuring, the officials said, is intended to take advantage of falling interest rates and to offset declining revenues at the Meadowlands Racetrack. The racetrack is the authority's chief source for retiring the bonds that financed construction of Giants Stadium and the Brendan Byrne Arena, as well as the track.
 
To Retire Bonds
 The plan calls for using $223 million to retire authority bonds that are being paid off at interest rates above 10 percent, replacing them with bonds that carry interest rates of about 7 percent. The move could save the authority an estimated $170 million over the long term, the officials said.
All but $25 million of the $193 million of borrowed funds left after the debt is restructured would be used to build the long-awaited convention center for Atlantic City, which is intended to help the resort town to compete more successfully for national conventions. It also could be the catalyst to attract private investment off the boardwalk, including new, casino-less hotels for the anticipated influx of visitors brought in by the increased convention business, according to authority officials.
The authority is prepared to argue that the convention center project will create 6,000 jobs, $10 million in tax revenues related to construction and $48 million in other taxes and that it will add about $195 million a year to the local economy.
The remaining $25 million of borrowed funds would be earmarked for Rutgers. Most of it would go for rebuilding the stadium, supporting the university's entry into the Big East Football Conference. The rebuilt stadium would have a total of 45,000 seats as well as new lights, a press box and concession areas. The university's track and soccer fields would also be relocated.
The officials said the sports authority, which manages the new aquarium in Camden and Monmouth Park racetrack in Oceanport in addition to the operations at the Meadowlands, is hoping to convince the state that the expansion into Atlantic City and the assistance planned for Rutgers are natural extensions of the authority's role as a statewide agency whose scope is not limited to its projects in northern New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Resolved: Subway Fares Will Rise. Debate Question Is, By How Much?

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
The fight over the transit fare has begun again, but this year the traditional and all-too-familiar sparring has two special twists that guarantee at least one thing for bus and subway riders: The fare will go up. The only question is by how much.
One difference in this year's negotiations is that the politicians who usually ride to the fare's rescue, and revel in that role, find themselves strapped and thus less able to help. 
 But something subtler is also working against any "save the fare" effort. For the first time in 20 years the fate of commuter-rail fares, which transit officials have promised to preserve, is not linked to the immediate future of the bus and subway fare in New York City.
That leaves suburban legislators with little motive to raise regional taxes -- an alternative to raising the fare or cutting service in the city. And that has left legislators from New York City boxed into arguing for another alternative -- that the city get a bigger share of the current state taxes that support mass transit.
 
Starting on New Year's Day
 These competing interests form the backdrop of the decision that will be made before Jan. 1, when the Transit Authority wants to raise the fare to $1.40 to balance its budget.
Though some increase in the fare is inevitable, the precise amount will ultimately be determined by a complex process that will unfold over the next five weeks and involve the Legislature, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Transit Authority and its parent agency, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
In part they will be arguing about how to divide up the pie, and in part they will be maneuvering around one another to avoid blame for the increase, or maybe to grab a bit of credit if it is whittled down from the $1.40 asked by the Transit Authority.
Though the players have wrangled like this in the past, state lawmakers, the governor and the mayor were usually in a better position to answer the authority's call, often in the form of revenues from new taxes.
This time, however, the legislators and the Governor are constrained by the state's projected $700 million budget gap for 1991. They are well aware that their recession-weary constituents would have little stomach for another tax.
"It's not a good time for anybody to be looking to Albany for a bailout," says James A. Yates, legislative counsel to the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, who has long been a supporter of the city's transit interests.
 
First Offer Rarely the Last
 If the fare increase is reduced, the politicians say, it is the Transit Authority itself that will have to retreat from its claim that it cannot trim any more fat out of its $3.4 billion budget.
Despite its emphatic claims on Tuesday that its projected $263 million deficit for 1992 was firm and could only be bridged with a fare increase, the Transit Authority has provided ample precedent over the last decade that its first offer is certainly not its last; fare requests that were at first perceived to be exorbitant have been repeatedly pared down by the agency.
Other than proposing a new tax, which is unlikely, the Legislature has only one viable option to offer the authority. That would be to reconfigure the way several transportation subsidies are allocated to upstate and suburban mass-transit agencies.
Tinkering with subsidy formulas may appeal to the Assembly, which is controlled by Democrats who represent the city. But such measures would also have to pass through the Republican-dominated Senate, where many Senators are firmly opposed to taking money from the suburban commuter lines -- like Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road -- to pay for the city's subways.
In the past, the gap between the city Democrats and the suburban Republicans on this issue has been bridged by overlapping interests: The Transit Authority, Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road have traditionally sought fare increases at the same time. But this year, for the first time since 1970, the Transit Authority stands alone.
 
Suburbs Are Off the Hook
 The suburban lines had been preparing for fare increases that would have averaged 8 percent, but M.T.A. officials, somewhat under pressure from Mr. Levy, announced last month that the increases would not be necessary because new ways had been found to close the railroad deficits projected for next year. The railroads' combined $36 million deficit for 1992, which pales in comparison to the Transit Authority's gap, will be plugged by refinancing bonds and making administrative cuts, the M.T.A. has said. (Connecticut officials, and not those at the M.T.A., set the fares on that state's portion of the New Haven line.)
Alan F. Kiepper, the Transit Authority president, said on Tuesday that he could not possibly reduce the agency's 1992 deficit below $263 million without sacrificing service or safety. But as recently as this summer, the agency had projected a 1992 deficit as high as $460 million.
Some politicians, including Mayor Dinkins and Governor Cuomo, have urged the agency to dig deeper; the Mayor opposes the fare increase, while the Governor has said through his aides that he will not support it. Neither has said much more.
What remains to be seen is how much a fare increase of any denomination will be blamed on Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Dinkins, who have named a majority of the M.T.A. board members. The board will vote on an increase on Dec. 20.
The Straphangers Campaign, a riders' advocacy group, intends to shower the subways with leaflets bearing the Mayor's and the Governor's phone numbers in order to link the two to the fare increase. The organization is also urging subway and bus riders to express their views at the five open hearings that the M.T.A. board will hold in the next four weeks.
"People, fairly or unfairly, will hold the Mayor or the Governor -- the big cheeses -- responsible for what they pay to go to and from work or school," said Gene Russianoff, the counsel to the Straphangers Campaign. "These are politicians. They're used to being in difficult places and getting out of them."
 
 
 
THE PLAYERS

 
Deciding the Fare Increrase
 
Who will determine how much the subway and bus fare will go up on Jan. 1
 
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo
 The Governor has said through a spokeswoman that he does not support raising the fare to $1.40. He has pressed the Transit Authority to further pare its budget deficit without sacrificing service. It seems unlikely, in light of the state's own $700 million budget gap, that he would propose legislation creating new revenues for the authority. The Governor nominated Peter Stangl, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and 5 of the 16 other M.T.A. board members. They will ultimately have the final say on an increase.
 
State Senator Norman J. Levy
 Mr. Levy, a Republican from Merrick, L.I., is chairman of the powerful Senate Transportation Committee. A vigorous advocate for suburban interests, he is likely to be the main obstacle to any Democratic proposals to reduce the amount of a fare increase by shifting subsidies from the Long Island Rail Roard and Metro-North to the Transit Authority.
 
Assemblyman Jerrold Nadler
 A Democrat from Manhattan, Mr. Nadler is considered Mr. Levy's counterpart in the Assembly. He is the chairman of the Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions and is adamantly opposed to a fare increase. A vocal supporter of New York City's transit interests, Mr. Nadler has urged the Legislature to shift the allocation of some transportation subsidies from the upstate communities and the suburbs to New York City. Such plans might fly in the Assembly, which is controlled by the Democrats, but would likely run into heavy opposition in the Senate, which is controlled by the Republicans.
 
State Senator Ralph J. Marino
 Mr. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I., is the majority leader of the Senate. Like Mr. Levy, with whom he will no doubt work closely on this issue, Mr. Marino is a champion of suburban interests.
 
Assemblyman Mel Miller
 Along with the Governor and Mr. Marino, Mr. Miller, the speaker of the Assembly, completes the triad of power in Albany. A Democrat from Brooklyn, Mr. Miller has traditionally supported New York City's transit interests. He has been somewhat distracted by the fraud trial in which he is a defendant in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
 
Mayor David N. Dinkins
 The Mayor has said through his aides that he opposes the $1.40 fare. He has instructed his appointees to the M.T.A. board to lean on the authority to find alternatives to the increase, either by cutting costs or pressing the Legislature for additional revenue.
 
Peter Stangl
 The chairman of the M.T.A. has supported the Transit Authority's contention that the fare must be raised to $1.40 unless help arrives from Albany. He has also threatened that the fare could go even higher unless Albany acts soon on the M.T.A.'s five-year, $10.6 billion construction and improvement plan.
 
Alan F. Kiepper
 The Transit Authority president first proposed the $1.40 fare on Tuesday, when he submitted the authority's budget to the M.T.A. Though he has whittled the Transit Authority's estimate of its 1992 deficit from $460 million to $263 million in recent weeks, he has said the agency can cut nothing more from the budget without jeaopardizing safety or service. Only Albany, he has said, can avert the fare hike.
 
The M.T.A. board
 The 17 members of the board will vote on the fare hike at a meeting on Dec. 20. Because four of the upstate members share one vote, only 14 votes will be cast in all. Besides the six board members named by the Governor, four are named by the Mayor and seven are named by county executives.

HEADLINE: Rising Fraud Worrying Car Insurers . . .

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Auto-insurance fraud is big business. The insurance industry estimates that at least 10 percent of the claims each year are fraudulent.
"Sixty billion dollars last year went for auto insurance claims," said Sean Mooney, chief economist of the Insurance Information Institute, which is supported by the property-casualty insurance industry. "So the total savings would be about $6 billion." 
 The losses from fraud, of course, can only be estimated because, as insurers point out, if they could identify all fraudulent claims, they simply would not pay them. But consumer advocates say the insurers bring some fraud on themselves. As Ralph Nader put it, "The more people think they're being ripped off, the more they try to fight back."
 
Count the Reasons
 Whatever the reasons -- greed, higher premiums, the recession or even perceptions of abuse by insurance companies -- there is little doubt that auto insurance fraud is a major problem in the United States. The schemes range from preplanned auto accidents to unnecessary medical treatment.
"It's a growing problem because of the increasing value of automobiles, and it impacts on each and every one of us," said Jim Long, insurance commissioner of North Carolina. Mr. Long is president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, which wants insurance fraud made a Federal crime.
 
All Kinds of Suspects
 Deputy Inspector Ronald G. Thrash, commanding officer of the auto crime division of the New York Police Department, said: "We estimate that about 25 percent of all cars reported stolen in New York City are insurance fraud. We arrest grandmothers, we arrest schoolteachers."
Insurance experts say that although auto theft show no signs of decline, fraud is most apparent in the sharp increase in claims for bodily injuries received in car accidents. Insurers believe that an inordinately large percentage of these medical claims are fraudulent.
"The ratio of bodily injury claims to property damage claims has increased about 50 percent over the last 10 years," said James F. Perry, a vice president of the State Farm Insurance. "That has occurred at a time when automobiles have become safer, and there should be fewer bodily injury accidents."
To many in the insurance business, this increase is evidence of fraudulent intent. "It seems to be very clear that there is a change in claimant behavior," said Donald W. Segraves, executive director of the Insurance Research Council, a nonprofit organization established by insurance companies. "It's the difference between looking at an accident as an opportunity to get back some of the premiums you've paid versus the good of policyholders as a group."
 
Popular Acceptance of Fraud
 Just last week, the council released a survey of public attitudes showing that more than one in five adults thinks it is all right to pad an auto insurance claim to avoid paying a deductible. And 14 percent said it was acceptable to value a stolen car at more than its worth to get more money from an insurance company.
"We don't know how many accidents happen out there that are illegitimate," said Arnold Schlossberg Jr., director of the Insurance Crime Prevention Institute, an industry organization that investigages complex fraud cases. "But it's a growth industry, no question about it."
Auto-insurance fraud includes these major categories:
*Staged Claims: Parts of a car are removed, stored and reported stolen. After the insurance is paid, the parts are put back in the car.
*Owner Dumping: A car is reported stolen. The owner collects a claim payment from an insurance company, while the car's parts are sold to salvage yards and auto shops.
*Abandoned Vehicles: A car is abandoned on a road or in a parking lot in the hope that it will be stolen or destroyed. Then the owner reports it stolen to the police and the insurance company to collect under the policy.
*Salvage Switches: The vehicle identification number tag, on dashboards in newer cars, is taken from a junked car and switched to a similar make and model that an owner has fraudulently reported as stolen. With the false number, this car is then re-registered and sold, often in a different state or country.
*Staged Auto Accidents: So-called crashers stage an accident. A doctor and a lawyer working with the owner of the car falsify a claim.
How do insurers deal with all this? "We have a special investigative unit that looks for certain red flags," said Gary S. Turner, material damage claim manager for Kemper National Insurance Companies. These fraud indicators include: a close relation between the date coverage was provided and the date of claim; the insurance premium paid in cash; no theft report to the police, and the absence of any sales invoice.
Consumer groups look at this situation through a somewhat different lens. They accuse insurers of passively accepting some fraudulent behavior because the cost is eventually borne by their policyholders.
"The insurance companies really haven't fought insurance fraud too hard because there is a pass-through mechanism," said J. Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization.
Harvey Rosenfeld, chairman of Voter Revolt, a consumer group in California, said, "Anything the industry says is a severe problem ends up being the consumer's problem."
 
 
 
STAYING OUT OF FRAUD'S WAY
 What can the consumer do to avoid innocent involvement in insurance fraud? Here is what the experts advise.
Refuse to buy a vehicle or accessory, like a radio, from an unknown party.
If you are buying a used car, make certain the title is in the name of the seller.
Be wary of auto parts offered at prices that are too good to be true.
Inform the police, your state insurance department and your insurer if you suspect a fraudulent transaction.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Trail From Lockerbie

 BODY:
American and Scottish authorities have now provided a breathtaking account of their investigation of the destruction of Pan Am flight 103, which killed 270 people just before Christmas three years ago. Their work makes an exciting story. It's also a challenge to nations to complete the task of doing international justice.
From the village of Lockerbie, where 11 people were killed, detectives fanned out in a dogged search for evidence that was blown clear across Scotland to the North Sea. They ingeniously pieced it together and then followed microscopic leads to their two suspects, Libyan intelligence officers now accused by both countries of mass murder. 
 That remarkable achievement raises profound questions. The indictment portrays the suspects, Lamen Khalifa Fhimah and Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, as merely the front-line agents of state-sponsored terrorism, which sets up another confrontation with Libya and its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. How should the United States and the United Kingdom proceed?
The clear answer is: aggressively, but judiciously. Washington has accused Tripoli of sponsoring this terrorism and Tripoli has denied it. Each is talking not to the other but to the world, all well in advance of even a formal request to deliver the suspects for trial. American spokesmen talk of keeping "all options open" while the Scottish prosecutor observes that the suspects aren't likely to be arrested "in the normal way." President Bush's Attorney General-designate, William Barr, is best known for a memorandum defending the legality of trying suspects snatched from other nations without their governments' consent.
But Mr. Barr's memorandum deals with legal power, not the wisdom and statesmanship that must guide global law enforcement. There are various options. Diplomatic and economic pressure, including trade embargoes, are the obvious first choices to be exhausted long before considering venturesome sorties to kidnap fugitives.
Some relatives of Lockerbie's victims are puzzled that Syria and Iran, once prime suspects, are no longer implicated. They suspect that President Bush, seeking help in his quest for Mideast peace, finds it convenient to declare that Syria has suffered "a bad rap." But the incredibly detailed trail of evidence, and Scotland's full participation in the inquiry, are the best assurances that there has been no diplomatic fix.
Still, it would seem fitting to look to Syria and Iran, along with many other nations, for help in pressing Libya both to satisfy justice and renounce terrorism. If world leaders can match the determination and ingenuity of Scottish detectives and American F.B.I. agents, there's hope for a just and satisfying sequel to the tragedy at Lockerbie.

HEADLINE: Regulators' Lawyers: A Growth Industry/A special report.;
U.S. Said to Squander Millions For Legal Work on the Bailout

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Two studies commissioned by the Government say the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, now the world's largest employer of private lawyers, has been wasting a significant portion of its outside legal expenses, which are expected to reach $700 million this year.
The studies found, among other things, that the F.D.I.C. and its affiliated agency, the Resolution Trust Corporation, failed to use competitive bidding or to negotiate steep-enough discounts or fixed fees when hiring lawyers, even though many lawyers are eager for the work.
<
 
Question of Whom to Hire
 The lawyers were hired to help the Government clean up the problems caused by the failure of banks and savings and loan institutions. Once on the job, lawyers earning $100 an hour or more were allowed to perform routine work, like reviewing bills, that could have been done by clerks, the studies say. The reports did not name specific law firms in these instances. 
 At the same time, a survey of Government records and numerous interviews show that the two regulatory agencies quietly adopted a policy allowing them to hire legal, accounting and security firms that have been accused in lawsuits of contributing to the collapse of banks or savings and loan institutions. The Government inherited many of these suits from institutions it took over and is now opposing in court the very firms it is hiring.
Among those facing such suits and now benefiting from the new policy are top accounting firms, including Coopers & Lybrand; Ernst & Young; Laventhol & Horwath; Grant Thornton and Cherry, Bekaert & Holland, and also such securities firms as Kidder, Peabody & Company, Prudential Securities, the First Boston Corporation and Shearson Lehman.
Concerned about the extraordinary growth in legal services and how it is being handled, members of the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs are holding a hearing next week to examine the two private studies that showed wasteful spending on lawyers. The first was done by a Philadelphia management consulting firm in February; the other by the accounting firm Price Waterhouse late this summer. Both came to similar conclusions.
In a written response to the Price Waterhouse report, Alfred J. T. Byrne, the F.D.I.C.'s general counsel, said, "Much of the report is both instructive and constructive." But in the same document, which was sent to Robert D. Hoffman, the F.D.I.C. inspector general who commissioned the report, Mr. Byrne asserted that the study failed to give the legal division sufficient credit for recent reforms.
Mr. Byrne also said the firm's report had not noted how difficult it has been to make changes while trying to accommodate a rapidly increasing caseload.
In an interview, Mr. Byrne said he had placed limits on how much any single law firm could be paid, starting at $2.5 million a year and subject to some exceptions. In addition, he said the use of more than 1,675 law firms spread the wealth and helped set up elements of competition. He also said the collections and recoveries by private lawyers far exceeded their pay.
Even with that, the regulators are expected to pay another $700 million for outside legal services next year, not including hundreds of millions of dollars for in-house work and outside lawyers working for other divisions.
Before he retired as chairman last month, L. William Seidman acknowledged, "We've got a lot more work to do in managing our legal things."
 
The Problem
The F.D.I.C. Faces A Herculean Task
 The ground for this rush to hire lawyers was laid in the late 1980's, when scores of banks and savings and loans failed because they had taken on too many risky real estate loans.
As part of the huge Federal bailout of the savings industry, approved by Congress in 1989, the Government became the nation's largest owner of residential and commercial real estate. A new agency, the Resolution Trust Corporation, was formed to manage and dispose of the property.
The Trust Corporation, scheduled to go out of existence in 1996, is also selling hundreds of billions of dollars of other investments it inherited from failed institutions. These range from blue-chip stocks to high-yield, high-risk junk bonds.
To manage this giant liquidation, the Trust Corporation has borrowed thousands of employees from the deposit insurance agency, which itself is growing rapidly to deal with the large number of failed banks. Both agencies have contracted with tens of thousands of accountants, property managers, investment bankers and lawyers.
The more efficiently the Government handles the disposition of seized properties and loans inherited from the failed institutions -- by selling the assets and collecting the debts -- the less the bailout will cost taxpayers. As it is, the savings and loan rescue is expected to cost the Government $200 billion, not including interest expenses.
Investigations by Congress and the agencies themselves have already found contractor abuses, and there is widespread concern that inadequate monitoring could lead to significant additional waste or fraud.
Earlier this year, the Trust Corporation hired the Pentagon's top contract fraud investigator, Howard W. Cox, as assistant director for contractor oversight and surveillance. The budget of the inspector general of the F.D.I.C., the agency's internal watchdog, has more than tripled in the last five years.
 
The Legal Bill
Soaring Costs Attract Attention
 No division of the F.D.I.C. has grown faster or attracted more attention than the legal division.
"Given the magnitude of expenditures involved and the public demand for accountability, the legal division faces unprecedented public scrutiny into its use, selection and management of outside counsel," Mr. Hoffman wrote the F.D.I.C.'s directors on Sept. 30, in reaction to the Price Waterhouse report.
The chairman of the Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs, Representative Doug Barnard Jr., Democrat of Georgia, says much of its hearing next week will focus on Mr. Hoffman's work with Price Waterhouse, which he calls the "first comprehensive and thorough analysis of these issues."
The panel plans to address many of its questions to the head of the F.D.I.C. general counsel, Mr. Byrne, who until June 1990 was a partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Dechert Price & Rhoads.
Public records show the agency's outside legal expenses soared to $615 million in 1990 from $92 million in 1989.
Mr. Hoffman said in an interview that he had ordered more audits of office legal expenses, and he has recommended tighter billing procedures, including requiring written approval before outside firms undertake significant tasks.
In one case Mr. Hoffman says his auditors questioned the payment of $200,000 in research costs to a law firm, Hopkins & Sutter -- a Chicago firm that was the agency's largest contractor last year, with billings of $17.5 million. The criticism, he added, was not of the firm's work but rather that the agency had permitted the firm to take on the research without written authorization.
 
Money Wasted
Lawyers Doing Clerical Work
 Mr. Hoffman's summary of the Price Waterhouse report does not identify any individual law firms or give estimates of the amount of money wasted. But according to Mr. Hoffman's Sept. 30 memo, the findings include these:
*"A large proportion of the work involves relatively straightforward transactional work," but because of managerial weaknesses, "attorneys spend significant amounts of time performing tasks that do not require a lawyer's skills, an arrangement which is expensive, inefficient, and can undermine morale."
*"Outside counsel are generally not selected on a competitive basis," placing the division "at risk of potential and perceived abuses in their contracting activities."
*The F.D.I.C. "generally pays hourly rates," instead of fixed-price bills, "which could result in excessive fees."
*The legal division has no policies to insure that the firm selected is best able to perform the tasks, so "work is not cost-effectively assigned to outside counsel."
In his reply, Mr. Byrne noted that there had been an occasional "mismatch of staff to workload," meaning that lawyers were used for jobs that could have been done by clerks. He said he hoped to correct this imbalance. His memo to Mr. Hoffman also cites recent cost-cutting efforts and concludes, "Our actual outside counsel costs for the first nine months of this year are running 20 percent below budget."
Several of Price Waterhouse's recommendations and criticism were also offered by a Philadelphia management consulting firm, Altman & Weil, that was hired by the F.D.I.C to conduct a similar study early this year.
This report said the agency was doing as well as could be expected but needed to take advantage of the buyer's market where "firms are screaming for the F.D.I.C.'s legal work." It also recommended greater use of discounts, fixed fees, and in-house counsel and suggested that Government lawyers rather than private lawyers be asked to prepare the budgets for legal work.
"Outside lawyers will sometimes low ball the original fee budget," the report said, "insuring that they receive the work, and then they will seek to exceed the original estimate.'
 
Hiring Standards
Potential Profit From Mistakes
<
When it set the hiring standards for the contractors, the Resolution Trust Corporation wrote in a regulation that "persons whose activities contributed to the decline of the thrift industry" would "play no role in contracting with the R.T.C." This was in response to a clear concern that Congress had raised when it passed the savings and loan rescue.
The F.D.I.C. and the Resolution Trust Corporation hope to recover billions of dollars from hundreds of lawyers, accountants and investment bankers by suing them for negligence. Many experts believe that lapses in professional responsibility by these people were a principal cause of the savings and loan disaster.
Before the hiring rules were formally issued last year, many professionals told the Trust Corporation they were too strict.
The final rules said anyone who caused a loss of more than $50,000 to a Federal insurance fund would be barred from doing business with the Trust Corporation. In addition, no contractor sued by the Federal agencies could get Government contracts, unless a special contractors' committee granted a waiver.
Then in March 1990, one month after their adoption, the regulations were modified with little public announcement. According to an internal memo to both the F.D.I.C. and Trust Corporation boards by the head of the special contractors' committee, both approved what "appears to be a blanket waiver."
With the change, firms accused of negligence could establish certain screening procedures so that people who were involved in the firm's work that is now the subject of Federal litigation could not work on agency business. Meanwhile, the firm as a whole would be eligible to win Federal contracts.
With that, accountants and lawyers accused of helping to draw the nation into the banking crisis stand to profit from the rescue. Even if these people do not work on the Trust Corporation cases directly, in many cases they can share in their firm's profits from this work.
This policy change was intended to increase competition, but the public documents describing it were not released to the Trust Corporation reading room until 15 months after it took effect. By then dozens of firms had applied for and been granted waivers, but for seven months the Trust Corporation refused to release the names of these firms.
One of the first waivers, to Coopers & Lybrand, precludes professional employees previously involved in advising the Silverado Savings Association in Denver from working on any new contract. This savings and loan collapsed in 1988, and the recovery will cost the Government $1 billion.
Coopers & Lybrand was the institution's auditor and has agreed to pay $20 million to settle any Government claims over its accounting work for Silverado. Critics of the waiver policy note that by simply limiting the ability of a few individuals to work for the Government, these people can still share in the firm's profits derived from cleaning up a problem they may have helped to create.
Abraham J. Briloff, a professor emeritus of accounting at the City Univerity of New York who has often testified before Congress, is one of the critics. In an interview he said accountants were eager to take on Trust Corporation work, so the agency had no need to hire those who are being sued. The agency, he added, should make "the firms as a whole responsible" for past mistakes by limiting an entire firm's work for the Government, not just the work of a few individuals.
But James Barth, a professor of finance at Auburn University and the former chief economist of the Government's savings and loan regulatory agency, contended that allowing what he called rehabilitated firms to compete for Trust Corporation work produced lower costs. That, he said, outweighed what he called the moral outrage of letting firms that helped cause the problem benefit from its cleanup.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 22, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about regulators' legal expenses linked to bank and savings-and-loan failures listed one firm erroneously among those still facing Government lawsuits. A suit against the First Boston Corporation was settled in July, in the firm's favor.

HEADLINE: Investors Rush to Buy Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Investors fleeing the stock market piled money into Treasury bills and notes yesterday, and short-term interest rates fell sharply.
 In addition to the stunning 120.31-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average -- a plunge that analysts said was at least partly a reaction to attempts in Congress to cap credit card interest rates -- credit market participants received another batch of economic reports that did nothing to dispel the notion that the economy, after a summer upturn, is sliding again. 
The reports included data from the Federal Reserve showing that industrial production was flat in October, continuing a trend in place since July, and from the Commerce Department showing that business inventories rose in September for the first time since January. The report on factory output had been expected, but the inventory buildup was a worrisome surprise. [Page 34.]
 Given recent poor retail sales numbers, analysts said the inventory buildup was probably involuntary. If it continues, further job layoffs could be coming, they said.
 Preliminary results of the University of Michigan's monthly survey of consumer attitudes, released to subscribers yesterday, reinforced the sense that conditions are worsening.
 Through the first two weeks of November, the survey showed that both confidence and expectations about the future had slipped sharply from their October levels.
 Bond traders, who normally dote on bad economic reports, did not respond to the day's developments by buying long-term securities.
 "Bond yields can't seem to get through the 7.80 level," said Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank.
 Concern about how much inflation might be generated by the steady decline in short-term interest rates engineered by the Federal Reserve is one reason that bond yields remain sickly, Mr. Chandross said. Another is that bond traders remain fearful that policy makers will at some point concoct a package to rescue the economy that will further inflate the Federal budget deficit.
 By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 102 1/8, down 1/32, to yield 7.81 percent, unchanged from late Thursday, but down from 7.87 percent last Friday.
 The plunge in equity prices sent investors scurrying into the secondary market for Treasury notes and bills.
 In late trading, the 6 7/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 14/32, up 10/32, to yield 6.52 percent. And prices for the 6 percent two-year notes rose by 6/32, to a late offered price of 100 30/32, to yield 5.48 percent.
 Short-term Treasury bill rates fell sharply.
 Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.55 percent late yesterday, down 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 9 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.58 percent. And one-year bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.59 percent, down 11 basis points.
