PUB-DATE: November 17, 1991

SECTION: Section 5; Page 16; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 11182 words

HEADLINE: WINTER IN THE SNOW;
Action On and Off the Slopes

BYLINE: By STANLEY CARR

 BODY:
SKI resorts around the country have become more enterprising than ever, improving their areas and services and offering deals in the face of recession and a dip in the number of skiers. According to a survey done for the United Ski Industries Association, there were 46.7 million skier visits last winter compared with more than 50 million in 1989-90 and 53.3 million in 1988-89.
Ski classes are becoming more scientific with a new crop of names. Sunday River, Me., for example, offers instruction called the Perfect Turn; Steamboat, Colo., has the Billy Kidd Center for Performance Skiing; and in Vermont, Mount Snow beckons with EXCL, standing for express customized learning, while Bolton Valley teaches the Effortless Turning Concept. 
 Deals that reduce the cost of the full-day lift ticket are spreading across the country. Stowe, Vt., sells a $99 book of 12 coupons each redeemable for a 50 percent reduction on the $39 any-day ticket. A pay-per-ride lift ticket book at Bromley, Vt., contains 40 coupons for use on lifts at the rate of one to five coupons, depending on the lift ridden. The book costs $50, and $32 for juniors aged 7 to 14, compared with daily ticket prices of $36 and $23 on weekends and holidays and $24 and $13 midweek. (At most ski centers, but not Bromley, junior means aged 6 to 12.) Another Bromley deal: juniors ski free midweek when accompanied by a ticket-buying adult.
At Steamboat, and Sierra Summit, Calif., children under 12 ski and stay free when a parent buys a five-day lift ticket and lodging. Most ski areas offer savings when skiers buy tickets for two or more consecutive days. Skiers should check with ski shops and ski areas for more information on cut-rate special days and programs for specific groups, including seniors and children. On "Forever Young Days" (every Tuesday) at Mount Cranmore, N.H., tickets are half price for anyone over 50.
Investment in snow-making equipment has become essential, even in areas known for high snowfalls. Bear Valley and Boreal in California credit their snow guns with saving their season during last winter's snow drought. Sun Valley, Idaho, says it spent $5.5 million this year boosting its man-made system on Baldy Mountain. Taos, N.M., has added top-to-bottom snow-making on the west side of the mountain.
But carrying out changes to ski resorts is no simple matter these days. Snow-making, which requires drawing on local water supplies, has become a critical issue, effecting fish and sewage disposal. Applications to draw on water sources often involve protracted negotiations. Ski areas are also confronting other environmental concerns. Keystone, Colo., says that the $32 million investment in the mountain's new Outback section being opened this winter includes $3 million spent on protecting and enhancing the quality of water, revegetation, wildlife, wetlands and utilities.
Bruce Watson, general manager of Whitetail, a new area opening next month in Pennsylvania, said that environmental negotiations, hearings, challenges and permit applications stretched over 11 years and cost the owners more than $1 million. The ski area at Loon, N.H., the United Ski Industries Association reports, has spent over $1 million on studies but to date has failed to receive final approval to expand onto the adjacent South Mountain. The association also says that permits to expand facilities were issued this past spring and summer to Okemo, Stowe and Sugarbush in Vermont and Mount Hood Meadows, Oregon, "after a decade of open and expensive discussions between resort owners and preservationists."
Meanwhile, the enhancement of ski resorts continues, attracting nonskiing recreation around them, from indoor tennis, pools, spas and hot tubs to hot-air ballooning. To these can be added some older staples like skating, ice fishing, museums, art galleries and, at Jackson Hole, Wyo., sleigh rides through elk herds.
The following survey offers a selection of ski areas that offer a lot for both skiers and nonskiers in the West, Northeast and Canada.
 
 
 
THE WEST
CALIFORNIA

 
BEAR VALLEY
Bear Valley Ski Company, Post Office Box 5038,
Bear Valley, Calif. 95223
Information, (209) 753-2301; lodging, (209) 753-6700; snow conditions, (209) 753-2308
On the Slopes Bear Valley, midway between Yosemite National Park and Lake Tahoe, provides excellent skiing conditions without the crowds encountered at Mammoth Mountain to the south or the Lake Tahoe-area resorts to the north. From a summit at 8,495 feet, skiers can choose from 82 runs that total 25 miles. Nine chairlifts take skiers up the mountain (vertical drop, 1,900 feet) and afford views of the Sierra Nevada, with its forest of pine and fir, surrounding the valley. Three surface lifts have been added this year. The runs, which cover more than 1,200 acres, are divided almost equally among beginner, intermediate and expert.
Lift ticket prices: $32 full day; $25 half-day; $25 for ages 13 to 23 with student ID; $16 for skiers 65 and over; $10 for disabled and children aged 7 to 12; $8 children 6 and under. Discounts packages, including lift tickets, equipment rental and lessons, are available for beginners and children.
Ski school begins at $20 for a two-hour group lesson. For racers, personalized coaching begins at $50 for two hours.
Bear Valley Cross Country, (209) 753-2834 and (800) 232-7123, offers cross-country skiing on 56 miles of trails. Basic rate: $12.50 full day; $9 half-day; discounts available for children, seniors and disabled. Lessons and rentals available. This company also holds occasional special events, including moonlight cross-country skiing and back-country tours, wine tastings and food festivals.
For Nonskiers Bear Valley provides ice skating ($3 rink fee for two hours; $4 skate rental) on a pond. On Saturday the pond is lighted for night skating accompanied by music and a bonfire.
Four miles away, in Bear Valley Village, the Bear Valley Lodge, (209) 753-2327 and (800) 794-3866, offers its guests restaurants, bars, hot tubs, a massage service and catering. Midweek discounts, with free lift tickets or cross-country trail passes, are available. Basic room rates: $79 to $169, double occupancy. Rooms at the Red Dog Lodge, (209) 753-2344, rent for $50, single or double. A shuttle van connects the hotels to the slopes.
Snowmobile rentals are available in Bear Valley, (209) 753-2323. Rates range from $25 for a small two-seater for a half-hour to $162 for a full day on a larger machine.
 
HEAVENLY SKI RESORT
Wildwood and Saddle Road, South Lake Tahoe, Calif. 96156, and Post Office Box 2180, Stateline, Nev. 89449-9919
central reservations, (800) 243-2836; snow conditions, (916) 541-7544; general information, (916) 541-1330
On the Slopes Heavenly, which straddles the California-Nevada border just south of Lake Tahoe, offers not only some of the best skiing in California but also some of its most spectacular views. Most of the 71 trails, at altitudes ranging from 6,550 to 10,100 feet, look out onto Lake Tahoe and the heavily wooded Sierra Nevada that ring the Tahoe Basin.
Twenty-five lifts, including a 50-passenger aerial tram and a high-speed quad, carry skiers up the mountain. From top to bottom, beginner, intermediate and advanced trails intertwine across the slopes and bowls, giving skiers of all levels access to the entire mountain. Skiers can start from one base lodge on the California side, or two on the more out-of-the-way Nevada side.
Lessons with Heavenly's 175 instructors range from $10 for a 20-minute clinic on a specific skill to $264 for a private six-hour session. Full-day packages for children aged 3 1/2 to 12, including lift tickets, equipment rentals, supervised skiing and lunch, are $55.
The regular cost of lift tickets: $38 full day; $27 half-day; children and skiers 65 and over, $17 full day and $12 half-day. Discounts are available on passes for three days or more.
For Nonskiers At the top of Heavenly's aerial tram, a full-service restaurant offers a view of the entire Tahoe Basin. But the area's primary nonskiing attraction lies nearly 2,000 feet below, in the miniature version of Las Vegas in Stateline, Nev. Heavenly provides free shuttle service to and from the south shore's hotel casinos. Caesar's Tahoe, Harrah's Tahoe, Harvey's Resort Hotel and the Horizon Radisson Resort are a few minutes' drive from Heavenly's California base lodge in South Lake Tahoe. Caesar's has a nightly hypnotist show at $12, and Harrah's and the Radisson have cabaret shows for $11. For reservations and information: Caesar's, (800) 648-3353; Harrah's, (800) 648-3773; Harvey's, (800) 553-1022; the Radisson, (800) 333-3333 for accommodations, (702) 588-6211 for shows.
South Lake Tahoe and Stateline have more than 50 hotels, motels and condominiums. Heavenly's reservations service provides information and makes reservations at most of them, and arranges car rentals and airline flights.
Two paddle-wheelers offer sightseeing tours of the lake in the afternoon, and dinner-dance cruises in the evening. The glass-bottomed Tahoe Queen, (916) 541-3364, cruises daily, year round. Fares: $14 daytime, $18 evening; children under 12: $5 daytime, $9 evening. Dinner entrees start at $18. The Ms. Dixie, (702) 588-3508, tours daily February to November, Saturdays only December and January. $12 daytime, $31 evening, including dinner.
 
 
COLORADO

 
ASPEN
Post Office Box 1248, Aspen, Colo. 81612
central reservations, (800) 262-7736; daily snow reports and calendar of events, (900) 740-2773 ($1.50 a minute)
On the Slopes Many skiers visualize financiers and famous faces skiing down Ruthie's Run or dancing at the Caribou Club until the wee hours. They're here -- as well as thousands of other skiers determined to have a good time in this fabled playground. Aspen, spawned in a silver boom during the late 1800's, now relies on snow. The resort actually offers four ski areas, which together encompass 3,700 acres of skiable terrain filled with more than 260 trails and open bowls. There is shuttle bus service around town and between the ski areas.
Aspen Mountain, an expert's nirvana, towers 3,267 vertical feet above the town. The black diamond terrain like the curves on Bell Mountain, Walsh's and Elevator Shaft and the intermediate cruising through Copper Bowl and on Ruthie's Run are all accessible via the speedy Silver Queen gondola and seven chairs.
Snowmass is an intermediate skier's area sprawled over several peaks surrounding a pedestrian-oriented village in a valley 12 miles from Aspen. The half-mile-wide Big Burn and Elk Camp provide the ultimate terrain for wide-open turns. There's also plenty of beginner terrain, as well as some entertaining advanced runs and challenging off-piste stretches for experts. The vertical drop is 3,615 feet.
Tiehack-Buttermilk Mountain (2,030 vertical feet) is the site for five-day intensive learning programs. It's a compact, prime teaching mountain that may have shorter lift lines than the other two ski areas owned by Aspen Skiing Corporation (Aspen and Snowmass).
The resort's fourth ski mountain, the independently owned Aspen Highlands, has challenging terrain for intermediates and experts, from the open Thunderbowl section to the precipitous Steeplechase runs.
The Aspen Skiing Company multiday lift tickets (good at Aspen Mountain, Snowmass and Tiehack/Buttermilk) are cheaper if purchased with lodging. Buy the four-area ticket book and lunch is free (up to $10) when you use it at Aspen Highlands. This year Aspen Highlands lift tickets rates have been reduced 25 percent -- to $30 daily. The four-area book is $156 for four of five days; and $228 for six of seven days. The Aspen Skiing Company ticket (for three mountains) is $152 for four of five days, and $222 for six of seven days. Rates for children and people 64 and over are about 40 percent less.
For Nonskiers Many people go to Aspen and never ski. Aspen is a true "shop till you drop" town, where purchases range from $10 T-shirts to $10,000 furs. Curious George Collectibles, (303) 925-3315, has Western Americana; Junior Mountain Sports, (303) 925-7889, stylish children's skiwear; and Pitkin Country Dry Goods Leathers, (303) 925-6204, fine leather apparel. The culture connection remains strong during the wintertime. There are many art galleries to explore, as well as the Aspen Art Museum, (303) 925-8050; admission $2. Try the Squash Blossom, (303) 925-3214, for traditional and contemporary Native American Indian jewelry, pottery and artworks, and the Heather Gallery, (303) 925-6170, for contemporary American crafts. The restored Wheeler Opera House, (303) 925-2750, is the scene for entertainment ranging from Harry Connick Jr. to the Nutcracker. At the Crystal Palace dinner theater-cabaret, (303) 925-1455, the staff waits on tables, then acts in a satirical revue based on people in the news. Its season starts Dec. 12.
History buffs should stop by the Aspen Historical Society, (303) 925-3721, for information on walking tours. Other nonskier activities include fishing in the Roaring Fork River, hot-air ballooning over the ski slopes, dogsled rides into the wilderness, sleigh rides to the Pine Creek Cookhouse, (303) 925-1044, two-stepping classes at the Cowboy Bar in the Silvertree Hotel, and snowmobiling into the wilderness. For more information contact Aspen central reservations, (800) 262-7736, or Snowmass central reservations, (800) 332-3245.
 
BRECKENRIDGE
Post Office Box 1058, Breckenridge, Colo. 80424
Lodging, (800) 221-1091; snow conditions, (303) 453-6118
On the Slopes Peaks 8, 9 and 10 make up the interconnected Breckenridge ski area, with a total of 112 trails. Half the runs are designated most difficult, a third are for intermediates and the remaining 20 percent are for beginners. At 12,998 feet, Peak 8 is the highest of the three mountains and offers the longest run of 3.5 miles. The vertical rise is about 3,400 feet.
Six-day lift pass: $174 and $90 for children and seniors aged 60 to 69. Seniors over 70 and children under 5 ski free.
A wristwatch with its intricate works exposed, soaring eagles and 10-foot elves and other marvelous statuary hewn from ice accent this trim town's Main Street every winter, making a casual stroll an essential part of the visit.
For Nonskiers Breckenridge, 85 miles west of Denver, is host of the International Snow Sculpture Championships, and this winter up to 16 teams of artisans will carve ice models depicting both abstract and realistic themes. The competition is being held Jan. 8-12, and the sculptures stay up until Feb. 1, weather permitting.
Standing a good deal more permanently behind the frosty and temporal display are more than 300 Victorian buildings, preserved in what is Colorado's largest National Historic District. Breckenridge is the oldest continually occupied town on the state's Western Slope. As a town and gold mining center, it peaked in the 1860's, when its population reached about 8,000. Prospectors quickly moved on to more promising gold fields, and as was so often the case the town barely existed until its revival as a ski resort in the 1960's. The Summit Historical Society can give information on both walking and mining tours (303-453-9022).
Many restaurants and boutiques and T-shirt shops line the route of the ice statuary so an ice tour does not have to be without its ulterior motive. Or, walkers can try to find their way through A Maze 'n Breckenridge, a confounding configuration of wood walls that changes weekly. Skating on Maggie Pond, sleigh rides and dogsledding for novices and children are also available.
The full-service Breckenridge Spa, (303) 453-9300, opened this year, along with 15 guest rooms and its restaurant overlooking the Continental Divide. For those who prefer indoor athletics and outdoor exercise other than skiing, it offers racquetball, a gymnasium and indoor pool as well as facials, herbal wraps and hot tubs. More guest rooms and a conference center are planned. The Breckenridge Recreation Center, (303) 453-5579, is scheduled to open in January with a swimming pool, gymnasium and tennis courts.
The ski area pays its annual tribute to Ullr, the Norse God of Snow and Winter, with a torchlight ski parade and children's events during the Ullr Fest from Jan. 12 to 19.
A 20-minute bus ride to the Silverthorne factory outlets expands the shopping universe considerably; more than 50 name-brand retail stores sell clothes and housewares at discounts.
 
KEYSTONE
Keystone Resort, Box 38, Keystone, Colo. 80435
Lodging, (800)-222-0188; snow conditions, (303) 468-4111
On the Slopes Keystone's expansion is the largest in the ski industry this year, and it increases the resort's skiable acreage by almost 40 percent. The Outback's 17 new trails feature glade skiing (terrain dotted with trees) and are geared for the advanced-intermediate and expert skier. More than half of all runs cater to intermediates, about 30 percent are for beginners, including a three-mile cruising run. The largest night skiing operation in the country enables skiers to stay on the mountain until 10 every night.
The Keystone area embraces four mountains: Keystone, North Peak, the Outback and Arapahoe Basin. Arapahoe's summit elevation of 12,450 feet usually assures skiing into early June.
Six-day lift ticket: $174 and $84 for children under 12. Six-day Ski-the-Summit ticket for Keystone, Breckinridge and Copper Mountain is $198 and $102 for children.
For Nonskiers While most of the $32 million that Keystone is spending this year is designated for improving and expanding downhill skiing amenities, nonskiers will be able to enjoy a chunk of it as well. The $6 million stone Outpost, at 11,444 feet on North Peak, is billed as America's highest full-service restaurant, and can be reached by nonskiers the year round via two gondolas, one new this year. Winter hours are 9 A.M. to 10 P.M.
Keystone resort maintains the largest outdoor ice skating rink in the country, open from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily. The fee is $5 for all day; skates can be rented, also for $5. There are two indoor tennis courts (court fee is $17 an hour), a weight room, and 11 swimming pool facilities with sauna and whirlpool at the various condonimiums. The pools are available free to guests staying at the resort. The Silverthorne shopping area is 10 minutes away by free shuttle bus.
At the 10-year-old Keystone Science School in the valley, visitors can attend the Mountain Speaker Series of nature talks every Friday evening from early January to mid-April. Admission is $4. Call (303) 468-5824 for more information, or write to the Keystone Science School Box 606, Keystone, Colo. 80435.
 
STEAMBOAT
Steamboat Ski Corporation, 2305 Mount Werner Circle, Steamboat Springs, Colo. 80487
Lodging, (800) 922-2722; snow report, (303) 879-7300
On the Slopes The area's 2,500 acres of trails cover a complete mountain range: Sunshine, Storm, Thunderhead and Christie Peaks. Its 3,600-foot vertical rise is second highest in Colorado (after Aspen Highlands). Steamboat says that it receives more snow than anywhere else along the Rocky Mountains in Colorado, with a seasonal average of 25 feet. Fifty-four percent of the resort's runs are rated for intermediate skiers, 31 percent are for advanced skiers, and 15 percent are for beginners.
Steamboat's latest offering for intermediate and advanced skiers is the Billy Kidd Center for Performance Skiing. The teaching methods are based on those developed by the Olympic gold medalist Billy Kidd and employ video and playback equipment on the slopes for instant critiques. A two-day instruction course is $280. For reservations or information call (303) 879-6111, extension 543.
Six-day lift tickets are $210. Children age 12 and under ski free when parents purchase a five-day or longer lift ticket and stay a minimum of five nights at a participating lodging.
 For Nonskiers The town of Steamboat Springs, named for the hot mineral waters chugging out of the earth, exudes a cowboy charm. The verdant Yampa Valley, where the resort is situated, contains some of the best grazing land in the state; the sprawling cattle ranches that remain may no longer thrive, but they do manage. Stetsons and cowboy boots, often paired with ski suits, are a part of the uniform in town.
The Steamboat Springs Health and Recreational Association, (303) 879-1828, puts the natural mineral water to use in an Olympic-size lap pool and three hot mineral pools. They are open daily from 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. and admission is $4.50. Weight room, saunas and massages are also available. For a more natural outdoor setting, and bathing, there are bus tours to the Strawberry Park Hot Springs, four miles away in the mountains above town.
At Inner Links, (303) 879-2916, nonskiers can play golf indoors from 10 A.M. to 2 A.M. daily. Several stables offer horseback riding all winter.
The exhilaration of the Continental Divide is available to nonskiers with Steamboat Snowmobile Tours, (303) 879-6500. The two-hour guided trips cruise through the Routt National Forest and cost $55 a person for two hours, $20 for children. A program that includes sleigh-ride dinners, afternoon elk feeding trips by sleigh and bungee jumping from a hot-air balloon is organized by Windwalker Tours, (800) 748-1642.
From 6 to 10 P.M., skiers can ride a chairlift up and a bobsled down Howelsen Hill for almost 5,000 feet of lighted track, weather permitting, (303) 879-2170. Rides are $7 a person, or a 10-ride card for $50.
Fully accredited medical, dental and legal courses and meetings are run throughout the ski season. The American Educational Institute, (800) 354-3507, and the Association for Continuing Education, (800) 525-3402, can supply more information.
 
TELLURIDE
Telluride Ski Resort, 562 Mountain Village Boulevard, Post Office Box 11155, Telluride, Colo. 81435
Lodging, (800) 525-3455; snow report, (303) 728-3614
On the Slopes Among skiers Telluride is famous for its fearsome vertical chutes and expert pitches, which comprise a quarter of the ski area. Fifty-one percent of the trails are designated intermediate, and 24 percent beginner. One of the three mountain faces, Sunshine Peak, is dedicated to beginners and is served by its own high-speed quad and a mountain restaurant. There are four runs each two and half miles long. As ski areas go, Telluride is comparatively small, with a ski terrain of 656 acres and an uphill capacity of 10,000 skiers an hour.
What sets this resort apart is the magnificent scenery. From anywhere on the mountain the skier gets a panorama of the 14,000-foot peaks of the San Juan range.
A lift ticket good for six out of seven days is $186; $120 for children.
For Nonskiers Today there are two Tellurides. The first is the silver-mining camp settled in the 1870's that is now a National Historic Landmark District. The Victorian architecture has been well preserved and is framed by mountains towering about 5,000 feet above the street on three sides. Just over the ridge is the Mountain Village, which reflects the latest in modern resort development: condominiums and the Doral Telluride Resort and Spa, scheduled to open in April 1992. Art galleries and upscale boutiques have been filtering in among the T-shirt emporiums and bars.
The locality was once an important hunting ground for Ute Indians. The best information about the diversity of Indian cultures in the region is available out of town. The Anasazi Heritage Center west of Dolores, (303) 882-4811, and the Cortez Center, (303) 565-1151, are open year round and, weather permitting, a visit to the Yellowjacket archeological site, about 15 miles northwest of Cortez, is possible. Either trip would take most of the day.
Telluride, a town of festivals, sponsors Winter Wine '92, which will feature a five-course dinner matched by wines, Jan. 29 and 30. Proceeds will be donated to the 11th Telluride Wine Festival to be held next summer.
Real estate is currently the town's booming industry, as vacant land and houses are selling at a brisk pace at the Mountain Village and in old Telluride. A nonskier can always spend the day touring dream homes.

VAIL
Vail, Post Office Box 7, Vail, Colo. 81658
Vail reservations, (800) 525-2257; Beaver Creek
reservations, (800) 622-3131; snow report,
(303) 476-4888 or 476-4889
On the Slopes When skiers visit this resort, they get two mountains for the price of one: Vail and Beaver Creek, 10 miles down the highway. Between the two, covered by the same lift ticket, skiers have a choice of 31 lifts to mountaintop beginner areas, long intermediate runs, relentless bump runs, children's fantasy mountains and extensive back bowls. There is shuttle bus service around town and between the ski areas.
Vail's skiable terrain spans seven miles, from the trails on Lionshead to the boundaries of China Bowl. (The view is spectacular from the new Two Elk Restaurant.) The network of 20 lifts, including 7 high-speed chairs, opens up more than 3,834 acres of terrain. The Back Bowls alone encompass 2,600 acres, a space within which one could fit many an Eastern ski area.
Grouse Mountain, a 1,808-vertical-foot peak, opens this winter, adding 110 acres of primarily advanced terrain to Beaver Creek. Those who previewed Grouse Mountain via Sno-Cat last winter say the new peak adds a needed diversity of terrain. Beginners have a mountaintop playground; the intermediate trails wind down the mountainside, often around large stands of trees, creating an illusion -- reinforced by panoramic views of the Gore and Sawatch mountain ranges -- of skiing in the wilderness. The intimidating Birds of Prey runs challenge advanced skiers.
In the children's ski areas, set within Vail and Beaver Creek, some of the skichool classes are led through "adventure zones" by costumed Western characters searching for treasure on Vail Mountain or hunting outlaws holed up at Beaver Creek.
Lift tickets are $40 a day, $27 for children; five-day tickets are $19, $200 Dec. 22 to Jan. 2; seven-day tickets are $259, $280 Dec. 22 to Jan. 2.
For Nonskiers You don't have to be a skier to enjoy Vail. The town exudes a cosmopolitan aura, from the accents of strolling shoppers to the window displays featuring souvenir mugs and chains dangling golden bears. Dining ranges from burgers at Bart and Yeti's to deep-fried spinach gnocchi or crabmeat ravioli in a carrot butter sauce at L'Ostello's. There are gallery walks during the winter, including stops at such diverse galleries as the Squash Blossom and the Cogswell. The night life beat throbs out on the sidewalks from clubs like Sheika's, (303) 476-1515, to Club Majiks, (303) 476-2626, a dinner theater presenting contemporary revues.
The wilderness is open to those who don't downhill ski. Some beautiful scenery can be admired while snowmobiling to Piney River Ranch, set alongside an alpine lake at the base of the 13,000-foot peaks of the Gore Range. There are morning ($60), afternoon ($60) and all-day tours ($110) and sunset dinner tours ($75). Information: the Adventure Company at (303) 476-9090 or Piney River Ranch, (303) 476-3941.
Visitors may also ride in a Sno-Cat-pulled sleigh through the snow-laden woods to Beano's Cabin for dinner ($69 and $46 for children). A spa day can be taken at Cordillera, (303) 926- 2200, or the Hyatt, 949-1234.
Hot-air ballooning over the slopes, ice fishing at Nottingham lake, ice skating at the Dobson Ice Arena and dogsledding are other outdoor options. Another is a ride on Vail's bobsled, $11 a ride; if the line is long, purchase a ticket, ask how long a wait, then return later. Riders reach speeds up to 50 miles an hour on the twisting 2,900-foot-long course. The Beaver Creek activities desk, (303) 949-9090, has more information and reservations for most of the activities.
 
 
NEW MEXICO

 
TAOS SKI VALLEY
Taos Ski Valley, N.M. 87525
(505) 776-2291; for information; reservations in the ski valley and in town, Taos Valley Resort Association, (800) 992-7669, or Taos Central Reservations, (800) 821-2437
On the Slopes It doesn't make a difference what type of terrain the skier enjoys. It's all here, from a small never-ever's learning hill at the base to chutes off the uppermost ridges that experts willing to hike are eager to ski. In between, there's a mountain that has been opened up to skiing but not tamed. The excitement comes, in part, from cruising down intermediate trails that incorporate (instead of smoothing over) the interesting rolls, humps and natural contours of the mountain.
Most skiers visiting Taos for a week put themselves in ski school, even if they are experts or former ski instructors. It's a skill-level form of rat packing, especially for better skiers. Advanced skiers who wouldn't dream of taking classes elsewhere will follow a Taos instructor down super-steep Stauffenberg and moguled Inferno, through the wooded Walkyries and on other precipitous terrain they wouldn't consider tackling alone.
Last summer, top-to-bottom snowmaking was installed on the west side of the 2,612-vertical-foot mountain. A quad chair was added, replacing the Kachina lift (keeping the number of lifts at 10), which should ease lift lines in Kachina Bowl. These improvements complement overall upgrading in recent years, from the addition of the Seventh Heaven chair to new base area buildings.
Daily lift tickets are $34, childrens' tickets, $19; multiday lift tickets (three days or more), $31 a day and $17 per child.
For Nonskiers Staying slopeside on one of the lodging, meals and lifts packages is a "10" for skiers, but non skiers might be happier lodging in the town of Taos, a 20- minute ride down the mountainside. (There are shuttle services to the mountain for skiers staying in town.) Residing in a bed and breakfast inn, like the Casa de Las Chimeneas, insures leisurely mornings and a short stroll to downtown. The Taos Bed and Breakfast Association at (800) 876-7857, supplies information on choices, and puts together ski packages.
The first view of Taos Plaza, surrounded by parked cars and pickup trucks, makes one wonder if Taos hasn't been oversold. But the city's charm creeps into the psyche as you wander along side streets lined with sun-washed reddish adobe casas and explore galleries rich with Indian artifacts, Southwestern paintings, and leather and woven clothing. The small museums display Kit Carson memorabilia and Maria Martinez's lustrous black pots, and then there is the Taos Pueblo, where Native American residents sell handmade crafts, jewelry and bread baked in outdoor ovens, and the St. Francisco de Asis Church.
The shops and galleries are a treasure trove of art, crafts, jewelry, kachina dolls and hand-made clothing; it's also a junk shopper's heaven stocked with T-shirts, cheap souvenirs and assembly-line paintings.
Art lovers should visit the Millicent Rogers Museum, (505) 758-2462, for its exceptional collection of Southwestern Native American and Hispanic art, and the Ernest Blumenschein Home and Museum, (505) 758-0330, the adobe home of a co-founder of the Taos Society of Artists.
Information about the town, museum hours, a list of galleries and a calendar of winter events are available from the Taos Chamber of Commerce, (800) 732-8267.
Santa Fe, with its galleries and museums, is one and a half hours away by car.
 
 
 
UTAH

 
PARK CITY
Post Office Box 39, Park City, Utah 84060
(801) 649-8111; lodging, (800) 222-7275; Deer Valley
Resort, (800) 424-3337
On the Slopes Remnants of Park City's silver-mining heyday, trimmed with the contemporary veneer of a modern resort town, are surrounded by three markedly different ski areas. But this season one of them, ParkWest, may not operate. The owner is considering an expansion program to make ParkWest more profitable. Local shuttle buses -- free -- move around town and between the slopes, the other two being Park City and Deer Valley.
A gondola and 12 chairlifts take skiers to the 80 designated trails and large bowls at Park City, which has a vertical drop of 3,100 feet. Runs for all skill levels flow off many lifts here, so friends can sit together on the way up but pursue their own excitement level on the way down. The runs off the Town lift offer high grade intermediate cruising and a view of the town's Victorian roof line. Precipitous Jupiter Bowl is a favorite haunt of experts.
When Deer Valley opened 11 years ago, it created a benchmark for service that other resorts are still scrambling to reach. From the elaborate lunchtime buffets in the base lodge to the careful grooming on the slopes, it projects a country club atmosphere. Thirteen lifts open up 83 trails and 650 acres of bowl skiing, including wide runs for beginners and intermediates, and steep slopes, glades and bumps cascading down the sides of Mayflower Bowl for the advanced. Last year's addition of Flagstaff Mountain added some intermediate runs.
Park City Ski Area daily lift tickets are $39 and $18 for children; five-of-six-days tickets are $180, $88 for children; six-of-seven-days tickets are $216 and $104 for children. Deer Valley daily: $41 and $26 for children, $18 for those aged 3 and younger. Three-of-seven-day tickets: $117, $72 for children; six-of-seven-days, $222 and $138.
For Nonskiers Nonskiers can walk down the same streets miners and gunslingers used to prowl, but today the Victorian buildings that housed saloons and brothels contain tourist-oriented businesses. There are more than 80 shops and galleries among the 45 restaurants.
Outside the town limits, visitors snowmobile through forested canyons, across open meadows and up to high ridges offering panoramic views of the Wasatch Range. Visitors can take a sleigh ride through the countryside and follow it with a five-course dinner at a country inn. Contact the Homestead Resort at (800) 327-7220 for information about snowmobiling and dinner sleigh rides. The Norwegian School of Nature Life, (801) 649-5322, arranges cross-country ski treks, cabin or snow cave overnights and other trips into the wilderness. More sedentary visitors might prefer a hot-air balloon ride with inflight champagne and a postflight brunch. For details, Balloon Affaire at (800) 658-8489.
Casino Caravans, (800) 876-5825, runs buses to the casinos in Wendover, Nev., on Wednesday and Thursday evenings. The two-and-a-half-hour ride passes quickly because there's bingo and roulette on board. The trip costs $14; riders receive $11 in coin as they step off the bus to enter the casinos.
To see the big city, visitors can hop on one of the frequent buses bringing Salt Lake City skiers to the slopes as it starts the return trip. They can stroll around Utah's No. 1 attraction: Temple Square, the symbolic heart of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The free tours, led by missionaries, include stops in most buildings and a verbal history of the Mormons' journey to Salt Lake City and the early years of struggle. For more information about what to see and do, contact the Salt Lake City Convention and Visitors Bureau, 180 South West Temple, Salt Lake City, Utah 84101; (801) 521-2868.
 
SNOWBIRD
Snowbird Ski and Summer Resort, Utah 84092-6019
801-742-2222; lodging, 800-453-3000
On the Slopes This self-contained resort is a concrete citadel guarding a narrow gap in Little Cottonwood Canyon. The 125-passenger tram ascends rapidly over steep slopes that lure experts, although there's an intermediate-rated "sightseer's" way down, wending across the mountain's front face. The network of open slopes for intermediates is nearby on the 3,100 vertical-foot mountain, and easily accessible from the resort's seven chairs. There is a separate beginners' learning area.
The ski school offers several programs in addition to the regular classes. Skiing Enhancement clinics are for adults who desire a blend of skiing and coaching. Intermediate Adventure days are for those who want to progress to parallel skiing and beyond. Super Clinics are for the advanced and experts eager to expand skiing versatility in special situations and conditions.
Some skiers take a shuttle bus to explore the slopes at Alta, three miles up the canyon road. Set at the end of the canyon, which traps extra feet of snow, Alta (2,050 vertical feet) is noted for powder skiing and scary steeps. But there are plenty of open runs and bowls for intermediates off the seven chairs.
Snowbird is celebrating its 20th anniversary this winter with a three-day party beginning Dec. 5.
Snowbird's all-area lift tickets including the tram are $36 a day, $21 for children; chairlifts only, $29 and $16 for children. Five-day tickets are $160; three days, $96. Children 12 and under ski free with an accompanying adult lift ticket purchase when lodging in their parents' room at Snowbird at a nightly rate. Alta's all-day tickets are $21.
For Nonskiers Snowbird is a choice spot for visitors who want to be pampered in a spa. The Cliff Spa, in the slopeside Cliff Hotel, offers as complete a list of amenities as one will find in any major United States facility. Massages, either plain or hydro, herbal and parafango wraps, and salt glows are offered, as well as salon services ranging from haircuts and coloring to Hawaiian pedicures. Aerobic classes are offered daily. The spa has a variety of full and half-day treatment packages but reservations are required for all services and visitors should call at least two weeks prior to arrival during peak weeks. (801) 742-2222, extension 5900 for spa, extension 5960 for salon.
Apart from the spa, on-site activities are limited at Snowbird. However, Salt Lake City is 25 minutes down the canyon, and people staying in Snowbird can step on one of the buses bringing Salt Lake City skiers to the slopes and join the return trip.
 
WYOMING

 
JACKSON HOLE
Post Office Box 290, Teton Village, Wyo. 83025
Information, (307) 733-2292; reservations, (800) 443-6931; snow conditions, (307) 733-2291
On the Slopes Jackson Hole ski area is draped across 2,500 acres of mountainside. Although long regarded as an advanaced skier's area, only one of the two peaks, Rendezvous, with a vertical drop of 4,139 feet, deserves that reputation. The other, Apres Vous (2,170 vertical feet), has been tamed and recontoured in recent years into choice intermediate terrain. The tram (63 passengers), seven chairs and two high-speed Poma lifts, open up the bowls and interconnecting trails, so few skiers realize they are moving between two mountains.
Advanced and expert skiers zoom uphill in the tram to challenge Rendezvous's many chutes, steep trails and relentless bump runs. Intermediates steer toward Easy Does It, lower Gros Ventre and St. John's for the training required to tackle steeper pitches. Beginners have a small network of trails on the lower part of Apres Vous Mountain.
Powderhounds know about heading for Grand Targhee Ski Resort, on the other side of the Grand Teton, a day or two after a big snowfall. It's a great place for an introductory powder lesson. Targhee also offers Sno-Catskiing on neighboring Peaked Peak. There's shuttle bus service from Jackson Hole to Grand Targhee.
Daily lift tickets at Jackson Hole are $38, $19 for children age 14 and under and for those age 65 and over; tram rides are $2 each and a valid chairlift ticket. Three-day lift tickets, $114, $57 for childen; seven-day tickets, $224 and $112.
For Nonskiers This naturally beautiful valley, ringed by jagged mountain peaks, anchors a host of outdoor entertainment. Thousands of elk spend winter in the National Elk Refuge managed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, which offers horse-drawn sleigh rides through the herds. Rides are $7.50 and $3.50 for children ages 6 to -12. More information: (307) 733-9212.
One entrance to Yellowstone National Park is approximately one hour away. Visitors may ride through the park in a heated snow coach, or steer a rented snowmobile on park roads toward Old Faithful, arriving in time to watch the geyser blow its top.
Several companies offer snowmobiling tours (which include warm suits and boots) along wooded roads in Grand Teton and open powder meadows on Togwotee Pass with its fine views of the valley. Tucked in the back of a dog-driven sled is another way to admire the scenery. Trekking along some of the cross-country trails threading these national parks is another option. After dark, the visitor may step into a horse-drawn sleigh for dinner at a cozy log cabin or heated yurt. If you want to see the bighorn sheep, elk, deer and other wildlife up close, sign on for a wildlife safari with a biologist, (307) 733-2623. For an overview, on a par with the bald eagles who soar over this region, there are plane, helicopter and balloon flights.
Cowboys have been hanging around Jackson Hole much longer than skiers, so the town displays an intriguing mixture of Wild West ambiance and nouveau ski area chic. There are art and photography galleries, boutiques and shops on the streets around the park, with its archways of elk antlers, in the middle of the town of Jackson, 12 miles from the slopes. The resident dance and music companies offer wintertime performances. The Jackson Arts Center at (307) 733-5465 supplies information on arts and events.
After dinner or a concert, visitors can stop by the Million Dollar Cowboy Bar or the Rancher and start two-stepping on the dance floor, or belly up to the Wort Hotel's silver dollar-studded bar for a pick-me-up. Without a doubt, there will a blue-jeaned real-life wrangler within a bar stool or two.
A Jackson Hole winter planner, which lists activities, can be had from the Jackson Hole Visitors Council, Post Office Box 982, Jackson, Wyo. 83001; (800) 782-0011.
 
 
 
THE NORTHEAST
MAINE

 
SHAWNEE PEAK
R.R. 1, Box 734, Bridgton, Me. 04009
General and snow conditions, (207) 647-8444; lodging
information available from three property managers: Bridgton Group, (207) 647-2591; Foster Property Management, (207) 647-8093; Chalmers Property Management, (207) 647-3311.
On the Slopes Shawnee Peak is Maine's oldest ski area, having noted its 50th anniversary under its previous name and ownership as Pleasant Mountain three years ago. With a vertical drop of 1,300 feet, Shawnee Peak offers 30 trails, rating them as 25 percent novice, 50 percent more difficult and 25 percent black diamond. This terrain is served by a triple and three double chairlifts and a T-bar. The area has 98 percent snowmaking and offers New England's largest night skiing facility daily.
The mountain offers group and private ski and snowboard lessons and packages. It does not offer cross-country skiing, although cross-country equipment rentals and trail information are available in local ski shops. The property agencies named above make reservations for condos and bed and breakfasts.
Lift prices are $25 midweek and $31 weekends and holidays, with special morning, afternoon, twilight, night and junior rates. Skiers 7 and younger ski free with parents, and skiers 70 and older ski free as well.
For Nonskiers Bridgton is a charming New England village, and it does have some attractions, although, like Shawnee Peak, it doesn't boast the full range of nonskiing activities of bigger destination resorts.
Bridgton abounds in antique shops. Although most are open for the summer only, many shops will open to satisfy a search for specific items; consult listing in Yellow Pages. Two big shops that are open are Wales & Hamblen, on Main Street, Bridgton, (207) 647-8344, open 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesday through Saturday and noon to 4 Sunday; and Emphasis on Maine, also on Main street, (207) 647-2161, 9:30 to 5:30 seven days a week. Wales & Hamblen rents space to dealers with a range of items from postcards to oak rolltop desks. Emphasis on Maine, not really an antique shop, offers made-in-Maine crafts in staggering variety.
Bridgton has the normal complement of small-town stores; for a mega-outlet center you have to drive over to North Conway, N.H., 20 miles to the west. In addition to its hundred or so national and factory outlets, the North Conway area also boasts indoor tennis and swimming, exercise rooms and spas. The North Conway Chamber of Commerce, (603) 356-3171, will supply details.
 Skating is offered daily from 3 to 6 P.M. and 11 to 6 on weekends by the Bridgton Recreation Department at Town Hall rink. For information call (207) 647-8786.
Film -- the Magic Lantern, Main Street, (207) 647-5065, shows first-run movies daily, with an occasional old or classic film. The Bridgton Historical Society Museum, Gibbs Avenue, is open from Tuesday to Saturday, 1 to 4 P.M.; phone, (207) 647-2765.
 
 
 
NEW HAMPSHIRE

 
WATERVILLE VALLEY
Waterville Valley, N.H. 03215
(603) 236-4174; snow conditions, (603) 236-4144;
lodging, (800) 468-2553 or (603) 236-8371
On the Slopes Although Waterville Valley has received lots of attention for the World Cup slalom and giant slalom races held there almost every spring for the last 11 years, the mountain is best known for delightful intermediate skiing. Of the 48 trails and 255 acres of skiing, only about 20 percent are expert and 20 percent for beginners. There are four double, three triple and one quad lift along with four surface lifts.
Off the 2,000-foot vertical rise, the wide slopes and groomed runs attract a large contingent of repeat visitors from Boston, about two-and-a-half hours away. One reason is the midweek frequent-skier card that gradually reduces the lift ticket prices from $30 a day, and $26 for people over age 55, to $14 after the sixth visit. Weekend and holiday rates are $37 a day, $24 for juniors 12 and under; juniors pay $20 a day during midweek periods. Children 5 and under and seniors 70 and over ski free.
A second ski center called Snow's Mountain has an additional five easy trails and one chairlift. Cross-country skiing is available on 70 kilometers of groomed and tracked trails. Daily fees are $11 and $8 for juniors on weekends, $8 and $5 in midweek.
Two on-mountain restaurants enable skiers to extend the ski experience through lunch. The Schwendi Hutte near the summit offers hearty meals and spectacular views, while the Sunnyside-Up Lodge has a cafeteria open for breakfast and lunch. At the base lodge there is a cafeteria and the World Cup Bar and Grill for lunch and apres ski. The Silver Streaks days for skiers 55 and over is one of the area's most popular programs, growing from 50 people three years ago to 500 last season. The "Streakers" have their own gathering spot in the base lodge and ski together at lower prices from Monday through Thursday. They also have instruction clinics, races and parties through the season.
For Nonskiers Just a shuttle-bus ride away from the mountain is the Waterville Valley Village and Town Square with six lodges, condominiums, eight restaurants and 10 shops and boutiques. Here also is the center of activities for nonskiers and tired skiers. The focal point is the Sports Center with indoor tennis courts, squash and racquetball, a running track, an indoor swimming pool, whirlpool, saunas, steam baths, aerobics classes and fitness training equipment. Massages are available and there is a Mexican restaurant on the premises.
Use of the Sports Center (full-weight room, bicycles, pool, aerobics room) is free for guests in the lodges; there is a $20-an-hour court fee for tennis, $15 for racquetball and squash. Call (603) 236-8303 for more information.
Snowshoeing was introduced at Waterville last year and this season there will be a triathlon on Jan. 11 in which competitors will do cross-country skiing and speed skating as well as snowshoeing. Rental shoes cost $6 a day. Snowshoe hikers use trails on the golf course. For information call the Cross-Country Center at (603) 236-4666.
The ice arena in the Town Square is open all day for skating at $3.50 a person. Weekly broomball tournaments on the ice -- with competitors wearing sturdy boots rather than skates -- are held in the evening and are open to all for $3.50. To obtain times and dates, call (603) 236-8311.
Horsedrawn sleigh rides around the valley depart hourly from the Town Square. The sleighs hold 20 passengers and seats may be reserved for families or groups as well as individuals seeking a quiet ride in the woods. Fees are $10, $6 for children. Information: (800) 468-2553 or (603) 236-8371. The Waterville Valley town recreation department offers an apres-ski program for children and families at the school gym near the resort's lodges. Among the activities are basketball, volleyball, crafts, bingo nights, dances and ice cream socials. Some activities are free, others cost $1 to $3. Information: (603) 236-4695.

 
 
NEW YORK

 
WHITEFACE MOUNTAIN
Route 86, Wilmington, N. . 12997
(518) 946-2223; snow conditions, (800) 462-6236; lodging, (800) 447-5224 or (518) 523-2445; event information, (800) 462-6236
On the Slopes Whiteface gained fame from two Olympics, 1932 and 1980, but for many skiers its true distinction lies in the mountain's contradictions. The 3,216-foot vertical rise holds some of the steepest trails in the East, as well as some of the easiest beginner terrain. Intermediates, however, may be disappointed with the size of the selection in between. In total there are 65 trails on 150 acres of terrain and more than 90 percent of the runs can be covered with machine-made snow. Few skiers will be disappointed with the space and uncrowded slopes or the usually short lines at Whiteface's two triple and seven double chairlifts.
Prices for lifts are $32, $20 for juniors 12 and under on weekends and holidays, and $28 and $17 during midweek periods. Until Dec. 22 and after March 16, lifts cost $20 and $14, while children 6 and under and seniors 70 and over ski free all season.
More than 100 miles of cross-country trails, both at Mount Van Hoevenberg, where trail fees are $7, and at other cross-country centers near Whiteface.
The ski area provides a selection of programs for children from 1 to 12. For the little ones there is a nursery offering an all-day supervised program for $3 an hour. When children are ready to ski, from ages 3 to 6, the Play and Ski program is a combination indoor nursery and outdoor ski lesson. Half-day is $20, full day is $38. In the same price category, the Bear's Den is a junior program for kids aged 7 to 12 who are grouped in classes according to ability.
 For Nonskiers Few places offer as wide a variety of winter activities as the combination of Whiteface, Mount Van Hoevenberg and the village of Lake Placid, all within about 10 miles of each other. High on the list of nonskiing activities are the bobsled and luge rides at Mount Van Hoevenberg. The half-mile bobsled ride with a driver and a brakeman is offered Tuesday through Sunday from 1 to 3 P.M. for $25 a person. The final five turns of the luge track can be piloted by riders during the same hours on Saturdays and Sundays at a cost of $10 a person. Information about both rides can be obtained at (800) 462-6236 or (518) 523-4436.
Skating is the second activity for which the region is known. In Lake Placid, the Olympic Arena, built in 1932, is open to the public from 1 to 3 P.M. on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday. Skate rentals are available and entry fees are $3 and $2 for children. The same prices prevail at the nearby Olympic Speed Skating Oval, open from 7 to 9 P.M. midweek and 1 to 3 and 7 to 9 P.M. on weekends. Information for both rinks: (800) 462-6236 or (518) 523-3325. Visitors can find dogsledding, curling, ice fishing, indoor tennis, sledding, sleigh riding, snowmobiling and tobogganing by calling the Lake Placid Visitor's Center at (518) 523-2445.
This winter, Lake Placid will be the site of Olympic trials to select competitors for many of the Olympic events in Albertville, France. Among the spectator events will be ski jumping, luge, biathlon and speed skating. At Whiteface, selections will be made for the freestyle ski team in mogul skiing, aerial maneuvers and ballet skiing. For information about these events: (800) 462-6236 or (518) 513-1655.
 
VERMONT

 
MOUNT SNOW
Mount Snow, Vt. 05356
(802) 464-3333; snow report, (802) 464-2151; reservations, (800) 245-7669 and, in Vermont, (802) 464-8501
On the Slopes The most surprising thing about Mount Snow is its size. Here, in Vermont's Deep South, is a major ski mountain wreathed with slopes and trails for skiers of all abilities. Besides Mount Snow's own four faces (including its recently enlarged south-facing Sunbrook area), ticket holders can now ski Haystack Mountain, three miles away. Mount Snow took over operation of the financially troubled Haystack this fall.
The addition of Haystack gives skiers access to 47 miles of trails and 24 lifts (including two quad and three triple chairlifts). Mount Snow has a 1,700-foot vertical drop. Most of the Haystack and Carinthia trails -- Mount Snow bought neighboring Carinthia Ski Area in 1986 -- are gentle enough for novices and low-intermediates to ski with comfort. But on the North Face, trails like Ripcord, Plummet and Jaws of Death live up to their names.
The most popular way down the mountain is on Exhibition, a wide and moderately pitched mile-and-a-half trail that runs beside the high-speed detachable quad lift, Yankee Clipper. Mount Snow has enough variety of terrain for a family of skiers with widely differing abilities to enjoy separate ski vacations at the same resort.
A one-day adult ticket costs $36 on weekdays, $40 on weekends. A five-day package costs $155. Haystack only, $32 on weekends, $24 midweek.
A tip: On crowded weekends, park the car at the Carinthia base lodge, where you can buy lift tickets and rent equipment. The lot is emptier and lines are shorter than at the main Mount Snow lodge.
 For Nonskiers Mount Snow was the first ski resort designed as a place for nonskiers to have fun. It was created in 1954 by a ski visionary, Walter Schoenknecht. He was much reviled for bringing nonathletes -- especially nonathletes with New York accents -- to the ski slopes. But he was determined to cater to all who wanted to come. To make sure they did, Mr. Schoenknecht created a ski theme park. He built an artificial lake, a gondola to carry visitors over the lake, a heated outdoor swimming pool, and an indoor ice rink. All except the lake (a water source for snowmaking) are gone now, but the spirit of off-slope pleasures remains. During reasonable snow years, the region offers cross-country skiing and snowmobile touring. Mount Snow provides sleigh rides four nights a week. Rides last 45 minutes and cost $12, $8 for children.
Both Snow Lake Lodge and Seasons Condominiums have fitness centers for their guests. The Hermitage, an inn and restaurant, has a game farm that welcomes visitors -- (802) 464-3511. In nearby Wilmington are a historic country store museum, the 1836 Country Store, (802) 464-5102, and a woodworking shop, John McLeod, (802) 464-3332, as well as antique, art, craft and specialty shops, horseback riding, a bowling alley and movie theater.
The Hermitage specializes in game dishes; the Inn at Sawmill Farm offers somewhat bland Continental food in an elegant, formal setting; Le Petit Chef has a largely French menu, and Two Tannery Road is popular with residents. Poncho's Wreck serves Mexican food in rooms filled with nautical paraphernalia, and the area's newest eating place is Panda North, a Chinese restaurant.
For dancing, the Snow Barn and Deacon's Den provide live music several nights a week. Mount Snow's children's programs accommodate skiing and pre-skiing children from 6 weeks to 12 years old.
 
SUGARBUSH
Sugarbush Ski Resort, R.R. Box 350, Warren, Vt. 05674-9993
(802) 583-2381; resort lodging, (800) 451-4213;
reservations in the valley, (800) 537-8427; snow
conditions, (802) 583-7669
 On the Slopes Sugarbush is a resort on the brink of rebirth. Founded as the American St. Moritz, it quickly established itself as the place to ski and be seen skiing in the East. Kennedys, Cassinis, Heinzes and Avons skied here, along with many of New York's leading fashion models. But fashions change, and the glitterati moved on. Despite its outstanding ski mountains, Sugarbush fell behind other resorts in snowmaking, lift capacity and amenities. It was particularly lacking in family activities. In the past two years, Sugarbush has made a major -- and expensive -- effort to regain its place in the snow. Last year the resort replaced its slowest lifts with three quad chairlifts including the Green Mountain Express, billed as "the fastest detachable quad in the world." Snow grooming has also improved and, by next season, a new snowmaking system should be in operation.
Skiers can choose from two major mountains, Sugarbush North (formerly Glen Ellen) and South. With a 4,135-foot summit and 2,600-foot vertical drop, Sugarbush North is the higher of the two and has the greater snowmaking capacity. North's toughest trails are Upper FIS, a broad, steep, and bump-ridden slope, and the aptly named Exterminator, a narrow and precipitous chute. For intermediates, Rim Run winds around the mountain before feeding into the long and gentle Northway. When natural snow is sparse, Which Way is the trail of choice.
While not quite as high or well covered with snowmaking, Sugarbush South has the more interesting trails. Organgrinder, a steep, straight run from the 3,975-foot summit (the vertical drop is 2,400 feet) to the base lodge, is the fastest way down. Jester is the most enjoyable. A classic high-intermediate trail, Jester wanders down from the peak, twisting, turning and reversing on itself as it makes its eccentric way toward the bottom.
A Sugarbush day ticket costs $35 midweek, $38 on weekends and holidays. A five-day midweek pass costs $145 and includes Sunday afternoon skiing and one day's use of the Sugarbush Sports Center.
A tip: Sugarbush South is a true bowl whose broad sides offer a range of terrain and conditions. Its edges may be awash in sunshine while the center is dark and cold. Before getting on a lift, check with the ski patrol for the day's best conditions.
 For Nonskiers While there is no shortage of things to do around Sugarbush, the chief attraction is the area's natural beauty. In a state famous for scenery, the Mad River Valley is outstanding -- massive mountains, narrow valleys, snaking streams. Within the valley, the towns of Waitsfield and Warren combine the look of old Vermont with the feel of new prosperity. Antique shops, art galleries and specialty food markets abound.
Without leaving the valley, the nonskier can try snowshoeing, ice skating, sleigh riding and snowmobiling. Within a half-hour's drive are tours of Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream factory, Cold Hollow Cider Mill, Champlain Chocolates and Vermont Distilleries.
Sugarbush maintains excellent swimming, tennis, squash, racquetball and workout facilities at the Sports Center within minutes of the base lodge. Use of the center costs $12 a day, plus court fees, $12 an hour for tennis, for example. Since last year, the resort has also established an activity program for children and teen-agers.
 
 
 
CANADA
QUEBEC

 
MONT ST.-SAUVEUR
Station Touristique, Mont St.-Sauveur, 350 Rue St. Denis, St.-Sauveur-des-Monts, Quebec JOR 1R3
(514) 227-4671; from Montreal, (514) 871-0101; toll free from Quebec, (800) 363-2426; from Ontario (800) 567-5672
On the Slopes One of 26 ski areas in the Laurentian mountains, Mont St.-Sauveur offers one of the longest ski seasons in Quebec, from November until mid-May. Computerized snowmaking machines allow the long season and insure that 90 percent of the terrain is covered with powder. Less than an hour's drive northwest of Montreal, Mont St.-Sauveur has the best night skiing in Canada. There are 26 runs, 23 of them lighted for night skiing, on a vertical drop of 699 feet. Forty percent of the trails are marked difficult; 40 percent intermediate; 30 percent easy. Skiers ride nine lifts: four quadruple chairs, two triple chairs, two doubles and a small T-bar.
An access trail links the area with an adjacent resort, Mont Avila. Avila's nine runs often appeal to budget-minded families who wish to pay less for lift tickets and ski less terrain.
Lift ticket prices for weekdays: about $24 a day, 4-hour block, $20; evenings (seven nights a week), $21, 4-hour block, $16. Weekends and holidays: $27 a day (includes Mont Avila); 4-hour block, $22. Mont Avila on weekdays: $15, 4-hour block, $11. Weekends and holidays: $23, 4-hour block, $19; evening: $15; 4-hour block, $10. Children under 13, students and people 60 and over pay reduced rates. Children age 5 and under, free. (Prices have been converted to United States dollars on the basis of $1.10 Canadian to the American dollar.)
For Nonskiers The village of St.-Sauveur is Quebec's answer to Aspen or St. Moritz with its night life, boutiques and art galleries. Some of the restored Victorian homes now house discotheques and bars, and it's easy to stay up all night. Bars such as Bourbon Street and Les Nuits Blanches serve alcohol until 2:30 A.M., and several stay open until dawn. There are more than 80 restaurants, including Chinese and Italian.
Art galleries, antique shops and boutiques line the village's two main streets, Rue de la Gare and Rue Principal. There are also four shopping centers and factory outlet stores that feature clothing by Esprit, Benetton and Naf-Naf.
For the fitness minded, guest memberships are available at the fitness center of Le Manoir de St.-Sauveur Hotel, (514) 227-1811, to use the pool, gym, whirlpool, sauna and squash courts. Pool use for nonguests is $8 a day; Nautilus-type equipment in gym, $10 a day; squash courts, $15 a court per hour, $5 racquet rental. Hours are Monday to Saturday, 7 A.M. to 10 P.M.; Sunday, 7 A.M. to 9 P.M. The spa is a five-minute walk from the center of the village.
Superforme, (514) 227-8572, offers aerobic classes, morning and evening from Monday to Saturday, at its studios in the center of town at $7 a class. Day and night ice skating is available at outdoor rinks at no charge but take your own skates, except for the outdoor rink at the base of Mont Habitant. Skates are rented at the resort.
Information about sleigh rides, sugaring-off parties (from mid-December) and horseback riding can be had from the St.-Sauveur Tourist Information desk at the Chamber of Commerce, (514) 227-2564.
The Musee du Ski, in the Faubourg shopping mall at 230 Rue Principal, details the history of skiing in the Laurentians. Open Monday to Thursday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Friday and Saturday, 10 to 9, and Sunday, 10 to 5. Free admission.

 
 
BRITISH COLUMBIA

 
WHISTLER MOUNTAIN
Box 67, Whistler Mountain, British Columbia V0N 1B0
Information and accommodations, from the United States, (800) 944-7853, and (604) 932-4222; ski school programs, (604) 932-3434; recorded snow phone, (604) 932-4191
On the Slopes The Whistler resort consists of both Whistler and Blackcomb mountains with more than 200 runs, including seven alpine bowls. Twenty-five percent of those runs are novice; 55 percent intermediate; 20 percent expert. Both mountains have several double-diamond (difficult) runs. The longest run on Whistler is 6.8 miles, from the peak to the village base. The vertical drop at Whistler is 5,020 feet; at Blackcomb, 5,280 feet.
There are five giant bowls and basins stretched across Whistler's high glacial areas. Seventh Heaven on Blackcomb has two high alpine bowls.
Whistler has 14 lifts: 1 10-passenger high-speed gondola, 3 detachable quads, 3 triple and 2 double chairs, 2 T-bars, 2 handle tows and 1 platter lift. On the top portion of the mountain there's glade skiing -- the transition from treeline to high alpine -- and limitless high-alpine bowl skiing.
Helicopter skiing is available for strong intermediate and advanced skiers. One operator is Whistler Heli-Skiing, (604) 932-4105, which offers three runs (10,000 vertical feet) for $300.
Lift prices: Dual mountain rates: three days, $112; five days, $177; seven days, $242. Prices are valid any day of the year. Whistler mountain only: one day, $36, valid any day. (Prices have been converted to United States dollars on the basis of $1.10 Canadian to the American dollar.)
An eight-mile set of cross-country trails rated beginner to advanced is adjacent to the village at Lost Lake Trails, (604) 932-5535. Children and seniors free. Whistler Golf Course has a beginner trail; no charge.
 For Nonskiers Whistler, 75 miles north of Vancouver, is British Columbia's busiest ski resort, a loosely knit community of hotels, condos, shops and restaurants at the base of the two mountains. It was planned with the pedestrian in mind. Visitors can park and walk along wide outdoor spaces housing shops and restaurants. There are a number of nightclubs, piano lounges and discotheques.
Five lakes in the valley provide natural skating rinks. Municipal Hall (604) 932-5535, has information on conditions. Skate rentals are available only at the K.O.A. Kampground, (604) 932-5181. Canadian Snowshoeing offers three excursions at $22 a person; details from Whistler Activity and Information Center, (604) 932-2394. Parawest Paragliding, (604) 932-7052, offers paragliding on Blackcomb and teaches a day course for $86. A snowmobile tour across back-country powder can be arranged with Whistler Snowmobile Guided Tours, (604) 932-4086.
The Delta Mountain Inn rents covered tennis courts; non-guests should call (604) 932-1982 for rates and times. The Pumphouse Fitness Center in Whistler Creek, six miles from the village, offers a weight room, cardiovascular fitness room and aerobic classes with drop-in membership fees; (604) 932-1984. Mountain Massage Therapy offers a certified shiatsu therapist, registered massage therapists and physiotherapists.
The Whistler Museum and Archives, (604) 932-2019, has displays about Whistler's early days; open weekends and holidays. The Shepard Gallery, 4433 Sundial Place, (604) 938-3366, specializes in contemporary Canadian art. Open daily; evenings Wednesday to Saturday.
From mid-October until mid-April, the Whistler Conference Center presents a series of monthly musical events. On Nov. 23 at 8 P.M. and Nov. 24 at 2 P.M., Benjamin Britten's one-act opera, "Noye's Fludde," the story of Noah's Ark, will be featured. Tickets are $10. Dec. 22 brings a Christmas program of choral music at the Chateau Whistler resort at 4 P.M. Free. Check with the resort for further information on concerts and dates, (604) 938-8000.
Educational seminars are offered by the Whistler Center for Business and the Arts, (604) 932-8310.

HEADLINE: The Boss: Underworked and Overpaid?

BYLINE: By Karen W. Arenson; Karen W. Arenson is the deputy business editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:

IN SEARCH OF EXCESS
The Overcompensation of American Executives.
By Graef S. Crystal.
272 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95. 
 HOW much should a company's top executive be paid? In Plato's view, Graef S. Crystal tells us, no one should earn more than five times the pay of the lowest-paid workers in a community. J. P. Morgan, Mr. Crystal says, suggested a cap of 20 times the pay of the lowest-paid worker in an enterprise.
In this revealing study of executive compensation, Mr. Crystal shows that executive pay in the United States falls nowhere close to either of those guidelines. The typical chief executive of a major American company earns roughly 160 times what the average American worker earns, says Mr. Crystal, an adjunct professor of business at the University of California, Berkeley, and a longtime business consultant. One of his recent studies found that 86 percent of the chief executive officers of 200 big American companies made more than $1 million in base salary -- and that the average pay of these chief executives was $2.8 million if bonuses, stock options and other types of special compensation were included.
Even those numbers pale next to the earnings of some of this country's highest-paid executives. Take Steven J. Ross, chairman of Time Warner Inc., who Mr. Crystal, dubbing him "the Prince of Pay," says is probably the highest-paid chief executive ever of a publicly owned company. Mr. Ross has done well for his shareholders but far better for himself. By Mr. Crystal's calculations -- and he walks the reader through them, step by step -- Mr. Ross took home about $275 million between 1973 and 1989, not counting lavish perquisites or company-financed insurance policies or pension.
Then there's Michael Eisner, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company. He, too, has done quite well for shareholders and for himself. Last year he earned $750,000 in salary plus a bonus of $10.5 million. But his real payoff, Mr. Crystal says, has come from stock options: as Disney's shares have soared under Mr. Eisner's fine touch, so have his generous options grants. He realized a profit of $32.6 million in 1989, when he cashed in some of them, but still has many more left.
That is not to say Mr. Crystal disapproves of all big pay. He says some high-earning executives, such as Mr. Eisner and Anthony O'Reilly of H. J. Heinz, are "good guys"; although they have earned fabulous sums, they would have done less well if their companies' performance had faltered.
What Mr. Crystal does not like is pay plans that rise when a company's earnings do not. Such arrangements include grants of "restricted shares," which the author describes as outright gifts of stock. Among the recipients he cites are Lee Iacocca of Chrysler and Louis V. Gerstner of RJR Nabisco.
He reports on other tricks, too. He points to Coca-Cola, for example, which eased the burden on its chief executive, Roberto Goizueta, by paying not only his salary and bonus but also the taxes on the bonus shares it gave him. Georgia-Pacific went one step farther for its chairman, T. Marshall Hahn, paying not only the taxes on the bonus shares but also the taxes on the taxes, the taxes on that and so forth. At least, Mr. Crystal says, the company set a high standard before the chief executive could take title to all of the shares. It allowed the executive to collect all of the restricted shares granted him only if the stock price had doubled within five years. The stock had to rise by at least 20 percent over five years for the executive to be allowed to claim any of these shares.
Nonetheless, Mr. Crystal concludes that the system is "rotten to the core," though he is quick to confess that as a corporate pay consultant he helped create the problem. Now he is trying to right the wrong by working for shareholder groups and by writing articles -- and "In Search of Excess." The result is a highly informative, very readable indictment of executive pay in the United States, larded with instructive examples.
ABOUT the only quibble I have is the strings of numbers Mr. Crystal presents to show how companies and their executives' pay have grown. Charts or tables might have made the numbers more accessible.
But the figures are there, and so is the message: that the United States cannot afford such extravagance and greed -- particularly when foreign competitors are holding costs down by paying executives considerably less. In Japan, for example, the typical chief executive earns less than 20 times the pay of the average worker. In Germany, the figure is 21 times.
Is there a way out? Mr. Crystal offers some hope and some ideas. He recommends that directors who set executive pay hire their own outside advisers. He suggests that they include foreign competitors among the companies they use as bench marks in deciding what to pay their executives. He would like to see executive pay packages fall more sharply when corporate performance falls, and he would like the Government to aim tax breaks only at pay plans that really serve as incentives to better performance.
As a first step, directors -- and shareholders and consumers -- would be well served to read "In Search of Excess." It is a thoughtful and generally entertaining look at an important subject. Readers may not all be willing to join Mr. Crystal's crusade "to put greed to work in the service of the U.S. economy," but they will have a better appreciation of why it is not working now.
