HEADLINE: Perspectives: The Benenson Approach;
A Sometime Builder at Work in 2 Cities

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE word that Charles B. Benenson gives to current conditions in the real-estate business is "peculiar." By that he means it is difficult to get financing. He finds it peculiar that development projects he considers sound should have that problem.
"How can we get out of a recession if builders can't build?" he asks. 
 Since Mr. Benenson has two major residential buildings under construction, one in Manhattan and one in Cincinnati, the lament itself might seem peculiar. Mr. Benenson doesn't even consider himself principally a builder. "We build maybe once every 10 years," he says.
But it took a year to get institutional financing for the Cincinnati project, even though it was for only 50 percent of the development cost, he said. He has not forgotten that experience, or the ongoing need that owners of commercial property have for new mortgage money to refinance existing buildings. Nowadays some banks are seeking to reduce their positions in investment real estate even when properties are fully rented with seemingly secure tenants, owners say.
The financing issue is constantly on the mind of investors like Mr. Benenson, who at 78 years of age is very much in charge at Benenson Capital Company. That is the name he gave in 1972 to a business founded by his father, Benjamin, who started building about 1905. The son joined his father in 1937, four years out of Yale. Now his own three children are partners. He presides over a small but busy warren of offices at 708 Third Avenue, at 45th Street.
Benjamin Benenson built in the Bronx. "He built five-story buildings -- today we call them tenements -- and he sold them," Mr. Benenson says. "His best customers were the butchers in the neighborhood."
In the lingo of the business, Benjamin Benenson was also an operator, which is to say a buyer and seller of investment properties. That led him to larger properties in Manhattan. Now Benenson Capital primarily holds commercial property, usually housing only one large tenant with a very long lease. The tenants in New York City include Sotheby's, Potamkin Cadillac and Avis Rent-a-Car.
"OUR philosophy is to hold and keep, if possible free and clear," Mr. Benenson says. The approach makes him more a long-term investor than a manager of property or a creator of it through new construction.
It also provides him with land that over time is suitable for redevelopment. Then he puts on his developer's hat. In 1976 he built the Connaught, a 360-unit rental apartment house on the southeast corner of Second Avenue and 54th Street. He kept it for five years and then sold it as a co-op under an eviction plan. All but 20 tenants bought.
The hat went on again in the mid-80's, when he began to vacate the apartment house he owned across Second Avenue from the Connaught, on the southwest corner of 54th Street. There were 49 tenants and it took five years to get them all to leave.
Mr. Benenson admits to impatience to start construction once that costly process ended, which may explain how he comes to be offering apartments at $600 a square foot in a far less than exuberant sales market. "I had hopes and still do that we'll be successful," he said. "The market wasn't that bad when we started."
THE building is Le Grand Palais, with 180 well-appointed units, at 250 East 54th Street. There are 40 floors to the building, and 6,000 square feet of stores on the ground level. Below that there is a "selling basement" of 10,000 square feet. And below that there is still another basement with a pool and a health club.
A two-bedroom, two-bath apartment with 1,200 square feet on the 20th floor has an asking price of $698,000. A one-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath unit on the fifth floor is listed at $330,000 and the three-bedroom, three-bath units at the 27th to 38th floors go for around $1 million. The five penthouse apartments, each with a floor to itself, are listed at $2.5 million to $3 million. None of the apartments is yet under contract to be sold.
The architect, the firm of Fox & Fowle, has designed a distinctive glass-enclosed tower with colorful wraparound bands of blue or red every fifth floor. One unusual aspect is that the tower has two contrasting shapes -- rectangular facing Second Avenue and curvilinear on the 54th Street side. They seem to fold into each other above the squarish base.
Just west of the building lies another 10,000-square-foot parcel that Mr. Benenson owns. Sitting on it is a garage building leased to Avis Rent-a-Car. The Avis parcel contributed developments rights to the corner plot.
In Cincinnati, Benenson Capital stepped in last year as a 50 percent partner in a development on the Ohio River called Adams Landing. It was struggling for lack of financing. His participation led to a construction start on the first building in an ambitious long-term development.
Ultimately, Adams Landing is supposed to have 1,250 housing units. Under construction so far is limited to a luxury condominium with 77 apartments on 13 floors. The search for institutional financing led finally to a $28.5 million loan from Yasudo Trust and Banking Company of Tokyo.
Adams Landing was started by Cincinnati real-estate figures -- George Stewart, an investor, and two builders, Alan Zaring and David Tipton. The site is on Pete Rose Boulevard a mile east of downtown.
When possible, Mr. Benenson does not go it alone. He picks up a phone and calls old friends, like Frederick P. Rose, the chairman of Rose Associates; or Jack D. Weiler, a founding partner of Swig Weiler & Arnow, the real-estate development and management firm; or Preston Robert Tisch and Lawrence A. Tisch, the co-chief executive officers of the Loews Corporation (and in Lawrence's case, chairman of CBS Inc. as well). They are real-estate investors all; the Tisches are partners on 54th Street.
"I know what they like," says Mr. Benenson. "If we find it, we go in together. Sometimes they like it better than I do so I let them have it. They don't like Cincinnati. None of my friends do. But I happen to love it."
Adams Landing is an unusual project for Cincinnati, where people are not used to paying $300,000 and more for high-rise living. As construction continues, it will begin to show Benenson touches, including a steel sculpture 40 feet high by Alex Lieberman, whose work the developer has used before.
THE Benenson activities extend beyond New York City and Cincinnati. In 1959, Mr. Benenson and Mr. Weiler bought an office building at 18th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington. In 1983, the World Bank leased the land, demolished the building and used it as part of an assemblage for a new headquarters. The Benenson-Weiler interests took back a lease on the land that lasts almost a century.
In another Washington deal, they bought the elegant Willard Hotel on 14th Street and Pennsylvania Avenue in 1960 and later set off a furor when they proposed to tear it down. That episode gave impetus to the efforts of the Pennsylvania Avenue Commission to gain Government financing for what has become a Pennsylvania Avenue renaissance. It also gave rise to a $9 million condemnation payment (the award plus interest) at the conclusion of a lawsuit 12 years later.
Mr. Benenson owns the land under 400 Park Avenue, an office building on 54th Street leased to Fisher Brothers. In partnership with the Tisches, he owns the automobile and industrial building at 787 11th Avenue, also on 54th Street, which was built in 1930 for Packard cars and is now occupied by Potamkin Cadillac and an Oriental rug dealer. With his two brothers he owns the Sotheby's building, at 1334 York Avenue, at 72d Street.
And in Miami, a mile west of the airport, he owns industrial property with the Tisches called Beacon Center. It was vacant land when they bought it in 1969. Now it has 400,000 square feet of buildings, mostly in the 60,000- to 100,000-square-foot range. More buildings are planned.
As for Le Grand Palais, where Crossland Savings Bank is a participating investor, Mr. Benenson began a sales campaign only a few weeks ago, having held off in hopes of a market improvement. He says it is too soon to say whether he has found that improvement.
If he doesn't, what will he do? Rent apartments out?
"Sure, of course," he said. "It's a strong rental market."

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1067 words

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Ready for Next Act in the Tax Drama

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
STATE legislators convene in special session this week to amend, or even repeal, the state's three-month-old income tax law, and most lawmakers expect a resumption of last summer's budget turmoil. But the political calendar is adding a powerful new twist.
Budget experts and legislators on both sides of the tax issue said the timing of the session -- in the middle of the fiscal year, just before the political campaign cycle that begins in January and leads to next fall's midterm elections -- has loaded the process with weighty political and fiscal considerations. 
"It's much harder to do things mid-way," said Michael B. Levin, a vice president of the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, a nonprofit budget research group. "I just see a kind of chaotic situation there."
 With less than seven months left before the next budget year starts, and only three months before the next regular legislative session is supposed to open, to pass that budget, an important question about the special session is when changes that are passed would take effect. Jan. 1? Retroactive to Aug. 22, when the budget and income tax were passed? July 1, when the next fiscal year begins? Or immediately upon passage? Compounding such decisions is that every day makes a change in the current budget year harder to impose. And time erodes the impact of the spending cuts that are certain to be offered by both Republicans and moderate Democrats. Eliminating a $100 million program, for instance, would only save perhaps $50 million by July 1, because months of higher spending commitments have already passed. If a tax is cut, is the change calculated into this year's budget or next?
But politics alone could spin the special session into an eccentric orbit. Last month lawmakers saw more than 40,000 angry residents converge on the State Capitol to rally against the income tax in one of the biggest protest demonstrations ever held in the state. Two weeks ago they saw the New Jersey Legislature turned inside out by tax-angry voters, who evicted a long-running Democratic majority and installed enough Republicans to override any veto from Gov. Jim Florio. And if Connecticut's lawmakers look ahead instead of back, they see more budget difficulties next spring, when all 187 members of the General Assembly have to face the voters.
There is also a structural stumbling block. In the long summer session the lawmakers passed three budgets without income taxes only to see them vetoed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. The General Assembly now has a majority willing to vote for repeal of the income tax, but there does not seem to be a two-thirds majority needed to override Mr. Weicker's promised veto.
For many Republicans, who have led the repeal drive but simultaneously pledged to make the income tax the issue of the 1992 campaign if repeal fails, the special session presents a painful choice of strategies. If they win now and repeal the tax, will they reduce the chances for a New Jersey-style rout of the Democrats next year, because the battle will be over? If repeal fails, do Republicans support a Democrat-led effort to amend the tax law and reduce the burden on middle- and upper-middle-income families -- or keep the law, as bad as they think it is, the better to bash Democrats with next year?
"It's a very serious tug-of-war in one's head," said Senator Philip S. Robertson, a Republican from Cheshire. Mr. Robertson said that he would vote for repeal, but that if repeal failed, he might also support a repaired income tax, even if it meant lessening the chances of a big Republican victory next year.
 
Prospect of Paralysis
 "The political argument would be to vote against repair, so the thing stays as bad as it is," Mr. Robertson said. "But I don't think I could do that. If they're trying to make the income tax better than the atrocity that they passed, then certainly I have an obligation to support those things that in a negative environment will at least somehow remove some of the negativism."
Many lawmakers say, however, that their greatest fear is not that the special session will go headlong into changing tax laws, but rather that the General Assembly will simply be paralyzed and find itself unable to do anything at all.
"The greatest risk that the state faces is more indecision," said Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a Democrat from West Hartford. Mr. Sullivan said he favors the income tax, but he has vowed to try to replace it with a more progressive system that would allow tax cuts for middle-class families. He said that if a deadlock emerges by mid-December, he will advocate jumping ahead of the regular February session and beginning work on next year's budget immediately, with the goal of forging an 18-month budget through June of 1993.
The Republican leader in the House, Edward C. Krawiecki Jr. of Bristol, also said that new rules were being considered for the session, in an effort to avoid a replay of last summer's stalemate. He said, for example, that a system of time blocks, similar to the format used in the United States Senate, was being considered to limit floor debate on the various tax bills. That would give each party a block of time, say four hours, that could be divided among members. Mr. Krawiecki said the chamber has not imposed formal debate limits in at least 15 years.
 
Schedule Is Proposed
 Under the preliminary draft of the rules that circulated at the Capitol last week, lawmakers would be prevented from single-handedly starting a filibuster, by proposing dozens of amendments for example. The rules would require any amendment to have multiple sponsors.
The draft document said that all bills for the session would have to be filed by Tuesday, with statewide public hearings tentatively scheduled for Nov. 22-25, with a vote on repealing the tax to be held between Dec. 6 and 9. The rest of the month, through the thicket of holidays, could see the attempted override of the veto, and probably only then would an attempt be made to amend the tax law. Also on the early agenda is a proposal to discuss the possibility of holding a statewide referendum on the income tax sometime next year.
"Will the troops be home for Christmas?" asked Mr. Sullivan. "It's doable. It's possible. But I am not altogether sure. A lot of people are a little more frightened and gun-shy than they were a few months ago."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: B. Altman's;
A Metamorphosis For 880,000 Sq. Ft.

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
TWO years ago, as B. Altman held its final sale, the crush was so great that management turned off the escalators to control traffic. Today, on the rare occasions when the escalators are turned on, their gentle rumbling is the loudest sound to be heard through the vast selling floors, each a two-acre forest of 22-foot-high columns.
What can be done with such an expanse, with floors that fill the block from Fifth to Madison Avenue, 34th to 35th Street? 
 A department store is obvious enough -- that was the purpose for which the 880,000-square-foot building at 361 Fifth Avenue was constructed, beginning in 1905. But the grand emporium is a vanishing species. The need of financial-service concerns for ample trading floors also is evaporating.
So the owners, KMO-361 Realty Associates of Manhattan, had to improvise. (The K is for Earle W. Kazis, the M for Peter L. Malkin, the O for Morton L. Olshan.)
Their solution is as unorthodox as their property is unusual: 650,000 square feet to be the New York Resource Center -- a mart for office and home furniture, fabrics, flooring, wall coverings, kitchen and bathroom fixtures, lighting and accessories. The center is to include a theater, conference center, meeting rooms and concierge. The architects are Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates and Emery Roth & Sons, both of Manhattan.
Most of the rest of the building, some 200,000 square feet, is to be the Science, Industry and Business Library, a division of the New York Public Library.
The owners expect that the library lease will be signed early next year, said Richard P. Steinberg, president of the Resource Center. "Once we start with the library," he added, "we've committed the building."
There are 12 deals in "active negotiation" for 90,000 square feet, said Daniel P. Weinreb, senior vice president of the center. The net rent ranges in the $20's, he said.
KMO-361 bought both the real estate and retail operations of B. Altman & Company in 1985 but soon sold the stores to Anthony R. Conti and Philip C. Semprevivo, who resold them in 1987 to L. J. Hooker, the American arm of the Hooker Corporation of Australia, headed by George Herscu.
In 1987, when B. Altman was still a going concern, the owners envisioned transforming the building into a complex called the Altman Business Center. Under this plan, the store would have been shrunk, to occupy only the lower five stories of the full-block building.
On the Fifth Avenue side, which has eight stories, the top three floors would have been leased out as office space. On the Madison Avenue side, which has 13 stories, an additional six floors would have been constructed, creating a 19-story tower. Meanwhile, Hooker planned a $25 million to $30 million renovation of the store itself.
Because B. Altman's is a landmark, the proposal to add extra floors was subject to approval by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Also, as a zoning matter, it was subject to approval from the City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate.
By the time all these approvals were won, however, the matter was moot.
B. Altman and L. J. Hooker filed for protection under the Federal bankruptcy law in August 1989. Within three months, B. Altman's was having the last sale in its 124-year history. (Mr. Herscu is now serving a prison sentence in Australia for bribery.)
Today, the owners of the building see some cause for gratitude that they were prevented from starting construction in 1988 or 1989. "Thank God, we didn't," Mr. Steinberg said. "If Altman's had gone under while we were under way, it would have been very painful."
In 1990, the landlords got back five suburban stores and the Fifth Avenue flagship -- "vacant and broom clean," in Mr. Steinberg's words. "In 1985 and 1986, we had all kinds of interest from Wall Street," he said. "By the time the building was vacant that market had disappeared." So, too, has the idea of a tower on Madison Avenue. "There is no way we can build new space and get it onto the market economically," he said.
Mr. Steinberg credits the market consultant Judson H. Spencer with the idea of turning the B. Altman store into a mart. At the same time as the Resource Center concept was being developed, however, another seed was planted that proved to be decisive.
The Public Library was looking to gather its Science, Industry and Business Library under one roof. Edwin S. Holmgren, the head of the branch library system, happened to be walking past the empty store when it dawned on him what a "wonderful location" it would be, recalled John Masten, the executive vice president of the library.
"ALTMAN'S was absolutely the best candidate of all the space we looked at," Mr. Masten said. It was only six blocks south of the Central Research Library and five blocks south of the Mid-Manhattan Library (the former Arnold Constable store). It had high ceilings and large, open floors.
It also had owners who were eager to get tenants. "The market, of course is soft now," Mr. Masten said. "The weakness in the real estate market is an important reason why it's possible for us to go ahead." Mr. Masten would not disclose the proposed terms.
The library will occupy six floors and the basement of the Madison Avenue side of the building. "It gives us our own front door and our own identity," Mr. Masten said.
"The library was the first to come forward," Mr. Steinberg said. "We looked at it as an anchor tenant, a bellwether to attract another tenant. The library was important to us in terms of getting the building started."
"There are a number of reasons why it is attractive to the industry," Mr. Weinreb said. "No. 1 is the location. No. 2 is the physical characteristics: floor size, ceiling heights, escalators, freight elevators, loading docks. No. 3 is the architectural significance of the building -- this is a grand dame of New York. No. 4 is the critical mass. With 650,000 square feet, we felt it was large enough to make an impact."
But aren't there enough homes for the industry -- the International Design Center, New York (I.D.C.N.Y.) in Long Island City, Queens; the Architects & Designers Building, 150 East 58th Street, at Third Avenue; the Decoration & Design Building, 979 Third Avenue, at 58th Street, and the Furniture Mart, 200 Lexington Avenue, at 32d Street?
"A significant number of the people we're talking to are not in any of the major buildings," Mr. Steinberg said. "Notwithstanding all the negatives in the furnishing business and the economy in general, it appeared there was an opportunity here. We felt, in the long run, this is needed."
Thomrock Realty of Queens, which owns the International Design Center, believes the market is saturated, having reached that conclusion in the 1980's when a mart was part of the 42d Street Development Project.
"We didn't feel the market was sufficient to support another location," said Harvey Schulweis, a general partner in Thomrock.
Center One and Center Two at the Long Island City complex have about 950,000 square feet between them, with 600,000 currently occupied by showrooms and 150,000 by offices of the School Construction Authority.
"Among the contract furniture industry," Mr. Schulweis said, "certainly the dominant companies are located at I.D.C.N.Y. The commitment to I.D.C.N.Y. as far as this industry is concerned has been total."
"Everyone of these major tenants has been approached by Altman's," said Arthur Katz, executive vice president of I.D.C. Inc., "and everyone has turned them down."
The Architects & Designers Building is the 160,000-square-foot base of a 500,000-square-foot office tower, owned by a Netherlands Antilles corporation called 150 Realty N.V.
Robert L. Billingsley, a partner in Abrams Benisch Riker, which manages and leases the building, seemed rather unconcerned about competition.
"We're never going to be a candidate for tenants looking for 30,000 square feet," he said. "We're going to be looking for smaller tenants who want visibility. We like to think of this as the Seagram Building of contract furnishings."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Slump Hits Connecticut Marinas Hard

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
EACH summer, thousands of sailboats, stately yachts and zigzagging speedboats create a postcard picture on Connecticut's rivers and Long Island Sound.
But now the recession has virtually beached the recreational boating industry, and in Connecticut some 25,000 marinas and dockominiums representing one of the state's most popular diversions are locked into the Northeastern slump, declining as much as 50 percent in value. 
 "Boating is a discretionary activity," said Ray Bovich, president of the Connecticut Marine Trades Association in Essex. "When the economy weakens, it's the first expenditure to go and the last to recover." His organization serves about 325 marine business members, down from 400 three years ago.
Lending institutions, already overwhelmed with bankrupt commercial and residential real estate, are having difficulty absorbing this new wave of insolvency. The properties are especially troublesome because they must continue to operate to minimize losses, and banks do not have the skills to oversee maintenance, environmental procedures and administration.
"We are evaluating a portfolio of 5,000 properties, a few of which are marinas, and we are expecting more," said George W. Burton, chief lending officer for the Chase Manhattan Bank of Connecticut. No estimates are available for the total number of marinas in trouble in Connecticut.
"They are very similar to other real estate of the go-go 80's," Mr. Burton said of marinas. "There was a levering up of the sales price as they turned over, and now that there is less demand they are suffering from a loss of cash flow. They are not selling as much fuel, or making repairs, and a surplus of space is bringing rental charges down."
The industry has been further depressed by an array of state taxes on boat sales, brokers' commissions, slip rentals and winter storage and the 10 percent Federal luxury sales tax. A limited survey by the Connecticut Department of Revenue Services disclosed that 1,382 boat owners last year owed more than $30.2 million in taxes.
"A marina is not on the same economic level as an office building or apartment house," said Michael Sachs, president of Westrec Marina Management in North Hollywood, Calif., owners and operators of two dozen large marinas around the country. "In an office building, you know what you get. It was a mistake to look at marinas as a form of real estate that would appreciate ad infinitum. It's a business that must have active, expert management."
CONVERSIONS to dockside condominiums were another major mistake, he said. "Predominantly located in the Northeast, they were for owner-users who spend more time partying at the dock than on the water, or for overleveraged speculators," he said.
Fifty 25-foot slips renting at $60 a foot will bring in $1,500 a slip, or $75,000 a season with no vacancies. But Mr. Sachs said that that amount "will not cover property taxes, insurance, utilities, office expenses, telephone, advertising, maintenance, parking, security and personnel, not to mention the problems of getting several owners to cooperate in management decisions."
A serious problem peculiar to marina property is getting the local, state and Federal permits controlling public access to waterways, pollution, dredging, salt marshes, breeding grounds for fish, marine plant life and other environmental concerns. Compliance can cost millions of dollars.
Gurdon Buck, a partner with Dwight Merriam in the Hartford law firm of Robinson & Cole, represents lenders who have taken over coastal projects. "An alarming pattern of flipping from developer to developer," he said, "frequently reveals that new owners, down to the foreclosure owner, failed to transfer or keep in force the necessary permits. When the lender takes back the project, he has no permits with which to complete it, and therefore no value."
Mansfield Landing on the Farm River in East Haven, now the property of Den Norske Bank, a Norwegian investor with offices in Manhattan, is typical. Opened in 1966 as a small family business, the 47-acre property was sold in 1986 after work had begun on 182 condominium units and 207 new slips. "Since then it has been resold four times, with each owner profiting by $500,000 to $1 million," Mr. Merriam said. In the process the permits expired and the project is not only incomplete with only 44 condominium units built, but is also in violation of many new government regulations.
"In some cases," Mr. Buck said, "the lender starts dragging his feet, finding himself on a phantasmagorical journey through a maze of permitting requirements." In a situation where the project is too complex and expensive, the bank can refuse to take title and thereby avoid becoming entangled in penalties and legal problems. It can abandon the property in foreclosure, even though it may mean walking away from a tremendous amount of money, according to the lawyers.
"What drove marina fever in the 80's was a perception that Connecticut was running out of shoreline and no new marinas would be built," said John Scott, president of Scott, Fitton & Company, a real estate research and consulting firm in Milford. "There was also a misperceived demand for residential development in conjunction with marinas, where slips were reserved for residents. But only 7 percent of those who bought residential units bought slips. Today, the condos are worth no more with a slip than without."
BECAUSE of state and Federal coastal regulations there are indeed few locations where new marinas can be built along Connecticut's 583 linear miles of shorefront (100 miles as the crow flies). And areas currently zoned for water-related purposes cannot be rezoned for other uses.
One solution is expected to lie in mergers of small side-by-side marinas. "In Greenwich, New London and elsewhere there are three and four marinas in a row and in trouble," said Arthur Collins, president of Collins Enterprises, a Stamford-based developer. "Put them together and you may have 500 viable slips. Separately, there is not enough cash flow to support them."
Mr. Collins, Mr. Sachs and Mr. Merriam are among the experts who will address a public seminar on positioning marinas for sale, Wednesday from 8:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the Seamen's Institute, South Street Seaport in Manhattan. For information call Coulter & Delaney, marina consultants, (203) 440-3380.

HEADLINE: At County Restaurants, Empty Tables and Smaller Checks

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
WANT to know how the economy is doing in Westchester? Go out for dinner. But wait for the weekend if you don't want to eat amid a sea of empty tables. Despite specially priced entrees, early-bird specials, discount coupons, low-cost wines and eager waiters, most consumers are staying home.
"You don't hear anyone bragging about their raises and promotions anymore," said Neil Novich, one of the owners of John Richards, a popular restaurant and pub in Dobbs Ferry, where business has declined for the first time in six years. 
 "You hear how '10 in my office just got laid off,' or '30 in my department just got their notices,' " said Mr. Novich, who doubles as the bartender. "People are worried, and they are not spending."
 
More Sharing and No Dessert
 A random survey of county restaurants, from those serving haute cuisine to those offering ethnic specialities, shows the same downward trend. Empty tables have increased, and the tabs have decreased. Customers are sharing entrees, drinking cheaper wine and skipping dessert. Worst of all for the owners, customers are coming less often.
Business in restaurants, hotels and taverns in the New York City area is off 20 to 30 percent compared with last year, industry analysts say, adding that a number of restaurants have closed. "The turnover is not so pronounced, because typically another restaurant springs up on the same spot," said Fred Sampson, executive director of the New York State Restaurant Association.
Restaurants are reacting to the situation in a variety of ways.
 
A Challenge to Creativity
 Although he has substituted domestic mushrooms for the more expensive shiitakes, Kevin Patrick Sullivan, the chef at Dudley's Restaurant, said the tough economy is more a challenge to his creativity than a signal for cutbacks in the kitchen.
For six weeks, the big seller at this tiny neighborhood restaurant in the heart of Ossining's historic district has been hanger steak, pan-seared with smoked bacon, green peppercorns, Cognac and cream.
"It's the part of the beef the butcher normally keeps for himself," Mr. Sullivan said, adding that although the cut tastes better and costs less than sirloin, it is more difficult to prepare. "It's a creative idea in response to the economy," said Mr. Sullivan, a graduate of the Culinary Institute of America of Hyde Park. "Anyone can use expensive cuts of meat. The key is to know how to make something out of the less-expensive parts."
The same principle was behind Mr. Sullivan's introduction of a second popular entree, Broken Arrow Ranch antelope, barbecued and served with port wine, shallots and pink peppercorns.
Despite Mr. Sullivan's creative ministrations and a loyal following that extends beyond Ossining, business at Dudley's has fallen off this year for the first time since Ralph and Joan Rink and their son Mark of Chappaqua bought the restaurant eight years ago.
Because of its small size -- 30 tables -- the restaurant has not had to lay off staff, but Mark Rink said, "Waiters are not making as much money as before."
The economic situation has dealt a harsh blow to one of the county's top-rated Indian restaurants, Abhilash India Cuisine in New Rochelle. Knowledgeable customers still flock in on weekends to sample Jose Kurian's chicken tikka, marinated in herbs and cooked in the tandoor oven, or his shrimp bhuna with spiced tomato gravy. But in the last few months, 40 percent of the staff has been laid off; part of the main dining room has been closed, and the sitar musician is gone.
 
Fewer Customers and Lower Checks
 Both the average check amount and the head count is down, said Mr. Kurian, the owner, adding that the restaurant offers many special discounts, including two-for-one coupons at the door.
"I'm afraid to spend additional dollars in the media because I'm afraid it won't be recouped," Mr. Kurian said. "I've been here 11 years, and I've never seen anything like this."
He added: "I've paid the mortgage, so I'll be able to stay on. Meanwhile, I'm sitting tight and waiting for good news."
At the Arch in Brewster, reservations are still preferred for the $45 fixed-price dinner, George Seitz, the owner, said, but he added that customers are purusing the menu for less-expensive wines.
His customers are often avoiding such extras as fresh caviar and pate de foie gras, but the restaurant is doing a better business than during the same period last year, Mr. Seitz said.
 
Offering Inexpensive Wines
 "The economy is so bad that maybe people are saying to hell with it," Mr. Seitz said. "They seem to be saying, 'Maybe we can't buy a car or go on vacation so let's go have a good dinner and some wine.' "
Like Mr. Sullivan at Dudley's, Mr. Seitz said he was enjoying the opportunity to find creative solutions to help customers through the economic slump. "I'm trying hard to offer some great wine selections at the lower-priced end," he said. "It takes a lot of sorting out and tasting, but I've found a wonderful '86 Rully that I can offer as a $15 house wine. I tell my customers, 'Why not stick to that?' "
Liquor distributors appreciate all the help wine connoisseurs like Mr. Seitz can give them. Business, they say, has never been worse, and the poor economy is only one of the reasons.
"Clearly, if the economy was robust, we'd still be in trouble," said Scott Wexler, executive director of the United Restaurant, Hotel and Tavern Association of New York State. Higher Federal and state taxes have added 10 percent to the cost of a bottle of liquor and doubled the tax on beer, he said.
 
Weekends a Bright Spot
 Mr. Wexler added that new restrictions on drinking were affecting what he called responsible social drinkers.
"People are afraid to go out to dinner and have two drinks," he said. "If people aren't going out to dinner, they aren't going to the movies, and they aren't going to the mall to buy shoes either."
At Dudley's, reservations are still mandatory on Friday and Saturday nights, and, Mr. Rink said, weekend reservations are actually filling up faster.
"A lot of people who used to go out during the week and can't afford it," he said, "are making more of an effort to make sure the weekend counts."

HEADLINE: 'Unserviced Zones'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A new concept called "unserviced zone" must be created to accommodate the justifiable demands of condominium unit owners who are victims of discrimination in being deprived of customary municipal services. "Unserviced zones" delineates those areas that do not receive such accepted municipal services as street maintenance, street lighting, snow removal and trash removal. "Unserviced zones" are comparable to "free-trade zones" where desirable businesses are accommodated with lowered assessments and taxes and other municipal benefits. 
 Condominium unit owners not receiving such municipal services and residing in such "unserviced zones" are entitled to a reduction by the municipality in the assessed valuations of their residences. Such lessened assessments are directly related to the fact that the municipality is not expending funds to furnish such municipal services to the condominium unit owner. There are at present only 10 Connecticut municipalities furnishing the same services to all.
 
WARREN FREEDMAN
Avon, Conn.

HEADLINE: Trapped in the Impoverished Middle Class

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill.

 BODY:
Michael Storm, who earns $18.01 an hour making transmission housings at Caterpillar Inc., talks with disillusionment about his purchase last year of a new Chevrolet Cavalier, the family's first new car in years. His wife, Joanne, had totaled their 1985 Cavalier in an accident, and Mr. Storm, who likes new things, thought a new car would please her as well. But the new car has ended up angering them both.
The $237 monthly payment was almost as much as the family's mortgage and property taxes combined. And the Storms couldn't build equity in the Cavalier because its first-year drop in value was so steep it more than offset each monthly payment. "My wife is saying that my time away from home working extra hours to support the car payments isn't worth it," Mr. Storm said. 
 By Peoria standards, indeed by national standards, the Storms have not fallen on hard times. Mr. Storm's annual wages of $45,000, including overtime, puts the family well into the middle class here and in most of the United States. But, as is true of 80 percent of the nation's households, the Storms' earnings have not gained ground on inflation since the early 1970's. Mr. Storm's annual raises have been overtaken by bigger gains in the Consumer Price Index, eroding his purchasing power.
Millions of Americans are in the same position. The optimism of ever-rising prosperity they had come to expect since the 1940's, whether they were janitors, sales clerks, factory workers or managers, has faded. Median household income in 1990, adjusted for inflation, was $29,943, or $1,000 less than it was in 1973, the Census Bureau reports. For all but the 20 percent of the population with incomes above $80,000 annually, income has stagnated.
This prolonged stagnation in American incomes, widely acknowledged by politicians, economists and sociologists, grew out of corporate efforts to cut labor costs to become globally competitive -- an endeavor aided both by Reagan Administration policies and a decline in union militancy. It is debatable how much these wage sacrifices have helped America's competitiveness -- one reason why the issue is expected to be central to the coming Presidential elections.
 
A Generational Shift
 The debate will be fed by a new recognition that income stagnation is altering attitudes and behaviors in profound ways just now being understood. It is not only influencing buying patterns, explaining the growing popularity of used cars and the relentless search for discounts; it is also changing the social and economic underpinnings of cities and towns, even the tenor of family life. Above all, for the first time since World War II, a generation of children is leaving college without a sense of a prosperous future.
"These are kids who are coming of age in an era of instability that is scarring them, even in families with steady incomes," said Katherine Newman, a Columbia University anthropologist. "We don't know how it will affect their consumer behavior, their marriages and their children."
Today, the adventurous search for opportunity is no longer rewarding. For generations, Americans migrated -- going West, so to speak -- when jobs in their communities became scarce or failed to pay well. But income stagnation is a nationwide phenomenon. Migration has become futile. Peorians, for example, uprooted themselves by the thousands in the early 1980's, when recession and then massive layoffs at Caterpillar and the numerous local companies that supply Caterpillar pushed the unemployment rate here above 16 percent. By the late 1980's, they were trickling home again.
"When they got to Oklahoma and Texas, they found that the promise of good wages was a lot of talk; they worked hard and had little to show for it," said David Koehler, executive director of the Peoria Area Labor Management Council. "Now, many have come home to jobs that pay less than they once earned, but they have returned because this is where their families are to help them."
Peoria is often thought of as the quintessential, middle-American town. Once the center of the nation's prosperous liquor industry, with 26 huge distilleries, since World War II it has been the headquarters for Caterpillar Inc., whose yellow tractors and earth movers are sold worldwide.
Like the distillery workers before them, most of Caterpillar's 10,000 blue-collar employees in the Peoria area are among the nation's best-paid wage earners, receiving nearly $17 an hour on average. Indeed, of greater Peoria's 340,000 residents, roughly one-third are Caterpillar families, or families supported by workers at the handful of other manufacturers that pay assembly-line wages of $14 an hour or more: the Keystone Steel & Wire Company, the Komatsu-Dresser Company (a Caterpillar competitor) and, 40 miles away, Mitsubishi's new Diamond-Star auto plant in Bloomington.
That has helped keep Peoria's median household income, now about $32,500, slightly higher than the nation's as a whole; only 8 percent above the 1970 level, adjusted for inflation. Yet these privileged workers increasingly moonlight to make ends meet, or depend on a working spouse for essential income, or do both. Mr. Storm, for one, earned an extra $8,000 this year moonlighting as a carpenter remodeling homes. "I think my wage at Caterpillar is a fair one," he said. "But it does not put me in a position that I can flaunt my money."
Quite the contrary. When he joined Caterpillar in 1973, Mr. Storm, who is 38, earned $7 an hour. His wages since then have gone up 157 percent, but the Consumer Price Index has risen 203 percent. That helps explain why, with the eldest of the Storms' four children approaching college age, Mrs. Storm, who is 34, entered a junior college last fall to study nursing. It is one of the few nonfactory jobs in Peoria that pays nearly factory wages: $12 an hour.
Some economists had argued that income would once again rise faster than inflation by the 1990's, because there would be fewer workers in the post-baby boom generation. But anticipated labor shortages have not materialized. In fact, many companies, including Caterpillar, are still shrinking their work forces, citing hard times and heavy competition in world markets.
Donald V. Fites, chairman of Caterpillar, which is locked in a dispute with the United Auto Workers over a new labor contract, made the latter point in an interview. His view is that American incomes should tread water while those of other nations catch up. "There is a narrowing of the gap between the average American's income and that of the Mexicans,," he said. "As a human being, I think what is going on is positive. I don't think it is realistic for 250 million Americans to control so much of the world's G.N.P."
 
The Income Scramble
 In such circumstances, the income scramble becomes an almost full-time family chore. In more than two dozen recent interviews here with Caterpillar families, tradespeople, teachers, lawyers, office workers and managers, only two or three said their families now exist on a single paycheck.
Stephen and Margaret Collier were one; he earns $16.24 an hour assembling tractor treads at Caterpillar and she runs the home. But Mrs. Collier clearly sees herself as an earner. "It takes me working full-time at home to keep the bills down to the point that we can live on his income," she said. "I split the wood [for the Franklin stove], plant and work a vegetable garden [covering an acre of their three-acre plot], can vegetables, buy meat when it is on sale, help my husband fix our cars [their newest is a 1982 Ford]."
The two-earner strategy is, of course, the most obvious adjustment to stagnant wages here and elsewhere. The preference for second-hand cars is a newer, but growing phenomenon. Bruce Saurus, the local Ford dealer, said that cars repurchased by Ford from Hertz, Avis and other rental companies and then auctioned to dealers like himself now account for half his sales. "We never bought these cars at all five years ago," he said.
Peoria is also a big center for discount stores, among them Wal-Mart, Best Buy and Kohl's. A year ago, Sam's Wholesale Club, a Wal-Mart-owned nationwide chain, had its biggest first-day sales ever in Peoria: $160,000. What's more, centers funded by United Way where families can pick up a week's supply of groceries free have multiplied. There are 150 today, covering every neighborhood, compared with only 30 eight years ago, concentrated in poor neighborhoods. "I get calls from people who are working and who, if they get one extra expense, are in trouble," said Nancy Gardener, a United Way official.
A similar dynamic is herding Peorians in rising numbers to hospital emergency rooms for free treatment, even though their ailments are minor. Peoria has three major medical centers, thriving mostly on the $40 million a year that Caterpillar pays out in health insurance for its 20,000 Peoria-area employees, both white and blue collar. The Methodist Medical Center, the largest, opened a new emergency room in the late 1980's designed to handle 30,000 people a year; 50,000 came through last year. "There were people with colds," said Robert Wierman, president of the center. "Many have jobs and even health insurance, but they come here rather than pay a doctor for the deductible portion."
The housing market in Peoria reflects a more subtle impact from stagnant wages. People who once purchased two or three homes in a lifetime, trading up as families and incomes grew, now stay in one, often a small frame house in an older neighborhood.
Several neighborhoods declined in the early 1980's as home prices fell and Caterpillar workers migrated, leaving dwellings unoccupied. Other families sold, at a loss. Without enough income to buy again, they made Peoria a town of thousands of renters.
The Colliers were one family that became renters. They had married in 1971 and three years later had bought a two-bedroom frame home in East Peoria for $12,000. "It was a lower-income neighborhood and we had hopes that it would improve," Mrs. Collier said. It did not. In the 1982 recession, with property values falling throughout the Rust Belt, the Colliers said, they found themselves living next to drug dealers.
"We folded; we sold out," Mrs. Collier said. They lost $10,000 on the sale, including the money invested in an extension on the home and a beauty salon that Mr. Collier had built for his wife in the garage.
For the next five years, the Colliers rented, moving further out into semirural suburbs. Finally, with savings that Mrs. Collier had helped to accumulate with a clothing-store job, the family purchased, for $78,000, a three-bedroom prefabricated home, taking on a $600-a-month mortgage.
"We have moved to the country and isolated ourselves from undesirable people," Mrs. Collier said. "That way we have more control over our kids [two teen-aged boys]. But there is so much work that I must do here, there is not much time for social life."
 
Declining Neighborhoods
 Families that stayed behind in the declining neighborhoods formed neighborhood associations to pressure landlords to make repairs or to try to oust families considered undesirable, often because of drug involvement. "We were fighting abandoned homes as Caterpillar workers left town in search of work," said Patricia Goitein, who became president of her association after the 1982 recession reduced to $45,000 the value of the home she and her husband, an economics professor at Bradley University, had purchased in 1979 for $56,000. "And as the Bradley student population declined, landlords in the neighborhood who could no longer rent to students turned to low-income families."
Such problems helped to kill off construction of lower-priced homes; for nearly a decade, virtually no home for less than $100,000 has been built. "When people had incomes, I used to build 100 lower-priced homes and sell them and build 25 more and sell them and that lasted until the early 1980's," said G. Raymond Becker, president of Peoria's largest construction company.
New home construction instead is concentrated today on five-and-six bedroom luxury houses that sell for $250,000 and more -- the equivalent of $600,000 homes in the East. These mansions are going up in outlying suburbs, the best-known being Thousand Oaks, with its private streets on a wooded rise in the Illinois prairie. The owners are a cross-section of wealthy families, many of them doctors, but also lawyers, entrepreneurs and corporate executives.
Nevertheless, in the Peoria public mind, Thousand Oaks is the home of "the doctors." That phrase comes up repeatedly in conversations, even with people like Thomas E. Leiter, a prosperous lawyer from one of the city's old families who is president of the Peoria Historical Society.
"The doctor phenomenon reflects in part the efforts of Caterpillar to pass along to its rank and file some of the cost of medical care," he said. "The doctors are contributing to a rising expense that must be paid from limited incomes, and the strain focuses attention on the doctors and their grand homes. It has not elevated to public resentment, but there is an awareness of class distinction."
For Ms. Newman, the Columbia anthro pologist, the unusual focus on doctors in Peoria, or wealthy Asians in the New Jersey community that she has studied, is inevitable. "When times get hard," she said, "you get a much sharper sense of class identity, directed in part against those perceived as doing better than they deserve."
In hindsight, income stagnation showed up in national statistics in 1973, with the onset of the Arab oil embargo and a rising inflation rate. But for millions of Americans, the most memorable dates are those when the stagnation really took hold in their communities.
The 1981-1982 recession represented that crisis for the Midwest, and in Peoria it was compounded by two other events: a 206-day strike at Caterpillar, the longest major strike in U.A.W. history, and Caterpillar's decision to shed 24,000 employees, including 12,000 in Peoria. With Caterpillar suppliers following suit, the work force fell 12 percent.
The city fathers have tried to offset the job loss through diversification. Mayor James A. Maloof, a relentless promoter, trumpets the arrival of numerous new enterprises, among them research labs, biotechnology companies, advertising firms, telephone marketing and mail order operations, an insurance firm -- even a riverboat gambling casino.
But the diversification effort reinforced the income stagnation. The new jobs remained scarce, and wages were lower. Eighteen years ago, Caterpillar was hiring 100 people a day; in the last three years, it has added only 300.
 
False Hope in Diversity>
 "People confuse diversification and new service companies with growth," said Mr. Leiter of the historical society. "But in reality it is just re-employment of a few."
Mr. Wierman at Methodist Medical Center confirms that impression. In Caterpillar's heyday, hospital workers moved on, at the first opportunity, to the higher-paying factory jobs. Now, the work force "has become a very stable one," Mr. Wierman said.
Michael Storm knows the feeling. After the strike, Caterpillar laid him off and recalled him three times. He took several lesser-paying jobs, as machinist, mechanic, carpenter. And now, he says, he faces another layoff as Caterpillar continues to automate the transmission plant where he works. While jobs are available -- greater Peoria's unemployment rate is about 6.7 percent, lower than the national level -- good pay isn't.
Understandbly, that makes the Storms cautious. Like many other Caterpillar workers in better days, he bought a two-bedroom starter home soon after his marriage 16 years ago, in nearby Lacon. He still lives there -- having turned the bedrooms over to his two sons and two daughters, and sleeping with his wife on the living room couch.
"Our large purchases can be liquidated, with the exception of our home," he said, referring to the new Chevy Cavalier. "But if I do lose my job, my mortgage and property tax payments [$266 a month] are affordable working on minimum wage at McDonald's."
Whatever the hardships, many Peorians who entered the work force in the 1960's, before the stagnation set in, are becoming increasingly convinced that they are the last generation able to expect $40,000-and-up jobs.
Such wages, they say, won't be available to their children, except for the small percentage who can escape to careers as doctors, lawyers, engineers or highly skilled specialists. The rest are adapting through what Ms. Newman, the Columbia University anthropologist, calls "the elongation of adolescence" -- living at home longer; enrolling in hometown, state-supported junior colleges, and taking odd jobs.
Barbara Drake, the 46-year-old editor of the editorial page at the Peoria Journal Star, shares the view that she and her friends escaped the income problem, but "our kids won't." She and her husband Bernard, a marketing executive at Dresser-Komatsu, earn a healthy $110,000 a year between them. Two of their three children are in college, and dinner party conversation, she says, frequently centers on the difficulties recent graduates have earning more than $8 or $10 an hour.
Donald Barker, who earns $17.41 an hour as a machinist at Caterpillar, has steered his 19-year-old son Jayme into Illinois Central Community College in Peoria. But Jayme is studying welding and blueprint reading, hoping some day for a job at Caterpillar.
Mr. Barker and his wife, Lynne, a graphics artist for the International Business Machines Corporation, would be happier if Jayme were a liberal arts major, going on to a four-year college and hopes of prosperity.
"He has a friend who is a welder and this friend makes $8 an hour and Jayme thinks this is pretty good starting pay for someone just out of high school," Mrs. Barker said. "But that sort of money is for the rest of your life."
 
 
 
A LIMITED LABOR WAR
 Locked in a labor dispute, Caterpillar Inc. is partly shut down. The United Auto Workers struck two plants on Nov. 4 and four days later the company closed several more. The combination strike and lockout means that, nationwide, 8,000 of Caterpillar's 16,000 blue-collar workers are on the street. But so far, neither side has dared to shut down Caterpillar entirely, invoking the terrible memories of the last, 1982-83, strike.
Peoria changed forever after that 206-day strike. The main issue was American labor costs at a time of recession and intensifying global competition which had made Caterpillar unprofitable for the first time since the 1930's. That dispute ended with massive, permanent layoffs and very modest wage increases for the rest of the 1980's.
After a period of profitability, Caterpillar is losing money again: $86 million in the first three quarters and at least that much in the fourth, the company said last week. And the company is once again demanding concessions. But this time the situation is different.
Caterpillar's sales of tractors and heavy construction equipment are down in the United States and abroad because of the recession, but so are those of its competitors, chief among them Japan's Komatsu Inc. Caterpillar says it has not lost market share, as it did in the early 1980's.
That raises the question: Given that labor productivity has improved greatly, should labor have to bear more of the cost-cutting burden? The union says no because Caterpillar wages are already on a par with those of competitors. But the company disagrees. A spokesman says: "Our whole point is that we have to stay competitive if we are to keep these jobs in the United States."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 329 words

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Argentina's Mr. Fix-It

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
Last week, the President of Argentina, Carlos Saul Menem, arrived in the United States for a whirlwind tour to drum up much needed investments and loans. But as he made the rounds in Houston, Washington, New York and Miami, many business people were carefully studying another member of the entourage: Economy Minister Domingo F. Cavallo, the architect of Argentina's stabilization program, which is fast becoming the envy of other Latin governments.
Mr. Cavallo's formula is little more than orthodox economics: prohibit the central bank from printing money unless it is backed by dollar or gold reserves; force Argentines to pay taxes; require a balanced budget monthly; lower tariffs; lay off Government workers; sell off bankrupt Government companies and eliminate almost all Government control of business. 
 Implemented in March, the Cavallo plan has had impressive results. Inflation, which had been 2,314 percent in 1990, is under 20 percent for the last six months. Mr. Cavallo claims 150,000 jobs have been created. Foreign investment has flowed in.
Despite such achievements, Mr. Cavallo has his critics, who say he is too sure of himself for his own good and has trouble countenancing opposing views. His projections for tax revenues are overly optimistic, say the critics, who worry that the budget could become unbalanced by next year.
What sets the 44-year-old Mr. Cavallo apart from previous economy ministers here is the team be brought with him. The founder of a highly regarded economic consulting firm, Fundacion Mediterranea, he appointed more than 100 associates to posts in the Economy Ministry. That team of technocrats was critical, for example, in creating a vast deregulation package announced last month.
Many say Mr. Cavallo, who has also served as Foreign Minister, could succeed Mr. Menem when his term expires in 1995. But Mr. Cavallo declines to speculate, noting that he is not even a member of the President's Peronist Party.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: November 17, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1653 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/November 10-15

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
The Economic News Was Bad, but the Market Was Worse
 
Last week, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 120.31 points to finish the week at 2,943.20, it was the stock market's fifth biggest tumble ever. Analysts were quick to point to the week's bad news: Retail and auto sales were off and the Producer Price Index rose unexpectedly. "Concern about the economy is clearly intensifying," said Hugh Johnson, an analyst at First Albany Corporation in Albany, N.Y. But on reflection, the news last week was not so different from the week before -- or the week before that. So why did the market drop? "There's a general pattern that the amount of the movement doesn't necessarily match up with the news," said Lawrence Summers, chief economist at the World Bank in Washington. "That's a puzzle to people who believe in a perfectly rational market," Mr. Summers said. Traders sitting at computers also have tools that make selling easier. "That exacerbates things when the market goes down," Mr. Summers said.
 
 
Midway Left Out in the Cold
 
Midway Airlines thought it was being handed a lifeline when Northwest Airlines said it would acquire the bankrupt carrier by taking over its $153 million of debt. But Midway, based in Chicago, ended up feeling it had been handed a line when Northwest abruptly withdrew from the deal. Last week Midway, which employs 4,300 people, shut down. "There's no choice. We don't have any money," said David Hinson, Midway's chairman. Analysts say the deal unraveled partly because Northwest, a unit of cash-strapped NWA Inc., based in Minneapolis, had received a $740 million loan from the state of Minnesota. Midway's precarious existence -- it was losing $1 million a day -- made Minnesota officials nervous. But Northwest said the deal was off because Midway gave it misleading financial information. Midway disagrees. Fifty-nine Midway planes remain where they last touched down.


Barbie, Minnie and Dumbo Too
 
They have been tumbling off the assembly line together since 1987 -- Barbie, G.I. Joe and Mickey and Minnie Mouse, that is. Last week, the Walt Disney Company and Mattel Inc., which already reaps $160 million in sales from its Disney-related toy line, agreed to extend their licensing agreement for 10 years. The new agreement will give Mattel the right to produce more Disney characters. Pinnochio, Bambi and Dumbo will be added to the list as well as all 101 Dalmations.


DEC Sides With Microsoft
 
Since summer, the International Business Machines Corporation has entered into more alliances than a delegate at a Presidential convention. But last week, its rival, the Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's No. 2 computer maker, made an alliance of its own with I.B.M.'s arch-nemesis, the Microsoft Corporation, the nation's No. 1 software maker. (I.B.M., once cozy with Microsoft, is now betting on software from Apple Computer Inc. instead.) DEC will now be able to integrate Microsoft's programs, including Windows, into its new offerings. Microsoft gets access to DEC's huge network of six million installed computers. "Windows is a big wave in the market right now," said Rick Sherlund, of Goldman Sachs & Company. "I.B.M.'s fighting it, and DEC wants to ride with it."


A Dreary, Dreary Christmas
 
Even with falling interest rates, consumers are watching their wallets as they wander into the department stores. According to the Commerce Department, retail sales fell by 0.1 percent in October. "The outlook for the Christmas season is not really wonderful," said Kathryn L. Kobe an economist at Joel Popkin & Company in Washington.

 
The French to the Rescue
 
After months of wrangling, California's insurance regulators selected a French group headed by Altus Finance, the investment arm of Credit Lyonnais, to take over the defunct Executive Life Insurance Company. They chose the French group because it promised to return more money to Executive Life's 372,000 nervous policyholders. Ninety-seven percent of them will have no losses, said John Garamendi, California's Insurance Commissioner. The French group was also chosen because it will transfer Executive's huge portfolio of junk bonds into a separate business.
 
 
Selling Off Maxwell's Empire
 
It did not take long. Last week Goldman Sachs & Company sold two million shares of Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C., which was founded by the late Robert Maxwell.

 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
The Slippery Surge
 
When the Producer Price Index was released last week by the Commerce Department, even the coolest economist's heart sank. The index showed a 0.7 percent surge in inflation at the producer level. Slow growth and inflation reminded some seasoned number-crunchers of the "stagflation" that plagued the economy in the 1970's. But on closer examination, economists were mollified somewhat. The inflation figures were skewed by an almost random run-up of prices for a most unlikely assortment of goods. The problem, said some economists, was that the Commerce Department did not properly correct for seasonal factors. "I think it's an aberration," said Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montagu Economics in Washington.
 

Giving the Numbers Meaning
 
It's not the numbers; it's how you interpret them. So what is the meaning of the modest 0.1 percent increase in consumer prices in October, the smallest gain in seven months? "It is encouraging," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities. "But this is the point in the cycle when the Fed typically eases rates too much when it should be patient." That interpretation means when growth comes, so will inflation.
 

Those Wacky Market Forces
 
The next candidate for a Presidential veto emerged from the House last week. It is the plan to put a cap on the interest rates charged by credit card issuers. The House plan would cap rates at about 14 percent. Most cards now carry rates of 18 or 19 percent, while the banks that issue them pay 7 percent or even less for their money. The Administration said it wants lower rates (who doesn't?) but prefers that market forces set them. Aren't those the forces that pushed rates up?


Will the Market Catch the Wave?
 
With the market's 120.31 point drop last week, the nervous chatter on the street turned to the "wave" -- not the football wave, the Elliot Wave. The Elliot Wave measures mass psychology, its adherents say. Bunkum, detractors say. But "wavologists" point to the wave's last big high -- the summer of 1987. After that, the crash. Now they sense a new top has come and gone. "The Elliot wave is about patterns. We think everything has peaked -- real estate, collectibles, jobs on Wall Street," said David Allman, research director for the Elliot Wave Theorist, an investor newsletter in Gainsville, Ga. What's next? "Sometime in the next three years the stock market will be trading at half what it is now."

 
Congress Fiddles, Bush Burns
 
President Bush vetoed two bills intended to extend unemployment benefits. The latest one is being held up by Congress. The House passed a bill last week that provides up to 20 weeks of additional unemployment insurance benefits to three million Americans who have been out of work for at least half a year. But the bill treats each state differently: Connecticut gets 20 additional weeks; Alabama gets just six. Those differences made the Senate balk. Senate and House leaders are haggling while President Bush is shouting "just approve it." The bill will cost $5.1 billion and is intended to pay for itself. How? From an increase in the estimated tax payments of some taxpayers and from a two-tenths of 1 percent surcharge added to the unemployment taxes employers pay. In Washington, that's the closest anything gets to "paying for itself."


The Manufacturing Blues
 
Just when it seemed as if the manufacturing sector was snapping back to life, a study released by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment says "beware." The five-year study says American manufacturing has lost its competitive edge and needs the Government's help to regain its luster. Support is split along party lines: the Democrats for it, Republicans against.
 
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Hedging a Flyer on the U.S.S.R.
 
The recent coup in the Soviet Union, or what's left of it, did not do much to attract investors. So last week, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Government agency, said it would provide $100 million of insurance coverage against expropriation, political violence and currency convertibility problems to an American investment group called the Soviet Companies Fund. The fund, sponsored by Batterymarch Financial Management in Boston and the State Commission on Military Industrial Products in Moscow, plans to invest $250 million, primarily in companies that make products for the military. OPIC will charge up to 60 cents for each $100 insured. But OPIC may lose on the deal. "The Soviet Union is really not a very good credit risk," said Benjamin Weiner, of Probe International, a consulting firm in Stamford, Conn.


British Standoffishness Softens
 
A single currency for the European Community seems pretty likely now. Prime Minister John Major of Britain indicated last week that he is prepared to accept a single currency by the end of the century. But he said he is against closer political ties between countries. So how will they manage the currency?

 
Even Japan Is Slowing Down
 
Last week, the Bank of Japan lowered its discount rate to 5 percent from 5.5 percent. The Japanese economy is a little out of breath. "Japan is not headed for recession, but it is slowing," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics. "This is not the last discount rate cut this cycle."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 5; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: All About/Watches;
Fighting the Recession By Spotting Some Fads And Inventing Others

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Plagued by the recession, a 10 percent luxury tax on watches costing more than $10,000 and the waning of brand loyalty, watchmakers and marketers are pulling out all the stops these days to sell their wares.
They are doing it by spicing up their lines with high-tech sports watches, multi-featured diving watches, new lines of trendy art watches as well as traditional, jewel-encrusted fashion offerings. They are also doing it by following the latest fad: offering reproductions of decades-old designs. 
 So far this year, world watch production is about equal to the 1990 level of 753 million units, according to Modern Jeweler magazine, a trade publication in Overland Park, Kan. Production was 685 million units in 1989. The largest producer of watches is Japan, followed by Hong Kong and Switzerland. The United States is primarily an assembler of watches from parts made elsewhere. Retail sales of all watches in the United States were about $4.5 billion last year.
"Everyone has found a niche," observes Gerry Grinberg, chairman and chief executive of the North American Watch Company, the American distributor for such high-priced Swiss brands as Piaget, Concord and Movado. "The Swiss have taken the upper price end," he said. "The Japanese have taken the lower, or middle price bracket."
Only at the very low end of market -- from $25 to $150 -- is there a free-for-all. The Swiss have a share with Swatch, the Japanese with Casio and Seiko, the Americans with Armitron (sold under dozens of different names) and the Norwegians with Timex.
Timex, which is privately held, does not disclose its overall sales figures. Industry analysts say Timex dominates the low-end market with about 24 percent of market share. It also produces the nation's largest selling watch: the Iron Man Triathalon, a digital watch priced at $39.95 that sells about 500,000 units a year.
At least one battle in the industry now appears to have been settled: the protracted competition between digital and analog watches. Analog watches have hands; digital watches have displays. Analog watches may have quartz or mechanical movements, while digital watches are only quartz.
The digital watch dominated the 1970's and early 80's. But in 1985, analogs broke through: 173 million analogs were sold against only 149 million digitals. Digital watches regained their lead briefly in 1986 and 1987. But in 1988, analogs took back the lead, this time permanently, industry experts say. In 1990, 405 million analog watches were sold versus 242 million digitals.
Though quartz watches dominate the market, mechanical watches still have significant, though declining, sales. In 1990, 106 million mechanical watches were sold, down from 143 million in 1985.

 
 
A New Caution
Just 1 Trendy Item, Not a Whole Line
 To gain sales momentum, the watch industry is relying on design flair and creativity. Companies are introducing watches in the forms of cucumbers, strips of bacon and even red peppers. Art watches -- some with painted faces -- are also making a reappearance.
But all that creativity is tempered with caution due to the fragile financial condition of many of the nation's retailers. That fragility has caused some manufacturers to market their products differently.
Rather than developing entire lines, or collections, "there's a trend toward item marketing in the business today," said Laurence Grunstein, president of the Citizen Watch Company of America, the American arm of the Citizen Watch Company of Japan. "You develop a hot item and you can quickly sell 25,000 to 50,000 units." he said. "Retailers want those hot items, especially those retailers involved in leveraged buyouts which need faster inventory turnover and more productive use of shelf space to pay down debt."
But Seiko Time, the big Japanese producer, is still opting for collections of watches. This is especially the case with its "sport-tech" watches, where 40 styles of largely analog quartz watches will be offered in a retail price range of $250 to $575.
Seiko is also bringing out a line of 10 new watch styles for the 1992 Olympic Games. Seiko has been designated the official timer for next year's Olympics to be held in Barcelona. "We're going to move aggressively into television with these watches," said Hal Wilensky, Seiko's executive vice president for its American operations. "We feel that a connection with the Olympics will draw a lot of attention to us."

 
 
Rescuing Swatch
It Couldn't Rely On Just Teen-Agers
 What can a company do when its sales finally flatten out because the novelty of its low-price, fashion products fizzles? That is the question Swatch, a unit of SMH International, the big Swiss producer, asked itself.
After a spectacular introduction in 1982, with new quartz technology, Swatch sold a stunning 25 million watches in the United States alone. But in the last few years, sales have dropped sharply.
Swatch decided to change its image, said Chris Keigel, vice president of sales and marketing at Swatch. "The brand had lost some of its novelty, its momentum. We were focused too heavily on teen-agers," Mr. Keigel said. "But if you target yourself on people in their 20's, the Swatch can be considered an aspirational thing, something to strive for at that age and younger."
To change its image, last year Swatch introduced a combination chronograph and watch that sold in stores for less than $100. Swatch sold 100,000 of them in the first few weeks. It also introduced a diving watch with a plastic body and sold it for $50 retail against the standard $250 to $300 for the diving watches made by its competitors.
Swatch is also "getting more American design input," Mr. Keigel said. "European styling is much more colorful, while U.S. design is more traditional, perhaps reflecting a return to basic values," he said.
But Swatch is taking no chances -- just a few weeks ago it began showing the works of the Swiss-Austrian artist Alfred Hofkunst, in the form of Pop Art "vegetable" watches -- like cucumbers and peppers.

 
 
Selling Luxury
Antique Watches Are Reproduced
 With sales of luxury goods hard hit by the recession and the imposition of a luxury tax last January, even upscale producers have had to innovate. One way they have done that is to offer "collectibles" -- limited offerings of specially produced, high-priced watches.
Movado, for example, recently produced a limited run of 110 watches to commemorate its 110th anniversary. All the watches, which had an 18-karat gold case and mechanical movement, were sold, for $10,000 each. Similarly, Movado ran off a limited amount of another, lower-priced anniversary model, a gold-plated mechanical watch for $595. That edition also sold out.
"The biggest change in our business is that people are collecting watches," said Mr. Grinberg, of the North American Watch Company, which distributes Movado. "This has led to new watches being made to look as if they were inspired by the old ones, which means mechanical movements. These may be a little impractical, but people want unique products. They become status symbols."
Hamilton Watch, a division of the Swiss SMH empire, has joined the collectibles trend by reincarnating its Ventura model, which was introduced in 1957 as "the world's first electric watch." The Ventura is now offered with a quartz movement and is selling well.
Piaget, which is distributed by North American Watch, has reached much further back in its nostalgic quest. It recently introduced the Tanagra, a newly-designed jeweled watch named after a city in ancient Greece. The Tanagra, which uses a Greek-design motif, retails for $6,000 to $20,000, depending on the band and jewels.
 
 
 
WATCHMAKER WITH 2,000 FACES
 Durable may be the best way to refer to Armitron, a 35-year-old watch brand assembled in New York by the E. Gluck Corporation. Today E. Gluck is the nation's second-largest watch assembler after Timex, with sales this year of more than $100 million.
Armitron was an early marketer of digital quartz watches. But its first digital watches used displays made of light emitting diodes, or LED's, a technology borrowed from computers. But it soon became apparent that LED's used too much power. Armitron's customers had to replace their batteries so frequently that thousands of them brought their watches back to the retailers. That almost drove Armitron out of business.
To solve the display problem, Eugene Gluck, the company's founder, had his suppliers switch the displays from LED's to liquid crystal. LCD's, as they are called, use less electricity than LED's. Their batteries for the newer watches lasted longer.
Armitron produces mostly inexpensive watches and sells them to discount and mass-market chains like Wal-Mart, K-Mart and Sears. Large retail chains now account for 50 percent of all watches sold.
Mr. Gluck and his designers have developed dozens of collections of watches for a number of different markets.
"When Swatch decided not to sell to mass chains, we came out with the AWatch by Armitron," said Sidney Gluck, Armitron's vice president. "Then, when AWatch succeeded, we decided to produce a fashion AWatch with sports functionality and called it Allsport."
E. Gluck and its affiliated company, Sutton Time -- which produces watches for the clothing designer Anne Klein -- occupies a 160,000-square-foot assembly plant in Queens, N.Y. From that location they produce 2,000 styles of watches.
