HEADLINE: In Poland, Hope and Need Confront the Realities of Time

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Why Poland Can't Flinch" (editorial, Oct. 26): 
 The last 50 years of a socialistic economy have taken their toll upon the psychic character of the Polish people. Although extreme shortages of goods for the general public produced the well-known phrase "nie ma" ("we don't have"), which Polish clerks retorted mechanically as a response to shortages, the phenomena of layoff and unemployment were virtually nonexistent.
This has created a naive response by many Poles. Democratization and the turn to a free-market economy have not been the panacea the multitudes hoped for. The rumblings of voters, many of whom have resorted to strikes in the workplace, reflect a wish to return to a time that, at least from their perspective, appeared better. Yet from my conversations with Polish Government representatives, I believe the greatest enemy, after public discontent, is time.
While the final result of "shock therapy" has yet to be seen, economic inroads have begun and are not merely on the horizon.
The greatest tragedy of the former Government's irresponsibility has been its abuse of the environment. Pollution throughout Poland approaches a catastrophic dimension. Yet the financial resources of the Government prevent an adequate response to this ecological nightmare.
Who can fault any Pole for wishing to escape the ecological poisoning taking place? And the vicious cycle begins. The most able and much-needed worker and professional have decided to flee polluted Poland.
What is needed is a radical infusion of Western money to assist with the privatization so badly needed in many of the industries previously controlled by the Government. At the same time, Western technology to combat the scourge of pollution is essential. The leaders in Warsaw cannot accomplish these tasks single-handedly. The time for help from Washington and the West is now. There may not be an opportunity next time.
 
(Rev.) JOHN E. LAZAR
Director, Downstate New York Div. Polish American Congress
Brooklyn, Oct. 30, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Wary Step Toward Regional Cooperation

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
A GROUP of countries that together control nearly half the world's economic life met last week, and the world hardly noticed. But that was partly by design; while the fragmented lands of the Asia-Pacific region organized the meeting to demonstrate a growing new unity of purpose, they also showed how wary they are about bonding themselves together too tightly.
The site was Seoul, where the 15 nations that make up Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation met to add momentum, very carefully, to the two-year-old body. For the first time, the members -- Japan, China and other East Asian countries, the United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealand -- agreed to create a permanent secretariat and a budget for 10 modest projects that would promote regional cooperation and growth. 
 A variety of proposals for region-wide cooperation has been floated over the last decade, only to founder because of a traditional lack of identity and coherence. Then in 1989 Australia, which for years resisted defining itself as part of Asia, reversed its stand and pushed for this new body. A realization of what this trade-oriented region was up against in the new world economic order taking shape finally drove the countries that rim the Pacific to embrace the idea of bonding themselves, if not immediately, with a common purpose.
 
Pragmatism
 At last week's meeting, in an unusual display of pragmatism over ideology, China, Hong Kong and Taiwan took their seats side by side. In addition, India, the Soviet Union and a host of Latin American nations have said they would like to join.
The potential significance of this group is evident in its clout: the 15 members account for nearly 50 percent of the world's gross national product, about 40 percent of its trade, 40 percent of its population and 30 percent of its land area.
"This organization is going to have immense implications," said Atsushi Oi, a senior official at Japan's Ministry for International Trade and Industry and a member of Japan's delegation. "The important thing is that it is based on economic reality, not politics. These relationships already exist." But for every positive sign there was also conspicuous nervousness, because of the great uncertainty that has been building in the export-driven economies of East Asia over the role various trade blocs may play in the trading system. As the unusual name Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation implies, so tentative are some participants about the group's direction that they do not even refer to themselves as an "organization" or "association." Indeed, the members spent much of the time in Seoul explaining what the economic grouping, known as Apec, would not be and how the region should not be organized.
Fearful that Apec could evolve into an exclusive trading bloc, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d attacked a Malaysian proposal for a body that would exclude the United States and be led by Japan. Malaysia was showing concern that the East Asian countries were being excluded from the other major trade groupings taking shape, the European Community and the North American Free Trade Agreement, which includes the United States, Canada and Mexico.
Mr. Baker responded with a series of denials about the exclusivity of both the North American body and Apec. "Apec is not a regional bloc," he insisted. "It will not cut off the Asia-Pacific region from the rest of the globe. Rather, Apec aims to be a catalyst for economic integration, trade liberalization and growth." But his sharp remarks only served to show that Malaysia had staked out one realistic option for the group -- and that the burden would fall on the United States to show it wanted to remain engaged in Asia.
 
A Message?
 The Japanese, meanwhile, insisted nervously that they had no intention of participating in a trade bloc. They said the whole aim was a more open trading regime world-wide. But some Japanese hinted that they would not mind it if the West saw that Asia has the will to organize, should it be cut out of the huge European or North American markets.
Japan and South Korea also fought quietly to keep out of the meeting's declaration a commitment to fully liberalize agricultural trade; both nations ban imports of rice and have been resisting pressure that they open their markets. And officials of South Korea and Taiwan have expressed concern over the prospect that they would be dominated by Japan if an Asian bloc took shape. These countries already suffer large trade deficits with Japan.
For all the anxieties on display, the grouping took several important steps, largely because of what the members felt was at stake if they did not act. The decision to organize a secretariat with a budget -- its size to be determined later -- will give Apec some permanence and encourage it to set policy goals. Japan, Thailand and Singapore have suggested they would like to be the group's home.
Apec also issued a declaration for the first time, spelling out its commitment to a free trade regime, even if that meant some members would have to alter longstanding protectionist policies. It called for a reduction of trade barriers, greater interdependence among the members and efforts to improve living standards in East Asia. Perhaps most important, Apec threw its influence behind a quick conclusion to the Uruguay Round, a major negotiation to promote more open markets that has stalled on the question of agricultural products.
The statement was not the sort to grab headlines. But it made a point: Asia, the most economically vibrant region in the world, is becoming organized and preparing to exert its considerable weight. President Bush has postponed his trip to the region, and thus highlighted the questions about America's commitment to the Pacific at a time when the region is starting to show that its greatest years for growth and influence may lie ahead.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
'Repatriation' Is the Trend For Refugees Worldwide

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
REFUGEES have almost always been seen as innocents adrift. With the end of the cold war, the question is being asked, can they go home again?
In the vast archipelago of the displaced, which runs from the arid camps of Malawi and Eritrea through the rocky slopes of Pakistan to the tent cities in the jungles of Thailand, a new word is being heard: repatriation. Depending on who among the world's 18.3 million refugees hears it, it means going home, going to a place that can never be home again, or being forced back to the things once fled from. 
 Repatriation is the word of choice among relief organizations whose tired workers have begun to hope that the long years of regional struggles that drove people from their homes would come to an end as the conflict between East and West began to fade away. But the word may not be so welcome for Vietnamese in Hong Kong being forced on planes to Hanoi, or for Haitians in flight from the military junta, only to be left in new holding facilities at the United States Naval base in Guantanamo Bay.
"Ninety-nine percent of the refugees in the world want to go home," said Sylvana Foa, a spokeswoman for Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner on Refugees. "People don't give up their culture, home, friends and belongings lightly." Last month, Mrs. Ogata declared her hope that 1992 will be "the year of repatriation."
For the United States, this change in the international approach to refugees is both welcome and discomfiting. The United States used to have an easy rule of thumb for deciding who was a refugee. A person fleeing Communism was almost automatically considered by the State Department to have "a well-founded fear of persecution," the 1951 United Nations language that became the legal definition of a refugee. But a person fleeing civil strife in El Salvador or Haiti was more likely to be an "economic migrant" seeking access to a better standard of living. The former could be nurtured; the latter deported. Now the old refugees from Communism may have become the new "economic migrants" in flight from economic disaster.
Most of the United States' refugee expenditures over those years have gone to resettling fugitives from Communism. Between the fall of Saigon in 1975 and the collapse of Soviet Communism in 1991, the United States admitted 1 million Asians, almost all of them Vietnamese, Cambodian or Laotian. Most of the rest of the 1.5 million admissions in that 16-year period consisted of 250,000 from the Soviet Union, 100,000 from Eastern Europe and at least 20,000 from Afghanistan.
 
Different Priorities
 Yet the number of refugees from countries like Vietnam and Cambodia -- those the United States has been most likely to take in -- is dwarfed by the number fleeing regional conflicts. Estimates by the United Nations and private groups indicate that Africa has 5.4 million refugees, most from conflicts in Ethiopia, Mozambique, Liberia and the Sudan. There are more than 9 million in the Middle East and South Asia, including 4 to 5 million Afghans. About 135,000 Kurds are still refugees, the last of 1.5 million who fled Saddam Hussein's troops. In East Asia, refugees from Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and Burma total perhaps 600,000.
Now other voices, like those of the British Government and the administration in Hong Kong, are saying that many in the latest wave of Vietnamese boat people are not southerners fearing persecution from old Communist enemies, but northerners who simply want a better life. These "economic migrants," they say, should be encouraged to go home voluntarily. If they do not, British and Hong Kong authorities argue, they are just as eligible for deportation as are Haitians and Salvadorans who attempt to flee to the United States.
These attitudes led to some unsettling images last week: weeping Vietnamese in Hong Kong being dragged onto a plane back to Hanoi, small boatloads of Haitians held on Coast Guard vessels.
American officials, who have condemned the military junta that ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, are clearly more reluctant to deport these latest Haitian migrants than they were to send home the earlier waves of "economic migrants" whose boats landed on Florida beaches in the 1980's.
"There are two aspects to repatriation: involuntary and voluntary," said Susan Forbes Martin of the Refugee Policy Group in Washington. "The question of involuntary return, in cases like Vietnam and Haiti, involves whether and how you return people who don't meet the formal definition of a refugee. They haven't left for political reasons but for equally troubling reasons.
"It might be a combination of pervasive repression, human rights abuses, deep-seated poverty or ethnic abuses," she said. "If you look at Haiti and Vietnam, you can't say it's pure economics and you can't say it's a pure refugee situation either. People may not be able to claim they have a well-founded fear of persecution, but they may have a well-founded fear of death."
The British argued that they had won guarantees from the Vietnamese Government that there would be no reprisals against those returning. The Bush Administration, with the angry voices of previous Vietnamese refugees ringing in its ears, voiced disagreement with the policy in the diplomatic equivalent of a whisper.
Voluntary repatriation, internationally monitored and with international support for shattered economies, "clearly is a perferred solution," said David Whittlesey, chief of the Division of Asia and Oceana for the International Organization for Migration, an independent group in Geneva. But, he said, "repatriation is going to be difficult in a situation like Cambodia," where fields are mined and the water is malarial.
"Another problem," he said, "is repatriation to what? The infrastructures have been severely damaged. Can repatriation precede the rebuilding of the infrastructure? Can you rebuild the infrastructure without repatriation?"

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Will Kenya's Bad Habits Jeopardize Its Aid?

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya

 BODY:
IN the 1980's Kenya was among a handful of African nations that could rely on large infusions of aid from Washington and the World Bank. Washington's interest in Kenya had a lot to do with its strategic position on the Indian Ocean, which made it a useful ally in the cold war. The World Bank's generosity was largely based on Kenya's capitalist outlook.
In the last two years, American aid has dropped significantly, in part because the cold war evaporated and American aid budgets tightened in general, but also because of growing displeasure with President Daniel arap Moi's intransigence on the issues of democratization, human rights and corruption. 
 Much of Africa is testing the possibilities of political pluralism now, but Mr. Moi continues to cling to a monopoly of power by squashing the opposition even as his regime is accused of corruption. Some diplomats have begun equating him with the despotic leader of Zaire, Mobutu Seso Seko -- a comparison that would have sounded implausible a few months ago.
Some Western donors, especially the United States and the Scandinavian countries, believe that recent events in Kenya will test the World Bank's seriousness about its declaration that "good governance" is a requirement for receiving aid. In little more than a week, Kenya's donors will meet in Paris under the auspices of the World Bank to decide the size of Kenya's aid package next year.
 
A Mysterious Death
 Last week, a retired Scotland Yard detective who had investigated the death of Robert Ouko, a former Foreign Minister, testified that corruption flourishes at the top of the Kenyan Government. The detective, John Troon, said he believed that Mr. Ouko was pushed into a car early one morning in February 1990, taken to the countryside near his house and shot because he was preparing a report on corrupt ministers in the Moi Government.
At the same time as the extent of the corruption has become public, Mr. Moi has refused to recognize opposition groups, and he banned a rally scheduled for yesterday. A dozen well-known leaders of the opposition, which has been calling for a multiparty political system, were arrested and armed riot police used tear gas to disperse crowds attempting to get to the meeting place.
Despite a major policy statement in 1989 that set "good governance" as a guiding rule for eligibility for aid in Africa, funding by the World Bank for Kenya has remained at high levels. In 1989, Kenya received nearly $1 billion from all Western donors, one-third of it from the World Bank and less than $100 million from the United States. By far the largest portion of bank aid went for financial support of the budget. Direct aid from the United States has fallen by half in the last two years, dropping from $80 million to $40 million.
Economists say there are a number of reasons for the World Bank's leniency toward Kenya.
First, the bank decided in the mid-1980's that more attention had to be given to Africa. The bank's vice president for Africa, Edward Jaycox, an American who has been fond of the continent ever since he took a postgraduate trip across Africa in the early 1960's, argued that Africa was a test case for development.
Two former presidents of the bank, A. W. Clausen and Barber B. Conable Jr., went along with Mr. Jaycox's argument. During their tenures, the bank allocated substantially more money to the continent, shifting some long-term aid away from Asia in doing so. In the years 1982-86, yearly disbursements in grants and loans to Africa averaged $1.9 billion; between 1987 and 1991, the support increased to $3.3 billion.
"Up until now it has been difficult for the bank to put money in East Africa other than Kenya," says David Gordon, a former official of the United States Agency for International Development in Kenya. "Uganda, Tanzania, Zimbabwe are all countries where five years ago it didn't make a lot of sense to put money." Uganda was still torn by war, and Tanzania and Zimbabwe still practiced their various versions of socialism. By contrast, Kenya had capable technocrats and a capitalist orientation. So funds were pumped into Kenya even though corruption was getting worse, Mr. Gordon said.
There is little doubt that the atmosphere at the Paris gathering will be grim. And the Kenyan delegation will be laboring under an added liability. The Vice President and Minister for Finance, George Saitoti, who will head the team, was named at the inquiry into Mr. Ouko's death as one of the ministers who demanded a kickback from a company planning to rehabilitate an industrial project.
Mr. Saitoti also offered what diplomats considered an unbelievable explanation last week of why the foreign exchange held by Kenyans overseas had soared tenfold from $200 million in 1982 to $2.6 billion this year. The United States Agency for International Development said the capital flight was due to "investor uncertainty and rampant corruption." Mr. Saitoti attributed the extraordinary size of the foreign holdings to undispersed money from foreign donors, a statement that could not be squared with the facts, diplomats said.
In advance of the Paris meeting, members of the opposition appealed to the donors to get tough. Until there is political reform in Kenya, they argued, economic aid will be counterproductive. "The current trends in our country show the limits of reforming economic policy in a deformed political environment," they said in an open letter.
Two days after the letter was made public, three of the signers, including Gitobu Imanyara, the editor of The Nairobi Law Monthly, were arrested.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
California Is Tired Of Hearing the Meaning of It All

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
CALIFORNIANS have long resented what they perceive as a condescending view of their sunny land in the national press. But as long as things went well, they could dismiss this as envy on the part of myopic East Coast editors forced to make their livings slogging through the winter slush of Manhattan. The Californians could tune out, grow rich and get sun tanned.
Now that times have turned tough on the West Coast, those tanned hides have proved thin. The California economy, which nearly everybody here thought invulnerable to national vicissitudes until recently, is deeply mired in recession and lagging the nation in recovery. Compounding this have been recent natural insults like the deadly fire that swept the hills above Oakland and Berkeley last month, not to mention the perennial problems of smog, street gangs and traffic congestion. 
 All of this has spawned a new round of articles in newspapers and magazines calling attention to the fragilities and difficulties of life in the largest state. The latest bruise was inflicted by Time magazine, whose cover story last week played the by-now-familiar theme of the paradise spoiled, the dream endangered.
The California press, which has done its share of chronicling these troubles, is now having a bad reaction to such coverage by the national media. And if the press is any reflection of the public psyche, then that psyche has been bruised.
Why pick on California? demanded Peter Schrag, associate editor of the Sacramento Bee in the Oct. 30 issue. He took issue with a number of recent articles in The New York Times, mainly one by this writer, that discussed the Oakland fire as a symbol of the hazards of pushing California civilization into beautiful but environmentally dangerous areas.
"Not that The Times is all wrong," Mr. Schrag wrote. "The facts are often depressingly correct. California is a troubled place, partly because the myths created by the California-paradise writers generated such absurd expectations and because it hasn't yet discovered a way to keep people out. Read the mounds of celebratory trash about nirvana-by-the-pool that was published in the late 60's and you can understand why sooner or later there had to be a yang for this yin."
But Mr. Schrag went on to say that many other places have troubles, including New York, Connecticut and New Jersey. He cited budget troubles in those states, muggings on the subway, Hurricane Hugo in 1989 and the arson fire at the Happy Land social club in the Bronx that killed 87 people, more than triple the number who died in the Oakland fire. And he cited such environmentally fragile places as Cape Cod and the Carolina coast, hit by recent storms, or flood-prone areas of the Ohio Valley. "Does The Times talk about their disasters in apocalyptic terms every other week and sometimes twice on weekends? Why is this state singled out?"
Then came Robert A. Jones, a columnist for The Los Angeles Times on Nov. 6. "California cannot have a simple disaster," he wrote. "There must be, somewhere, a meaning to each flood, each fire, each earthquake. And that meaning, one way or the other, has to do with doom. I cannot think of any other place on Earth that carries this burden."
He, too, cited the recent East Coast storm that flooded President Bush's summer home in Kennebunkport, Me.: "A bad, malignant storm. But as of yet this storm has inspired no talk of Armageddon. No one has mentioned bargains with the devil. Or the foolhardiness of Easterners who have chosen to defy nature by living along the Atlantic coast.
"And after the President said he planned to restore his house and return for more summers, I have seen no television commentators shaking their heads in wonder. The story, you see, remained merely a storm. It had no moral quotient and carried no meaning about the spiritual corruption of its victims."
Next came Peter H. King, a new columnist at The Los Angeles Times, on Nov. 12. He cited articles in Newsweek, Time, The Wall Street Journal, the Economist and The New York Times, some of which mentioned a growing flow of residents out of California. "What will finally emerge from all this tumult won't be the California that brought the Gold Rush settlers, or my Oklahoma ancestors, or even my friends who came from so many other cities to pursue a dream," he wrote. "But don't schedule the funeral.
"Even the gloomiest accounts concede that our economy is certain to rebound, that the quake and fire victims will rebuild and, most important, that the number of Californians moving out will prove to be an insignificant trickle compared to the incoming tide of foreign immigrants. These immigrants come with dreams of their own, a possibility overlooked in the doomsday reports.
"The oversight is unfortunate -- because what is really going on here is not a death, but a revision. As California is remade, so is the dream."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Washington Tries to Sort Out Health Insurance Proposals

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

 BODY:
WITH voters making it clear that they are unhappy with rising medical costs and the fact that 34 million Americans have no health insurance, Democrats and Republicans are realizing that the issue will be important in the coming Presidential election.
Republicans in Congress introduced a health insurance bill last week. The White House said it would speed up work on its own bill, and a coalition of businesses and labor unions unveiled theirs on Tuesday.
 
The system's flaws
 Although medical care in the United States is the most sophisticated in the world, the system for delivering it has major flaws. 
 *About 34 million people -- 13 percent of the nation -- have no health insurance. Most work, but are not insured on the job, cannot afford coverage and are not poor enough for Medicaid or old enough for Medicare. The United States is the only major industrialized nation without universal coverage.
*Health care is expensive. Spending per person is three times what it is in Britain and double what it is in Germany and Japan, and a disproportionate amount goes for the administration costs of the many insurers.
*Dozens of insurers, Medicaid and Medicare have their own rules that doctors and patients have to comply with. Many doctors, fed up, refuse to work with some plans.
*Workers lose coverage when they leave jobs. Because small employers pay far more per worker than large ones, many small companies and many with low-wage workers offer no insurance.
*Neither patients nor doctors have much incentive to keep costs down, and fear of malpractice suits leads to unnecessary tests.
 
Bills before Congress
 There are more than 20 health insurance bills before Congress now. All envision one of three kinds of plans:
Canadian-style: Some would create systems like Canada's, under which taxes pay for government-administered health insurance. The simplest bills merely extend Medicare to all legal residents. Under others, patients would present insurance cards, and doctors and hospitals would apply to the government for payment. Governments would either set fees or decide how much they would pay and let doctors charge more.
Critics say such a system would mean large tax increases, would put medical insurers like Blue Cross out of business and replace them with government bureaucracies that would become indifferent and expensive and could end up rationing treatment. Defenders say Canada has universal access to health care for less money per patient than is spent in the United States. But they concede that there are often long waiting lists for some tests and operations, and that the United States develops most state-of-the-art care, which arrives only slowly in Canada.
Play or pay: Most of the other proposals, including that of several key Democrats, keep the element of health insurance that is characteristically American -- it is usually a job benefit. These proposals, nicknamed "play or pay" plans, would require employers of as few as three people to either insure them or pay a tax into a state-administered pool that would offer policies. Some bills propose taxes of 7 or 8 percent of the payroll. Anyone unemployed or self-employed would be covered by an expanded Medicare program or have to buy private insurance. Versions of such plans are used in Germany and France, although the insurers, who levy payroll taxes of from 8 to 16 percent for premiums, are non-profit and heavily regulated.
Most of these bills also include provisions for insurance market reform, described below, and would let the self-employed write off health insurance premiums against taxes.
These plans are strongly opposed by small-business owners, who say the costs would make them lay off workers or go bankrupt.
Insurance market reform: In a limited approach that may have the best political chance of passage soon, some bills would focus on insurers. Most would force them to group small companies in pools insured at rates close to those for big companies. Some would forbid them to refuse people with pre-existing conditions or would reduce waiting periods to six months.
While this can make a dent in the numbers of uninsured, critics say these plans would still leave out the unemployed, seasonal workers, domestics and many others.
Two national health plans that are not in any Congressional bills are British-style health care, under which doctors become government employees, and "market oriented" plans that would cancel all on-the-job insurance and Medicare and give residents tax credits or vouchers to buy their own insurance with. There is virtually no support for the British plan, but growing interest among conservatives in the market one.
 
Cost-cutting provisions
 Different bills include a variety of ways to control spiraling costs.
Rate-setting: Canadian-style bills create government agencies to set fees and medical practices. Other bills create entities that would bargain with doctors and hospitals to lower rates or would oversee negotiations between doctors and insurers.
Managed care: Under "play or pay" bills, patients would be encouraged, as they are now, to join health-maintenance organizations or use networks of doctors that offer discount services. Some have government agencies or insurers scrutinize private doctors' decisions. Critics say this creates new layers of bureaucracy, and irritates doctors.
Certificates of need: Under some Can adian-style systems, Federal or state governments would be able to limit, for instance, how many hospitals, cardiac surgery teams or expensive diagnostic detectors a state or county could have. Defenders say areas with many hospitals like New York City wastefully duplicate resources, while rural areas suffer. Critics say rationing leads to delays or long trips for tests and care. An example of the problem: The United States has 2,000 $2 million magnetic resonance imaging scanners while the whole of Canada has only 15.
Tax reform: Right now, businesses deduct health insurance premiums for employees from before-tax profits. The self-employed can deduct 25 percent of their premiums. Some bills would give small employers tax credits for buying insurance and let the self-employed deduct all their premiums.
Malpractice limitations: Some bills change malpractice laws, limiting awards for pain and suffering, for instance. This is intended to lower malpractice insurance premiums and cut spending on "defensive medicine" -- tests ordered to forestall suits.
Caps on expenditures: Some bills would set an annual health budget for the entire country, which could not be exceeded, though it is not clear how that would be enforced. In Germany, budgets are set even for single hospitals and doctors, and when levels are exceeded, reimbursement drops dramatically. Proponents say this makes doctors and hospitals more likely to weigh priorities and avoid waste. Critics say it means care is denied and medical progress is slowed.
Rationing: Insurers could bargain to exclude some treatments, just as many now refuse to pay for cosmetic surgery and infertility treatment. Some of the bills, for example, do not pay for prescription drugs.
